Editor's note— Ord. No. 025-04, § 1, adopted June 21, 2004, added provisions designated as Article E. In order to avoid conflicts in the designation of articles the editor has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. 025-04 as Article F. 

Sec. 4-1201. - Statement of policy. 
It shall be the policy of the City of East Point to recognize employee organizations in an orderly manner through a formal, structured process. This policy delineates the methodology used to recognize the organization, authorize dues deductions if requested, and payment of deducted dues to the organizations. This policy also outlines and defines the rights of employee organizations regarding East Point leave policies. This policy recognizes and regulates employee organizations operating within East Point Government. This policy in no way obligates city to bargain or contract with employee organizations. 
(Ord. No. 025-04, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 4-1202. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Community of interest means a group of employees who share common interests in wages, hours and other conditions of employment. 
Dues authorization card means the official form used by an employee organization to authorize the deductions of dues from their payroll checks and the payment of these deductions to a recognized employee organization. 
Eligible employees means all employees who share a community of interest and who are not: 
(1)  In an executive position as defined by the Fair Labor Standards Act. This term includes employees who have the actual authority to hire, fire or discipline. 
(2)  Confidential employees who work directly with and report directly to the City of East Point Council Members, other elected or appointed officials, department heads, or directors. 
Employee organization means any organization of East Point employees, including unions and associations, recognized as such by a resolution of the city council, mayor and city manager. 
Meet and confer is a proposed meeting to engage in dialogue with the city manager or city manager's designee as directed by the city manager. These meetings may be conducted for the purpose of fact finding, gathering information, making clear or resolving issues regarding the work environment, human resources management, human resources training, disciplinary action, and regulation of hours, and other conditions of employment. 
(Ord. No. 025-04, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 4-1203. - Applicability of article. 
This policy shall apply to all East Point employees who receive an East Point payroll check and to any current or future employee organization as defined above. 
(Ord. No. 025-04, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 4-1204. - Procedures. 
(a)  Any entity desiring to be recognized by the city as an employee organization must request same by filing a written petition on the entity's letterhead with the city manager's office. 
(b)  The city manager shall submit the request to the mayor and city council with an analysis and recommendation no later than ninety (90) days after written receipt if recognition is approved. This analysis shall include the number of employees affected, administrative costs, and any other factors deemed necessary by the city manager. If recognition of the employee organization is granted, the city manager will so notify the director of finance and the employee organization. 
(c)  Within three (3) pay cycles of properly completing a dues authorization card, any East Point employee receiving a East Point payroll check who has joined a recognized employee organization shall have member dues deducted from the employee's payroll check and paid to the employee organization in due course. 
This deduction will be in force unless employment is terminated, the employee stops deduction, the dues authorization expires, or the employee organization is no longer recognized by the city. The above-mentioned deduction is also conditioned upon the fact that any employee or any official of an organization, individually or collectively, will not strike, and will not take part in any strike, sit down, slow-down, or any interference with the operation of East Point Government. The dues deduction shall not be made in the event the wages of an employee for any period of pay, after making all deductions required by law and previously authorized by the employee, should not equal the amount of such dues. 
(d)  After deducting administrative costs to the city for implementing such deduction of dues, the finance director will remit the balance of dues collected to the employee organization, together with a list of names of employees from whom the dues were collected as soon as feasible after each payroll deduction period. 
(Ord. No. 025-04, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 4-1205. - Prohibited discrimination and adverse actions and reprisals. 
(a)  There shall be no discrimination or retaliation against any East Point employee because of the fact that such employee is a member of a recognized employee organization. There shall be no discrimination or retaliation against any East Point employee because such employee was provided representation by an appropriate employee organization regarding disciplinary action, wages, working conditions, or conditions, or conditions of employment. 
(b)  No disciplinary action or other adverse action shall be taken or threatened against any employee, nor shall any employee be intimidated by any supervisor or appointing authority who has the authority to take, direct others to take, recommend, or approve any personnel action as a reprisal for an employee's membership or participation in an employee's organization. All members of employee organizations shall be allowed to conduct standard and customary activities, subject to the employee's compliance with East Point's leave policy or prior city council's approval for attending East Point functions. 
(c)  No employee shall be required, as a condition of employment with East Point, to become a member of any employee organization. 
(Ord. No. 025-04, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 4-1206. - Meet and confer. 
(a)  Meetings. 
(1)  When an employee organization requests a meeting with the city, the designated city representative shall meet at a convenient time with the appointed representative of the employee organization for the mutual purpose of discussing issues of concern, hours or working conditions, insofar as such may be appropriate under county, state, and federal laws, and the city personnel regulations. 
(2)  Reasonable access to work locations shall be provided to representatives of employee organizations on employment related matters, and such representatives shall have access to city employees during non-work time and in non-work areas, including break rooms and cafeterias. Such access shall include both representatives who are city employees and those who are not, and in either case all existing security procedures shall be observed. Employee organizations may, with prior approval, be granted the use of city facilities for meetings of employees. 
(b)  Meet and confer. Meet and confer sessions shall be the method by which employees, through their chosen employee organization, exchange information, ideas and cooperatively and constructively resolve problems. There shall be three (3) types of meet and confer sessions: 
(1)  Meet and confer over disciplinary action. A member of a recognized employee organization may request, and the city shall permit, representation from the organization in the case of any disciplinary action against the employee, including suspension without pay, demotion and dismissal. A representative of the employee organization has the right to advocate for the employee through the established dispute resolution procedures or personnel procedures set by the city. 
(2)  Meet and confer to resolve grievances. A member or members of a recognized employee organization may request, and the city shall permit, representation from the organization through a meet and confer session to resolve problems arising from: 
a.  A disagreement with application of city policy or practice; 
b.  A disagreement with application of department policy or practice; or 
c.  A workplace conflict with supervision that has direct impact on the workplace. 
(3)  Meet and confer for employee input into policy. 
a.  Representation from recognized employee organizations shall meet and confer with the designated representatives of the city on a monthly basis or as needed in order to discuss policy issues which affect employee's concerns, hours, and the other conditions of employment. 
b.  The participants in these monthly meetings shall be empowered to form committees around specific issues relating to hours, and other conditions of employment and will report in an advisory capacity to the city manager every three (3) months. 
c.  When an employee organization requests a meet and confer session with appropriate city representatives under subsection (2) or (3) above, the appropriate representative shall meet with specified time lines of the dispute resolution procedure or personnel regulations. 
(c)  Official leave. Activities which are not contemplated by the employee organization ordinance and would not be charged to official leave would include, but not be limited to, regular employee organization meetings, membership drives, and city council meetings where non-employee organization issues are on the agenda. Employees who wish to attend these type meetings must obtain prior approval form their supervisors and charge this time to vacation or compensatory time. 
(Ord. No. 025-04, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 4-1207. - Representative of the city. 
The city manager of the city shall designate a person in the personnel department to serve as the city's representative to meet with employee organizations when appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 025-04, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Secs. 4-1208—4-1230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE G. - LEGAL DEFENSE OF OFFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 4-1231. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. 
(1)  Claim means any assertion of damage or demand for action or payment presented to or against an employee prior to the institution of a proceeding. This term shall apply where the claimant asserts personal liability for damages arising out of the performance of duties or the claim is in any way connected with the performance of duties, whether based on negligence, violation of contract rights, or violation of constitutional law, common law, or statutory rights, whether federal, state or local. 
(2)  Employee means the mayor and members of the East Point City Council, employees of the city, and appointed city officials, including members of city commissions, councils, and boards. The term shall not include independent vendor or contractors doing business with the city or members of independent or state chartered boards and commissions. 
(3)  Proceeding includes any claim instituted in or before any court or administrative agency of this state, any other state, or the United States. 
(Ord. No. 009-05, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 4-1232. - Construction. 
Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to constitute a waiver by the city or by any of its employees of the sovereign immunity, official immunity, or any other immunity afforded under the constitution and laws of the State of Georgia or of the United States. The city and its employees specifically reserve the right to assert immunity in response to any claim or proceeding, and this ordinance shall not construed so as to require the city or any employee to pay any sums based on claims from which the city and its employees are immune. 
(Ord. No. 009-05, § 2, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 4-1233. - Defense of employees. 
(a)  Whenever any claim is made or any proceeding is instituted against an employee, the city shall be authorized, upon written request, to provide for the employee's defense unless otherwise limited by the terms of this article. In terms of providing a defense, the city shall direct the city attorney or engage outside counsel of the city's choosing to provide a legal defense for the employee. The costs for providing legal defense shall be borne by the city. 
(b)  The provisions of this article shall not apply unless the employee provides notice in writing of any claim or proceeding to the city manager within thirty (30) days after the employee has notice of a claim and/or within five (5) days after the employee has been served with process in any proceeding. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to confer to any employee a legal right or entitlement to a defense by the city as to any claim or proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 009-05, § 3, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 4-1234. - Grounds for refusal of defense. 
(a)  The city may refuse to provide for the defense of a claim or proceeding brought against any employee if it determines that any one or more of the following conditions exists: 
(1)  The act or omission forming the basis of the claim or proceeding did not arise in the course and scope of the employees duties for the city; 
(2)  The employee acted or failed to act because of actual or intentional misconduct, fraud, corruption, malice, or bad faith; 
(3)  The claim or proceeding is criminal in nature or the employee acted or failed to act in such manner as to constitute a criminal act; 
(4)  The employee acted or failed to act as a result of, or at a time when, the employee's self-indulgence substantially impaired the employee's judgment, including, without limitation, an employee being intoxicated or under the influence of illegal narcotics while acting on behalf of the city; 
(5)  The employee acted or failed to act, except in under extenuating circumstances, directly contrary to advice of the city attorney or safety personnel; 
(6)  The employee fails to cooperate in the defense of the claim or proceeding or knowingly supplies false information regarding the claim or proceeding; 
(7)  The employee acted or failed to act in willful disregard of city policy or the specific instructions of the city council or the employee's supervisor; or 
(8)  Provision of a defense against the claim or proceeding would not be in the best interest of the city. 
(b)  The determinations required by subsection (a) of this section shall be made solely by the city council upon the advice of the city attorney and upon due consideration of any internal investigation the council may require. The city attorney may commence an initial representation and defense of an employee if the claim or proceeding requires that action be taken before the next scheduled meeting of council and the city attorney concludes, in his or her discretion, that the claim or proceeding would satisfy the criteria for defense by the city. At any time prior to or after the approval or assumption of the defense, the city may discontinue or refuse to provide the defense of an employee if the council determines that any of the grounds for refusal set forth in this section exists or has come to exist. 
(c)  Upon approval by city council of the defense of a claim or proceeding against an employee, the matter shall be referred to the city attorney or an outside attorney for disposition. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the city from providing a defense against claims or proceedings where there is a conflict between one employee or group of employees as compared with another employee or group of employees. If two or more employees or groups of employees are involved in a claim or proceeding, and the interest of one employee or group of employees conflicts with the interest of another employee or group of employees, city council shall approve or refuse to provide a defense to the respective employees or groups of employees in accordance the terms of subsection (a). 
(e)  If the city approves providing a defense to two (2) or more employees or groups of employees involved in a claim or proceeding, and the interest of one employee or group of employees conflicts with the interest of another employee or group of employees, council shall specify which employee or group of employees shall be represented by the city attorney and shall authorize the other employee or group of employees to retain separate counsel at the expense of the city; provided, however, that the selection and compensation of such separate counsel shall be subject to the prior approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 009-05, § 4, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 4-1235. - Payment of judgments and settlements. 
(a)  Where defense of a claim or proceeding against an employee is provided in accordance with this article, all final judgments awarded in courts of competent jurisdiction against the employee, or any amount payable under a settlement of such claim or proceedings, shall be paid by the city as hereinafter provided. All compromises of claims or proceedings governed by this article shall be approved by city council upon recommendation of the city attorney or outside counsel, as the case may be. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, payment of judgments and claims shall be limited as follows: 
(1)  No sum will be paid under the provisions of this division for punitive or exemplary damages. 
(2)  No sum shall be paid under the provisions of this division unless the claimant unconditionally releases the employee and the city from any and all claims, causes of action, or judgments arising from the subject claim or proceeding. 
(3)  Any claim or proceeding as to which insurance is provided by the city is specifically excluded from the operation of this article. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to confer to any employee a legal right or entitlement to have the city pay any settlement or any judgment, fine, fee, or cost rendered on a claim or proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 009-05, § 5, 5-16-05) 
CHAPTER 2. - CITY PROPERTY, FUNDS AND LABOR 

Sec. 4-2001. - Article to control expenditures. 
This article shall control the expenditure of all city funds from all sources whatsoever, including funds arising from city bonds. 
(Code 1959, § 2-114) 
Sec. 4-2002. - Buildings department; superintendent as head. 
The head of the buildings department of the city shall be designated and classified as superintendent. 
(Code 1959, § 2-115) 
Sec. 4-2003. - Use of buildings and recreation centers—Permit. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or permit the use of any city buildings or recreation centers except a financially responsible bona fide resident of the city to whom the permission may be granted only in writing by the director of parks and recreation which shall set forth the name and address of the financially responsible person granted the permission, and stating the time the building shall be used and by whom and for what purpose, and clearly stating that the person granted the permit shall be responsible for the building and the contents thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 2-116) 
Sec. 4-2004. - Same—Permission to use at night. 
It shall be unlawful after 11:30 p.m. any night for any one (1) or more persons except police officers or parks personnel in the proper discharge of their duties to open or cause any city building or recreation center within any city park to be or remain open without first obtaining written permission from the director of parks and recreation; and all such persons permitted to use the buildings shall, before leaving the buildings, see that they are securely closed, and that all water, gas and lights are turned off therein before leaving the building. 
(Code 1959, § 2-117) 
Sec. 4-2005. - Same—Investigating at night after closing. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police or other police officer in charge of the police department to see each night that a police officer visits and investigates all recreation centers and public buildings within the public parks of the city between 11:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight each night to see that all of the buildings are closed, and that the person responsible for the buildings and their contents on each occasion the building and contents are used for any entertainment, dance, party, programs or exercise account for the contents of the buildings and for the condition of the building and its contents. 
(Code 1959, § 2-118) 
Sec. 4-2006. - Same—Authorized purpose only. 
It shall be an offense punishable as prescribed in section 1-1006 for any person to use any city building for any purpose than the purpose for which the building is let to the person and the chief of police shall see that this section is faithfully enforced. 
(Code 1959, § 2-119) 
Sec. 4-2007. - Administrative procedures for the abandonment of city-owned rights-of-way, lanes and alleys. 
Administrative procedures for the abandonment and disposal of city-owned rights-of-way, lanes and alleys are as follows: 
(1)  All private requests to abandon city-owned rights-of-way, lanes and alleys shall be made in writing to the city manager. 
(2)  Requests shall include the names and addresses of all property owners whose land abuts the subject property, and an acknowledgment to pay for the cost of title investigation, ordinance and deed preparation, and recording. 
(3)  Upon a determination by the city manager as to the desirability of abandoning the subject property, applicant shall provide the city with a survey of the subject area and an appraisal suitable for determining the fair market value of each portion to be transferred to abutting property owners. A determination by the city manager or the receipt of a survey and appraisal shall not bind the city to pursue or complete the abandonment and transfer. 
(4)  Upon a determination by city council that the property no longer serves any public purpose the property may be abandoned. The city manager is authorized to provide for the disposal of abandoned property in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 32-7-4 or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 008-02, § 1, 5-20-02) 
Secs. 4-2008—4-2010. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1176-48, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1998, repealed former §§ 4-2007—4-2010 in their entirety which pertained to use of and fees for the use of the municipal auditorium and derived from the Code of 1959, §§ 2-12—2-122. Ord. No. 1176-48 enacted rules and fees for the use of the auditorium as Attachment A which has not been set out at length herein but is available in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 4-2011. - Maintenance and cleaning of city buildings. 
The maintenance and cleaning of all city buildings, except buildings housing the fire and police departments, shall be under the supervision and control of the director of parks and recreation provided, all carpenter work required in the maintenance of buildings under the control and supervision of the director of parks and recreation shall be done by the carpenter in the city building department, under similar supervision. 
(Code 1959, § 2-123) 
Sec. 4-2011.1. - Smoking, establishment of policy. 
(1)  The mayor and council are dedicated to providing a health, comfortable and productive work environment for the city's employees and the general public. It shall therefore be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with the provisions of this section [Ordinance No. 1014-91] or any ordinance or resolution of the City of East Point establishing a smoking policy within the public areas of the city. It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city that smoking in enumerated public places shall be a public nuisance and dangerous to the public health and that "No Smoking" and "Smoking Permitted" signs shall be posted in conspicuous places to assure notice. Smoking shall be generally not permitted in any public building and shall be generally permitted on any public grounds. 
(2)  Smoking or the carrying of lighted tobacco or other substances in any form in areas designated "No Smoking," and the smoking or discarding of any lighted or smoldering substance in any place or area where "No Smoking" signs are posted is hereby prohibited and unlawful and any violation of this section shall be punishable as other offenses in the city court of East Point. 
(3)  (a)  Departments will give this smoking policy wide dissemination to all employees. 
(b)  Signs that are uniform in language and color shall be placed in all appropriate areas indicating "No Smoking" or "Smoking Permitted," as hereinafter designated by mayor and council. 
(c)  All prospective new employees or appointees will be informed of this smoking policy prior to employment or appointment. 
(Ord. No. 1014-91, § 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 4-2012. - Custodian of keys to municipal building. 
The city clerk shall be custodian of keys to the municipal building in which is located the office of the city clerk, and in which is located the council chamber of the city. It shall be the duty of every person to whom a key is issued under this section, upon suspension, discharge or removal from the service of the city to immediately surrender the key to the custodian. 
(Code 1959, § 2-124) 
Sec. 4-2013. - Duplicate keys. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any duplicate of any key issued by the custodian under the provisions of section 4-2012, and in no case shall any key be duplicated except when authorized by the council. It shall be the duty of the custodian, however, to obtain for each lock where keys may be necessary, sufficient keys to have on hand two (2) keys in addition to those issued to persons authorized to use the offices. 
(Code 1959, § 2-125) 
Sec. 4-2014. - Borrowing, etc., of keys; meaning of section. 
It shall be unlawful for any officer, agent or employee of the city to whom a key is issued to borrow, obtain, give, lend or use any key not previously issued to such person, officer, agent or employee, or which key was issued to another. The meaning of this section is that no person shall use any key except the key issued to him under authority of the council, and any effort to evade the provisions of this section by borrowing, lending, or giving a key or by using a key borrowed, loaned or otherwise obtained without express authority from the city council is unlawful. 
(Code 1959, § 2-126) 
Sec. 4-2015. - Loss or destruction of keys; temporary keys. 
The loss or destruction of any key shall be immediately reported to the custodian by the person to whom the key was issued, whereupon it shall be the duty of the custodian to report this fact to the next regular meeting of the city council. The custodian may issue a temporary key to the person losing or destroying his key until the next regular meeting of the city council when such loss or destruction shall be reported to the council by the custodian. After consideration of the report of the custodian of the loss or destruction of the key, the council shall give direction in the premises as in its judgment the circumstances of the case may required. 
(Code 1959, § 2-127) 
Sec. 4-2016. - Explosives belonging to city. 
(a)  Purchase order required. It shall be unlawful for any person to accept delivery of dynamite, detonation caps or other explosives without a purchase order from the purchasing department of the city. 
(b)  Delivery transportation to filter plant. Wherever delivery from magazine is made, the explosives shall be transported immediately to the filter plant and properly sorted in the shelters provided therefor. Delivery shall be acknowledged in writing by the filter plant superintendent or other operator on duty at the time. 
(c)  Duty of filter plant superintendent. It shall be the duty of the filter plant superintendent to keep all explosives of the city under lock and key, and to issue them to department heads or their authorized employees for the necessary use by the city. 
(d)  Issuance; records. All materials shall be issued upon written receipts which shall state the location of the job in progress, and any unused explosives shall be properly returned to the storage houses and signed for by the operator in charge. The filter plant superintendent shall keep an accurate record of the materials on hand and used during any month so that proper reports can be made to the state fire marshal's office. 
(e)  Authorized personnel. Each department head shall furnish the filter plant superintendent with the names of persons authorized to handle explosives and no other persons shall use explosives except under direct supervision of authorized persons. 
(Code 1959, § 2-127.1) 
Sec. 4-2017. - Use of city funds, property or services of personnel for private purposes prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for city funds, property or services of personnel to be used when or where it is primarily for the benefit of any private person as distinguished from the public. It shall likewise be unlawful for any private person to receive any city funds, property or services of city personnel under circumstances mentioned in this section. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall, upon conviction thereof in the city court be punished as provided in section 1-1006 and if the offender be an officer or employee of the city, the officer or employee shall, in addition to other penalties imposed, be subject to suspension, definite or indefinite, demotion, removal or discharge in the discretion of the city council. 
(Code 1959, § 2-128) 
Sec. 4-2018. - Donations of city property and funds to churches, etc., prohibited. 
Donations and contributions of city property, funds and services to churches and religious organizations by the city are hereby prohibited, and it shall be unlawful for any city funds, services or property to be contributed, donated or given to any church, religious or sectarian body or institution. 
(Code 1959, § 2-129) 
Sec. 4-2019. - Purchase of property by city at marshal's sales. 
In the event that the city shall purchase property at any sale conducted by the marshal, the city treasurer shall be placed in possession of the property. 
(Code 1959, § 2-130) 
Sec. 4-2020. - Executions in favor of city on perishable property. 
Whenever any execution in favor of the city is levied upon perishable property or property the keeping of which is attended with expense, the levying officer shall apply to the proper court or officer authorized by law to grant an order permitting the same to be sold at once, and shall sell it as authorized by the order. 
(Code 1959, § 2-131) 
Sec. 4-2021. - Replevy of personal property levied upon by marshal. 
Whenever any personal property has been levied upon by the marshal or tax commissioner by virtue of any execution in favor of the city, the marshal may, in his discretion, allow the defendant in fi. fa. to replevy the property under the same rules and conditions as prescribed for sheriffs and constables. 
(Code 1959, § 2-132) 
Sec. 4-2022. - Damage to city property; prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, damage, mar, destroy, deface, remove, sever, pull down, set fire to or carry away any furniture, fixtures, equipment, books, papers, records, magazines, periodicals, supplies or other property of the city or any agency thereof; or to cut, dig up, pull down, break, injure, damage, remove or carry away any of the shrubbery, hedges, flowers or trees about the public grounds, parks or buildings of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 2-133) 
Sec. 4-2023. - Same; liability for use of city buildings or property. 
Any person using any city building or property shall be liable for any damages to the buildings as a result of the use. 
(Code 1959, § 2-134) 
Sec. 4-2024. - Sale of property; generally. 
When it is deemed advisable to dispose of any personal property belonging to the city and used in the various departments thereof, or under the supervision of the council, the sale of the property shall be made by the purchasing agent. The purchasing agent shall confer with the head of the department selling the property, with the view to getting the best price possible in making the sale. This section is not intended to authorize the sale of the property without a resolution of the council, but where a resolution has, for any reason, provided for the sale of any such property belonging to the city, the sale of the property shall be supervised by the purchasing agent, acting with the proper official of the city familiar with and in charge of the property proposed to be sold. 
(Code 1959, § 2-135) 
Sec. 4-2025. - Same; or purchase where value exceeds $1,000. 
Except as otherwise provided by law, no purchase or sale contract in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) may be lawfully made by the city without first obtaining competitive sealed bids, unless an emergency makes it unwise to take necessary time to secure the bids. In all purchases the city shall accept the lowest and best bid if it accepts any, and in all sales by the city, the highest and best bid shall be accepted, if any are accepted; but the city shall in all cases reserve the right to reject any and all bids; provided, this section shall not apply to marshal's sales if an owner's right to redeem exists after the sale, but it shall apply to all public improvement contracts, and to all other real estate sales, but shall not apply to real estate purchases, nor to any other contract if its application thereto would clearly increase the city's cost. It shall not apply to contracts of employment. (See Act approved March 5, 1957, Ga. L. 1957). 
(Code 1959, § 2-135.1) 
Annotation: "This ordinance does not make it mandatory for the city to obtain competitive bids in all sales of real estate, and the ordinance does not apply to real estate purchases … The courts will not control the discretion of a municipality in disposing of its property unless such discretion is manifestly abused." Watson v. City of East Point 223 Ga. 185, 187 (1967) 
Sec. 4-2026. - Same; worn out and useless property. 
When any property owned by the city in the possession of its various departments has become worn out or useless, or has become junk or has been used to such an extent that it is advisable to dispose of same, the head of the department in charge of the property shall certify to the purchasing committee that certain itemized property is in possession of the department, and is no longer useful in the service of the city; and thereupon the purchasing agent shall, at public sale, sell the property and turn the proceeds thereof over to the city treasurer, crediting the department from which the property was obtained with the amount of same. No sale of the property shall be made by the purchasing agent where other provisions are made under other ordinances for the sales, but this section shall apply only to property of the kind named for the sale of which no provision is otherwise made; provided, however, the purchasing agent is hereby authorized to dispose of junk accumulated in the various departments to the best advantage of the city, by selling, trading or transferring to another department, whichever in his discretion will be most advantageous to the city. 
(Code 1959, § 2-136) 
Sec. 4-2027. - Same; advertisement; private sales. 
All public sales by the purchasing agent shall be advertised at least one (1) time in the official newspaper of the city, and by posting a notice of the time, place and terms of sale and describing the property to be sold in at least three (3) public places in the city, including the bulletin board in the lobby of the city hall, provided, after a public offering of property for sale by the purchasing agent as provided in this section, it shall be lawful for the purchasing agent to sell at private sale under supervision of the purchasing committee of the city council if the price at the private sale is better than can be obtained at public auction. 
(Code 1959, § 2-137) 
CHAPTER 3. - PROCUREMENT CODE[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, adopted July 3, 1995, repealed former Ch. 3, §§ 4-3001—4-3018, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Ch. 3 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1959, §§ 2-138—2-155. 

ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 4-3101. - Citing of chapter. 
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as "The Procurement Code of The City of East Point." 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3102. - Application. 
This chapter applies to contracts for the procurement of equipment, supplies, services, construction, professional and consultant services solicited or entered into by the city after the effective date unless the parties agree to its application to a contract solicited or entered into prior to the effective date. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3103. - Specific repealer. 
This chapter repeals all previously issued ordinances, rules or regulations pertaining to public procurement for this city. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3104. - Effective date. 
This chapter shall become effective at 12:01 a.m. on October 1, 1994. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3105. - Procurement records. 
(1)  Contract file: All determinations and other written records pertaining to the solicitation, award or performance of a contract or purchase order shall be maintained by the city in a contract file by the purchasing agent. 
(2)  Retention of procurement records: All procurement records shall be retained and disposed of by the city in accordance with records retention guidelines and schedules approved by the city council. If a contract is being funded in whole or in part by assistance from a federal agency, then all procurement records pertaining to that contract shall be maintained for three (3) years from the closeout date of the assistance agreement or the final disposition of any controversy arising out of the assistance agreement. 
(3)  Public access: Procurement information shall be a public record to the extent required by the laws of the State of Georgia, with the exception that privileged and confidential commercial or financial information obtained in response to a request for proposals shall not be disclosed. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3106. - Compliance with federal requirements. 
When the procurement transaction involves the expenditure of federal assistance or contract funds, the procurement transaction shall be conducted in accordance with any applicable mandatory federal law and authorized regulations which are not reflected in this chapter. Notwithstanding federal requirements, where federal assistance or contract funds are used in a procurement, requirements of this Code that are more restrictive than federal requirements shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Secs. 4-3107—4-3200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - OFFICE OF THE PURCHASING AGENT 

Secs. 4-3201, 4-3202. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-3203. - Authority and duties of the purchasing agent. 
(1)  Principal public purchasing official: Except as otherwise provided herein, the purchasing agent shall serve as the principal public purchasing official for the city and shall be responsible for the procurement of equipment, supplies, services, construction, and professional or consultant services in accordance with this chapter, as well as the management and disposal of supplies. 
(2)  Duties: In accordance with this chapter, and subject to the supervision of the city manager, the purchasing agent shall: 
(a)  Procure or supervise the procurement of all equipment, supplies, services, construction, and professional or consultant services needed by the city; 
(b)  Exercise direct supervision over the city's central stores and general supervision over all other inventories of supplies belonging to this city; 
(c)  Sell, trade or otherwise dispose of surplus equipment or supplies belonging to the city as authorized in this Code section or in section 4-3707 of this Code; and 
(d)  Establish and maintain programs for development of specifications and administer, inspect, and accept contracts in cooperation with the using department. 
(3)  Operational procedures: Consistent with this chapter, the purchasing agent shall adopt operational procedures relating to the execution of his or her duties. All operating procedures shall be approved by the city manager and adopted by the city council. These operating procedures shall be set forth in a purchasing manual and shall be consistent with financial reporting requirements as provided by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3204. - Centralization of procurement authority. 
(1)  Purchasing agent: Except as provided herein, the purchasing agent shall have the authority to solicit and recommend contracts for the procurement of all equipment, supplies, services, construction, and professional or consultant services for the city. 
(2)  Purchasing staff. Under the authority of the purchasing agent, the purchasing staff shall execute responsibilities at all bid openings which shall include coordination of clock calibration with the National Bureau of Standards, stamp all bids received, and any subsequent responsibilities as specified prior to and after all bid openings. 
(3)  Other city officers or employees: With the approval of the city manager, the purchasing agent may delegate authority to purchase certain equipment, supplies, services, or construction items to other city officials, if such delegation is deemed necessary for the procurement of those items. Any unauthorized action shall result in disciplinary action by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3205. - Requirements upon using departments. 
(1)  Relationship with using departments: The purchasing agent shall maintain a close and cooperative relationship with the using departments. The purchasing agent shall afford each using department agency reasonable opportunity to participate in and make recommendations regarding procurement matters affecting the using department. When in consultation with the using department regarding a procurement, the purchasing agent, to the extent practicable, shall use every effort to reach an agreement with the using departments. 
(2)  Requisitions: All departments, with the authority of the director of the department, shall file with the purchasing agent detailed requisitions or estimates of their requirements of equipment, supplies, services, construction, professional or consultant services, in such manner and at such times and for future periods as the purchasing agent shall prescribe in writing including the following: 
(a)  Unforeseen requirements: A using department may file with the purchasing agent at any time a requisition or estimate for any equipment, supplies, services, construction, professional or consultant services, the need for which was unforeseen or not anticipated when the above-detailed estimates were filed; and 
(b)  Revisory power of purchasing agent: The purchasing agent shall examine each requisition or estimate and shall have the authority to revise it as to quantity, quality or estimated cost; provided, that the needs of the departments are met and revisions as to quality and quantity shall be made in accordance with standards and specifications established pursuant to this chapter. 
(3)  Estimates: All departments shall file with the purchasing agent, within thirty (30) days after the adoption of the annual budget and quarterly, thereafter, estimates of their needs for the procurement of equipment, supplies, services, construction, and professional or consultant services for the ensuing fiscal year or calendar quarter. The purchasing agent shall utilize such estimates for the scheduling of work activities and of procurements to be made by the purchasing agent. The purchasing agent shall compile and consolidate all estimates of supplies needed by the departments to determine total requirements of a given commodity. 
(4)  List of authorized signatures: All heads of departments shall provide the purchasing agent annually with a list of signatures of persons in the department who are authorized to sign requisitions on behalf of the department. 
(5)  Examination of contracts: The purchasing agent and the head of the department shall examine all contracts to determine the accuracy of the substance and the inclusion of required bonds and certificates of insurance. 
(6)  Receiving reports: The department shall deliver receiving reports to the city treasurer and to the purchasing agent upon receipt of supplies procured under city contracts. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3206. - Further authorization of city council; when required. 
The purchasing agent shall have the authority to enter into and sign contracts on behalf of the city, pursuant to section 4-3203 of the Code of the City of East Point, in the following circumstances: 
(1)  For the purchase of supplies of every type and description and contracts which take the form of purchase orders where the city council has authorized the purchase in the normal course of the budget process, without further authorization by the city council. 
Provided, that the purchasing agent complies with all other requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95; Ord. No. 011-03, § 1, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 4-3207. - Further authorization of city council. 
All contracts, letters of engagement or agreements for equipment, supplies, services, construction services, professional services and consultant services resulting from the bid/procurement process must be approved by council before being executed by the purchasing agent and mayor. Council will approve such contract if they meet the scope of work bid out and the price of the accepted bid. 
(Ord. No. 011-03, § 1, 3-3-03) 
Secs. 4-3208—4-3300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - SOURCE SELECTION AND CONTRACT FORMATION 

Sec. 4-3301. - Methods of source selection. 
Unless otherwise authorized by law, all city contracts in an amount greater than twelve thousand five dollars ($12,500.00), except for the purchase, sale and disposition of real estate, shall be awarded by competitive sealed bidding, pursuant to section 4-3302 (Competitive sealed bidding), except as provided in: 
(1)  Section 4-3303 (Competitive sealed proposals); 
(2)  Section 4-3304 (Small purchases); 
(3)  Section 4-3305 (Sole source procurement); 
(4)  Section 4-3306 (Emergency procurement); 
(5)  Section 4-3307 (Competitive selection procedures for professional and consultant services); 
(6)  Section 4-3704 (Recurring inventory items); 
(7)  Section 4-3707 (Disposition of surplus supplies). 
(8)  Section 4-3323 (Aggregated purchasing groups). 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95; Ord. No. 034-015, 8-17-15 ) 
Sec. 4-3302. - Competitive sealed bidding. 
(1)  Conditions for use: Contracts or purchase orders shall be awarded by competitive sealed bidding except as otherwise provided in section 4-3301 (Methods of source selection). 
(2)  Invitations for bids: An invitation for bids shall be issued and shall include a purchase description and all contractual terms and conditions applicable to the procurement. 
(3)  Public notice: Where the estimated contract is in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), an advertisement inviting bids shall be published at least once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks, in at least one (1) newspaper of general circulation in the city, at least fourteen (14) days preceding the date set for receipt of bids. Notice of bid security, if required, shall be included in the public notice. The public notice shall contain a general description of the equipment, supplies, services, construction, and professional or consultant services to be procured and shall state the location of where appropriate solicitation documents may be obtained, and the time and place of opening of solicitation documents. 
(4)  Bidders' list: The issuance of a public notice shall not be required where the estimated amount 
of the contract does not exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) and the purchasing agent has established and maintains a current bidders' list. The bidders' list must contain more than an adequate number of vendors with the capacity to furnish the service or supplies required. Further, the list shall constitute a reasonable representation of all prospective vendors in the market place. 
(5)  Clock calibration: Prior to all bid openings, the purchasing agent or staff shall coordinate the clock calibration used in the bid process, with the National Bureau of Standards. 
(6)  Bid opening: Bids shall be opened publicly in the presence of one (1) or more witnesses at the time and place designated in the invitation for bids. The name of each bidder, the amount of each bid, and such other relevant information as the purchasing agent deems appropriate shall be recorded. The record and each bid shall be open to public inspection. 
(7)  Bid acceptance: Bids shall be unconditionally accepted without alteration or correction, except as authorized in this chapter; provided, that the bids are delivered to the purchasing agent at the time, place and under the conditions contained in the invitation for bids. 
(8)  Bid evaluation: Bids shall be evaluated based on the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids. The criteria that will affect the bid price and be considered in evaluation for award shall be objectively measurable, such as discounts, transportation costs, and total or life cycle costs. The invitation for bids shall set forth the evaluation criteria to be used including but not limited to inspection, testing, quality, workmanship, delivery, and suitability for a particular purpose. No criteria may be used in bid evaluation that are not set forth in the invitation for bids. 
(9)  Correction or withdrawal of bids: 
(a)  Before bid opening: Correction or withdrawal of bids may be allowed by the purchasing agent before the scheduled time and date of bid opening. The bidder may withdraw the bid, without revealing the amount of the bid, by submitting a new sealed bid or providing written notice of withdrawal before bid opening. Notice of withdrawal must be received by the purchasing agent prior to bid opening. 
(b)  After bid opening: Mistakes or errors in bids discovered by the purchasing agent or bidder after bid opening may be corrected or withdrawal of bids may be allowed, in accordance with this section. A bidder who discovers a mistake or error in the bid may request relief from the purchasing agent; and the purchasing agent may allow relief as prescribed below: 
(i)  Clerical mistakes: Any obvious clerical mistake, including but not limited to an error in price extension, placement of decimal points, reversal of prices, FOB destination, or FOB point of origination may be corrected by the purchasing agent after written verification is made by the bidder. 
(ii)  Corrections: A written determination is made that the following conditions are met: 
1.  Evidence of the mistake and the bid intended is clear and convincing on the face of the bid; and 
2.  The bid received and as actually intended is the lowest responsive bid received. 
Provided, that if there is no clear and convincing evidence, the bidder shall not be permitted to withdraw the bid without prejudice or to correct the error; and upon failure to enter into contract, such bidder shall forfeit the bid security. 
(iii)  Withdrawal: If there is a significant and obvious disparity between the prices of the lowest bidder and of the other bidders, a bidder may be permitted to withdraw without prejudice, upon submission of evidence that a nonintentional error occurred. Provided, that a withdrawal of bid shall not be allowed without prejudice unless clear and convincing evidence exists to support the error. 
(10)  Tie bids: In the event two (2) or more bidders are tied in price while otherwise meeting all of the required conditions, the contract shall be awarded to a bidder whose principal place of business is within the city. 
(11)  Award: The contract shall be awarded with reasonable promptness by written notice to the lowest responsible and responsive bidder whose bid meets the requirements and criteria set forth in the invitation for bids. Provided, however, that the city reserves the right to reject all bids. In the event all bids exceed available funds as certified by the city treasurer, and the low responsive bid does not exceed such funds by more than five (5) percent, the purchasing agent is authorized, when time or economic considerations preclude resolicitation of work of a reduced scope, to negotiate an adjustment of the bid price, including changes in the bid requirements, with the low responsible and responsive bidder in order to bring the bid within the amount of available funds. 
(12)  Multistep sealed bidding: When it is considered impractical to initially prepare a purchase description to support an award based on price, an invitation for bids may be issued requesting the submission of unpriced offers to be followed by an invitation for bids limited to those bidders whose offers have been qualified under the criteria set forth in the first solicitation. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3303. - Competitive sealed proposals. 
(1)  Conditions for use: When the purchasing agent determines that the use of competitive sealed bidding is neither practicable nor advantageous to the city, a contract may be entered into by the use of the competitive sealed proposals method. 
(2)  Request for proposals: Proposals shall be solicited through a request for proposals. 
(3)  Public notice: Public notice of the request for proposals shall be given in the same manner as provided in section 4-3302(3) (Competitive sealed bidding, public notice). 
(4)  Proposal opening: Proposals shall be publicly opened, and only the names of the offerors shall be disclosed at the opening. Contents of competing offerors' proposals shall not be disclosed during the process of negotiation. Proposals shall be open for public inspection only after contract award. Proprietary or confidential information marked as such in each proposal shall not be disclosed without written consent of the offeror. 
(5)  Evaluation factors: The request for proposals shall state the relative importance of evaluation factors. 
(6)  Discussion with responsible offerors and revisions to proposals: Discussions may be conducted with responsible offerors who submit proposals determined to be reasonably susceptible of being selected for award for the purpose of clarification to assure full understanding of and responsiveness to the solicitation requirements. Offerors shall be accorded fair and equal treatment with respect to any opportunity for discussion and revision of proposals, and such revisions may be permitted after submissions and prior to the deadline for submission for the purpose of obtaining best and final offers. In conducting discussions, there shall be no disclosure of information derived from proposals submitted by competing offerors. 
(7)  Award: Award shall be made to the responsible offeror whose proposal is determined in writing to be the most advantageous to the city, taking into consideration the evaluation factors set forth in the request for proposals. No other factors or criteria shall be used in the evaluation. The contract file shall contain the basis on which the award was made. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3304. - Small purchases. 
(1)  General procedures: Any contract or purchase order for equipment, supplies, services and construction not exceeding twelve thousand five hundred dollars ($12,500.00) may be made without public notice in accordance with small purchase procedures adopted by the purchasing agent in accordance with this chapter. Contract requirements shall not be artificially divided so as to constitute a small purchase under this section. To the extent possible, said purchases shall be made from the vendors on the current bidders' list maintained by the purchasing agent pursuant to section 4-3302(4) of this chapter. 
(2)  Small purchases under two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00): The purchasing agent shall adopt operational procedures for making small purchases of up to two thousand-five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or less by authorized persons other than the purchasing staff. Such operational procedures shall provide for obtaining adequate and reasonable competition for the equipment, supply, service, or construction being purchased. Further, such operational procedures shall require the preparation and maintenance of written records adequate to document the competition obtained, properly account for the funds expended, and facilitate an audit of the small purchase made. 
(3)  Competitive quotations: Contracts or purchases for amounts equaling twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or less may be authorized by the purchasing agent for equipment, supplies, services, or minor construction, through the use of competitive quotations. Quotations of this nature may be oral or written, however, the company name, telephone number, and contact person for all competitive parties shall be made available as a bid record for scrutiny, and must meet the test of sections 4-3320(2) (Contract audit) and section 4-3321 (Reporting anti-competitive practices). 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95; Ord. No. 034-015, 8-17-15 ) 
Sec. 4-3305. - Sole and single source procurement. 
A contract may be awarded without competition when the purchasing agent determines in writing, after conducting a good faith review of available sources, that there is only one (1) source for the required equipment, supply, service, construction item or professional or consultant service. The purchasing agent shall conduct negotiations, as appropriate, as to price, delivery and terms. A record of sole source procurements shall be maintained that lists each contractor's name, the name and type of each contract, a listing of the item(s) procured under each contract, and the identification number of each contract file. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3306. - Emergency procurement. 
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, where the purchasing agent determines that an emergency exists, the purchasing agent may make or authorize others to make emergency procurements or equipment, supplies, services, construction items or professional or consultant services when the purchasing agent determines there exists a threat to public health, welfare or safety under emergency conditions. Such emergency procurements shall be made with as much competition as is practicable under the circumstances. A written determination of the basis for the emergency and for the selection of the particular contractor shall be included in the contract file. As soon as practicable, a record of each emergency procurement shall be made and shall set forth the contractor's name, the amount and type of the contract, a listing of the item(s) procured under the contract, and the identification number of the contract file. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3307. - Competitive selection procedures for professional and consultant services. 
(1)  Conditions for use: The purchasing agent, upon the request or recommendation of the department as provided in section 4-3205 (Requirements upon using departments), shall procure professional and consultant services in accordance with this section, except as authorized under section 4-3305 (Sole source procurement) and section 4-3306 (Emergency procurement). 
(2)  Statement of qualifications: In the procurement of professional and consultant services, the purchasing agent shall request persons to submit statements of interest in providing such types of services with their statement of qualifications and performance data for inclusion in a professional or consultant qualifications list that shall be maintained by the purchasing agent. Each using department shall encourage professional and consultant firms, which desire to provide services to the department, to submit statements of qualifications to the purchasing agent. The purchasing agent may specify a uniform format for statements of qualifications. Persons may amend these statements at any time by filing a new statement. Any person placed on the qualifications list shall be removed if found in violation of this article within this chapter or in default of any contract with the city. 
(3)  Public notice: Where the estimated cost is in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), the purchasing agent shall issue public notice for request for proposals from professional and consultant offerors as provided in section 4-3302(3) (Competitive sealed bidding, public notice). The public notice for request for proposals shall describe the services required, list the type of information and data required of each offeror, and state the relative importance of particular qualifications. 
(4)  Selection process: The purchasing agent, in consultation with the head of the department and upon the recommendation of the head of the department, shall conduct discussions regarding the contract and shall select from among the offerors no less than three (3) offerors deemed most qualified to provide the required services. Provided, that the purchasing agent may waive the requirement of three (3) offerors upon the written determination that three (3) firms are not available to perform the proposed professional or consultant services. The selection shall be made in order of preference, based upon criteria established and published by the purchasing agent with the recommendation of the department head. The criteria shall include but not be limited to the following factors: 
(a)  Previous experience demonstrating competence to perform work involved in the project; 
(b)  Past performance of previous contracts with respect to time of completion and quality of work; 
(c)  The fee or compensation demanded for the work or services; 
(d)  The ability to comply with the applicable ordinances and resolutions of the city, the regulations and ordinances of the county in which the work is to be performed, and the laws of the State of Georgia and the United States; 
(e)  The ability to comply with the schedule of the commencement and completion of the work or services as required by the city; 
(f)  The financial ability to furnish the necessary bonds; 
(g)  The financial condition of the professional or consultant; and 
(h)  The ability to provide staffing of management personnel to the project, satisfactory to the city. 
(5)  Negotiations and award: The purchasing agent shall negotiate a contract with the most qualified firm for the professional or consultant services to be performed at compensation which the purchasing agent determines in writing to be fair and reasonable to the city. In making this decision, the purchasing agent shall take into account the estimated value, the scope, the complexity and the professional nature of the services to be rendered. Should the purchasing agent be unable to negotiate a satisfactory contract with the firm considered to be the most qualified at a price the purchasing agent determines to be fair and reasonable to the city, negotiations with that firm shall be formally terminated. The purchasing agent shall then undertake negotiations with the second most qualified firm. Failing accord with the second most qualified firm, the purchasing agent shall undertake negotiations with the third most qualified firm. Should the purchasing agent be unable to negotiate a contract at a fair and reasonable price with any of the selected firms, the purchasing agent and the using department shall select additional firms in order of their competence and qualifications and the purchasing agent shall continue negotiations in accordance with this section until an agreement is reached. After reaching an agreement the proposed contract will be sent back to council for final approval prior to its execution by the purchasing agent and the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95; Ord. No. 011-03, § 1, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 4-3308. - Cancellation of invitations for bids or requests for proposals. 
An invitation for bids, a request for proposals, or other solicitation may be canceled, or any or all bids or proposals may be rejected in whole or in part as may be specified in the solicitation, when it is for good cause and in the best interest of the city. The reasons therefor shall be made part of the contract file. Each solicitation issued by the city shall state that the solicitation may be cancelled and that any bid or proposal may be rejected in whole or in part for good cause when in the best interest of the city. Notice of cancellation shall be sent to all businesses solicited. The notice shall identify the solicitation, explain the reasons for cancellation, and, where appropriate, explain that opportunity be given to compete on any resolicitation or any future procurements of similar items. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3309. - Responsibility of bidders and offerors. 
(1)  Determination of responsibility: Responsibility of the bidder or offeror shall be ascertained for each contract awarded by the city based upon full disclosure to the purchasing agent concerning capacity to meet the terms of the contract and based upon past record of performance of similar contracts. 
(2)  Determination of nonresponsibility: If a bidder or offeror who otherwise would have been awarded a contract is found nonresponsible, a written determination of nonresponsibility setting forth the basis of the finding shall be prepared by the purchasing agent. The unreasonable failure of a bidder or offeror to supply prompt information in connection with an inquiry with respect to responsibility may be grounds for a determination of nonresponsibility. A copy of the determination shall be sent to the nonresponsible bidder or offeror. The final determination shall be made part of the contract file and be made a public record. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3310. - Bid security for nonconstruction contracts. 
(1)  Requirement for bid security: Bid security shall be required for all competitive sealed bidding for contracts for supplies and services when the price is estimated by the purchasing agent to exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). Bid security shall be a bond provided by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Georgia, or the equivalent in cash, cashier's check or certified check. Nothing herein prevents the requirement of such bonds on contracts for supplies and services under one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) when the purchasing agent determines that the circumstances warrant such requirement. 
(2)  Amount of bid security: Bid security shall be in an amount equal to at least five (5) percent of the amount of the bid. Unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to the return of the bid security. Upon failure of a successful bidder to enter into a contract within ten (10) days after the purchasing agent tenders the proposed contract, the bidder shall forfeit the bid security. 
(3)  Rejection of bids for noncompliance with the bid security requirement: When the invitation for bids requires security, the bid shall be rejected if the purchasing agent determines that the bid fails to comply in a substantial manner with the security requirements. 
(4)  Withdrawal of bids: If a bidder is permitted to withdraw its bid before the deadline for submission as provided in section 4-3302(9)(a) (Competitive sealed bidding, correction or withdrawal of bids), no action shall be had against the bidder or bid security. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3311. - Performance and payment bonds for construction contracts. 
(1)  When required amounts: When a contract for supplies or services is awarded in excess of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) (or when a contract for professional or consultant services is awarded and the purchasing agent determines that the circumstances so warrant), the following bonds or security shall be delivered to the city and shall become binding on the parties upon the execution of the contract: 
(a)  A performance bond satisfactory to the city, executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Georgia or otherwise secured in a manner satisfactory to the city, in an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the price specified in the contract; and 
(b)  A payment bond satisfactory to the city, executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Georgia or otherwise secured in a manner satisfactory to the city, for the protection of all persons supplying labor and material to the contractor or its subcontractor for the performance of the work provided for in the contract. The bond shall be in an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the price specified in the contract. 
(2)  Reduction or waiver of bond: The purchasing agent is authorized to reduce or waive performance and payment bonds for contracts for equipment, supplies and services for one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or less, when the purchasing agent makes a written determination that it is in the best interests of the city to do so. Nothing herein prevents the requirement of such bonds on supply or service contracts under one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) when the circumstances warrant. The purchasing agent is authorized to reduce or waive payment bonds on contracts for professional or consultant services when the purchasing agent determines it is in the best interests of the city. 
(3)  Authority to require additional bonds: Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the authority of the city to require a performance or payment bond or other security in addition to those bonds, or in circumstances other than those specified in subsections (1) and (2) of this section. 
(4)  Suits on payment bonds right to institute: Any person who has furnished labor or material to the contractor for the work provided in the contract, for which a payment bond is furnished under this section, and who had not been paid in full within ninety (90) days from the date on which that person performed the last of the labor or supplied the material, shall have the right to sue on the payment bond for any amount unpaid at the time the suit is instituted and to prosecute the action for the amount due that person. 
(5)  Suits on payment bonds where and when brought: Every suit instituted upon a payment bond shall be brought in a court of competent jurisdiction for the county or district in which the contract for equipment, supplies, services, construction, and professional or consultant services was to be performed; but no such suit shall be commenced after the expiration of one (1) year after the day on which the last of the labor was performed or material was supplied by the person bringing suit. The obligee named in the bond need not be joined as a party of any such suit. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3312. - Insurance requirements. 
(1)  General insurance requirements: The purchasing agent, in consultation with the city treasurer, shall, at least annually, determine the minimum insurance requirements of the city and evaluate current insurance policies to determine whether minimum insurance requirements continue to be met. The purchasing agent, with the approval of the city manager and in consultation with the city treasurer, shall develop procedures for the purchase of insurance for the city, in accordance with this ordinance. Insurance requirements for the city shall be considered for the following purposes: 
(a)  Bonds, covenants or conditions of indebtedness of the city; 
(b)  Any employee benefit program; 
(c)  Public liability insurance for contractors doing business with the city; 
(d)  Any other purpose for which insurance is required or expedient, as determined by the purchasing agent, after consultation with the city manager. 
(2)  Public liability insurance for contracts: The purchasing agent is authorized to establish standard ranges for limits of liability in public liability insurance coverage, as appropriate, for all contracts let by the city where work thereunder will expose the general public to the risks of bodily injury and property damage. Where the purchasing agent determines that it is appropriate to the type of work under the contract and maximizes competition in the bidding or proposal process, lower limits of liability may be prescribed. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3313. - Prequalification of suppliers. 
(1)  When required: The purchasing agent, in consultation with the using department, may determine that it shall be in the best interests of the city to prequalify suppliers for particular types of equipment, supplies, services, construction, and professional or consultant services. Prequalification standards may be imposed by the purchasing agent which must be met by any contractor in order to qualify to respond to an invitation for bids or a request for proposals. Contractors shall be required to submit information to the purchasing agent to assure a fair and impartial determination of whether a contractor has met such prequalifications standards. When prequalification is required, only those contractors who submit the required prequalification information and who are actually prequalified to submit a bid or proposal on the contract in question, or who are parties to a joint venture formed by contractors who are prequalified under this section, shall be allowed to submit bids or proposals on the contract in question. 
(2)  Public Notice: Public notice of prequalification shall be given in the same manner as provided in section 4-3302 (Competitive sealed bidding, public notice). 
(3)  Prequalification standards: When the purchasing agent determines that prequalification standards shall be required, those standards shall include but not be limited to the evaluation factors set forth in section 4-3302 (Competitive sealed bidding, award). 
(4)  Prequalification: The purchasing agent and other affected city departments shall review all information submitted by contractors; and, if necessary, additional information may be required. If the purchasing agent, in consultation with the using department determines that the contractor meets all of the prequalification standards established under this ordinance, then the purchasing agent shall prequalify the contractor as qualified to submit a bid or proposal. The contractor shall be notified in writing of prequalification. 
(5)  Failure to prequalify: If a contractor is found not to meet the prequalification standards established under this chapter, a written determination setting forth the basis for such finding shall be prepared by the purchasing agent. A notice of failure to prequalify shall be sent to the contractor, which notice shall inform the contractor of the reasons for the failure to prequalify and the steps necessary to cure the failure. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3314. - Cost or pricing data. 
(1)  Required submissions relating to the award of contracts: A prospective contractor shall submit cost or pricing data when the contract is expected to exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) and is to be awarded by section 4-3302 (Competitive sealed proposals), by authority of section 4-3305 (Sole source procurement), or by section 4-3307 (Competitive selection procedures for professional and consultant services). 
(2)  Exceptions: The submission of cost or pricing data relating to the award of a contract is not required where: 
(a)  The contract price is based on adequate price competition; 
(b)  The contract price is set by law or regulation; or 
(c)  It is determined in writing by the purchasing agent that the requirements of section 4-3314 may be waived, and the determination states the reasons for such waiver. 
(3)  Required submissions relating to change orders or contract modifications: A contractor shall submit cost or pricing data prior to the pricing of any change order or contract modification, including adjustments to contracts awarded by competitive sealed bidding, whether or not cost or pricing data were required in connection with the initial pricing of the contract, when the modification involves aggregate increases in costs plus applicable profits that are expected to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(4)  Exceptions: The submission of cost or pricing data relating to the pricing of a change order or contract modification is not required where: 
(a)  Unrelated and separately priced adjustments for which cost or pricing data would not be required are consolidated for administrative convenience; or 
(b)  It is determined in writing by the purchasing agent that the requirements of provision (1) of this section may be waived, and the determination states the reasons for such waiver. 
(5)  Certification required: A contractor, required to submit cost or pricing data in accordance with this section, shall certify that, to the best of its knowledge and belief, the cost or pricing data submitted was accurate, complete and current as of a mutually specified date prior to the award of the contract or the pricing of the change order or contract modification. 
(6)  Price adjustment provision required: Any contract award, change order or contract modification under which the submission and certification of cost or pricing data are required shall contain a provision stating that the price to the city, including a profit or fee, shall be adjusted to exclude any costs found by the city to have been increased because the contractor-furnished cost or pricing data was inaccurate, incomplete or not current as of the date agreed upon between the city and the contractor. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3315. - Cost or price analysis. 
If a contract is being funded in whole or in part by assistance from a federal agency, a cost analysis or a price analysis, as appropriate, shall be conducted prior to award of the contract. A written record of such cost analysis or price analysis shall be made a part of the contract file. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3316. - Types of contracts. 
(1)  General authority: Subject to the limitations of this section, any type of contract which is appropriate to the procurement and which will promote the best interests of the city may be used; except that the use of a "cost plus a percentage of construction cost" contract is prohibited. A "cost reimbursement" contract may be used only when the purchasing agent determines in writing that such contract is likely to be less costly to the city than any other type or that it is a professional or consultant service contract. 
(2)  Multi-term contracts. 
(a)  Specified period. Unless otherwise provided by law, a contract for equipment, supplies or services may be entered into for any period of time deemed to be in the best interests of the city, provided the term of the contract and conditions of renewal or extension, if any, are included in the solicitation and funds are available for the first fiscal period at the time of contracting. Payment and performance obligations for succeeding fiscal periods shall be subject to the availability and appropriation of funds therefor and shall comply with applicable laws. 
(b)  Determination prior to use. Prior to the utilization of a multi-term contract, it shall be determined in writing: 
(i)  That estimated requirements cover the period of the contract and are reasonably firm and continuing; and,
