(ii)  That such a contract will serve the best interests of the city by encouraging effective competition or otherwise promoting economies in city procurement. 
(c)  Cancellation due to unavailability of funds in succeeding fiscal periods. When funds are not appropriated or otherwise made available to support continuation of performance in a subsequent fiscal period, the contract shall be cancelled. The cost of cancellation may be paid from any appropriations available for such purposes. 
(3)  Multiple source contracting. 
(a)  General. A multiple source award is an award of an indefinite quantity contract for one or more similar supplies or services to more than one bidder or offeror. The obligation to order the city's actual requirements is limited to such requirements as may occur in good faith pursuant to O.C.G.A. Section 2-306(1). 
(b)  Limitations on use. A multiple source award may be made when award to two (2) or more bidders or offerors for similar products is necessary for adequate delivery service or product compatibility. Any multiple source award shall be made in accordance with the provisions of Section 4-3302 (Competitive sealed bidding), Section 4-3303 (Competitive sealed proposals), Section 4-3304 (Small purchases), and Section 4-3306 (Emergency procurements), as applicable. Multiple source awards shall not be made when a single award will meet the city's needs without sacrifice of economy or service. Awards shall not be made for the purpose of dividing the business, making available product or supplier selection to allow for user preference unrelated to utility or economy, or avoiding the resolution of tie bids. Any such awards shall be limited to the least number of suppliers necessary to meet the requirements of this section. 
(c)  Contract and solicitation provisions. All eligible users of the contract shall be identified in the solicitation, and it shall be mandatory that the actual requirements of such users that can be met under the contract be obtained in accordance with the contract, provided that: 
(i)  The city shall reserve the right to take bids separately if a particular quantity requirement arises which exceeds its normal requirement or an amount specified in the contract; and, 
(ii)  The city shall reserve the right to take bids separately if the purchasing agent approves a finding that the supply or service available under the contract will not meet a nonrecurring special need of the city. 
(d)  Intent to use. If a multiple source award is anticipated prior to issuing a solicitation, the city shall reserve the right to make such an award and the criteria for the award shall be stated in the solicitation. 
(e)  Determination required. The purchasing agent shall make a written determination setting forth the reasons for a multiple source award, which shall be made a part of the procurement file. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3317. - Extension and expiration of contracts. 
(1)  Extension: The purchasing agent may extend a contract once for ninety (90) days after the date of expiration under the contract, when the following conditions are met: 
(a)  The purchasing agent determines in writing that the extension of the contract is in the best interests of the city and would encourage effective competition; 
(b)  The city council, by duly enacted legislation, authorizes and appropriates funds for the extension; and 
(c)  The city treasurer verifies the availability of funds. 
(2)  Expiration: The purchasing agent shall provide written notice of the expiration date of contracts to the using department and to the city council at least ninety (90) days prior to the expiration date of the contracts. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3318. - Approval of accounting system. 
Except with respect to firm fixed-priced contracts, no contract type shall be used unless it has been determined in writing by the purchasing agent that: 
(1)  The proposed contractor's accounting system will permit timely development of all necessary cost data in the form required by the specified contract type contemplated; and 
(2)  The proposed contractor's accounting system is adequate to allocate costs in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3319. - Right to inspect plant. 
The city may, at reasonable times, inspect the part of the plant, place of business, or worksite of a contractor or subcontractor which is pertinent to the performance of any contract awarded or to be awarded by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3320. - Right to audit records. 
(1)  Audit of cost or pricing data: The city may, at reasonable times and places, audit the books and records of any person who has submitted cost or pricing data pursuant to this section to the extent that such books, documents, papers and records are pertinent to such cost or pricing data for three years from the date of final payment under the contract unless a shorter period is authorized in writing. 
(2)  Contract audit: The city shall be entitled to audit the books and records of a contractor or subcontractor under any negotiated contract or subcontract other than a firm fixed-price contract to the extent that such books, documents, papers and records relate to the performance of such contract or subcontract. Such books and records shall be maintained by the contractor for a period of three (3) years from the date of final payment under the prime contract and by the subcontractor for a period of three (3) years from the date of final payment under the subcontract unless a shorter period is authorized in writing. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3321. - Prohibition against and reporting of anticompetitive practices. 
Collusion and other anticompetitive practices among bidders and offerors are prohibited by city, state and federal laws. When, for any reason, collusion or other anticompetitive practices are suspected among any bidders or offerors, a notice of the relevant facts shall be transmitted to the city attorney for investigation. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3322. - Assurance of payment clause. 
(1)  Requirement: Before final payment to a contractor is made by the city, the contractor shall provide, in a form satisfactory to the city, that all subcontractors and material suppliers involved in the execution of the city contract, have been paid in full at the time of final payment to the contractor by the city. 
(2)  Contract clause: All city contracts, purchase orders or solicitations, where applicable, shall set forth the requirement of assurance of payment as provided in subsection (1) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3323. - Aggregate purchasing groups. 
A contract may be awarded without notice and/or solicitation when the purchasing agent determines that the use of an aggregated purchasing group is appropriate. Only aggregated purchasing groups that utilize an open solicitation process may be used. Any contract awarded via such procedure shall require approval by the city council. 
( Ord. No. 034-015, 8-17-15) ) 
Secs. 4-3324. - Local vendor purchasing preference. 
(1)  Policy. The city has a significant interest in encouraging the creation of employment opportunities for its residents and for businesses located within the city. As a purchaser of goods and services, the city will benefit from expanded job and business opportunities for its residents and businesses through additional revenues generated by its activities. It is in the interest of the city and its residents to give preference on eligible local projects to those eligible offerors who have direct physical and economic relationships with the city. 
(2)  Definition: A "local vendor" or "local business" means any corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship, franchise, or other business form which: 
(a)  Has its headquarters, distribution point, retail location, locally-owned franchise, or place of business within the territorial limits of the city, where work and business is and has been regularly conducted for at least six (6) months immediately prior to the issuance of the request for competitive proposals by the city; and 
(b)  Holds all business or professional licenses required by state law, county ordinance, and city ordinance at the location within the city for at least six (6) months immediately prior to the issuance of the request for competitive proposals by the city. 
(3)  Application of local preference to specific procurement activity: In an effort to nurture small and large businesses, create jobs, boost local economic activity, and tax revenue, the city will grant the lesser of a five-percent or five-point local preference to all otherwise responsive and responsible vendors who have an actual physical presence and direct economic relationship within the city. This provision is applicable only to the city's acquisition of materials, equipment, or services through the request for proposal (RFP) or request for qualification (RFQ) process as provided in code sections 4-3303, 4-3307, and 4-3313. 
(4)  Method of granting local preference: 
(a)  Each corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship, franchise, or other business form seeking local preference points under this section shall certify under oath that it is eligible to receive the local preference points as set forth above as a part of the submission of its proposal or bid to the city and, in the event the affidavit or other declaration under oath is determined to be false, such business shall be deemed "non-responsive" and shall not be considered for award of the applicable contract by the manager of contracts and procurement. 
(b)  Any local vendor who has been determined by the manager of contracts and procurement to be otherwise responsive and responsible, which also provides proof of its local status under oath will receive the lesser of a five-percent or five-point preference on its total evaluated score. 
(5)  Local preference shall not apply to the following: 
(a)  Procurement methods other than a request for proposal (RFP) or request for qualification (RFQ) process as provided in section 4-3303, 4-3307, and 4-3313; or 
(b)  Procurements for which state or federal law, federal grant provisions, or other funding source prohibits granting a local vendor preference; or 
(c)  Goods and services provided under a cooperative purchasing agreement or piggyback contracts; or 
(d)  Emergency, and single or sole source procurement. 
( Ord. No. 043-015, 11-2-15 ) 
Secs. 4-3325—4-3400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 4-3401. - Definitions of terms used in this article. 
(1)  Brand name specification: A specification limited to one (1) or more items by manufacturers' names or catalogue numbers. 
(2)  Brand name or equal specification: A specification limited to one (1) or more items by manufacturers' names or catalogue numbers to describe the standard of quality, performance and other salient characteristics needed to meet city requirements, and which provides for the submission of equivalent products. 
(3)  Specification: Any description of the physical or functional characteristics or of the nature of a supply, service or construction item. It may include a description of any requirement for inspecting, testing or preparing a supply, service or construction item for delivery. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3402. - Maximum practicable competition. 
All specifications shall be drafted so as to promote overall economy for the purposes intended and to encourage competition in satisfying the city's needs, and shall not be unduly restrictive. The policy enunciated in this article applies to all specifications. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3403. - Brand name specification. 
(1)  Use: Brand name specification may be used only when the purchasing agent makes a written determination that only the identified brand name item or items will satisfy the city's needs. 
(2)  Competition: The purchasing agent shall seek to identify sources from which the designated brand name item or items can be obtained and shall solicit such sources to achieve whatever degree of price competition is practicable. If only one source can supply the requirement, the procurement shall be made under section 4-3305 (Sole source procurement). 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3404. - Brand name or equal specification. 
(1)  Use: Brand name or equal specification may be used when the purchasing agent determines in writing that: 
(a)  No other design or performance specification or qualified products list is available; 
(b)  Time does not permit the preparation of another form of purchase description, not including a brand name specification; 
(c)  The nature of the product or the nature of the city's requirements makes use of a brand name or equal specification suitable for the procurement; or 
(d)  Use of a brand name or equal specification is in the city's best interest. 
Provided, that the purchasing agent determines that the essential characteristics of the brand name included in the specifications are commonly known in the industry or trade; brand name or equal specifications shall include a description of the particular design, function or performance characteristics which are required. 
(2)  Designation of several brand names: Brand name or equal specifications shall seek to designate three (3), or as many different brands as are practicable, as "or equal" references and shall further state that substantially equivalent products to those designated will be considered for award. 
(3)  Nonrestrictive use of brand name or equal specifications: Where a brand name or equal specification is used in a solicitation, the solicitation shall contain explanatory language that the use of a brand name is for the purpose of describing the standard of quality, performance and characteristics desired and is not intended to limit or restrict competition. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Secs. 4-3405—4-3500. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE E. - PROCUREMENT OF CONSTRUCTION, ARCHITECT-ENGINEER AND LAND SURVEYING SERVICES 

Sec. 4-3501. - Definitions of terms used in this article. 
(1)  Architect-engineer and land surveying services: Those professional services within the scope of the practice of architecture, professional engineering, land surveying, landscape architecture and interior design pertaining to construction, as defined by the laws of the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3502. - Responsibility for selection of methods of construction-related services. 
The using department, at the time the construction project is being developed, shall provide the purchasing agent with information for the scheduling of the project and, if necessary, for the method of selection of architect-engineer and land surveying services, construction services and construction management of the project. In determining which method to use for the selection of architect-engineering and land surveying services, construction services and construction management, the purchasing agent shall consider the city's requirements, its resources and the potential contractor's capabilities. The methods chosen shall be those which are most advantageous to the city and which will result in the most competitive, timely, economical and successful completion of the construction project. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3503. - Contract administration. 
The purchasing agent, with the assistance of the using department and other appropriate city departments, shall establish the standards for a contract administration system designed to ensure that a contractor is performing in accordance with the solicitation under which the contract is awarded and the terms and conditions of the contract. Such system shall require the inclusion of receiving reports from all appropriate agencies in the contract file. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3504. - Bid security for construction contracts. 
(1)  Requirement for bid security: Bid security shall be required for all competitive sealed bidding for construction contracts when the price is estimated by the purchasing agent to exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). Bid security shall be a bond provided by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Georgia, or the equivalent in cash, certified check, letter of credit or otherwise supplied in a form satisfactory to the city. Nothing herein prevents the requirement of such bonds on construction contracts under fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) when the circumstances warrant. 
(2)  Amount of bid security: Bid security shall be in an amount equal to at least five (5) percent of the amount of the bid. Unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to the return of the bid security. Upon failure of a successful bidder to enter into a contract within ten (10) days after the city tenders the proposed contract, the bidder shall forfeit the bid security. 
(3)  Rejection of bids for noncompliance with the bid security requirements: When the invitation for bids requires security, the bid shall be rejected if the purchasing agent determines that it fails to comply in a substantial manner with the security requirements. 
(4)  Withdrawal of bids: After the bids are opened, they shall be irrevocable for the period specified in the invitation for bids, except as provided in section 4-3302(9) (Competitive sealed bidding, correction or withdrawal of bids). If a bidder is permitted to withdraw its bid before award, no action shall be had against the bidder or bid security. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3505. - Contract performance and payment bonds for construction contracts. 
(1)  When required—amounts: When a construction contract is awarded in excess of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), the following bonds or security shall be delivered to the city and shall become binding on the parties upon the execution of the contract: 
(a)  A performance bond satisfactory to the city, executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Georgia or otherwise secured in a manner satisfactory to the city, in an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the price specified in the contract; and 
(b)  A payment bond satisfactory to the city, executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Georgia or otherwise secured in a manner satisfactory to the city, for the protection of all persons supplying labor and material to the contractor or its subcontractors for the performance of the work provided for in the contract. The bond shall be in an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the price specified in the contract. 
(2)  Reduction or waiver of bond: The purchasing agent is authorized to reduce or waive performance and payment bonds for contracts for one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or less, when a written determination is made that it is in the best interests of the city to do so. Nothing herein prevents the requirement of such bonds on construction contracts for one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or less when the circumstances warrant. 
(3)  Authority to require additional bonds: Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the authority of the purchasing agent to require a performance bond or other security in addition to those bonds, or in circumstances other than those specified in subsections (1) and (2) of this section. 
(4)  Suits on payment bonds: Any person who has furnished labor or material to the contractor for the work provided in the contract, for which a payment bond is furnished under this section, and who has not been paid in full within ninety (90) days from the date on which that person performed the last of the labor or supplied the material, shall have the right to sue, as provided in section 4-3311(4) and (5), on the payment bond for any amount unpaid at the time the suit is instituted and to prosecute the action for the amount due that person. 
(5)  Retention: 
(a)  Maximum amount to be withheld: In any contract or subcontract for construction which provides for progress payments in installments based upon an estimated percentage of completion with a percentage of the contract's proceeds to be retained by the city pending completion of the contract or subcontract, the retained amount of each progress payment or installment shall be no more than ten (10) percent. 
(b)  Release of retained funds: Funds held by the city as retainage under the contract shall be released to the contractor as specified in the contract. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3506. - Bond forms and copies. 
(1)  Bond forms: The form of payment and performance bonds shall be prescribed by the purchasing agent, in consultation with the city attorney. The purchasing agent shall designate the bond forms to be used for a particular contract. 
(2)  Bond copies: Any person may request and obtain from the city a copy of the bond form upon payment of the cost of reproduction and postage. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3507. - Architect-engineer and land surveying services. 
Architect-engineer and land surveying services shall be procured as provided in section 4-3307 (Competitive selection procedures for professional and consultant services), except as provided in section 4-3305 (Sole source procurement) and section 4-3306 (Emergency procurement). 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Secs. 4-3508—4-3600. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE F. - CONTRACT CLAUSES AND THEIR ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 4-3601. - Contract clauses. 
All city contracts for equipment, supplies, services, construction, and professional and consultant services shall include provisions necessary to define the responsibilities and rights of the parties to the contract. The purchasing agent, after consultation with the city attorney, may issue clauses appropriate for equipment, supply, service, construction, and professional and consultant service contracts, addressing the following subjects: 
(1)  The unilateral right of the city to order in writing changes in work within the scope of the contract; 
(2)  The unilateral right of the city to order in writing temporary stopping of the work or delaying performance that does not alter the scope of the contract; 
(3)  Variations occurring between estimated quantities of work in a contract and actual quantities; 
(4)  Defective pricing; 
(5)  Liquidated damages; 
(6)  Specified excuses of delay or nonperformance; 
(7)  Termination of the contract for default; 
(8)  Termination of the contract in whole or in part for the convenience of the city; 
(9)  Suspension of work on a construction contract ordered by the city; and 
(10)  Site conditions differing from those indicated in the contract, or ordinarily encountered, except that differing site conditions clause need not be included in a contract: 
(a)  When the contract is negotiated; 
(b)  When the contractor provides the site or design; or 
(c)  When the parties have otherwise agreed with respect to the risk of differing site conditions. 
(d)  In the absence of agreement by the parties, by a unilateral determination by the city of the costs attributable to the events or situations under such clauses with adjustment of profit or fee as computed by the city, as accounted for in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles and subject to the provisions of 4-3801 (Appeals and remedies). 
(11)  A contractor shall be required to submit cost or pricing data if any adjustment in contract price is subject to the provisions of section 4-3314 (Cost or pricing data). 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3602. - Standard clauses and their modification. 
The purchasing agent, after consultation with and approval by the city attorney, may establish standard contract clauses for use in city contracts. If the purchasing agent establishes any standard clauses addressing the subjects set forth in subsection (1) of this section, such clauses may be varied provided that any variations are supported by a written determination that states the circumstances justifying such variations and provided that notice of any such material variation be stated in the invitation for bids or request for proposals. Any such variations must, however, be approved by the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3603. - Further authorization of city council. 
All contracts, letters of engagement or agreements for equipment, supplies, services, construction services, professional services and consultant services resulting from the bid/procurement process must be approved by council before being executed by the purchasing agent and mayor. Council will approve such contract if they meet the scope of work bid out and the price of the accepted bid. 
(Ord. No. 011-03, § 1, 3-3-03) 
Secs. 4-3604—4-3700. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE G. - SUPPLY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 4-3701. - Definitions. 
(1)  Excess supplies: Any supplies other than expendable supplies having a remaining useful life but which are no longer required by the using agency in possession of the supplies. 
(2)  Expendable supplies: All tangible supplies other than nonexpendable supplies. 
(3)  Nonexpendable supplies: All tangible supplies having an original acquisition cost of over one hundred dollars ($100.00) per unit and a probable useful life of more than one (1) year. 
(4)  Supplies: For the purpose of this article, supplies owned by the city. 
(5)  Surplus supplies: Any supplies other than expendable supplies no longer having any use to the city. This includes obsolete supplies, scrap materials, and nonexpendable supplies that have completed their useful life cycle. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3702. - Supply management. 
(1)  Duties of the purchasing agent: The purchasing agent shall be responsible for: 
(a)  The sale, lease or disposal of surplus supplies by public auction, competitive sealed bidding or other appropriate method in the best interests of the city, provided that no employee of the owning or disposing using department shall be entitled to purchase such supplies; and 
(b)  The transfer of excess supplies to using agencies of the city. 
(2)  Policies and procedures: Consistent with this chapter and with the approval of the city manager and adoption by the city council, the purchasing agent shall develop operational procedures relating to supplies owned by the city during their entire life cycle. These procedures shall be set forth in a purchasing manual and shall promote the objectives of city supply management, which include: preventing waste, continuing utilization of supplies; and obtaining a fair return of value upon disposal of supplies. The procedures adopted shall provide for inspection, testing, warehousing, inventory and effective transfer and disposition of supplies. 
(3)  Requirement upon using departments: No using department shall transfer, sell, trade in, or otherwise dispose of supplies owned by the city without written notification to the purchasing agent, and in accordance with property disposition procedures. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3703. - Quality assurance, inspection and testing. 
The purchasing agent, in consultation with the using department, shall ascertain or verify that equipment, supplies, services, construction or professional and consultant services procured for the city conform to specifications. The purchasing agent may establish inspection or testing facilities, employ inspection personnel, enter into arrangements for the joint or cooperative use of inspection and testing facilities, and contract with others for inspection and testing work as needed. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3704. - Inventory management. 
The purchasing agent shall exercise general supervision of all inventory of supplies, whether warehoused or in use, belonging to the city or any of its departments. The department, however, shall maintain an inventory of supplies under its control. All warehouses and similar storage areas shall be inventoried at least annually by each department, a written report of which shall be submitted to the purchasing agent and to the city manager accounting for inventory. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3705. - Warehousing and storage. 
The purchasing agent shall exercise general supervision of any receiving, storage, and distribution facilities and services of the city maintained and operated by the purchasing department. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3706. - Excess supplies. 
Using departments shall notify the purchasing agent, at prescribed times, of all excess supplies. The purchasing agent shall transfer excess supplies to other city agencies as determined by need and in accordance with operational procedures adopted pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3707. - Disposition of surplus supplies. 
(1)  General requirements: Unless otherwise provided, the purchasing agent shall dispose of any supplies owned by the city, upon the recommendation of and after consultation with the department, as herein provided. Surplus supplies which have an estimated value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be offered through competitive sealed bids or public auction. Surplus supplies which have an estimated value of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less may be offered by established markets, posted prices, or by any other means advantageous to the city. The purchasing agent shall determine the estimated value of the surplus property to be sold. Notwithstanding the above, the purchasing agent may exchange or trade in surplus supplies with another property owner if such exchange or trade is deemed to be in the best interests of the city. 
(2)  Competitive sealed bidding: 
(a)  Solicitation and opening: When making sales of surplus supplies by competitive sealed bidding, notice of the sale shall be given by advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation at least once no less than fifteen (15) nor more than sixty (60) days before the date set for receipt of bids. Notice may also be given by mailing an invitation for sale bids to prospective bidders, including those bidders on lists maintained for this purpose, and by making invitation for sale bids publicly available. The invitation for sale bids shall list the supplies offered for sale, designate their location and how they may be inspected, and state the terms and conditions of sale and instructions to bidders, including the place, date and time for bid opening. Bids shall be opened publicly. 
(b)  Award: Award shall be made in accordance with the provisions of the invitation for sale bids to the highest responsible bidder, provided that the price offered by such bidder is acceptable to the purchasing agent. Where such price is not acceptable, the purchasing agent may reject the bids in whole or in part and negotiate the sale provided the negotiated sale price is higher than the highest responsive and responsible bidder's price, or such officer may resolicit bids. 
(3)  Auctions: Supplies may be sold at public auction. Notice of such auction shall be given by advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation at least once no less than fifteen (15) nor more than sixty (60) days before the day of the auction. When appropriate, an experienced auctioneer should be used to cry the sale and assist in preparation of the sale. The notice shall contain a general description of the property to be sold, all the terms and conditions of the sale, that a deposit may be required in order to participate in the bidding, that the purchaser must remove within a stated time all surplus supplies purchased, and that the city retains the right to reject any and all bids. 
(4)  Established markets, posted prices and trade-in: Surplus supplies which have an estimated value of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less may be sold in established markets where such supplies, including but not limited to livestock and produce, are regularly sold in wholesale lots and prices are set by open competition. Surplus supplies may be sold at posted prices as determined by the purchasing agent, provided that such prices are based on fair market value and the sale is conducted pursuant to procedures established under this article. Surplus supplies may be traded in only when the purchasing agent determines that the trade-in value is expected to exceed the value estimated to be obtained through the sale or other disposition of such supplies. 
(5)  Payment for surplus supplies: Only United States postal money orders, certified checks, and cashier's checks shall be accepted for sales of surplus property, except cash or a personal check may be accepted for petty cash sales of less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). A copy of all sales notices or invoices shall be sent to the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3708. - Disposition of proceeds. 
Upon completion of sale, lease or disposal of surplus or excess property owned by the city, the purchasing agent shall notify the commissioner of the department of finance in writing, which notice shall contain, at a minimum, a description of the property sold, the inventory control number, the amount for which the article was sold, and the using department in which the property was used. The city treasurer shall make the necessary corrections to the inventory of the city. The purchasing agent shall pay the proceeds of such sales, lease or disposal of property owned by the city to the city treasurer, as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Secs. 4-3709—4-3800. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE H. - APPEALS AND REMEDIES 

Sec. 4-3801. - Authority to resolve bid protests. 
(1)  Right to protest: Any actual or prospective bidder, offeror, contractor or subcontractor who is aggrieved in connection with the prequalification, solicitation or award of a contract shall protest to the purchasing agent. Protestors are urged to seek resolution of their complaints initially with the purchasing agent. A protest with respect to an invitation for bids or request for proposals shall be submitted to the purchasing agent in writing within five (5) calendar days after such aggrieved person knows or should have known of the facts giving rise thereto, but in no circumstance after five (5) calendar days of notification of award of contract. 
(2)  Authority to resolve protests: The purchasing agent shall have authority, prior to protest to the city manager, to settle and resolve a protest of an aggrieved bidder, offeror, contractor or subcontractor, actual or prospective, concerning the prequalification, solicitation or award of a contract. 
(3)  Decision: If a written protest is submitted, the purchasing agent shall inform the protestant of the decision in writing within seven (7) calendar days. The decision of the purchasing agent shall state the reasons for the action taken and inform the protestant of the right to review by the city manager as provided in this article. 
(4)  Finality of decision: A decision under subsection (3) of this section is final and conclusive, unless fraudulent, or any person adversely affected by the decision appeals to the city council in accordance with this article. 
(5)  Finality of city manager's decision; contractor's right to appeal: The city manager's decision shall be final and conclusive unless, within seven (7) calendar days from the date of receipt of the decision, the contractor mails or otherwise delivers a written appeal to the city council or commences an action in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(6)  Failure to render timely decision: If the city manager does not issue a written decision regarding any contract controversy within ten (10) calendar days after written request for a final decision, or within such longer period as may be agreed upon between the parties, then the aggrieved party may proceed as if an adverse decision had been received. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3802. - Solicitations or award in violation of law. 
(1)  Applicability: This section applies where it is determined by administrative review, that a solicitation or award of a contract is in violation of law. 
(2)  Remedies prior to award: If prior to award the purchasing agent, after consultation with the city attorney, determines that a solicitation or proposed award of a contract is in violation of law, then the solicitation or proposed award shall be cancelled or revised to comply with the law. 
(3)  Remedies after award: If after an award the purchasing agent, after consultation with the city attorney, determines that a solicitation or award of a contract is in violation of applicable law, then: 
(a)  If the person awarded the contract has not acted fraudulently or in bad faith: 
(i)  The contract may be ratified and affirmed, provided it is determined that so doing is in the best interest of the city; or 
(ii)  The contract may be terminated and the person awarded the contract shall be compensated for the actual expenses reasonably incurred under the contract, plus a reasonable profit, prior to the termination; 
(b)  If the person awarded the contract has acted fraudulently or in bad faith: 
(i)  The contract may be declared null and void or voidable; or 
(ii)  The contract may be ratified and affirmed if such action is in the best interests of the city, without prejudice to the city's right to such damages as may be appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Secs. 4-3803—4-3900. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE I. - ETHICS IN PUBLIC CONTRACTING 

Sec. 4-3901. - Rejection of bids and offerors and cancellation of contracts. 
The city council, by a duly enacted resolution, may reject a bid, offer or other response to the city solicitation, or cancel any contract, because of any false representation contained in or made in conjunction with an invitation for bids, request for proposals, or any other solicitation of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3902. - Conflicts of interest. 
It shall be unethical for any city employee to participate directly or indirectly in a procurement contract when the city employee knows that: 
(a)  The city employee or any members of the city employee's family has a financial interest pertaining to the procurement contract; or, 
(b)  Any other person, business, or organization with whom the city employee or any member of a city employee's immediate family is negotiating or has an arrangement concerning prospective employment is involved in the procurement contract. 
A city employee or any member of a city employee's immediate family who holds a financial interest in a disclosed blind trust shall be not deemed to have a conflict of interest with regard to matters pertaining to that financial interest. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3903. - Gratuities and kickbacks. 
(1)  Gratuities: It shall be unethical for any person to offer, give or agree to give any employee or former employee, or for any employee or former employee to solicit, demand, accept or agree to accept from another person a gratuity or an offer of employment in connection with any decision, approval, disapproval, recommendation, preparation or any part of a program requirement or a purchase request, influencing the content of any specification or procurement standard, rendering of advice, investigation, auditing, or in any other advisory capacity in any proceeding or application, request for ruling, determination, claim or controversy, or other particular matter, pertaining to any program requirement or a contract or subcontract, or to any solicitation or proposal therefor. 
(2)  Kickbacks: It shall be unethical for any payment, gratuity or offer of employment to be made by or on behalf of a subcontractor under a contract to the prime contractor or higher tier subcontractor or any person associated therewith, as an inducement for the award of a subcontract or order. 
(3)  Contract clause: The prohibition against gratuities and kickbacks prescribed in this section shall be conspicuously set forth in every contract and solicitation therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3904. - Prohibition against contingent fees. 
(1)  Prohibition against contingent fees: It shall be unethical for a person to be retained, or to retain a person, to solicit or secure a city contract upon an agreement or understanding for a commission, percentage, brokerage or contingent fee, except for retention of bona fide employees of bona fide established commercial selling agencies for the purpose of securing business. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3905. - Contemporaneous employment. 
Unless otherwise provided herein, it shall be unethical under this article for any employee who is participating directly or indirectly in the procurement process to become or to be, while such an employee, the employee of any person contracting with the governmental body by whom the employee is employed. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3906. - Use of confidential information. 
In accordance with this article, it shall be unethical for any employee or former employee willfully to use confidential information for actual or anticipated personal gain, or for the actual or anticipated personal gain of any other person. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3907. - Penalties. 
(1)  Criminal penalties: To the extent that violations of the ethical standards of conduct set forth in this article constitute violations of the Georgia State Code, or violations of the city standards of conduct, they shall be punishable as provided therein. Such penalties shall be in addition to the civil sanctions set forth in this article. Criminal, civil and administrative sanctions against employees or nonemployees which are in existence on the effective date of this ordinance shall not be impaired. 
(2)  Sanctions: 
(a)  Employees: The city manager may impose any one (1) or more of the following sanctions on an employee for violations of the ethical standards contained in this article: 
(i)  Oral or written warnings or reprimands; 
(ii)  Suspension with or without pay for specified periods of time; or 
(iii)  Termination of employment. 
(b)  Nonemployees: The city council may impose any one (1) or more of the following sanctions on a nonemployee for violations of the ethical standards: 
(i)  Written warnings or reprimands; 
(ii)  Termination of contracts; or 
(iii)  Debarment or suspension in the city's bidding and contracting processes. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3908. - Recovery of value transferred or received in breach of ethical standards. 
(1)  General requirement: The value of anything transferred or received in breach of the ethical standards of this chapter by an employee or a nonemployee may be recovered from both the employee and nonemployee. 
(2)  Recovery of kickbacks by the city: Upon a showing that a subcontractor made a kickback to a prime contractor or a higher tier subcontractor in connection with the award of a subcontract or order thereunder, it shall be conclusively presumed that the amount thereof was included in the price of the subcontract or order and ultimately borne by the city and will be recoverable hereunder from the recipient. In addition, that amount may also be recovered from the subcontractor making such kickbacks. Recovery from one offending party shall not preclude recovery from other offending parties. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
Sec. 4-3909. - Notice requirement and appeal. 
Unless otherwise provided by law, when sanctions are imposed under this article, the city manager shall give written notice to the offending party, by registered or certified mail, which notice shall state the reasons therefor and effective date, and shall notify the offending party of the right to protest and appeal to the city council as provided in Article H (Appeals and Remedies) of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 7-3-95) 
CHAPTER 4. - CITY OFFICERS AND OFFICIALS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 807-82, adopted Sept. 20, 1982, amended provisions of the City Charter relative to the city clerk. For up-to-date legislation concerning the office of the city clerk, the user's attention is directed to § 4-102 of the Charter. 

ARTICLE A. - CLERK 

Sec. 4-4001. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1062-93, § 1, adopted Sept. 20, 1993, repealed former section 4-4001 in its entirety, which pertained to the combination of the offices of city clerk and city treasurer and derived from the Code of 1959, § 2-31. 
Sec. 4-4002. - Furnishing copies of ordinances to chief of police and library. 
It shall be the duty of the city clerk to furnish the chief of police and the public library each with a certified copy of every ordinance of a general and permanent nature except ordinances calling elections, issuing bonds, revenue anticipation certificates; or fixing tax, water, electric and license rates; or authorizing contracts, street, sewer, sidewalk or other public improvements; or assessing costs of public improvements which are finally adopted by the city council and not vetoed by the mayor; and it shall be the duty of the chief of police to keep the copies available at all times for inspection by anyone desiring to examine the same, and it shall be the duty of the city librarian to keep the copies furnished him available in the library for inspection by anyone when the library is open for use by the public. 
(Code 1959, § 2-32) 
Sec. 4-4003. - Approval of bonds. 
Except where otherwise expressly provided for, all bonds and the sureties thereon required by law or by any ordinance of the city shall be approved by the city clerk, whose duty it shall be to determine the solvency and financial ability of the sureties thereon. 
(Code 1959, § 2-33) 
Sec. 4-4004. - Statements of light and water cutouts to be furnished certain officers. 
It shall be the duty of the treasurer at the end of each month, to furnish the superintendent of the light and water department with a statement showing the number of cutouts issued during the month against persons failing to pay their water and light bills for the preceding month. 
(Code 1959, § 2-34) 
Sec. 4-4005. - Release of tax, etc., liens—Upon payment of delinquency. 
It shall be the duty of the city clerk, and in the absence of the clerk, it shall be the duty of the assistant city clerk, to execute on behalf of the city any proper and suitable legal instruments of writing, releasing the lien of the city against any property, real or personal, on account of any tax or assessment, upon payment to the clerk or assistant clerk of all of the tax or assessment and all interest and cost thereon. 
(Code 1959, § 2-35) 
Sec. 4-4006. - Same—Release to be absolute. 
Any release issued on behalf of the city by the clerk or assistant clerk, as provided in section 4-4005, shall be a full, complete, absolute release of the property from the lien and tax, assessment, interest and cost shall have been paid in cash. 
(Code 1959, § 2-36) 
Sec. 4-4007. - Duty to maintain ordinance book. 
It shall be the duty of the city clerk to secure an ordinance book in which he shall copy all ordinances and properly index the same. 
(Code 1959, § 2-37) 
Sec. 4-4008. - Deputies; when appointment authorized. 
(a)  When a vacancy exists in the office of assistant city clerk, the clerk, with the advice and consent of the city council, shall, from among the regular full time officers or employees in his office, or any other office in the city hall, appoint such deputies as may be necessary to discharge the duties of city clerk, or city treasurer, or both, as the case may require, in the absence or disability of the clerk-treasurer, but before the deputies shall exercise any of the powers or authority of city clerk, or city treasurer, he shall make bond in such amount as is required of the city treasurer subject to approval of the city council; provided, appointees pursuant to the provisions of this section shall not receive extra compensation for their service without prior approval thereof by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  No extra bond shall be required of an appointee under the provisions of this section is the appointee is an officer or employee of the city already under a sufficient and adequate bond to be adjudged by the city council. 
(Code 1959, § 2-38) 
Sec. 4-4009. - City clerk, secretary to mayor and council. 
The city clerk shall serve in the capacity of secretary to the mayor and city council of the city. 
(Ord. No. 808-82, § 1, 9-20-82) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 808-82, § 1, adopted Sept. 20, 1982, did not expressly amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as § 4-4009 was at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 4-4010—4-4020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - CITY ATTORNEY AND ASSISTANTS 

Sec. 4-4021. - Attending council meetings. 
The city attorney or the assistant city attorney shall attend all regular meetings of the city council unless excused by the mayor or city manager. It shall be the duty of the city attorney to see that this section is carried out. If the city attorney is unable for any cause to attend a regular meeting, he shall notify the assistant city attorney to be present at the meeting. 
(Code 1959, § 2-42) 
Sec. 4-4022. - Authority of city attorney to hire additional legal assistance. 
The city attorney is authorized and empowered to hire any lawyer or firm of lawyers, at the city's expense, to do research work in situations involving special or extraordinary circumstances where he deems it advisable and in the interest of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 2-43) 
Sec. 4-4023. - Approval of written contracts. 
No contract which it is proper to have reduced to writing shall be executed on behalf of the city by any officer, agent or employee of the city unless or until the legality and form thereof is approved in writing by the city attorney or assistant city attorney. 
(Code 1959, § 2-44) 
Sec. 4-4024. - Furnishing legal advice prejudicial to city. 
It shall be unlawful for the city attorney to knowingly furnish legal advice, whether gratuitously or for a consideration, to any person, with reference to any matter then pending before the council or any department of the city where the legal advice or information may or might be used to the prejudice of the council or the city itself; or where the information or advice may or might be employed to discredit, embarrass, prejudice or work injury to the city or the council or to any officer thereof when there may be reason to suspect that the legal service would or might be so used. 
(Code 1959, § 2-45) 
Sec. 4-4025. - Suits against city—Reports to council. 
It shall be the duty of the city attorney to report all legal proceedings to the council at its next regular meeting after he has received notice of the proceedings from the city clerk. 
(Code 1959, § 2-47) 
Sec. 4-4026. - Same—Verification of pleadings. 
If pleadings prepared by the city attorney in any legal proceedings require verification, they shall be verified by the head of the city department most involved or interested in such legal proceeding or the consequences thereof; or by any officer or employee of the city familiar with the facts, or by both. 
(Code 1959, § 2-48) 
Sec. 4-4027. - Same—Acknowledge service; waiver of formal service; notification of council. 
The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to acknowledge service of any suit, order, process, proceeding or notice against the city and to waive formal service and notice, when, in the judgment of the city attorney, such acknowledgement or waiver will or may benefit the city by its advance notice or by expediting the preparation of its defenses or by saving court costs. In all the cases the council shall be notified at or before its next regular meeting if the acknowledgment or waiver is on a new action or proceeding of which the council has no previous notice. 
(Code 1959, § 2-49) 
Sec. 4-4028. - Claims against city—Form for proof of claim, supply of forms. 
(a)  The following "proof of claim" form is hereby adopted as the official form on which all claims hereafter made against the city shall be filed with the city clerk, and on which all accidents shall be reported:

(c)  It shall be the duty of the city clerk to have printed and keep on hand at all times a sufficient supply of the forms to enable him to supply the heads of the respective departments of the city with a sufficient supply for the needs of their departments. 
(Code 1959, § 2-50) 
Sec. 4-4029. - Same; duty of city employees in case of accidents. 
All officers and employees of the city engaged in any work where an accident occurs, or who shall witness any accident in which the city is involved, shall immediately obtain the names and addresses of all persons witnessing the same, or who may have knowledge relating thereto. They shall immediately report the action to the heads of their respective departments with the names and addresses of all of the witnesses and persons having knowledge relating to the accidents. The report shall be as full and complete in detail as possible, and the head of each department with which any accident report is filed under the provisions of this section shall in turn immediately transmit the report to the clerk of the city. The city clerk shall immediately make a copy of the report for his files and transmit the original of the report to the city council. 
Sec. 4-4030. - Same; reference to city attorney; payment upon certain conditions. 
All claims for damage against the city shall be promptly referred to the city attorney for investigation and written recommendation. Payments of any such claim shall not be recommended, nor will the city pay, settle or compromise any claim until it has been reduced to judgment in a court of competent jurisdiction, except: 
(1)  when supported by clear and convincing proof; 
(2)  when there is a clear and definite legal liability; 
(3)  when it is required by equity and good morals; 
(4)  when the amount is clear and liquidated, or there is a formula or standard by which the exact amount can be definitely computed without litigation or speculation; and 
(5)  when the claim has been filed with the city clerk in due time on a claim form furnished by the city. 
(Code 1959, § 2-52) 
Sec. 4-4031. - Duties of assistant city attorney. 
The assistant city attorney shall perform such duties as may be assigned to him from time to time by the city attorney. 
(Code 1959, § 2-55) 
Secs. 4-4032—4-4040. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - CITY CHAPLAIN 

Sec. 4-4041. - Office created; appointment; term; duties; compensation. 
(a)  The office of city chaplain in and for the City of East Point is hereby created. 
(b)  The city chaplain shall be appointed by the city council for a term expiring with the term of the mayor. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the chaplain to attend meetings of the city council and open the meeting with prayer whenever possible and to perform such other duties in the city as are usual and customary in the county for the county chaplain of Fulton County. 
(d)  The compensation of the chaplain shall be determined and fixed by the city council, and he shall be allowed monthly expenses in such amount as the city council determines to be reasonable and proper. 
(Code 1959, § 2-30.1) 
CHAPTER 5. - MEDIATION PROGRAM FOR THE CITY OF EAST POINT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, adopted July 18, 1994 added a new Ch. 5 to Part IV as herein set out. Ord. No. 1088-94, § 1, adopted Nov. 7, 1994, amended the caption of Ord. No. 1181-94 without amending the text of said ordinance. 

Sec. 4-5001. - Definitions. 
In this chapter: 
Mediation means a process whereby a neutral third person called a "mediator" acts to encourage and facilitate the resolution of a dispute between two (2) or more parties. It is an informal and nonadversarial process with the objective of helping the disputing parties reach a mutually acceptable and voluntary agreement. In mediation, decision-making authority rests with the parties. The role of the mediator includes, but is not limited to, assisting the parties in identifying issues, fostering joint problem-solving, and exploring settlement alternatives. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5002. - Policies. 
It is the policy of the city to encourage the peaceful resolution of disputes through the process of mediation. It is the opinion of the city that the increased utilization of the mediation process will result in tangible benefits to both the city itself as well as its citizenry, including but not limited to savings in actual monies spent on litigation as well as increased efficiencies in the operations of the city and the judicial system at large. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5003. - Referral of pending disputes for mediation. 
(a)  In instances where an employee has made a request for the submittal of a matter to mediation pursuant to section 4-1012(b) hereof, such submittal shall be mandatory upon the city. 
(b)  In addition, the city or its officials may on its own motion or the motion of a party, refer to mediation any matter whereby an aggrieved employee or third party asserts a claim against the city or any of its employees or officials. However, such referrals shall be made only in the sole discretion of the city and only with the consent of the aggrieved party and shall further be made in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Such claim shall be screened by the city either on its own or in cooperation with a mediator to determine whether the claim is appropriate for mediation. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5004. - Notification. 
(a)  All third-party claimants filing an action against the city shall be informed in writing of the existence of the City of East Point's mediation system by the mailing of a copy of this Chapter 5 to such address as is listed for said third-party claimant within the action filed. Furthermore, if the city determines that a third party's claim is appropriate for referral to mediation, the city shall notify the aggrieved party of its determination and shall actively encourage the third party to agree to submit the matter to mediation in accordance with the provisions of this Code. The notice letter shall contain a brief statement advising the aggrieved party that, in the event the matter is ultimately submitted to mediation, each party shall be responsible for the payment of one-half (½) of the costs associated with the mediators' services and that each party shall be solely responsible for their own attorney fees, if any, incurred in relation thereto. 
(b)  The aggrieved party may, at any time after its receipt of the notice under subsection 4-5004(a), notify the city in writing of its objection to the referral. 
(c)  In the event the third party objects to the referral, the city may not refer the dispute to mediation. In the event the third party agrees to submit the dispute to mediation, the city shall go forward with such submittal in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5005. - Appointment of impartial mediator. 
(a)  If the city refers a pending dispute for resolution to mediation pursuant to this chapter, the city may appoint a mediator to facilitate this procedure. 
(b)  The city may appoint a mediator who is agreed on by the parties if the person otherwise qualifies for appointment under this chapter. 
(c)  The city may appoint more than one mediator under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5006. - Qualifications of mediator. 
(a)  Except as provided by subsection 4-5006(b), to qualify for an appointment as a mediator under this chapter a person must have completed a minimum of forty (40) classroom hours of training in dispute resolution techniques in a course conducted by an alternative dispute resolution center or other dispute resolution organization approved by the city. 
(b)  The city may in its discretion appoint a person as a mediator who does not qualify under subsection 4-5006(a) if the city bases its appointment on legal or other professional training or experience in a particular dispute resolution process. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5007. - Standards and duties of mediator. 
(a)  A mediator appointed under this chapter shall encourage and assist the city and the aggrieved party in reaching a settlement of their dispute; however, the mediator may not compel or coerce the parties to enter into a settlement agreement. 
(b)  Unless expressly authorized by the disclosing party, the mediator may not disclose to either party information given in confidence by the other and shall at all times maintain confidentiality with respect to communications relating to the subject matter of the dispute. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5008. - Compensation of mediator. 
The city shall pay all fees associated with the services of a mediator appointed under sections 4-1012(b), 4-1070, section 4-1071(d) or section 4-1072 out of the general operating funds of the city. The city and the aggrieved third party shall each be responsible for the payment of one-half (½) of the fees associated with the services of any mediator appointed under section 4-5004(c) hereof. However, both employees and aggrieved third parties utilizing the mediation process as provided for herein shall be solely responsible for their own attorney fees, if any, incurred in relation thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5009. - Effect of written agreement. 
If, through the mediation process, the parties reach a settlement and execute a written agreement disposing of the dispute, the agreement is enforceable in the same manner as any other written agreement. However, notwithstanding the foregoing, no agreement reached in any mediation shall be enforceable against the city unless and except such agreement has been approved by duly authorized city officials in the same manner as is provided for in this Code for the approval of other binding agreements with the city. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5010. - Confidentiality of communications in mediation. 
(a)  Unless the parties agree otherwise, all matters, including the conduct and demeanor of the parties and their counsel during a mediation, are confidential and may never be disclosed to anyone. 
(b)  Any statement made during a mediation or early neutral evaluation conference whether before or after the institution of formal judicial proceedings, is confidential, not subject to disclosure, and may not be used as evidence in any subsequent administrative or judicial proceeding. 
(c)  Any document or other evidence generated in connection with a mediation or case evaluation or early neutral evaluation is not subject to discovery. An agreement resulting from a mediation or case evaluation or early neutral evaluation conference is not immune from discovery unless the parties agree in writing. Otherwise discoverable material is not rendered immune from discovery by use in a mediation or case evaluation or early neutral evaluation. 
(d)  Neither the neutral nor any observer present with permission of the parties in a mediation may be subpoenaed or otherwise required to testify concerning a mediation or case evaluation or early neutral evaluation conference in any subsequent administrative or judicial proceeding. A neutral's notes or records or records of the mediation program are not subject to discovery. 
(e)  In his or her opening statement, the neutral should discuss any limitation on confidentiality imposed by any statutory duty to report information. 
(f)  Observation by neutral-trainees with the consent of the parties does not breach the confidentiality of a mediation or case evaluation or early neutral evaluation conference. 
(g)  If this subsection conflicts with other legal requirements for disclosure of communications or materials, the issue of confidentiality may be presented to a court of competent jurisdiction of the proceedings to determine, in camera, whether the facts, circumstances and context of the communications or materials sought to be disclosed warrant a protective order of the court, or whether communications or materials are subject to disclosure. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5011. - Agreements reached in mediations. 
Notwithstanding any other provision contained herein to the contrary, any and all agreements reached in any mediation involving the city must ultimately be approved by duly authorized city officials before becoming binding on the city. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 4-5012. - Additional rules relating to mediation process. 
The city shall have the power to establish further rules applicable to the mediation process to further the established goals of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1181-94, § 3, 7-18-94) 
CHAPTER 6. - DOMESTIC PARTNERSHIP 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 4-6001. - Introduction. 
The City of East Point shall provide, with respect to the city programs and services, equal treatment to the residents of the city and employees of the city, to the extent allowed by the terms and procedures of such programs and services. 
(Ord. No. 005-05, § 1, 4-4-05) 
Sec. 4-6002. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(a)  Declaration of domestic partnership shall mean a form provided by the city business license office in which two (2) people agree to be jointly responsible for the necessities of life incurred during the domestic partnership and that all qualifications for domestic partnership are met when the declaration is signed. The form will require both partners to provide reasonable proof of their primary, regular and permanent residence address. The form must be signed under penalty of perjury and must be witnessed and notarized. The business license office shall, within thirty (30) days of the effective date of this ordinance, make such forms available. To help defray costs associated with the providing and filing of these forms, the business license office is authorized to charge a fee as set forth herein for each completed form. 
(b)  Domestic partnership shall mean two (2) adults who live together in the mutual interdependence of a single home and have signed a declaration of domestic partnership in which they attest that: 
(1)  They share the same primary, regular and permanent residence and have lived together for the previous twelve (12) months (documentation must be submitted verifying joint residency); 
(2)  They have a committed personal relationship with each other that is mutually interdependent and intended to be lifelong; 
(3)  They agree to be jointly obligated and responsible for the necessities of life for each other; 
(4)  They are not married to anyone or legally separated from anyone; 
(5)  They are eighteen (18) years of age or older; 
(6)  They are of the same gender; 
(7)  They are competent to enter into a contract; 
(8)  They are not related by blood closer than would bar marriage in the state; 
(9)  They are each other's sole domestic partner; 
(10)  They agree to file a termination of domestic partnership within thirty (30) days if any of the facts set out in this definition change; and 
(11)  Any prior domestic partnership in which their domestic partner participated with a third party was terminated not less than twelve (12) months prior to the date of such affidavit, and, if such earlier domestic partnership had been acknowledged under provisions of this section, that notice of termination of such earlier domestic partnership was provided to the city in writing to the business license division of the department of finance not less than twelve (12) months prior to the date of said affidavit. If the prior domestic partnership was terminated by the death of the partner, there shall be no waiting period. 
(c)  Live together shall mean that two (2) people claiming domestic partnership status share the same primary, regular and permanent residence. It is not necessary that the legal right to possess the residence be in both names. Domestic partners do not cease to live together if one leaves the shared residence for a period not to exceed one (1) year, but intends to return. Whether the relationship between these two people is or is not sexual is in no way relevant for the purposes of determining eligibility under this chapter. 
(d)  Necessities of life shall mean the cost of basic food, shelter, clothing and medical care. The individuals need not contribute equally or jointly to the cost of these expenses as long as they agree that both are responsible and obligated for the cost. 
(Ord. No. 005-05, § 1, 4-4-05) 
Sec. 4-6003. - Legal effect of declaration. 
(a)  Rights and duties created: 
(1)  Neither this chapter nor the filing of a declaration of domestic partnership shall create any legal rights or duties from one of the parties to the other, except those that specifically refer to domestic partnership. 
(2)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to explicitly or implicitly create a marital relationship. 
(3)  Nothing contained in this chapter shall create any rights in either domestic partner that are not covered, included or created in the underlying insurance or benefits plan documents of the city. 
(4)  This chapter does not attempt to alter or affect the laws in the state that regulate any private or civil relationships. 
(b)  Duration of rights and duties: Once a domestic partnership ends, the partners will incur no further obligations to each other under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 005-05, § 1, 4-4-05) 
Sec. 4-6004. - Establishment. 
(a)  Generally: Domestic partners who are residents of the city or who are employees of the city may establish the existence of their domestic partnership by presenting an original declaration of domestic partnership to the business license office of the city along with reasonable proof of residence such as, but not limited to, a driver's license, utility bill, or state I.D. card. The business license office will file the declaration and provide the partners with a certificate showing that the declaration was filed with the business license office. The standard declaration form will be available in the business license office during normal business hours. 
(b)  Limitations: The business office shall only accept for filing declarations of domestic partnership submitted by domestic partners who have residence in the city or who are employees of the city. 
(c)  Amendments to the declaration: A partner may amend a declaration of domestic partnership filed with the business license office at any time to show a change in such partner's primary residence address. 
(d)  New declarations of domestic partnership: No person who has created a domestic partnership may create another until twelve (12) months after a notice of termination has been signed and filed with the business license office; provided, however, that if the domestic partnership ended because of the death of the other party, a new declaration may be filed any time after the notice of termination has been filed. 
(e)  Evidence of domestic partnership: Any person who requires a person to provide evidence of the existence of a domestic partnership must accept the declaration of domestic partnership, but may choose not to require the declaration, as complete proof of the existence of a domestic partnership. The declaration of domestic partnership may be considered reasonable proof for qualifying for any present or future domestic, partner benefits that private corporations or public institutions offer. 
(Ord. No. 005-05, § 1, 4-4-05) 
Sec 4-6005. - Records, copies, filing fees. 
(a)  Records of the city's business office: The clerk at the city's business license office shall keep a record of all declarations of domestic partnerships, amendments to declarations of domestic partnership, and all notices of termination. The records shall be maintained so that amendments and notices of termination shall be filed with the declaration of domestic partnership to which they pertain. 
(b)  Filing fees: The business license office shall charge a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) for the filing of a declaration of domestic partnership and shall charge a fee of ($5.00) for providing certified copies of declarations, amendments or notices of termination. There will be no charge for the filing of amendments or notices of termination. 
(Ord. No. 005-05, § 1, 4-4-05) 
Sec. 4-6006. - Termination. 
(a)  Termination: A domestic partnership ends when: 
(1)  One partner sends the other partner written notice that such partner has ended the domestic partnership; 
(2)  One of the partners dies; or 
(3)  The partners no longer meet one or more of the qualifications or conditions for domestic partnership. 
(b)  Notice of termination: 
(1)  To domestic partners. When a domestic partnership ends, the partners must execute a notice of termination naming the partners and stating that the partnership has ended. The notice of termination must be dated and signed under penalty of perjury by at least one of the partners. The notice of termination must be filed with the business license office. 
(2)  To third parties. A domestic partner who has given a copy of a declaration of domestic partnership to any third party in order to qualify for any benefit or right must, whenever the domestic partnership ends, give that third party a copy of the notice of termination. If a partner has died, the surviving partner must give notice of termination to those third parties such partner knows were given copies of the declaration by the deceased partner in order to qualify for a benefit or right. The notice of termination must be sent to the parties identified in this section within sixty (60) days of the termination of the domestic partnership. 
(3)  Failure to give notice. Failure to give notice as required by this chapter will neither prevent nor delay termination of the domestic partnership. 
(4)  Termination by city. Notwithstanding any of the above, the city shall terminate a domestic partnership if the city finds that the partners no longer meet one or more of the qualifications or conditions for domestic partnership. The effective date of such termination will be retroactive to the date that such qualifications or conditions were no longer met. 
(Ord. No. 005-05, § 1, 4-4-05) 
Sec. 4-6007. - Enforcement. 
(a)  County or superior court: Any person may apply to the State Court of Fulton County or the Superior Court of Fulton County, or the appropriate courts for residents of city employees who live outside Fulton County, depending on jurisdictional requirements, to the extent allowed by such courts, for enforcement of the provisions of this article, in law or equity. 
(b)  Two-year limit: Any action to enforce this chapter must be commenced no later than two (2) years after the claimed violation. 
(Ord. No. 005-05, § 1, 4-4-05) 
Sec. 4-6008. - Disclaimer. 
Despite any other provision, nothing in this chapter shall require the city to provide insurance or benefits to resident domestic partners in which neither partner is an employee of the city. This provision shall supersede any conflicting language or provision. 
(Ord. No. 005-05, § 1, 4-4-05) 
Part 5 - FINANCE[1]
