CHAPTER 1. - TAXATION 
ARTICLE A. - PROPERTY TAX 

Sec. 5-1001. - Annual tax on real estate and tangible personal property. 
(a)  Generally. On January 1, each year there is hereby imposed upon all real estate, including buildings and improvements thereon in the city not exempt from taxation by law, which shall be assessed in accordance with the Charter, and also upon all tangible personal property held or owned by any person or otherwise, whether individually or as trustee, guardian, administrator, receiver, assignee, agent or otherwise, on the first day of January during the years in which this chapter is in force, and there is hereby levied a tax on every dollar of the taxable value thereof or less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) in value in proportion, for the respective years; and all persons who may have held or owned such property as above described on the first day of January during the years in which this chapter is in force shall, between the first day of January and the first day of April of such years make return to the department of administrative services of the city under oath of the full extent and amount of such real and personal property, and in default shall be subject to execution, levy, cost and penalties as provided in this Code and the City Charter applicable thereto. 
(b)  Annual tax on real estate and tangible personal property hereafter annexed. Within all areas annexed to the limits of the City of East Point after the effective date of this section, there shall be imposed upon all real estate, including buildings and improvements thereon in the newly annexed areas not exempt from taxation by law, which shall be assessed in accordance with the Charter and state law, and also upon all tangible personal property held or owned by any person or otherwise, whether individually or as trustee, guardian, administrator, receiver, assignee, agent or otherwise, on the first day of January in the years in which this section is in force, and there is hereby levied a tax on every dollar of the taxable value thereof or less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) in value in proportion, for the respective years according to the following classifications and percentages as hereinafter specified; and all persons who may have held or owned such property as above described on the first day of January during the years in which this section is in force shall, between the first day of January and the first day of April of such years, make return to the department of administrative services of the city under oath of the full extent and amount of such real and personal property, and in default shall be subject to execution, levy, cost and penalties as provided in this Code, the City Charter and state laws applicable thereto. 
(1)  Agricultural use and service tax district. 
a.  Defined. Agricultural use and service tax district shall be an area determined by the city council to fall within this category and shall be predominated, used and developed for agricultural purposes and the ancillary and necessary services in support thereof. Such agricultural uses shall include but not necessarily be limited to planting, cultivation and growth of forests for timber, pulpwood and other forest products, dairy and beef cattle farm operations, planting, cultivation and harvesting of row crops and including growth, cultivation and harvesting of hay. Use for the purposes of mining or quarrying of any type is excluded from agricultural use for the purposes of this section. The predominant determination of this category shall be that the use and any and all products derived from such areas shall be a product of the land and earth upon which it is situated. The ancillary and incidental uses thereto shall include residence of the owner or operator and living quarters of support personnel, together with structures used directly in support of the predominant agricultural use. Such area, because of its rural and predominant agricultural use, shall require minimal police and fire services. This classification shall be deemed to be abandoned when any additional development inconsistent with its predominant agricultural use is undertaken as may be evidenced by the request or furnishing of any of the following utility services, including but not limited to sewage collection system, water distribution system, storm drainage system or additional read [road] installation. Any application for rezoning other than for agricultural use shall be prima facie evidence of abandonment of the agricultural use and service tax district. 
b.  Tax schedule. 
1.  There shall be no ad valorem tax imposed by the City of East Point upon land classified in the agricultural use and service tax district for the tax year commencing January 1 following the annexation of such area. 
2.  Commencing January 1 of the second year after annexation of any area within this classification, there shall be imposed thereon an ad valorem tax as above stated equivalent to twenty-five (25) percent of the millage applicable to full service tax districts of the City of East Point. 
3.  Commencing January 1 of the third year after annexation of any area within this classification, there shall be imposed thereon an ad valorem tax as above stated equivalent to forty (40) percent of the millage applicable to full service tax districts of the City of East Point. 
4.  Commencing January 1 of the fourth year after annexation of any area within this classification, there shall be imposed thereon an ad valorem tax as above stated equivalent to fifty (50) percent of the millage applicable to full service tax districts of the City of East Point, and continuing at this level from year to year thereafter until termination of the agricultural use and service tax district. 
(2)  Developmental use and service tax district. 
(a)  Defined. Developmental use and service tax district shall be any area annexed to the City of East Point which has been or becomes transitional from a predominant rural and agricultural use to development for residential, commercial or industrial usage. For the purposes of determining developmental classification, it shall be conclusively presumed to be developmental unless already in use for residential, commercial or industrial use when there is filed an application for rezoning for other than agricultural use, or utility services of water distribution, sewage collection, storm sewer drainage or street improvements are permitted and installed upon such property. 
(b)  Tax schedule. 
1.  For developmental use and service tax districts so defined upon annexation, the ad valorem tax assessment on such property shall be zero percentage of the city millage for the first year commencing on January 1 after its annexation. 
2.  On January 1 after becoming classified as developmental use from agricultural use and service tax districts or the second year after annexation and so classified upon annexation, the ad valorem tax imposition against such property shall be fifty (50) percent of the millage imposed upon all full service tax districts of the city. 
3.  On January 1 of the second year after becoming classified as developmental use from agricultural use and service tax districts or the third year after annexation and so classified upon annexation, the ad valorem tax imposition against such property shall be seventy-five (75) percent of the millage imposed upon all full service tax districts of the city. 
4.  On January 1 of the third year after becoming classified as developmental use from agricultural use and service tax districts or the fourth year after annexation and so classified upon annexation, the ad valorem tax imposition against such property shall be one hundred (100) percent of the millage imposed upon all full service tax districts of the city. 
(3)  Full service tax district. 
(a)  Defined. [A full service tax district shall consist of] all other properties of the City of East Point except agricultural use and service tax districts and developmental use and service tax districts developed for residential, commercial or industrial usage. 
(b)  Tax schedule. On and after January 1 of the year after annexation, all property not meeting the two (2) preceding categories shall have imposed thereon one hundred (100) percent of the citywide tax millage. 
(Code 1959, § 20-2; Ord. No. 689-78, § 1, 9-18-78) 
Sec. 5-1002. - Failure to file returns. 
If any person fails, refuses or for any reason neglects to make or file a tax return covering real estate or personal property subject to taxation under the Charter and ordinances of the city, or to truly answer such questions as may be asked or propounded, or to submit or reveal such property for inspection and valuation, or to furnish a full disclosure by the production of records, policies, balance sheets or otherwise as requested, then, in that event, it shall be the duty of the director of finance, from the best information in hand in reference to the property in question and the value thereof, to fix a value by assessment and place the same on the tax records. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1003. - False returns. 
(a)  In case of false, fraudulent, incomplete or inadequate tax returns, the director of finance shall, in his discretion, cite the person or taxpayer making the return to appear before him on a day specified and show cause why the return filed should not be corrected. 
(b)  Upon any such person, taxpayer or representative, as mentioned in the preceding paragraph, appearing before the director of finance, he may hear evidence as to the value of the real or personal property in dispute and after the hearing determine the same. If any person so cited refuses, neglects or fails to appear, or fails or refuses, upon request of the director of finance, to submit full and complete information, records, balance sheets, policies or otherwise, or fails to submit the property in question for inspection, if so requested, it shall be the duty of the director of finance then, after such a hearing, according to the best information in his possession, to fix a valuation by assessment, and place the same on the records in the office of the director of finance. The director of finance shall have full authority to request or require full disclosure and information in the form requested as to the property in dispute, and it shall be the duty of the taxpayer to submit the records, information or property on request of the director of finance. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1004. - Form for tax returns. 
The forms used for filing tax returns shall be prescribed by the director of finance and such forms are hereby adopted as the legal form for use in the receiving of tax returns by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1005. - Same to be on file in the office of the director of finance. 
All forms referred to in section 5-1004 and blanks thereof shall be kept on file in the office of the department of administrative services. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1006. - Procedure as to property not returned for taxation. 
In the event any owner of property subject to taxation in the city fails to make a return as herein provided, it shall be the duty of the director of finance to nevertheless assess the unreturned property for taxation as provided in this chapter. The owner of the unreturned property shall be notified of the assessment as fixed by the director of finance and the notice shall be mailed to the last known address of the owner as appears on the tax records of the city. In the event that the owner of any unreturned property shall be unknown, and the director of finance is unable to ascertain who the owner is, the property shall nevertheless be duly assessed and returned by the director of finance in the same manner as other property is asinglessessed, except that it shall be returned as "owner unknown." 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1007. - Appeals from assessed valuations; generally. 
(a)  Any taxpayer feeling aggrieved at the assessment of his real or personal property may file a petition with the mayor and council setting forth, under oath, all the property, real and personal, owned by the taxpayer and subject to taxation by the city, at its true market value as well as giving the assessment thereon by the director of finance, whereupon the mayor and council shall have a hearing thereon, after giving notice of the time and place of the hearing to the petitioner as well as to the director of finance. At the same time and place, the mayor and council shall investigate all the facts relating to the taxpayer's return, and after the investigation, shall order the same reduced, raised or approved as they may find to be just, fair and reasonable and these findings shall thereupon be held final for the year for which the assessments were made. At such hearings the mayor and council may require the production of books, papers or records necessary for a full investigation. They shall also have power and authority to issue subpoena duces tecum to any taxpayer, requiring production of all his books, papers, policies, etc., in order that the true values may be ascertained. 
(b)  On the hearing of an appeal by a taxpayer against the assessment of his property by the director of finance the mayor and council, acting through the chairman, may issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of any person on the hearing of the appeal and may at the hearing swear them as witnesses and secure from them all facts of which the witnesses may have knowledge. 
(c)  Any person subpoenaed before the mayor and council or director of finance, either to appear in person or to bring documents, who refuses to attend as required by the subpoena or who afterwards declines to answer questions pertinent to the issue or who declines to produce the documents or paper required by the subpoena duces tecum, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1008. - Same—Time of filing. 
All requests or appeals to the director of finance or to the mayor and council, for a review or revision of assessed valuations against real or personal property, must be filed in writing with full details, as required by law, between January 1 and April 1 during the year for which the tax is levied. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1009. - Same—Form. 
The form prescribed by the city council addressed to the mayor and council and headed "appeal on assessed valuation of property," is hereby adopted for filing of appeals with the mayor and council on property valuations, and it shall be the duty of the taxpayer or property owner filing the appeal to furnish the information called for on the form together with any other information deemed relevant by the director of finance or the mayor and council in the proper consideration of the appeal, and the appeal shall be signed and sworn to by the taxpayer or property owner. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1010. - Executions; advertisement and sale of property thereunder; disposition of proceeds of sale. 
(a)  Executions shall be issued by the director of finance on the 20th of December in each year against the property and the owners thereof for the amount of all unpaid taxes due, the interest thereon, and the cost for the issuance of the execution, which execution shall be directed to and levied by the city marshal upon the property of the person against whom issued and the property shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder, on the first Tuesday in any month, within the legal hours of sale, 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.; provided, the time and place of sale shall first be advertised once a week for four (4) weeks in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city. The proceeds arising from the sale shall be applied first to the payment of taxes due, including the interest, costs and expenses of sale, and any surplus remaining shall be paid to the owner of the property; provided, that the city may buy any property sold under and by virtue of the tax executions. 
(b)  Whenever any fi. fa. shall issue against any person of the city or any person who shall have property within the corporate limits of the city, subject to taxation, it shall be the duty of the city marshal forthwith to levy the same upon the property of the defendant or a sufficiency thereof to satisfy the fi. fa. and costs. 
(c)  All ad valorem tax executions in favor of the city shall be enforced by levy and sale, when not otherwise paid, in the following manner: The execution by the director of finance shall be levied upon the property as in the discretion of the levying officer may be suitable and available for such purposes, and the same shall be advertised once a week for four (4) weeks next preceding the date of sale in the official organ of the city; and such sales shall be had on the first Tuesday of each month before the door of the city hall, or the usual meeting place of the city council, between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., and the same shall be conducted by the city marshal. All property shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92; Ord. No. 1062-93, § 2, 9-20-93) 
Sec. 5-1011. - Levy and sale under tax executions other than ad valorem tax executions. 
(a)  All assessments other than ad valorem tax executions, in favor of the city shall be enforced by levy and sale, when not otherwise paid, in the manner described in paragraph (b) below. 
(b)  The execution shall be by the marshal or deputy marshal levied upon such property as in the discretion of the levying officer may be suitable and available for such purposes, and the same shall be advertised once a week for four (4) weeks next preceding the date of sale in the official organ of the city; and such sales shall be had on the first Tuesday of each month before the door of the city hall, or the usual meeting place of the authorities of the city having control of the municipality, between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., and the same shall be conducted by the marshal or deputy marshal of the city. All property shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash. 
(Code 1959, § 20-15) 
Sec. 5-1012. - Judicial in rem tax. 
Article 5 of Chapter 4 of Title 48 of the Official Georgia Code Annotated as adopted by the Georgia Legislature in 1995, as amended, is adopted. 
(Ord. No. 024-01, § 1, 10-19-01) 
Sec. 5-1013. - Same—Service of notices. 
When tax executions are levied upon real estate, notice of sale shall be given to the tenant in possession of the property levied upon, if the same is occupied, and if the real estate be vacant property, the notice shall be served upon the owner of the property, if resident in the city, personally, or by leaving same at his most notorious place of abode. If the property is vacant and the owner is not a resident of the city, then notice of the levy shall be mailed to him at his last known address; the notice to be given at least sixty (60) days before the date of the sale. 
(Code 1959, § 20-17) 
Sec. 5-1014. - Same—Levying officer's records. 
(a)  The levying officer shall keep a register of all sales of real estate in a book provided by him for that purpose, in which he shall enter each tract, lot or parcel of land exposed to sale, the quantity sold and the amount of taxes and costs for which the same was sold and the purchaser's name, leaving at the end of each line three (3) columns in blank, leaving a sufficient space to insert the name of the person who may redeem the tract, lot or parcel of land, the date of redemption and the amount of redemption money paid, which book shall be kept in a neat and legible manner, and shall always be open for the inspection of any and all persons interested and who shall apply to the levying officer for an examination of the same. 
(b)  The levying officer shall also: 
(1)  Keep a file of all newspaper in which his official advertisements appear; 
(2)  Keep an execution docket in which he shall enter a full description of all executions levied by him on any kind of property, showing what property levied on, the date of levy and the service of notice, together with all his acts and doings thereon; 
(3)  Keep a book in which shall be entered a record of all sales made by him, describing the property and the process under which sold, the date of the levy and sale, the name of the purchaser and the price; and 
(4)  Keep the book indexed for each entry thereon. 
(Code 1959, § 20-18) 
Sec. 5-1015. - Same—Purchase for city of property sold for taxes; authority of director of finance. 
The director of finance may act for the city in bidding the amount of tax and costs on property sold for taxes where no one else bids that amount. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1016. - Records; deeds, etc., to be filed. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the director of finance to keep a record of all property purchased by the city at tax sales, showing whose property was so purchased, the amount bid for it by the party bidding from the city, and what portion of it was tax and what portion was costs and expenses of advertising, respectively. 
(b)  He shall also file and carefully keep in his office the deed to the city made by the levying officer, and the execution under which the land was sold or attached, which shall be delivered to him by the levying officer and a copy of the newspapers in which any such sale at which the city purchased was advertised. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1017. - Sale of property bought by city; authorization by mayor and council; reports and deeds. 
No property purchased on behalf of the city at city tax sales shall be sold, unless and until the same shall have been specially authorized by the mayor and council. It shall be the duty of the marshal conducting the sales to report the same to the mayor and council at the next regular meeting thereof. Deeds to property sold by the city at such sales at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash shall be signed on behalf of the city by the mayor thereof, after, but not before, the sales shall have been reported to the mayor and council and the report entered on the minutes of the council. 
Sec. 5-1018. - Same—Minimum sale price. 
No property purchased on behalf of the city for city taxes shall be sold, even to the highest bidder when the highest bid is less than the amount due the city for taxes, interest and cost on account of which the property was originally purchased by the city, except by special order of the mayor and council. 
Sec. 5-1019. - Same—Collection and disposition of proceeds; rejection of bids by city. 
All reports by the marshal of the city, of sales of property purchased by the city at city tax sales shall be accompanied by the proceeds from the sale of the property and it is hereby made the duty of the marshal to collect from the purchaser of the property prior to the regular meeting of the council next after date of the public sales; provided, further, the city reserves the right to refuse or reject any bid and refund the money of any purchaser up to but not after execution and delivery of the deed. 
Sec. 5-1020. - Same—Resale after termination of redemption period; procedure. 
(a)  Property purchased by the city at tax sales for city taxes, and which has been held by the city for one (1) year, under deed made in pursuance of the sale, shall be sold and disposed of by the city as follows: The director of finance shall present to the mayor and council at any regular or called meeting thereof a full description list of all property so purchased by the city and which has been so held by the city for one (1) year, and showing that proper steps have been taken foreclosing the former owner's right of redemption. 
(b)  The mayor and council may then by resolution direct a sale of all or such portion of the property as in their judgment should be sold. Such direction being given, it shall be the duty of the marshal to advertise the property for sale and to have notice of the same served on the owner, agent or tenant in possession; or in case of vacant property upon which there resides no tenant, notice shall be given by posting the notice thereon and a return of the service of whatever notice is given shall be made by the marshal or party giving the notice. 
(c)  The marshal shall sell or have sold the property to the highest bidder for cash, and each piece of the real property shall be sold separately. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1021. - Same—Purchaser's deed; failure to comply with bid. 
Purchasers at a sale described in section 5-1020 shall receive from the city a quitclaim deed, to be executed by the mayor upon the payment of the purchase money to the director of finance. In case of failure to comply with the bids, the city shall have the same alternatives and remedies as prescribed by the laws of this state in cases of sheriff's sales. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1022. - Same—Execution of bill of sale for personal property. 
The officer making a sale of personality at a sale described in section 5-1020 shall execute to the purchaser in cases of sales of personality, a bill of sale to same in the usual manner of the execution of deeds and bills of sales by sheriffs under similar circumstances. 
(Code 1959, § 20-26) 
Sec. 5-1023. - Release of tax and lien upon purchase of part of property covered by fi. fa. 
It shall be lawful to release a parcel of land from the tax and lien under a tax fi. fa. issued by the city, when the parcel is the subject matter of a purchase, which purchase does not include all of the property embraced within the tax fi. fa., but embraces the parcels released from the lien and tax, upon request of the purchaser and payment of the tax against the parcel sought to be released. The release shall be executed in such manner and form as may be prescribed by the mayor and council. 
Sec. 5-1024. - Forms—Writ of fieri facias, execution. 
A form of the writ of fieri facias, execution, which shall be used for the collection of delinquent city taxes shall be as follows: 
"State of Georgia, Fulton County, City of East Point. 
To the Chief of Police, City Marshal, and police officers of the City of East Point and to all and singular the sheriffs and constables of this state—Greetings: 
You are hereby required that of the goods and chattels, lands and tenements of ___________ you cause to be made by levy and sale sufficient thereof to make the sum of _______ city taxes for the year 19___; also, the further sum of twenty dollars ($20.00) for this fi. fa. and a sufficient amount to cover interest on the said principal at the rate of one (1) percent per month, from ________, 19___, until settled together with all costs that may hereafter accrue; and have you the said sums of money before the City Council of East Point at its first regular meeting after the expiration of 90 days after the issuing of this writ of fi. fa. in payment of said tax and cost; and you have then and there this writ of fi. fa. 
WITNESS the Honorable _____ _______, Mayor of said city, this the ___ day of ________, 19___. 
Given under my hand and official signature, this ___ day of ________, 19___. 
_____ (L.S.) City Clerk, City of East Point" 
(Code 1959, § 20-28; Ord. No. 999-90, § 1, 1-2-90; Ord. No. 1059-93, § 1, 8-16-93) 
Sec. 5-1025. - Same—Entry of levy of tax fi. fa. 
The entry of levy of the tax fi. fa. shall be in the following form: 
"Georgia, Fulton County, City of East Point. 
Levied the within fi. fa. on the following described property, to-wit: A certain lot in the City of East Point in Land Lot _______ in the 14th District of Fulton County, Georgia, fronting _____ feet on the _____ side of _____ Street between _____ and _____ Street, and running back _____ feet, more or less, in a _____ direction, the house on said lot being known as No. _____ on said street according to the present numbering of streets in said city, the same being _____ property in the City of East Point adjoining property now or formerly owned by ___________, levied on as the property of _____ to satisfy a fi. fa. in favor of the City of East Point and against said lot and against said ___________ for city taxes for the year 19___. 
Served this ___ day of ________, 19___. 
_____ Marshal, by 
_____ Deputy Marshal" 
(Code 1959, § 20-29) 
Sec. 5-1026. - Same—Transfer or assignment of tax fi. fa. 
The form of transfer or assignment of tax fi. fa. shall be as follows: 
"Georgia, Fulton County, City of East Point. 
For and in consideration of the sum of $_____, the tax, cost and interest due on the within fi. fa. I hereby transfer and assign same to ___________. 
This ___ day of ________, 19___. 
_____ Chief of Police, Marshal" 
(Code 1959, § 20-30)

(Code 1959, § 20-31; Ord. No. 1059-93, § 1, 8-16-93) 
Sec. 5-1028. - Same—Tax deeds. 
The city marshal in conveying property sold for city taxes shall use such forms for tax deeds as he or she deems appropriate from time to time. 
(Code 1959, § 20-32; Ord. No. 764-81, § 1, 11-30-81) 
Sec. 5-1029. - Homestead exemptions. 
(a)  Any resident of the City of East Point who is seventy (70) years of age or over or disabled is granted an exemption from all ad valorem taxes levied for city government purposes, including ad valorem taxes levied to pay interest on and retire bonded indebtedness of the city government, for the full value of the homestead owned and occupied by such resident if such resident's adjusted gross income, together with the adjusted gross income of the resident's spouse who also resides at such homestead, does not exceed the maximum amount which may be received by an individual and an individual's spouse under the Federal Social Security Act. As used in this subsection, the term "adjusted gross income" shall have the same meaning as defined in the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1986, except that for the purposes of this subsection, the term shall include only that portion of income or benefits received as retirement, survivor, or disability benefits under the Federal Social Security Act or under any other public or private retirement, disability, or pension system which exceeds the maximum amount which may be received by an individual and an individual's spouse under the Federal Social Security Act. The homestead exemption provided for in this section shall not apply to any state or county ad valorem taxes or to any ad valorem taxes levied for the Fulton County School District. 
(b)  In order to qualify for the exemption provided for in subsection (a) of this section as being disabled, the person claiming such exemption shall be required to obtain a certificate from not less than three (3) physicians licensed to practice medicine under state law relative to medical practitioners, as now or hereafter amended, certifying that in the opinion of such physician or physicians such person is mentally or physically incapacitated to the extent that such person is unable to be gainfully employed and that such incapacity is likely to be permanent. 
(c)  A person shall not receive the homestead exemption granted by subsection (a) of this section unless the person or person's agent files an affidavit with the tax commissioner of the City of East Point giving the persons age, or if disabled, the certificate or certificates required by subsection (b) of this section, and the amount of income which the person and the person's spouse received during the last taxable year for income tax purposes, and such additional information relative to receiving such exemption as will enable the tax commissioner to make a determination as to whether such owner is entitled to such exemption. The tax commissioner shall provide affidavit forms for this purpose. 
(d)  After a person has filed the proper affidavit and certificate or certificates, if disabled, as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, it shall not be necessary to make application and file the said affidavit and certificate thereafter for any year and the exemption shall continue to be allowed to such person. It shall be the duty of any such person, however, to notify the tax commissioner in the event such person becomes ineligible for any reason to receive the homestead exemption granted by this section. 
(e)  The homestead exemption granted by this section shall be cumulative of any other homestead exemption applicable to City of East Point ad valorem taxes. The homestead exemption granted by this section shall apply to all taxable years beginning after December 31, 1989. 
(Ord. No. 987-89, § 1, 6-19-89) 
Sec. 5-1030. - Late charge for payment of bills. 
The director of finance of this city is hereby required to charge a minimum charge of one dollar ($1.00) on any and all bills paid after the fifteenth of October of each year. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1031. - Costs in issuing and enforcing fi. fas. 
The fees to be charged in connection with fi. fas. for taxes, shall be as fixed by council from time to time. 
Sec. 5-1032. - Chief of police to serve as city marshal; deputy marshals. 
(a)  The chief of police shall serve as the city marshal and shall exercise such powers of the office of city marshal as are authorized under the charter and ordinances of the city. 
(b)  The chief of police is authorized to appoint as deputy city marshals any officers employed in the police department. 
(c)  The director of finance shall serve as ex officio deputy city marshal, and shall perform such levy and sale duties as are assigned by the city marshal. 
(Ord. No. 1063-93, § 1, 9-20-93) 
Sec. 5-1033. - Installment agreements for delinquent taxes. 
(a)  The director of finance is authorized to enter into installment arrangements for periods not exceeding twenty-four (24) months for the collection of ad valorem taxes which are delinquent not less than twelve (12) months when, in the opinion of the director, such arrangement is in the best interests of the city. No installment arrangement shall cancel any interest or penalty authorized by law. 
(b)  Upon the occurrence of default by the property owner of any installment arrangement not cured to the satisfaction of the director of finance the subject property shall be sold as provided under section 5-1010 of this article within ninety (90) days of the date of default. 
(Ord. No. 1102-95, § 1, 4-23-95) 
Secs. 5-1034—5-1050. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - HOTEL AND MOTEL TAX 

Sec. 5-1051. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases shall, for the purposes of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, be defined as follows: 
(1)  Director of finance. The director of finance of the City of East Point. 
(2)  Designated official. The director of finance of the City of East Point or such other city official as may from time to time be designated. 
(3)  Guest room. A room or series of rooms occupied or intended to be occupied, designed or arranged as temporary, short-term accommodations for living or residential purposes. 
(4)  Hotel. Any structure or any portion of a structure, including any lodging house, rooming house, dormitory, turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto court, inn, public club or private club, containing guest rooms and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy, by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. It does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention or other buildings in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. 
(5)  Monthly period. The calendar months of any year. 
(6)  Occupancy. The use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or apartment in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. 
(7)  Occupant. Any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. 
(8)  Operator. Any person operating a hotel in the City of East Point, Georgia, including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessees, sublessees, lender in possession, licensee or any other person otherwise operating such hotel. 
(9)  Permanent resident. Any individual, who, as of a given date, has or shall have occupied or has occupied any guest room in a hotel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days next preceding such date. 
(10)  Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, joint adventure, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States of America, the State of Georgia, and any political subdivision of either upon which the city is without power to impose the tax herein provided. 
(11)  Rent. The consideration received for occupancy valued in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
(12)  Return. Any return filed or required to be filed as herein provided. 
(13)  Tax. The tax imposed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92; Ord. No. 067-016 , § 1, 12-19-16) 
Sec. 5-1052. - Tax rate imposed. 
(a)  There is levied and assessed, and there shall be paid an excise tax of eight (8) pe cent of the rent for the furnishing for value to the public of any hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly or periodically furnished for value. 
(b)  There is adopted herewith the following budget plan for the City of East Point for expending the proceeds of the tax imposed in subsection (a). 
(Code 1959, § 20-47; Ord. No. 003-11, § 1, 4-18-11) 
Editor's note— The budget plan adopted by Ord. No. 003-11, § 1, adopted April 18, 2011 is not set out herein but is available at the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 5-1053. - Collection of tax by operator; receipt to occupant; rules for collection schedules. 
Every operator maintaining a place of business in this city, as provided in the next preceding section, and renting guest rooms in this city, not exempted under section 5-1054 of this article shall, at the time of collecting the rent from the occupant and on demand, give to the occupant a receipt therefor. In all cases of transactions upon credit or deferred payment, the payment of tax to the operator may be deferred in accordance therewith, and the operator shall be liable therefor at the time and to the extent that such credits are incurred in accordance with the rate of tax owing on the amount thereof. The designated official shall have the power to adopt rules and regulations prescribing methods and schedules for the collection and payment of the tax. 
(Code 1959, § 20-48) 
Sec. 5-1054. - Exemptions. 
No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a permanent resident. 
(Code 1959, § 20-49) 
Sec. 5-1055. - Registration of operator; form and contents; certificate of authority. 
(a)  Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in this city shall immediately register with the designated official of this city, on a form provided by the designated official. Persons engaged in such business must so register not later than thirty (30) days after the date this article becomes effective and the tax is imposed as set forth in section 5-1052, but such privilege of registration after the imposition of such tax shall not relieve any person from the obligation of payment or collection of tax on and after the date of imposition thereof, regardless of registration. 
(b)  Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place or places of business and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the designated official may require. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; in the case of ownership by a corporation, by an executive officer or some person specifically authorized by the corporation to sign the registration. The designated official of the city, shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each operator to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. Each certificate shall state name and location of the business to which it is applicable and shall be prominently displayed therein so as to be seen and to come readily to the notice of all occupants and persons seeking occupancy. Such certificates shall be nonassignable and nontransferable and shall be returned immediately to the designated official of the city upon the cessation of business at the location named, or upon sale or transfer of such business at that location. 
(c)  Should the designated official of the city deem it necessary, in order to facilitate initial registration hereunder of persons engaged in business, or prior to the date of imposition of tax as set forth in this article, he may prescribe administrative provisions therefor, other than those provided in this section. Such provisions shall be made to effect the purposes hereof. 
(Code 1959, § 20-50) 
Sec. 5-1056. - Determination, returns and payments. 
(a)  Due date of taxes. The tax imposed by this article shall be collected from the occupant at the time of occupancy of any hotel in this city. 
(b)  Return; time of filing; persons required to file; execution. On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the designated official of the city, in such form as the designated official may prescribe, by every operator, liable for the payment of tax hereunder. 
(c)  Contents of return. All returns shall show the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the designated official of the city. 
(d)  Delivery of return and remittance. The person required to file the return shall deliver the return, together with the remittance of the net amount of tax due to the designated official of this city at the East Point City Hall, East Point, Georgia 30344. 
(Code 1959, § 20-51) 
Sec. 5-1057. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax. If the designated official of this city is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One (1) or more than one (1) deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one (1) or more than one (1) monthly period. 
(b)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the determination, shall bear interest at the rate of 0.542 percent per month, or fraction thereof from the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(c)  Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination, the designated official of the city may offset overpayment, for a period or periods, against underpayments, for another period or periods, against penalties, and against the interest on underpayments. The interest on underpayments shall be computed in the manner set forth in section 5-1058. 
(d)  Notice of designated official. The designated official of the city, or his designated representative, shall give to the operator written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the designated official of the city. In case of service by mail of any notice required by this article, the service is complete at the time of deposit in the United States Post Office. 
(e)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three (3) years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three (3) years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(Code 1959, § 20-52; Ord. No. 067-016 , § 1, 12-19-16) 
Sec. 5-1058. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any person fails to make a return, the designated official of the city shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the person, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals in this city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the person failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the designated official of the city. Upon the basis of this estimate, the designated official shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to five (5) percent after 120 days with an additional five (5) percent assessed after each successive 120 days to a maximum of twenty (20) percent of the principle amount due. One (1) or more determinations may be made for one (1) or for more than one (1) period. 
(b)  Manner of computation; offsets; interest. In making a determination, the designated official of the city may offset overpayments against penalties or the interest on the underpayments. The interest on underpayments shall be computed in the manner set forth in subsection (c) herein. 
(c)  Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of 0.542 percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period, for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. 
(d)  Giving of notice; manner of service. Promptly after making his determination, the designated official shall give to the person written notice to be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. 
(Code 1959, § 20-53; Ord. No. 067-016 , § 1, 12-19-16) 
Sec. 5-1059. - Collection of tax. 
(a)  Action for tax; time for. At any time within three (3) years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected becomes due and payable and at any time within three (3) years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the designated official of the city may bring an action in the courts of this state, of any other state, or of the United States in the name of the city to collect the amount delinquent together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount under this article sells his business or quits the business, his successors or assignee shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the designated official of the city showing that he has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  Liability for failure to withhold; certificate of notice of amount due; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold purchase price as required, he becomes personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. Within thirty (30) days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the designated official of the city shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his address as it appears on the records of the designated official of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall start to run at the time the operator sells out his business or at the time that the determination against the operator becomes final, whichever event occurs the later. 
(d)  Tax credit, penalty or interest paid more than once or erroneously or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city under this article, it may be offset as provided in section 5-1057. If the operator or person determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the designated official of the city, he will have three (3) years from date of payment to file claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the designated official of the city, the excess amount paid the city may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from, the person by whom it was paid, or his administrators or executors. 
(e)  Issuance of fi. fa. The director of finance is hereby authorized under this section to issue a fi. fa. for execution and levy to satisfy the amount of tax due but not paid under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1959, § 20-54; Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Sec. 5-1060. - Administration of article. 
(a)  Authority of designated official (director of finance). The designated official shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this article. 
(b)  Rules and regulations. The designated official of the city shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with the ordinance or other laws of the City of East Point and the State of Georgia, or the constitution of this state or the United States for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the taxes hereunder. 
(c)  Records required from operators; form. Every operator renting guest rooms in this city to a person shall keep such records, receipts, invoices, and other pertinent papers in such form as the designated official of the city may require. 
(d)  Examination of records; audits. The designated official of the city, or any person authorized in writing by the designated official may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator renting guest rooms to a person and any operator liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(e)  Authority to require reports; contents. In administration of the provisions of this article, the designated official of the city may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in such person's or persons' possession or custody information relating to rentals of guest rooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the designated official when required by the designated official and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the date or dates of occupancy, and such other information as the designated official may require. 
(f)  Disclosure of business of operators, etc.; limitation on rule. The designated official of the city or any person having an administrative duty under this article shall not make known in any manner the business affairs, operations, or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator or any other person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty, or the amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures, or any particular thereof, set forth or disclosed in any return, or to permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having such administrative duty under this article, except in case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the tax hereby levied and assessed. Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees and guarantors, if directly interested, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax required to be collected, interest and penalties. 
(Code 1959, § 20-55; Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 7-20-92) 
Secs. 5-1061—5-1070. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - CHARGE ON PREPAID WIRELESS SERVICE AT POINT OF SALE 

Sec. 5-1071. - Charge imposed. 
(a)  9-1-1 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2, there is hereby imposed a prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charge as defined by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(a)(4) upon every prepaid wireless retail transaction occurring within the jurisdiction of the public service answering point in the amount of seventy-five cents ($0.75). 
(b)  Collection of 9-1-1 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. Prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charges collected by sellers shall be remitted to the Commissioner of the Department of Revenue at the times and in the manner provided by Chapter 8 of Title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated with respect to the sales and use tax imposed on prepaid wireless calling service. 
(d)  Depositing of funds; use of funds. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(j)(5), funds received by this city from charges imposed by this section shall be deposited in the Emergency Telephone System Fund maintained by this city pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134(d)(2) and kept separate from general revenue of the jurisdiction. All such funds shall be used exclusively for the purposes authorized by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134(f). 
(Ord. No. 027-11, §§ 1, 2, 4, 11-21-11) 
Secs. 5-1072—5-1080. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - RENTAL MOTOR VEHICLE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Nonamendatory Ord. No. 1143-97, §§ 1—12, adopted Jan. 6, 1997 is included herein as Chapter 1, Article D at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 5-1081. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms, and phrases shall, for the purposes of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, be defined as follows:] 
(a)  Rental charge means the total value received by a rental motor vehicle concern for the rental or lease for thirty-one (31) or fewer consecutive days of a rental motor vehicle, including the total cash and nonmonetary consideration for the rental or lease including, but not limited to, charges based on time or mileage and charges for insurance coverage or collision damage waiver but excluding all charges for motor fuel taxes or sales taxes. 
(b)  Rental-motor vehicle means a motor vehicle designed to carry ten (10) or fewer passengers and used primarily for the transportation of persons that is rented or leased without a driver regardless of whether such vehicle is licensed in this state. 
(c)  Rental motor vehicle concern means a person or legal entity which owns or leases five (5) or more rental motor vehicles and which regularly rents or leases such vehicles to the public for value. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 1, 1-6-97) 
Sec. 5-1082. - Levy of tax. 
There is hereby imposed and levied a tax of three (3) percent upon the rental charge collected by a rental motor vehicle concern when such charge constitutes a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under Article 1 of Chapter 8 of Title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. The tax is imposed only at the time when and place within the city where a customer pays sales tax with respect to the rental charge. The customer who pays a rental charge that is subject to the tax levied by this article shall be liable for the tax. The tax shall be paid by the customer to the rental motor vehicle concern. The tax shall be a debt of the customer to the rental motor vehicle concern until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery of other debts. The rental motor vehicle concern collecting the tax shall remit the tax to the city, and the tax remitted shall be a credit against the tax imposed on the rental motor vehicle concern. Every rental motor vehicle concern subject to tax shall be liable for the tax at the applicable rate on the charges actually collected or the amount of tax collected from customers whichever is greater. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 2, 1-6-97) 
Sec. 5-1083. - Exemption. 
No tax shall be imposed under this article on the rental charge associated with the rental or lease of a rental motor vehicle if either: 
(1)  The customer picks up the rental motor vehicle outside this state and returns it in this state; or 
(2)  The customer picks up the rental motor vehicle in this state and returns it outside this state. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 3, 1-6-97) 
Sec. 5-1084. - Registration; form and contents; certificate of authority. 
(a)  Every person engaging or about to engage in business as a rental motor vehicle concern in this city shall immediately register with the designated official of this city, on a form provided by the designated official. Persons engaged in such business must so register not later than thirty (30) days after the date this article becomes effective and the tax is imposed as set forth in this article but such privilege of registration after the imposition of such tax shall not relieve any person from the obligation of payment or collection of tax on and after the date of imposition thereof, regardless of registration. 
(b)  Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place or places of business and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the designated official may require. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; in the case of ownership by a corporation, by an executive officer or some person specifically authorized by the corporation to sign the registration. The designated official of the city, shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each operator to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of a rental motor vehicle concern. Each certificate shall state name and location of the business to which it is applicable and shall be prominently displayed therein so as to be seen and to come readily to the notice of all customers. Such certificates shall be nonassignable and nontransferable and shall be returned immediately to the designated official of the city upon the cessation of business at the location named, or upon sale or transfer of such business at that location. 
(c)  Should the designated official of the city deem it necessary, in order to facilitate initial registration hereunder of persons engaged in business, or prior to the date of imposition of tax as set forth in this article, he may prescribe administrative provisions therefor, other than those provided in this section. Such provisions shall be made to effect the purposes hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 4, 1-6-97) 
Sec. 5-1085. - Procedure; compensation. 
(a)  Return; time of filing. On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the designated official of the city, in such form as the designated official may prescribe, by every rental motor vehicle concern liable for the payment of tax hereunder. 
(b)  Contents of return. All returns shall show the gross rental charges, exempt rental charges, taxable rental charges, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the designated official of the city. 
(c)  Delivery of return and remittance. The concern required to file the return shall deliver the return, together with the remittance of the net amount of tax due, to the designated official of the city. 
(d)  Compensation. Concerns collecting the tax shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in the submitting, reporting, and paying the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of deduction shall be three (3) percent of the tax due. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 5, 1-6-97) 
Sec. 5-1086. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax. If the designated official of this city is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One (1) or more than one (1) deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one (1) or more than one (1) monthly period. 
(b)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of 0.542 percent per month, or fraction thereof from the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(c)  Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination, the designated official of the city may offset overpayment, for a period or periods, against underpayments, for another period or periods, against penalties, and against the interest on underpayments. The interest on underpayments shall be computed in the manner set forth in section 5-1087(c) below. 
(d)  Notice of designated official. The designated official of the city, or his designated representative, shall give to the rental motor vehicle concern written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail such service shall be addressed to the rental motor vehicle concern at its address as it appears in the records of the designated official of the city. In case of service by mail of any notice required by this article, the service is complete at the time of deposit in the United States Post Office. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 6, 1-6-97; Ord. No. 067-016 , § 2, 12-19-16) 
Sec. 5-1087. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross rental charges. If any person fails to make a return, the designated official of the city shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross rental charges in this city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the person failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the designated official of the city. Upon the basis of this estimate, the designated official shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty of five (5) percent after 120 days with an additional five (5) percent assessed after each successive 120 days to a maximum of twenty (20) percent of the principle amount due. One (1) or more determinations may be made for one (1) or for more than one (1) period. 
(b)  Manner of computation; offsets; interest. In making a determination, the designated official of the city may offset overpayments against penalties or the interest on the underpayments. The interest on the underpayments shall be computed in the manner set forth in subsection (c) herein. 
(c)  Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of 0.542 percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period, for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. 
(d)  Giving of notice; manner of service. Promptly after making his determination, the designated official shall give to the person written notice to be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 7, 1-6-97; Ord. No. 067-016 , § 2, 12-19-16) 
Sec. 5-1088. - Collection of tax. 
(a)  Action for tax; time for. At any time within three (3) years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected becomes due and payable and at any time within three (3) years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the designated official of the city may bring an action in the courts of this state, of any other state, or of the United States in the name of the city to collect the amount delinquent together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  Duty of successors or assignees of rental motor vehicle concern to withhold tax from purchase money. If any person liable for any amount under this article sells his business or quits the business, his successors or assignee shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the designated official of the city showing that he has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  Liability for failure to withhold; certificate of notice of amount due; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold purchase price as required, he becomes personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. Within thirty (30) days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate of authority, the designated official of the city shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his address as it appears on the records of the designated official of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall start to run at the time the person sells out his business or at the time that the determination against the person becomes final, whichever event occurs the later. 
(d)  Tax credit, penalty or interest paid more than once or erroneously or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city under this article, it may be offset as provided in section 5-1087(b). If the person determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the designated official of the city, he will have three (3) years from date of payment to file claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the designated official of the city, the excess amount paid the city may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person by whom it was paid or his administrators or executors. 
(e)  Issuance of fi. fa. The director of finance is hereby authorized under this section to issue a fi. fa. for execution and levy to satisfy the amount of tax due but not paid under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 8, 1-6-97) 
Sec. 5-1089. - Administration. 
(a)  Authority of designated official (director of finance). The designated official shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this article. 
(b)  Rules and regulations. The designated official of the city shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with the article or other laws of the City of East Point and State of Georgia, or the constitution of this state or the United States for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the taxes hereunder. 
(c)  Records required from operators; form. Every rental motor vehicle concern in this city shall keep such records, receipts, invoices, and other pertinent papers in such form as the designated official of the city may require. 
(d)  Examination of records; audits. The designated official of the city, or any person authorized in writing by the designated official may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any person renting motor vehicles and any person liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the person, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(e)  Authority to require reports; contents. In administration of the provisions of this article, the designated official of the city may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in such person's or persons' possession or custody information relating to rentals of motor vehicles which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the designated official when required by the designated official and shall set forth the charge for each rental, the date or dates of rental, and such other information as the designated official may require. 
(f)  Disclosure of business of rental motor vehicle concerns, etc.; limitation on rule. The designated official of the city or any person having an administrative duty under this article shall not make known in any manner the business affairs, operations, or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty, or the amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures, or any particular thereof, set forth or disclosed in any return, or to permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having such administrative duty under this article, except in case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the tax hereby levied and assessed. Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees and guarantors, if directly interested, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax required to be collected, interest and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 9, 1-6-97) 
Sec. 5-1090. - Termination of levy. 
The imposition and levy of tax by this article shall terminate on December 31, 2038 unless earlier terminated by ordinance. Nothing in this section shall abrogate or reduce any obligation or any power under this article arising prior to the date of termination of levy. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 10, 1-6-97) 
Sec. 5-1091. - Existing contracts not impaired. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to impair, or authorize the impairment of, any existing contract or contractual rights. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 11, 1-6-97) 
Sec. 5-1092. - Expenditure of tax levy proceeds; purposes. 
(a)  For each year in which proceeds of the tax levied under this article are collected, the proceeds from such collection shall be applied and expended for: 
(1)  Promoting industry, trade, commerce, and tourism; 
(2)  Capital outlay projects consisting of the construction of convention, trade, sports and recreational facilities, or public safety facilities, including the acquiring, constructing, renovating, improving and equipping of parking facilities, pedestrian walkways, plazas, connections, and other public improvements associated with such convention, trade, sports and recreational facilities or public safety facilities or the retirement of debt issued with respect to such capital outlay projects; 
(3)  Maintenance and operation expenses or security and public safety expenses associated with capital outlay projects funded pursuant to subparagraph (2) of this paragraph; 
(4)  Plan and implement promotional projects which promote convention, visitor and tourist development of the city; and 
(5)  Plan and conduct programs of information and publicity designed to attract tourists, visitors, and other interested persons from outside the city. 
(Ord. No. 1143-97, § 12, 1-6-97) 
CHAPTER 2. - BUSINESS AND OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, adopted Feb. 18, 2008, repealed former Ch. 2, §§ 5-2001—5-2024, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Ch. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1116A-95, § 1(Exh. A), adopted July 17, 1995. 

Sec. 5-2001. - Purpose and scope. 
For the year 2008 all businesses new to East Point, and all businesses in subsequent years thereafter, engaged in any business, trade, profession or occupation whether with a location in the city, or in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in Georgia exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession or occupation: which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in East Point, Georgia, such business tax registration shall be shown to the planning and zoning director or his/her designee or to any police officer of said city upon his/her request. 
The occupation tax levied in this chapter is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade or calling. The occupation tax applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A 48-13-5 to 48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2002. - Applicability. 
All persons, firms, corporations, including professional corporations, or other business entities now or hereafter operating a business having a location or office in the City of East Point shall be subject to the requirements of this chapter. Stock or manufacturing companies or other companies, subsidiaries, agencies, district offices, branch offices, corporations or individuals, having a location or office located within the city, and either represented by the officers of the company, or any agent, for the purpose of soliciting patronage for the same, or for the transaction of any business pertaining thereto, shall be subject to the requirements of this chapter. This chapter shall apply to such other persons, firms, corporations, professional corporations or other business entities as may be provided herein in the manner prescribed. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2003. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
Business shall maintain its ordinary and customary usage according to context but also may be used to generally identify a person or entity carrying on a trade, occupation, profession, or other commercial or non-commercial enterprise. 
Planning and zoning director includes the planning and zoning director or his/her designee. 
Business/occupational tax division means that part of the department of planning and zoning made responsible for assisting the planning and zoning director or his/her designee with the administration of the business/occupation tax according to the context may also mean the location where the operations of the business tax division are carried out. 
Dominant line means the type of business within a multiple line business that the greatest amount of income is derived from. 
Certificate means a document issued to the person after registration of a business, from which the greatest amount of income derived. 
Employee means: 
(1)  An individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form I.R.S. W-2 but not a form I.R.S. 1099. 
(2)  An individual who performs work under the direction and supervision of one business or practitioner in accordance with the terms of a contract or agreement with another business which recruits such individual is an employee of the business or practitioner which issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form I.R.S. W-2. 
"Employee" includes individuals who entirely own a business for which he labours. 
Gross receipts means the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including, without limitation, the following: 
(1)  Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; 
(2)  Gain from trading stocks, bonds, capital assets or instruments of indebtedness; 
(3)  Proceeds from commissions on sale of property, goods, or services; 
(4)  Proceeds from fees for services rendered; and 
(5)  Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty or dividend income. 
Gross receipts shall not include the following: 
(1)  Sales, use or excise tax; 
(2)  Sales returns, allowances and discounts; 
(3)  Inter-organizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(1), or between or among the units of brother-sister group controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563 (a)(2); 
(4)  Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent; 
(5)  Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions or the interest income derived from such funds received by a nonprofit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this chapter, if such funds constitute 80 percent or more of the organization's receipts; and 
(6)  Proceeds from sales of goods which are delivered to or received by customers who are outside of the state at the time of delivery to or received by customers who are outside of the state at the time of delivery or receipt. 
Location of office shall not include a temporary worksite which serves a single customer or project. 
Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business for revenue raising purposes. 
Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or as an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession or business.
