The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by paragraph 8 of O.C.G.A. 36-71-2 or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. 
Return means all documents or forms filled with the payment of an occupation tax and/or those documents or forms, which are used to determine any underpayment or overpayment on taxes paid in any previous year. 
Person wherever used in this chapter shall be held to include sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits or any other form of business organization. 
Practitioner of profession or occupation is one who by state law requires state licensure regulation of such profession or occupation. 
Practitioners of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2004. - Levy 
As provided in this chapter and in accordance with state law, an occupation tax is herby levied and assessed on each person engaged in any business, trade, profession or occupation located within the jurisdiction of the city and on each person whose business, trade, profession or occupation is carried on, operated or performed within the jurisdiction of the city; except that no occupation tax, regulatory fee is levied on any state or local authority or nonprofit organization. In the case of an out-of-state business with no location in Georgia, which exerts substantial efforts within the state and city pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, an occupation tax shall be levied and assessed on such business, trade, profession or occupation. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2005. - Administration. 
The planning and zoning director or his/her designee shall administer and enforce this chapter for the levy, assessment and collection of license fees, occupation taxes, and any fees, interest and penalties imposed in this chapter except for those fines or court costs that are judicially imposed. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2006. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter may be cited and required to appear before the court with jurisdiction over violations of city ordinances. Upon conviction before the municipal court of the City of East Point violators will be fined in an amount not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisoned not exceeding thirty (30) days, either or both, in the discretion of the city judge. The imposition of any judicially imposed fines or court costs or other punishment shall not relieve the taxpayer from liability for the payment of all taxes, penalties and interest which are past due. This section shall not authorize the issuance of citations where another section of this chapter excuses compliance from a particular requirement. 
(b)  Any person required to pay an occupation tax or to register with the business tax division, and who fails to do so in the manner provided by this chapter, shall also be liable to have the tax or any fees, penalties and interest collected by the issuance of execution by the planning and zoning director or his/her designee, ex officio marshal or deputy pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26. For the purpose of administering this section and for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, a person who is an employee in apparent authority at the location where the business is registered or who is an agent acting in a capacity of apparent authority may be served with any notices and/or citations directed to the taxpayer. This section further authorizes collection of the tax and any fees, penalties and interest by the issuance of execution by the planning and zoning director or his/her designee, ex officio marshal or deputy pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26 against those delinquent taxpayers without any requirement that citations be issued. 
(c)  Any person who registers with the business tax division as a nonprofit organization, and is exempted from payment of business taxes, regulatory fees, and administrative fees pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-13(5), and who is determined by the planning and zoning director or his/her designee not to qualify for the exemption provided for nonprofit organizations by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-13(5), may be cited for violation of this ordinance and shall be responsible for the payment of all taxes, penalties and interest which are past due. For the purpose of administering this section and for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, a person who is an employee in apparent authority at the location where the business is registered or who is an agent acting in a capacity of apparent authority may be served with any notices and/or citations directed to the taxpayer. 
(d)  Compliance with this chapter shall not be a precondition to the practice of any profession licensed by the state. The sole purpose for the imposition of all fines, penalties and interest provided by this chapter is to support and enhance the collection of the taxes levied by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2007. - Planning and zoning director or his/her designee duties; generally. 
(a)  The planning and zoning director or his/her designee shall see that every person engaged in any and every kind of business, occupation, calling and profession complies with all city business and occupational tax ordinances and all laws and ordinances requiring permits before commencing any building, construction, paving, plumbing, electric or other activity or undertaking. He/she shall see that all business and occupational tax, regulatory fees and all permit fees and taxes are promptly paid. The planning and zoning director or his/her designee shall go to each and every place where any business, occupation, calling or profession is being pursued or carried on, including warehouses, offices, building sites, wholesale and retail establishments of every kind, places of entertainment, sport and all others and determine whether the business and occupational tax ordinance is being violated. He/she shall investigate and determine whether business tax ordinances and zoning ordinances are being violated, and shall enforce the same by prosecuting violators thereof in the recorder's (city) court of the city. 
(b)  The planning and zoning director or his/her designee shall make cases against all persons violating any provision of any business tax or zoning ordinance, and if necessary to have arrested such violators and have them imprisoned in the city jail, unless and until bail is furnished in a reasonable sum. Such planning and zoning director or his/her designee shall prosecute such accused persons in the recorder's (city) court of the city or in such other courts and tribunals as may have jurisdiction of the offense charged. 
(c)  The planning and zoning director or his/her designee is authorized and directed, in addition to his/her duties as the planning and zoning director, to assist in the duties of the general inspector, in the performance of which duties he/she shall have all of the rights, power and authority of the general inspector, and it shall be the duty of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee when performing the duties of the general inspector, to perform all of the duties, exercise all of the power and authority, and have all the rights, immunities, exemptions as such general inspector in the performance of such duties of such general inspector; provided it is not the intention of the city council by adopting this section to make the planning and zoning director or his/her designee a second general inspector, nor is it its intention or purpose to make the planning and zoning director or his/her designee an assistant general inspector. The sole purpose of this section is to enable the planning and zoning director or his/her designee to aid and assist the general inspector when it is convenient and does not require any substantial extra effort on the part of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee, it being the intention of the council to provide for the planning and zoning director or his/her designee, in the course of his/her duties inspecting business tax registrations, too often be in such position and locality that checking on buildings and building sites will not require extra time, or if so, a very small extra time and effort on the part of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee. 
(d)  By this section the general inspector is not relieved of his/her duties as general inspector, nor that the planning and zoning director or his/her designee discharge or perform any of the duties of the general inspector except in cases where it is inconvenient for the general inspector to make such inspection and it is convenient for the planning and zoning director or his/her designee to do so. 
(e)  The general inspector is authorized and directed, in addition to his duties as the general inspector to assist in the duties of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee in the performance of which duties he/she shall have all of the rights, power and authority of the city planning and zoning director or his/her designee and it shall be the duty of the general inspector, when performing the duties of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee, to perform all of the duties, exercise all of the power and authority and have all of the rights, immunities and exemptions as such planning and zoning director or his/her designee in the performance of such duties of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee; provided it is not the intention of the city council, by adopting this section to make the general city inspector a second planning and zoning director or his/her designee. The sole purpose of this section is to enable the general inspector to aid and assist the planning and zoning director or his/her designee when it is convenient and does not require any substantial extra effort on the part of the general inspector, it being the intention of the city council to provide for the general inspector, in the course of his/her duties inspecting buildings and building sites to often be in such position and locality that checking on a business tax registration will not require extra time, or if so a very small extra time and effort on the part of the general inspector. 
(f)  By this section the planning and zoning director or his/her designee is not relieved of his/her duties, nor shall the general inspector discharge or perform any of the duties of planning and zoning director or his/her designee except in cases where it is inconvenient for the general inspector to do. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2008. - Same—Vested with police powers. 
The planning and zoning director or his/her designee shall be clothed with full police powers in the discharge of his/her duties prescribed in section 5-2007. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2009. - Exemption of city officers, agencies or employees from provisions of chapter. 
Since regulatory provisions of city ordinances requiring occupation tax and permits are not generally applicable to the city itself, no city tax or permit shall be necessary for any construction, alteration, repair or installation of the city by any competent city officer, agency or employee unless clearly made applicable to the city by name by express provision of the city ordinance or resolution applicable to such work. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2010. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. 
All persons subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this chapter shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for said business as described in this chapter, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. Every person commencing business in the City of East Point after January 1st of each year shall likewise obtain the registration herein provided for before commencing the same; and any person transacting, or offering to transact in the city, any of the kinds of business, trade, profession or occupation without first having so obtained said registration shall be subject to penalties provided thereof. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2011. - When registration tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. 
(a)  The registration referred to in this article shall automatically expire on December 31 of the year of its issuance. 
(b)  Renewal applications for all business required to register shall be completed on or before February 1 of each year. The failure to renew registration by the date required shall be a violation of this article, but such violation shall not prevent any business from being allowed to continue its operation. 
(c)  Any person, business, corporation who fails to pay the occupation tax for ninety (90) days from the due date, March 31 in any year, shall be subject to and shall pay a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax due. Any occupation tax not paid by the due date shall be considered delinquent and bear interest at the rate of one and one-half (1½) percent per month. 
(d)  Each person commencing business in the city after January 1st of each year shall obtain the registration required before commencing such business. Any person transacting or offering to transact in the city any business, trade, profession or occupation without first having obtained said registrations shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 5-2006. Said penalties shall be in addition to all other penalties, civil and criminal herein provided; and may be collected by the remedies herein provided for collection of the occupation tax, and shall have the same lien and priority as the occupation tax to which the penalty is applied. 
(e)  The registration herein provided for shall be issued by the planning and zoning director or his/her designee, and if any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall after said occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the city, any of the kind of business, trade, profession or occupation without having first obtained said registration, such offender shall be subject to the penalties provided thereof. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08; Ord. No. 026-11, § 1, 11-21-11) 
Sec. 5-2012. - Determination of amount. 
The occupation tax amount shall be determined by the sum of four (4) components: 
(a)  A nonrefundable annual administrative fee of seventy-five ($75.00); 
(b)  A fifty-dollar ($50.00) minimum flat tax; 
(c)  A gross receipt tax based on an estimated gross receipts figure and; 
(d)  A per employee fee. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2013. - Tax rate structure. 
(a)  A non-prorated, nonrefundable administrative fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) shall be required on all business and occupation tax accounts except for businesses of those persons who are not required to pay the occupation tax for the initial startup, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. The administrative fee can only approximate the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax, return application. 
(b)  A non-prorated, nonrefundable minimum flat tax of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(c)  (i)  All occupation taxes levied by this chapter are levied on the amount of business transacted during the current calendar year and the number of employees to be employed in the business conducted. However, for convenience of both the city and the taxpayer those businesses subject to the occupational tax shall on or before February 1 file with the business/occupational tax division a return showing all gross receipts of that business during the preceding calendar year ending on December 31 or form BUS 1A. This return showing preceding calendar year gross receipts shall be used as an estimate of gross receipts for making payments on the occupation tax for the current calendar year. The number of employees reported for the current year's business operations may be based upon the number of employees employed in the business conducted during the previous year. Applicants or owners engaged in the business shall be reported as employees of the business. For continuing businesses, the return required on or before February 1 showing the business' preceding year's actual gross receipts and number of employees shall also be used to adjust the estimated return for the same period. Differences will be billed or credited to the business' occupational tax billing as required. Should a business department's business occupation tax section file a final return reporting the actual number of employees and those gross receipts not previously reported. 
(ii)  If a business is to begin on or after January 1 of the occupation tax year, the tax on such business shall be due and payable on the date of the commencement of the business and shall be based upon estimated gross receipts of the business from the date of commencement until the end of the calendar year. The business shall also file the required registration form and shall pay the administrative fee required by the chapter. 
(d)  (1)  The number of employees of the business or practitioner as computed on a full-time position basis or full-time position equivalent basis, provided that for the purposes of this computation an employee who works forty (40) hours or more weekly shall be considered a full-time employee and that the average weekly hours of employees who work less than forty (40) hours weekly shall be added and such shall be divided by forty (40) to produce full-time position equivalents. 
(2)  In the case of an employee who works for the same business or practitioner in more than one (1) municipal corporation or county, the municipal corporation or county in which the employee works for the longest period of time within the calendar year shall be authorized to count the individual as an employee who is employed within the local government's geographic jurisdiction for the purposes of occupation tax. 
(e)  No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one (1) occupation tax for each of its locations. 
(f)  No occupation tax will be required upon more than one hundred (100) percent of a business's gross receipts. 
(g)  An occupation tax shall not be levied in any other manner, on those affected businesses or practitioners except as described in chapter. 
(h)  No business is required to pay taxes on any gross receipts in excess of three million dollars ($3,000,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08; Ord. No. 014-12, § 1, 10-15-12) 
Note— Schedule A can be found at the end of this chapter. 
Sec. 5-2014. - Professional occupation tax. 
(a)  Classification. Practitioners as described in O.C.G.A. § 14-13-9 are as follows: 
(1)  Lawyers; 
(2)  Physicians; 
(3)  Osteopaths; 
(4)  Chiropractors; 
(5)  Podiatrists; 
(6)  Dentists; 
(7)  Optometrists; 
(8)  Psychologists; 
(9)  Veterinarians; 
(10)  Landscape architects; 
(11)  Land surveyors; 
(12)  Practitioners of physiotherapy; 
(13)  Public accountants; 
(14)  Embalmers; 
(15)  Funeral directors; 
(16)  Civil, mechanical, hydraulic or electrical engineers; 
(17)  Architects; 
(18)  Marriage and family therapists, social workers and professional counselors; 
(19)  Dealers of motor vehicles, as defined in paragraph (1) f O.C.G.A 100-1-622; 
(20)  Owners or operators of bona fide coin operated amusement machines, as defined in O.C.G.A. 48-17-1 and owners or operators of businesses where bona fide coin operated amusement machines are available for commercial use and play by the public, provided that such amusement machines have affixed current stickers showing payment of annual permit fees, in accordance with O.C.G.A. 48-17-9; 
(21)  Merchants or dealers as defined in O.C.G.A. 48-5-354 as to their deliveries to businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations in areas zoned for commercial use; and 
(22)  Any other business, profession, or occupation for which state licensure or registration is required by state law, unless the state law regulating such business, profession, or occupation specifically allows for regulation by local governments. 
(b)  Determination of rate or amount of payment: At the time of the payment of the tax, the professional practitioners listed in subsection (a) of this section shall elect as their entire occupation tax one (1) of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on gross receipts combined with profitability ratios and classes as set forth in section 5-2014. If the practitioner of the profession elects to calculate the occupation tax due based on gross receipts combined with profitability ratios and classes as set forth in section 5-2014, a fee of seventy-five ($75.00) is imposed to pay the cost to process the payment and an employee fee. 
(2)  A fee of $400.00 per practitioner. An administrative fee of $75.00 shall be imposed and an employee fee based on the number of employees. Practitioners paying according to this subsection shall not be required to provide information to the local government relating to the gross receipts of the business of the business or practitioner. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. 
(c)  Compliance with this chapter shall not be a precondition to the practice of any profession, listed herein, or licensed by the state. The sole purpose for the imposition of all fines, penalties and interest provided in this chapter is to support and enhance the collection of the taxes levied by this chapter. No administrative fee shall be charged to the practitioner of any profession listed in this section in the event that the practitioner requests to file any documents with the city prior to the time of payment of the tax. It shall be the responsibility of the taxpayer to inform the business tax division of their claim of entitlement to be treated as a practitioner of a profession under state law where the interpretation of this chapter in such a manner would entitle such taxpayer to a different application of the business tax ordinance or any rules and regulations promulgated by the planning and zoning director or his/her designee. 
(d)  Practitioners of professions may be asked to provide information as to the location where they may be served with notices or citations issued in support of the enforcement of this chapter and upon the failure or refusal to do so, the city shall direct the notices or citations to the address listed with the appropriate state licensing agency. 
(1)  This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by January 1st of each year. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2015. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for the government. 
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the united states, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the united states, the state or a municipality or county of the state, shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2016. - Regulatory fees. 
(a)  The City of East Point shall assess a regulatory fee on certain businesses and practitioners of professions or occupations on which the city must actually and customarily perform investigations or inspections of such businesses or practitioners as a protection to the public health, safety or welfare or in the course of enforcing a state or local building, health or safety code. 
(b)  Unless provided otherwise, regulatory fees are paid annually. 
(c)  Examples of businesses or practitioners of professions or occupations which may be subject to a regulatory fee include, but are expressly not limited to the following: 
(1)  Auto and motorcycle racing—$5,000.00; 
(2)  Billiard parlors/poolrooms—$500.00; 
(3)  Boxing and wrestling promoters-$1000.00; 
(4)  Bingo games - $100.00 per game; 
(5)  Building and construction contractors, subcontractors, and workers—$50.00; 
(6)  Burglar and fire alarm installers—$500.00; 
(7)  Businesses which provide appearance bonds—$1,000.00; 
(8)  Carnivals—$150.00 per week or part of a week, $50.00 per vendor annually; 
(9)  Dealers in precious metals—$2,000.00; 
(10)  Escort services—$1,000.00; 
(11)  Exhibitions—$100.00 per week or part of week; 
(12)  Family day care homes (residential)—$100.00; 
(13)  Flea markets—$100.00 per weekend up to three weekends or $500.00 annually; 
(14)  Firearms dealers—$2,000.00; 
(15)  Food service establishments $200.00; 
(16)  Fortunetellers—$500.00; 
(17)  Gaming hall or emporium (bingo)—$1,000.00; 
(18)  Garbage collectors—$250.00; 
(19)  Handwriting analysts—$200.00; 
(20)  Health clubs, gyms, and spas—$200.00; 
(21)  Hotels and motels—$100.00 + $3.00 per room per year; 
(22)  Hypnotists—$200.00; 
(23)  Junk dealers—$500.00; 
(24)  Junk yards—$1,500.00; 
(25)  Landfills—$5,000.00; 
(26)  Locksmiths—$500.00; 
(27)  Massage parlors—$500.00; 
(28)  Modeling agencies—$500.00; 
(29)  Newspaper vending boxes—$25.00 each; 
(30)  Nursing and personal care homes—$200.00; 
(31)  One day auction—$35.00; 
(32)  Parking lots—$300.00 + $3.00 per parking space per year 
(33)  Pawnbrokers—$2,000.00; 
(34)  Peddlers—$400.00; 
(35)  Scrap metal processors—$2,000.00; 
(36)  Shooting galleries and firearm ranges—$500.00; 
(37)  Stables—$200.00; 
(38)  Tattoo artists—$100.00; 
(39)  Taxicab and limousine operators—$250.00; 
If a non-preempted business not included in the preceding list is determined by the mayor and city council to require additional regulation, council shall review evidence to determine the appropriate amount of regulatory fees and shall adopt the same into this section. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08; Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-10) 
Sec. 5-2017. - Paying occupation tax of business with no business location in Georgia. 
Registration and the assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners with no location or office in the State of Georgia if the business' largest dollar volume of business in Georgia is in the City of East Point and the business or practitioner: 
(1)  Has one (1) or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the City of East Point for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2018. - Registration fee on certain business/occupations with no fixed location in the city 
Building and construction contractors, subcontractors, and workers shall be required to register a current year business license from the county or municipality in which their business is located. The registration shall be done each year and a registration fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be due at the time of registration. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2019. - Audit of businesses and confidentiality of information. 
(a)  In case it appears to the planning and zoning director or his/her authorized representative that there are errors or inaccuracies in the statement of number of employees as submitted, the planning and zoning director or his/her designee or his/her authorized representative is authorized to conduct an examination of the books and records of such business for which the returns are made. Upon demand of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee or his/her authorized representative, such books and records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within thirty (30) days. Failure of submission of such books or records within thirty (30) days shall be grounds for revocation of the tax registration currently existing to do business in the City of East Point. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the planning and zoning director or his/her designee at his/her discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency in the number of employees reported occurs as a result of underreporting, a penalty of one hundred and twenty-five (125) percent of the prime interest rate times the amount of deficient will be assessed for the period delinquent. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the prime interest rate shall be that which is published by The Wall Street Journal. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2020. - Businesses not covered by this chapter. 
The following businesses are not covered by the provision[s] of this chapter but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the State of Georgia or by act of local law. 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission. 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under Chapter 3 of title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. 33-8-9, et seq. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. 48-5-355. 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the State of Georgia governed by O.C.G.A. 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. 48-13-55. 
(11)  Alcoholic beverages. 
(12)  Any other business or occupation not covered by local law. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2021. - Copy of latest state tax return or other appropriate documentation of gross receipts required for tax certificate; locations and records open to inspection; record retention requirements. 
(a)  Each business, trade, profession, or occupation required to pay a tax based upon gross receipts shall be required to provide the business tax division with a copy of the entity's latest state tax return, or other appropriate documentation of statewide gross receipts that is acceptable to the business inspector, upon the renewal, adjustment or final application for a tax certificate. 
(b)  Upon demand by the planning and zoning director or his or her designee, it shall be the duty of any person who is required to obtain a business license from the city to open all portions of any location, where business is conducted inside the city, for the purpose of enabling the planning and zoning director or his or her designee to ascertain and gain information necessary for the determination of the proper classification of any business for business or occupation tax purposes. 
(c)  Upon demand by the planning and zoning director or his or her designee, it shall be the duty of any person, who is required to obtain a business license from the city, to produce, furnish or make available, during regular business hours at a location inside the city, all books of account, invoices, papers, reports and memoranda containing entries showing amount of purchases, sales receipts, inventory and other information, from which the determination of the proper classification of any business for the previous three calendar years may be determined for business or occupation tax purposes or from which the amount of business or occupation tax for the previous three calendar years may be determined or verified, regardless of whether such records are maintained outside of the city. Such records may include but are not limited to bank deposit books, bank statements, copies of sales tax reports made to the state of Georgia, and copies of state and federal income tax returns. 
(d)  Any person who is required to obtain a business license from the city and who is required to produce, furnish or make available, during regular business hours at a location inside the city, any documents or records described in this chapter shall keep and preserve all such documents or records for a period which includes the three previous calendar years. 
(e)  It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to fail or refuse to perform any duty herein imposed or to obstruct or interfere with the business inspector or his or her designee in the performance of their duties or to refuse to produce, furnish or make available any documents or records described in this chapter. Any person violating this section may be cited by the compliance investigators and upon conviction by the municipal court shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the estimated business tax or portion thereof then due or five hundred dollars ($500.00), whichever is greater. For the purpose of administering this section and for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, a person who is an employee or agent acting in a capacity of apparent authority shall be joint and severally liable for the payment of all fines, taxes, penalties and interest which are past due. 
(f)  In lieu of submitting state tax returns applicants may submit form BUS 1A. This notarized form certifies that to the best of the applicant's knowledge, the information provided is true an accurate. The applicant also understands that failure to provide accurate information will result in the revocation of associated permits. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2022. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 028-11, § 1, adopted Nov. 21, 2011, repealed former § 5-2022 in its entirety which pertained to a delinquent penalty for late filing and derived from Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, adopted Feb. 18, 2008. 
Sec. 5-2023. - Business license required before entering into business. 
Any person, firm or corporation who does any business with respect to which a business or occupational tax is hereby imposed without paying said tax to the city before entering upon such business shall be guilty of doing business without a license, and upon conviction therefore in the municipal (city) court shall be liable as provided in the Code of the city provided, however that neither this section nor section 5-2014 hereof shall be applicable with respect to any other business for which East Point may not issue a license under the terms of the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2024. - Locations of businesses; change of address. 
(a)  Any license granted under this chapter shall not authorize the holder thereof to exercise or carry on the trade, business or profession named herein at any other place than designated on the face of said license. 
(b)  Any person moving from one location to another shall notify the planning and zoning director or his/her authorized representative of such move and the new address, in writing, on a form provided by the planning and zoning or his/her authorized representative no later than the day of moving. A new license or receipt for business/occupational tax will be issued at the new location if said new location conforms to the zoning regulation of the city. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2025. - Business or occupational tax receipts not transferable. 
Business/occupational tax receipts shall not be transferable and a transfer of ownership shall be considered in the same light as the termination of such business and the establishment of a new business. Therefore, a new business or occupational tax shall be required for the new owner of the business. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2025. - Separate businesses. 
Where a business is conducted at more than one (1) location or place, or where a person, firm, company or corporation is engaged in different lines of business at separate locations, each location or place shall be considered a separate business under the terms of this chapter and a separate business tax and/or occupational tax shall be levied and paid. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2026. - Duration of business or occupational tax period. 
Such business tax or occupational tax referred to in this chapter, shall automatically expire on December 31st after the year of its issuance. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2027. - Tax registration to be revoked for failure to pay tax, file return, permit inspection of books. 
Upon the failure of any business to pay said occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of said returns within the time required herein, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as above provided, any business tax registration granted by the City of East Point under this chapter permitting the owner of said business to do business in the city for the current year shall be ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax registration shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax herein provided for is at that time unpaid, or to an individual, firm or corporation who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the planning and zoning director or his/her designee in accordance with provisions found in this chapter. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct its business, the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2028. - Effect of failure to comply with chapter provisions; continuing in business after tax registration revocation. 
Any person, their managers, agents or employees, who do business in said city after the registration for said business has been revoked as above; any persons, their managers, agents or employees, hereby required to make returns, showing the number of employees and who fail to make said returns within the time and in the manner herein provided, or refuse to amend such returns so as to set forth the truth, or who shall make false returns, and any persons, their managers, agents or employees who refuse to permit an inspection of books in their charge when the officers, agents, employees or representatives of the city request such inspection, during the business hours, for the purpose of determining the accuracy of the returns herein provided for, shall be subject to penalties provided herein. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct its business, the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2029. - Execution for delinquent occupation tax. 
In addition to other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, the planning and zoning director or his/her designee of East Point, Georgia, upon any tax or installment of said tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of said tax against the persons, partnership or corporation liable for said tax, which said execution shall bear interest at the rate of one and one-half (1.5) percent per month from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover the property (in the city) of the person, partnership or corporation liable for said tax, all as provided by the ordinances and charter of said city and the laws of Georgia. The lien of said occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the director of planning of said city upon the property of defendant located in said city, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as provided by ordinances and charter of said city and laws of Georgia, and the defendant in said execution shall have all rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the charter of said city and laws of Georgia in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the director of planning and zoning against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect fees and charges due him or her as though he or she had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2030. - Revocation and refusal to renew. 
(a)  In case it appears to the business inspector or his/her authorized representative that a business which is required to pay a business and/or occupational tax in the city has conducted the business in such a way as to be a hazard to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of east point or that a concern may be doing business in such a way as to result in complaints by consumers as to fraud, deceit, manner of rendering service or other deceptive practices, the planning and zoning or his/her authorized representative shall notify the business in writing that its license shall not be issued or shall be revoked. Said written notice shall specify in reasonable detail the reasons why said license shall not be issued and shall be revoked. 
(b)  In the event the planning and zoning director or his/her authorized representative refuses to issue or revokes a business license, the taxpayer shall have the absolute right to appeal the refusal to issue said license or the revocation thereof to the mayor and council of East Point in accordance with the appellant process as outlined in section 5-2045. In all cases arising under this section, it shall be the duty of the city to prove, that a person or concern is in violation of the provisions of this section, ordinances of the city or laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2031. - Rules and regulations. 
The planning and zoning director or his/her authorized representative shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this chapter or other laws of the city and the state, or the Constitution of this state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and the collection of the business tax or occupational tax hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2032. - Liquor, beer and wine excluded. 
Business tax and/or occupational taxes respecting retail and wholesale dealers in liquor, wine, beer, and malt beverages are not provided for in this chapter and the same are provided by separate ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2033. - Casual and isolated activities relative to individually owned residential units. 
(a)  Nothing herein contained shall be interpreted so as to require any person who may engage in casual or isolated activity and commercial transactions, where such involved personal assets are not the principal occupation of the individual, to obtain a business license or pay a business tax therefore. 
(b)  Within the context of this provision, there is hereby created a rebuttal presumption that individually owned residential rental units of five (5) or more units are not casual or isolated activity and commercial transactions and such units shall be subject to assessment and a business tax therefore. 
(c)  Within the context of this provision, there is additionally hereby created a rebuttal presumption that individually owned commercial rental units of one (1) or more units are not casual or isolated activity and commercial transactions, and such units and the gross rental incomes received there from shall be subject to assessment and a business tax therefore. 
(d)  Within the context of this provision, the definition of a "unit" shall be defined as square footage authorized and allowed for the conduct of a particular business or activity, or as the residence and dwelling, of a single-family entity. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2034. - Amendment; repeal of provisions. 
This chapter shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Said amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the city of additional occupation taxes, upon the same person, property or business. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2035. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. 
This chapter does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulator fee provided for in said ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provision hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2036. - Exemption on grounds that business operated for charitable purpose. 
No business on which a business registration or occupation tax is levied by this chapter shall be exempt from said registration or tax on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless seventy-five (75) percent or more of the entire proceeds from said business are devoted to such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2037. - Disabled veteran's license. 
Persons who can qualify for a state veteran's free license must secure such license from the State of Georgia and present same to the planning and zoning director or his/her authorized representative who will issue said person a free East Point License. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2038. - Evidence of state registration required if applicable; state registration to be displayed. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the Secretary of State pursuant to Title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city registration may be issued. 
(b)  Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all time while the license remains valid. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2039. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certifi cates of qualification, certificates of competence or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, show evidence of such qualification. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2040. - Enforcement of provisions. 
It is hereby made the duty of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee to see that the provisions of this chapter relating to occupation taxes are observed and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the recorder's court as often as in his/her judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted there under. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2041. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by council. 
This chapter shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the council. All provisions hereto relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2042. - Requirement of public hearing before tax increase. 
After January 1, 2008, the council shall conduct at least one (1) public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2043. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in occupation tax. 
The council may by subsequent ordinance or resolution provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one (1) or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions' as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2044. - Appeal of decisions of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee; claims for refunds. 
(a)  Any decision of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee under this chapter, including without limitation, such decisions as to entitlement to exemptions, profitability classifications, methods of accounting, the imposition of penalties and interest, and the amount of tax due, may be appealed, in writing by any taxpayer. Such appeal shall be filed in writing with the business tax division and no special form is required except that the taxpayer set forth sufficient information for the determination of the appeal. The taxpayer shall be responsible to set forth the information, which the taxpayer considers pertinent to the appeal and the planning and zoning director or his/her designee may consider the appeal based only on the information submitted by the taxpayer. The planning and zoning director or his/her designee shall act on such appeals only when submitted by the taxpayer, an attorney acting directly on the behalf of a taxpayer or from a person who presents a signed and notarized power of attorney that they are authorized to represent the taxpayer. 
(1)  The filing of an appeal as to the amount of tax due shall not act to relieve the taxpayer of the requirement to pay the amount of tax levied or to prevent the imposition of penalties and interest. The filing of an appeal of the amount of tax calculated to be due follows a separate procedure from a claim for refund and taxpayers are hereby put on notice that the filing of an appeal of the determination of the amount of tax due is not a claim for refund and does not preserve any rights of the taxpayer with respect the time limits within which refunds must be claimed under state law. 
(2)  The planning and zoning director or his/her designee shall make a written determination on all appeals, except for claims for refunds, within six (6) months of its filing. Other than a refund claim, any appeal, not acted on within six (6) months is deemed denied. 
(3)  An appeal of a decision of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee as to decisions made under this section shall be to the Superior Court of Fulton County by writ of certiorari wherein the errors complained of are plainly and distinctly set forth. 
(4)  Any appeal concerning the issuance of executions shall be governed in the manner set forth by state law. 
(b)  Any claim for refund of any tax provided for in this chapter shall be subject to the provisions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380 as it exists now or as it may be amended. 
(1)  Any claim for refund of any tax provided for in this chapter shall be in writing and shall be addressed, by the taxpayer, to the planning and zoning director or his/her designee, who is herein designated by the city council to accept claims for refunds. The claim shall identify the taxpayer, specify the business location, the tax years for which refunds are claimed and the dates of payment for which the refund is claimed. The claim shall also include a summary statement of the grounds on which the taxpayer relies and shall specify the tax years and dates of payments to which such grounds apply. In the event that the taxpayer desires a conference or hearing before the planning and zoning director or his/her designee in connection with any claim for refund, the taxpayer shall so specify in writing at the time of filing the claim. The planning and zoning director or his/her designee shall grant a conference at a time of his/her convenience except in those cases where the city council must hear the claim. 
(2)  The date of filing shall be the date that the claim for refund is received by the planning and zoning director or his/her designee. In any case where the planning and zoning director or his/her designee does not make a refund for any or the entire amount claimed, or cause the refund claim to appear on the agenda city council, within one year of the date that the claim is received, the taxpayer may consider that the claim is denied. No claim shall be deemed approved by the failure of the planning and zoning director or his/her designee to make a decision on the claim or to failure of the claim to appear on the agenda of the city council. The planning and zoning director or his/her designee and the taxpayer may agree in writing to extend the one year period for processing of the claim and such action shall stay the presumption of denial until the written agreement expires. 
(3)  In cases of error, clerical or otherwise, the city council shall approve or disapprove the claim through a resolution which shall also be considered at least once at a meeting of the city council, prior to a final vote. In such cases where the taxpayer has requested a hearing before the governing authority, such hearing shall take place at said committee meeting. 
(c)  Further proceedings concerning the denial of refund claims shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380 as it may be from time to time amended. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2045. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this chapter between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2046. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this chapter, and not preserved hereby, be, and the same are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08) 
Sec. 5-2047. - Severability. 
If any section, provision or clause of any part of this chapter shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this chapter as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such individuality shall not be construed to effect the portions of this chapter not so held to be invalid, or the application of this chapter to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent that this chapter would have been adopted and such invalid portion not be included herein. 
(Ord. No. 008-08, § 1, 2-18-08; Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-10) 
SCHEDULE A (RESERVED) [4]
