CHAPTER 3. - BUSINESS LICENSES, GENERALLY 
ARTICLE A. - INSURANCE TAX 

Sec. 5-3001. - Insurers business tax. 
There is hereby levied an annual business tax registration fee upon each insurer doing business with the city in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). For each separate business location in excess of one (1) not covered by section 5-3002 which is operating on behalf of insurers within the city there is hereby levied a business tax fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 028-08, § 1, 10-20-08) 
Sec. 5-3002. - Business tax for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. 
For each separate business location not otherwise a subject to a business tax under this article, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term-financing and in connection with such loans or sales, offers, solicits or take application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, said insurer shall pay an additional business tax of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per location for each year. 
(Ord. No. 028-08, § 1, 10-20-08) 
Sec. 5-3003. - Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. 
There is hereby levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing, life, accident and sickness insurance with the city in an amount equal to one (1) percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. 33-8.8.1. "Gross direct premiums" as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the business tax registration imposed by section 5-3001 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 028-08, § 1, 10-20-08) 
Sec. 5-3004. - Gross premiums tax, all other insurers. 
There is hereby levied an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in subsection 1 of O.C.G.A. 33-3-5, doing business within the city in an amount equal to two and one-half (2½) percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. 33-8-8.2. "Gross direct premiums" as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. 33-8-8.2(a). 
(Ord. No. 028-08, § 1, 10-20-08) 
ARTICLE B. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS 

Sec. 5-3005. - Business tax. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. 48-6-93, there is hereby levied an annual business tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan association, state building and loan associations, a business tax at the rate of one quarter of one percent of the gross receipts of said institution as defined. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the minimum amount of business tax due from any depository financial institutions pursuant to this article shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year. 
(Ord. No. 028-08, § 1, 10-20-08) 
Sec. 5-3006. - Gross receipts calculations and exceptions. 
For the purposes of this article "gross receipts" shall mean the total amount of revenue generated from the sources itemized below during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax, imposed by the article, is due: 
(1)  Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to banks are as follows: 
a.  Interest and fees on loans, less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others; 
b.  Interest on balances with other depository financial institutions; 
c.  Interest on federal or correspondent funds sold and securities purchased on agreements of resale; 
d.  Interest on other bonds, notes, and debentures, excluding interest on obligations in the State of Georgia or its political subdivisions and obligations on the United States; 
e.  Dividends on stocks; 
f.  Income from direct lease financing; 
g.  Income for fiduciary activities; 
h.  Service charges on deposit accounts; 
i.  Other service charges, commissions, and fees; and 
j.  Other income. 
(2)  Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to savings and loan associations are as follows: 
a.  Interest on mortgages loans less any interest collected on those, portions of loans sold in service for others; 
b.  Interest on mortgages, participation or mortgage-backed securities; 
c.  Interest on real estate sold on contract; 
d.  Discounts on mortgage loans purchased; 
e.  Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the State of Georgia or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; 
f.  Interest and dividends on investments and deposits; 
g.  Loan fees; 
h.  Loan servicing fees; 
i.  Other fees and charges; 
j.  Gross income from real estate owned operations; 
k.  Net income from office building operations; 
l.  Gross income from real estate held for investment; 
m.  Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries; 
n.  Miscellaneous operating income; 
o.  Profit on sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans, and other assets; and 
p.  Miscellaneous nonoperating income. 
(3)  The following items shall be deducted from gross receipts calculated pursuant to paragraph (1) or (2) of this section. 
a.  An amount equal to the amount in interest paid on all liabilities for the period; 
b.  An amount equal to the income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to article 5(a) of Chapter 1 of Title 7 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; 
c.  An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons or entities located outside of the United States, its territories or possessions; 
d.  An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than Georgia; and 
e.  To the extent that any deductions are made pursuant to subparagraph b, c, and d of this subsection, any deductions taken under subparagraph a of this subsection shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in subparagraphs b through d of this subsection bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to subparagraphs a through d above. 
(Ord. No. 028-08, § 1, 10-20-08) 
Sec. 5-3007. - Severability. 
If any section, provision or clause of any part of this chapter shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this chapter as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity shall not be construed to effect the portions of this chapter not so held to be invalid, or application of this chapter to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent that this chapter would have been adopted and such invalid portion not be included herein. 
(Ord. No. 028-08, § 1, 10-20-08) 
ARTICLE C. - BILLIARDS AND POOL 

Sec. 5-3008. - Occupation tax, license, registration required. 
It shall be unlawful to engage in, maintain or operate a billiard parlor, poolroom or similar business without first obtaining from the city regulatory license and paying the required regulatory fee and occupation tax to keep and operate a billiard parlor or poolroom in the city. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3009. - Application. 
Before any billiard parlor or poolroom license shall be issued, the applicant for such license shall make written application to the city for such license, which application shall give the name, residence and business address of the applicant, the occupation and address of the applicant for the ten (10) years prior to date of such application, the particular location of the intended billiard parlor or poolroom and the number of tables to be placed and kept in such billiard parlor or poolroom. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3010. - Occupation tax. 
In addition to the regulatory license fee, every person who shall make application for a license to keep, maintain and operate a billiard parlor or poolroom shall pay an annual occupation tax, which shall accompany the application for the license with the regulatory fee. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3011. - Notice to be posted by applicant. 
It shall be unlawful for any billiard parlor or poolroom license to be issued until the applicant shall cause to have posted in a conspicuous place on the property a sign not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the hearing. Each such posted sign shall not be less than twelve (12) square feet in area, and each sign shall contain information as to the proposed use and the date, time and place of the public hearing before the mayor and city council. Each applicant shall have a notice published, at the applicant's expense, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks prior to public hearing, which notice shall state the following: 
(a)  The full and correct names of all the applicants, if there is more than one (1) applicant; 
(b)  Whether the applicant is an individual, partnership, or a corporation; 
(c)  The residence and business address of the applicant(s); 
(d)  The business and residence address and name of each partner if the applicant is a partnership; 
(e)  The business address of the applicant if the applicant is a corporation and the residence address of the principal officer and stockholder. For the notice to be sufficient in any case, the address stated therein must be the addresses showing residence and place of business of each person whose address is required to be set forth in such notice; 
(f)  The full and complete name of every person interested or to be interested in the business to be conducted or carried on under such business registration or permit; 
(g)  The name and number of the street where such business is to be conducted; 
(h)  The name and residence and business address of the landlord of the premises where the business is to be conducted or carried on under such license; 
(i)  The date such notice in the newspaper of general circulation of the city is first published; 
(j)  The date, place and hour at which the mayor and city council will consider the application, which shall be at least thirty (30) days following the date of the first publication of the notice in a newspaper of general circulation; 
(k)  The nature of the license desired, and the date when such place of business shall first open for business; 
(l)  The statement that such application has been filed with the city, and that any person having objections to the issuance of such license should file the same in writing with the city at or before the meeting of the mayor and council at which time the council will consider such application and all objections thereto; 
(m)  In order that the notice will attract attention of any casual reader it shall appear under the words "notice" printed in capital letters one-eighth ( 1/8 ) of an inch in height; 
(n)  The provision of this section requiring applicant to post sign and publish such notice in a paper of general circulation of the city for a period of two (2) consecutive weeks shall not apply to mere change of location of the business of such billiard parlor or pool room operator from one (1) building location to another building and location within the same city block, when prior approval by the mayor and city council of East Point has been obtained for such change by adoption of a resolution of approval. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3012. - Violators of liquor laws prohibited. 
No business registration license shall be issued to any person who shall have been convicted within ten (10) years prior to the date of the issuance of such business registration of the violation of any crime involving: 
(A)  Moral turpitude; 
(b)  Lottery law violations; 
(c)  Gambling; 
(d)  Gaming violations; 
(e)  Possession, distribution or sale of illegal narcotics or alcoholic beverages; 
(f)  Pandering, solicitation for lewd purposes, prostitution or other sex-related offenses; and 
(g)  Tax offenses. 
These offenses are deemed by the mayor and city council to be reasonable, clearly articulated and ascertainable standards which are rationally related to the business of billiard parlor/pool room operation. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3013. - Revocation. 
If a license is issued for a billiard parlor or pool room and the holder or owner thereof shall violate any part of the provisions of this article, or shall aid or abet in the violation of the same, on conviction thereof, such license shall be subject to revocation in addition to all other penalties and not in lieu thereof. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3014. - Opening and closing hours. 
A keeper or owner of any billiard parlor or pool room shall be required to close the same at 12:00 midnight on Tuesday through Thursday, and at 1:00 a.m. on Friday and Saturday night, and not open thereafter until 6:00 a.m. on the next business day. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3015. - Intoxicating liquors prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have, possess or control any spirituous, malted, vinous or intoxicating liquors within any billiard parlor or pool room. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3016. - Disorderly conduct; prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of any billiard parlor or pool room within the city to permit or allow any loud, profane, obscene, vulgar or boisterous talking within any billiard parlor or pool room within the city, or to permit any kind of disorderly conduct or misconduct within such billiard parlor or poolroom. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
ARTICLE D. - BINGO 

Sec. 5-3017. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful to engage in, maintain or operate a bingo game without first obtaining from the city a license to operate a bingo game in the city. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3018. - Application. 
Before any bingo game business license shall be issued the applicant for such license shall make a written application to the city for such license, which application shall give the name of the nonprofit organization operating the bingo game, the address of the nonprofit organization, the name and residence address of the party or person making application on behalf of the nonprofit organization and the address or location at which the bingo game or games will be played. This application shall be returned to the city along with a certified copy of the approval of the organization operating the game as a tax-exempt organization by the state revenue commissioner, and a check in the amount of the fee as described herein. When payment is made for subsequent license, the application for renewal shall return to the city, a copy of the current license approved by the State of Georgia for operating non-profit bingo games along with a check in the amount of the fee as described in section 5-2016. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3019. - Revocation. 
If a license is issued for a bingo game and the holder or owner thereof shall violate any part of the provisions of this article, or shall aid or abet in the violation of the same, or shall violate any part of the laws of this state regulating bingo and bingo games, or shall aid or abet in the violation of the same, on conviction thereof, such license shall be subject to revocation addition to all other penalties and not in lieu thereof. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3020. - Opening and closing hours. 
All bingo games shall be required to close a 2:55 a.m. and shall not reopen again until 7:00 a.m. of the same day except on Saturday evenings when they must close at 12:00 midnight. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3021. - Location of bingo games. 
Bingo games as allowed and authorized by state law and this article shall be operated only upon those premises as designated by state law and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3022. - Minors prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or organization in charge of a bingo game to permit or allow in such room where bingo games are being conducted, any minor (under the age of eighteen (18)) or to allow any minor (under the age of eighteen (18)) to play at any such bingo games. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3023. - Disorderly conduct; prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or organization in charge of any bingo game within the city to permit or allow any loud, profane, obscene, vulgar or boisterous talking within any premises in which a bingo game is being conducted within the city, or to permit any kind of disorderly conduct or other unlawful conduct within such premises. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3024. - Gaming hall and/or emporiums. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to engage in, maintain or operate a gaming hall or emporium for the playing of bingo without first obtaining from the city, a license to keep and operate such a gaming hall or emporium. 
(b)  A gaming hall or emporium is defined as any establishment owned and/or operated by any person, firm, partnership, or corporation for the purpose of providing premises, facilities, equipment, or personnel to non-profit organizations for the purpose of holding, operating or maintaining non-profit bingo games. 
(c)  The license fee for a gaming hall or emporium shall be as set out in section 5-2016. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
ARTICLE F. - JUNK DEALERS 

Sec. 5-3025. - Definitions. 
Except where the context indicates otherwise, the words "junk dealer" as used in this article shall mean any person engaged as principal, officer, agent or employee in the business of buying gathering, selling, soliciting, peddling, keeping, storing, or gathering in junk as defined by this article. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3026. - Junk dealer's business registration required; compliance with article. 
No person shall engage in the business of junk dealer, junk buyer, junk peddler, or junk gatherer without a license and payment of occupation tax therefore from the city, and without complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3027. - Application; certain persons disqualified. 
Every person desiring to engage in the business of dealing in junk as a junk buyer, operating or conducting a junkyard, a junk peddler or junk gatherer in the city shall make application to the city specifying therein the place where such business is to be carried on. Such application shall be signed by the applicant who shall be recommended in writing by at least three (3) citizens of the city of good reputation certifying to the reputation, fair name and moral character of the applicant; provided, no license shall be granted to any person who has within five (5) years prior to the presentation of such application, been convicted in any court of buying, receiving or concealing stolen property, nor shall any license be granted to any person who on account of moral character based on conviction within five (5) years of application of a crime of moral turpitude is unfit to engage in such business. The offenses listed herein are deemed to be reasonably related to the purpose of the regulation and are clearly articulated reasons to deny the license provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3028. - Bond. 
If application required by section 5-3027 shall be granted, before any license shall be issued the applicant shall post a bond payable to the city in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned to comply with the ordinances of the city and to make good any losses occasioned by violations thereof, and each applicant granted a license to operate as a junk peddler, junk buyer or junk gatherer shall execute a bond payable to the director of finance of the city in the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), conditioned to pay the city for the use and benefit of any and all persons sustaining injury, loss or damages on account of dishonest, fraudulent, immoral or improper conduct of the business so registered, and the bond shall be renewed each year and upon the same conditions; provided, the sureties in all such bonds shall be approved by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3029. - Revocation. 
(a)  The mayor and city council shall have and do hereby retain the right, power and privilege of revoking any permits, license and privileges granted to such applicant under the terms of this article. 
(b)  The violation of any provision of this article by any business person registered or his/her servant, agent or employee shall be cause for the revocation of such license. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3030. - Transporting junk without license; lettering of vehicle. 
It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to peddle or transport junk in the city without a license, and any vehicle used in such transportation shall have printed on each side thereof in large letters of not less than six (6) inches in height the name of the registered junk buyer, junk peddler or junk gatherer operating such vehicle, and the registration number of such junk buyer, junk peddler or junk gatherer. For the purposes of this article, recycling companies and operators shall be considered junk dealers. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3031. - Items which are considered junk. 
Junk shall consist of: 
(a)  Any wrecked, dismantled, worn-out, burned, damaged, out of order or broken-down automobile, motorcycle, truck, tires, tubes, lamp, stove, wire, battery, jewelry, automobile body, cart, truck, milk bottles, electric fixtures, gas fixtures, toys, cabs, railway rails, heater, radio, fence, radiator, furniture, television, water hose, air brakes, fire hose, sweeper, vacuum cleaner, vehicle, pump, wheel, builder's hardware, railroad, knuckle pins, plumbing, plumbing fixtures, railroad brasses, mantels, sewer, sewer cover, manhole cover, storm water inlet cover, grating, books, swings, musical instruments, engine, old gold, old jewelry, old silver, toys, clocks, pistols, guns, surgical dressing, electric fans, fire sets, surveyor's instruments, tools, railroad journals, railroad equipment, lawn mowers, chandeliers, electric wiring, electric switches, transformers or any other kind of metal, wood, glass, china, textile, plastic or mineral substance, scrap, thing or material dismantled, processed, gathered, received, bought, sold or held for storage or sale, except as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Any part of any wrecked, dismantled, damaged, burned, worn-out, broken-down, out-of-order or used engine, automobile, motorcycle, bicycle, tricycle, truck, wagon, buggy, cart, cab, van, trailer, car, locomotive, railroad car, railroad equipment, motor bus, carburetor, battery, transformer, electric fixtures, electric switch, electric appliance, gas fixtures, gas appliance, plumbing fixtures, bed, bed springs, water pipe, pump, water fixtures, stove, heater, house furniture, range, radiator, television, radio, fence, lamp; grate, mantel, swing, musical instruments, watch, clock, toy, park, equipment, surgical instruments, pistols, guns, tools, sweeper, vacuum sweeper, electric fan, surveyor's instruments, lawn mower, plow or any metal, china, wood, plastic, glass, textile, mineral thing, scrap or material gathered, received, bought, sold, processed, dismantled, held or offered for storage or sale, except, as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3032. - Articles not included. 
Junk shall not include any: 
(a)  New, undamaged or unused property; 
(b)  Property in the hands of the ultimate consumer or user thereof; 
(c)  Property in the hands of a seller not engaged as principal or agent for another in the business of gathering, purchasing, selling or dealing in junk; 
(d)  Property in the hands of any bona fide dealer prevented from obtaining new items or parts by government regulations adopted to conserve or restrict the use of scarce or critical materials, substances or services for national security purposes; 
(e)  Property taken in pledge by bona fide licensed pawnbrokers or precious metal dealers; 
(f)  Property in the hands of any bona fide machine shop, garage or other service establishment for its own use in repairing or servicing machines, vehicles, equipment, engines, mechanical and other devices or things of its patrons or customer when it cannot secure new merchandise because of government regulations adopted to conserve or restrict the use of scarce or critical materials, substances or services for national security purposes; 
(g)  Property in the hands of any bona fide manufacturer, processor or wholesale or retail dealer exclusively in the business of dealing in new or unused merchandise; 
(h)  Property in the hands of the United States, the state or any political subdivision thereof; and 
(i)  Property in the hands of any duly authorized or licensed common carrier while in transit. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3033. - Used property. 
Property shall be considered "used" for the purpose of this article when it has been acquired by a consumer for his/her use but not for resale by itself or in connection with any other property. Also, property shall be considered used in manufacturing, building, erecting, repairing, making, developing, producing, creating, processing, extending, enlarging, improving, changing or altering any product or part thereof, or when it has for any purpose been devoted to the use for which it was intended. 
Sec. 5-3034. - Requisites to purchase, receive, junk by junk dealer; report to police. 
(a)  Every person, registered to carry on the business covered by this article shall make a record in a book kept for that purpose of the purchase, acquisition, receipt or acceptance of any junk as defined by section 5-3031 or property to be converted into junk as defined by section 5-3031, such record to be made at the time of acquiring, receiving or accepting of any junk or property. At the close of each day's business such licensee shall mail or deliver to the chief of police of the city a report in legible English including a list of each article purchased, received, acquired or accepted with the name and address of the person from whom acquired, purchased, received or accepted. The record book that junk dealers are required to maintain by this section to keep shall at all reasonable times be kept open for inspection by the chief of police, any police officer or detective of the city, and the mayor and members of city council. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to buy, receive or possess any junk without first providing to the chief of police of the city in writing a report compliant with the provisions herein. 
C.  The report shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name of the person from whom the junk is to be acquired; 
(2)  A full description of the material to be acquired; 
(3)  The physical business address or house address of the person from whom it is to be acquired (post office boxes shall not be acceptable); 
(4)  The location of the material to be acquired, giving the house or business street address; 
(5)  The price to be paid for such junk; 
(6)  A description of each item of junk acquired; 
(7)  Any VIN or other identifying number found on the junk; 
(8)  The date junk was acquired; 
(9)  A description of the person from whom the junk is acquired including age, sex, race, height, weight, eye color, hair color or any identifying marks, scars or tattoos, driver's license number or state issued ID card number or other similar identification bearing a photograph of the seller; 
(10)  Signature of the seller; 
(11)  Any original bill of sale or invoice related to the junk; and 
(12)  An accurate description of the article purchased, acquired, received or accepted and the amount of money or other consideration paid therefore and the name and address of the person furnishing the junk or property. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3035. - Inspection by chief of police. 
When a report is made to the chief of police for junk, it shall be his/her duty to review the report or to designate a police officer to make such review. The person making the inspection shall make a written report of the results of the report and compare the same to any list of missing or stolen property reported to the police. A copy of the reports shall be kept in the office of the chief of Police. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3036. - Record of junk. 
Each junk dealer shall keep a record of all junk handled by him as otherwise provided by this article. The person handling same shall keep a record of not only the junk but of the person from whom it was acquired. At a minimum, the record shall contain the information required in section 5-3034. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3037. - Segregation of articles believed to be stolen. 
If after review of the report provided in section 5-3034 the police officer shall have or discover reasonable cause to believe that any of such junk is stolen property after notice, it shall be the junk dealer's duty to segregate the articles the police believes to be stolen and it shall be unlawful for the person in possession thereof to remove, dispose of, mutilate, alter, disfigure or interfere with the property so segregated until the lapse of ten (10) days from the date of inspection. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3038. - Dealing with and employing minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to buy or receive any junk from any person under the age of eighteen (18) years except when such person has the written consent of his parent or guardian. 
(b)  It shall unlawful for any junk dealer to employ, apprentice, engage, suffer, cause or allow any minor under the age of eighteen (18) years to be employed, apprenticed or engaged to work in any junk yard or on any junk vehicle, wagon or other junk gathering device, as driver, operator or in other capacity in connection with junk business. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3039. - Concealing junk. 
It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to conceal junk in or under any residence or house, or by burying it under the, ground, or by concealing it in any stable, barn, woodshed, coal house or other building, outhouse or otherwise or in any other place whatsoever, where the same is not open for inspection. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3040. - Changing form of junk within ten (10) days of inspection. 
It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to melt, cut, mash, or disfigure any junk or material, or to dismantle, alter, tear down, process or change the condition of any property acquired as or for junk by him until the lapse of ten (10) days from the report thereof as hereinafter provided to the police. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3041. - Receipt of unreported junk by common carriers. 
It shall be unlawful for any common carrier or other person to knowingly receive or accept for any purpose, except as authorized by law, from any junk dealer any junk covered by this article unless the same has been reported as provided in 5-3034. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3042. - Purchase of unreported junk. 
It shall be unlawful for any person whether a licensed dealer or otherwise, to buy or receive from a junk dealer, buyer, peddler or gatherer any junk unless such material shall have been reported as provided in section 5-3034. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3043. - Melting unreported junk. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating a brass or copper foundry or any machine shop or foundry or furnace to place any junk as defined in section 5-3031 in any such furnace or in a melting pot to be melted or disfigured or rendered unrecognizable or more difficult of identification unless such material shall have been first reported as provided in section 5-5046. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3044. - Melting pots. 
It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to own, possess or operate or cause any melting pot or furnace to be operated at any junk yard or elsewhere in connection with any junk business unless the junk dealer operates a recycling facility and the report and ten (10) day hold required by section 5-3034 has been conducted. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3045. - Records. 
(a)  Every person, registered to carry on the business covered by this article shall make a record in a book kept for that purpose of the purchase, acquiring, receiving or accepting of any junk as defined by section 5-3031 or property to be converted into junk as defined by section 5-3031, such record to be made at the time of acquiring, receiving or accepting of any junk or property, and to consist of an accurate description of the article so purchased, acquired, received or accepted and of the amount of money or other consideration paid thereof and the name and address of the person furnishing the junk or property as well as the information required under section 5-3034. At the close of each day's business such licensee shall mail or deliver to the chief of police of the city a report in legible English including a list of each article purchased, received, acquired or accepted with the name and address of the person from whom acquired, purchased, received or accepted as well as the information required under section 5-3034. 
(b)  The record book that junk dealers are required to maintain by this section shall at all reasonable times be kept open for inspection by the chief of police, any police officer or detective of the city, and the mayor and members of city council. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3046. - Business hours for junk dealers, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer, junk peddler, junk buyer, or junk gatherer to handle junk, as a dealer, gatherer, buyer or peddler or otherwise before sunrise or after sunset. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3047. - Fees. 
The fee for a junk dealer's license shall be set out in section 5-2016. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
ARTICLE G. - SCRAP PROCESSORS 

Sec. 5-3048. - Definitions. 
Except where the context indicates otherwise, the words "scrap processor" as used in this article shall mean any person engaged as principal, officer, agent or employee in the business of crushing, cutting up or otherwise permanently destroying any item, object or thing which is made from or partially made from metal, steel, or iron, which shall include but not be limited to motor vehicles, motor vehicle parts and/or motor vehicle accessories. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3049. - Scrap processors license required; occupation tax paid; compliance with article. 
No person shall engage in the business of scrap processor without a license and occupation tax certificate from the city, and without complying with the provisions of this article. Scrap processor may also engage in junk dealing and/or recycling, however the more expansive regulations shall apply if any material beyond that set out in section 5-3048 is accepted by the processor. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3050. - Application, certain person disqualified. 
Every person desiring to engage in the business of scrap processor, in the city shall make application to the city specifying therein the place where such business is to be carried on. Such application shall be signed by the applicant who shall certify that the applicant has not within five (5) years prior to the presentation of such application, been convicted in any court of buying, receiving or concealing stolen property. A license shall not be granted to any person, who has been convicted in any court of buying, receiving or concealing stolen property within five (5) years prior to the presentation of such application such requirements are deemed rationally related to the regulation of scrap processor set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3051. - Revocation. 
(a)  The mayor and city council shall have and does hereby retain the right, power and privilege of revoking any permits, licenses, and privileges granted to such applicant under the terms of this article. 
(b)  The violation of any provision of this article by the applicant of the license or his servant, agent or employee shall be cause for administrative revocation of such license. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3052. - Classification of persons from whom items are purchased and/or received. 
The following classifications shall apply to all parties from which items are purchased and/or received: 
(a)  Class (A): Any registered scrap, junk dealer or wrecker company whose name appears on each side of the vehicle transporting the items. 
(b)  Class (B): Any individual, party or person who does not possess or who has not obtained a business license to engage in the scrap, junk and/or wrecker business. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3053. - Classifications of items; articles included. 
The following classification of items is included within this article: 
(a)  Class (1): Any motor vehicle whether it is new, used, undamaged, wrecked, dismantled, worn out, burned, damaged, out-of-order, or broken down and any motorcycle whether it is new, used, undamaged, wrecked, dismantled, worn out, burned, damaged, out-of-order, or broken down. 
(b)  Class (2): Any motor vehicle parts and/or accessories and any motorcycle parts and/or accessories whether new, used, undamaged, wrecked, dismantled, worn out, burned, damaged, out-of-order, or broken down. 
(c)  Class (3): Any and all other items, objects or things which are made from or partially made from metal, steel or iron. 
(d)  Class (4): Any and all other items, objects or things made from or partially made from something other than metal, steel or iron. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Secs. 5-3054, 5-3055. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 028-11, § 1, adopted Nov. 21, 2011, repealed former §§ 5-3054, 5-3055, in their entirety which pertained to requisites of purchase for various classes of items and derived from Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, adopted Feb. 21, 2011. 
Sec. 5-3056. - Records. 
The appropriate records and forms as required by this article shall be at all times open to inspection by the chief of police, any police officer or detective of the city. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
ARTICLE H. - PAWNBROKERS 

Sec. 5-3057. - Compliance with requirements. 
No person, firm, partnership or corporation shall directly or indirectly by himself or through others, operate the business of pawnshop or pawnbroker within the city except as provided by this article. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3058. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the words and phrases as used hereinafter shall have the following meaning. 
Employee: Any person engaged or working for a pawnshop or licensed pawnbroker. 
Pawn or pledge: A bailment or assignment of personal property as security for any debt or engagement, redeemable upon certain terms and with implied power of sale upon default. 
Pawnbroker: Any person engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business or purchasing tangible personal property from person or sources other than manufacturers of licensed dealers as a part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this paragraph. 
Pawnshop: Any business which takes or receives, by way of pledge, pawn or exchange, any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind of personal property as security for the repayment of money lent thereon. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3059. - Permit required annually. 
All persons engaged, either as an employee or otherwise, in pawnshop or pawnbroker operation within the city shall file for an annual registration certificate upon forms prescribed by and with the bureau of identification or other designated agency of the East Point Police Department. License, registration certificate, permit and work certificate shall be used synonymously in this article. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3060. - Application for permit; annual fee; occupation tax. 
The application for annual permit required in section 5-3059 shall state the address at which the business operates or proposes to operate. The application shall contain the full name, address, home phone number, business phone number, date of birth and social security number of all such persons together with such additional information as may from time to time be required by the records and identification unit or other designated agency of the East Point Police Department. No registration certificate shall be issued except in compliance with section 5-5076 hereof. Further, no pawnbroker shall commence business unless occupation tax has been paid in addition to the license required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3061. - Permits prerequisite to application for license. 
No license shall be issued to any person, partnership, firm or corporation engaging as a pawnshop or pawnbroker until the registration certificate required in section 5-3059 shall have first been obtained from the records and identification unit or other designated agency of the East Point Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3062. - License required: duration. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of pawnbroker or pawnshop in the city without first obtaining a license. 
(b)  No business license shall be issued to any person to conduct the business of pawnbroker or pawnshop within the city of any period of less than one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3063. - Regulation of employees. 
No person shall be employed by a pawnshop or pawnbroker in any capacity until such person shall have first obtained the registration certificate prescribed under section 5-3059 from the records and identification unit or other designated agency of the East Point Police department. It shall be unlawful for any person to work for any pawnshop or pawnbroker without first acquiring a registration certificate. It shall be unlawful for any pawnshop or pawnbroker to employ or otherwise engage any person who has not first obtained a work registration certificate as described in section 5-3059. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3064. - Restrictions of license and registration certificates to certain persons. 
No license shall be issued to any person, firm, partnership, or corporation which has an owner, stockholder or employee who has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude or any crime of theft, or against property. These standards are deemed to be clearly articulated and rationally related to the objective of the prevention of fencing and laundering of stolen merchandise which this article is designed in part to hinder. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3065. - Records and information to be maintained for inspection by police. 
All pawnbrokers or pawnshops shall keep books wherein there shall be entered an accurate description of all property pledged or traded to them. This description shall include but not necessarily be limited to the following information: 
(a)  Date and time of the transaction; 
(b)  Full name of the person making the pawn ("pledgee") to the pawnbroker; 
(c)  Full name, age, street address, business and home phone numbers of the seller together with the identification numbers of the pledgee's driver's license or some other form of identification containing a photograph of the pledgee; 
(d)  A clear and accurate description and identification of the goods purchased including serial number, model or other identifying marks or numbers ascribed thereon; 
(e)  Price paid for the goods pawned; 
(f)  Number of the check issued for the pawn amount if payment is made by check; and 
(g)  Signature of the pledgee. 
The records maintained in compliance herewith shall be legible English, shall be in chronological order and numbered sequentially. All information must be obtained and no blanks or lines skipped or left incomplete. No obliterations, alterations or erasures may be made. Corrections shall be made by drawing a single ink line through the entry without destroying its legibility. Said records shall be maintained for each purchase and all records maintained for at least four (4) years from the date of purchase. Said records shall be open for inspection by any duly authorized law enforcement officer during the regular business hours or at any reasonable time. Said records shall be kept at the business premises during ordinary hours of business. In the event of the closing of any such business the East Point Police department shall be notified as to the place said records will thereafter be maintained pursuant to the relevant state laws. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3066. - Purchase records required. 
(a)  Each pawnshop or pawnbroker shall record on forms prescribed by the Chief of the East Point Police department, or his designee, the details of each purchase. These records shall be maintained in legible English at the time of each transaction, and each form shall bear the number of the corresponding entry made in the records required in section 5-5077. Each record shall include such information as may be reasonably required by the East Point Police department and shall include but not necessarily be limited to: 
(1)  An accurate description of all articles received in each transaction. The description shall include to the extent possible the maker or manufacturer of each article, any identifying mark, number or initials, a description of shape or pattern, and statement of the kind of materials of which it is made; 
(2)  Date and time of transaction; 
(3)  Name and address of the dealer; 
(4)  Name of the person making the purchase on behalf of the pawnshop or pawnbroker; 
(5)  Full name, date of birth, street address, home and business phone numbers, race, height, weight and gender of the seller as well as a general description of the seller; 
(6)  Number of the seller's valid Georgia driver's license or state issued ID card, or other similar identification bearing a photograph of the seller; and 
(7)  Signature of the seller. 
(b)  Each card or form required by this section shall be delivered or mailed to the chief of police within twenty-four (24) hours after the day on which the transaction occurred, and shall be handled in the following manner. 
(1)  All such forms shall be maintained in a locked container under the direct supervision of the chief of police and shall be available for inspection only for law enforcement purposes. 
(2)  The chief of police may, in his/her discretion, authorize any person to inspect the records for the purpose of locating stolen property, providing said person demonstrates theft of goods by presenting an incident report or other similar document. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3067. - Photographs of firearms received and sellers of firearms. 
(a)  Each dealer shall take a well focused, properly exposed color photograph of all firearms received, which are purchased by the pawnshop or pawnbroker. 
(b)  In addition to photographing the items purchased, the pawnshop or pawnbroker shall take a well focused, properly exposed color photograph of the seller of firearms, and shall attach the photograph to the corresponding form or card required by section 5-3066 above. In addition to the required photographs, seller shall attach to said form a photocopy of any bill of sale, receipt, or other document tending to show the seller's driver's license or other identification required by this article. 
(c)  All photographs required herein may be made with self-developing camera and film system as may be authorized in writing by the chief of the East Point Police department. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3068. - Hours of operation. 
No pawnshop or pawnbroker may be open for the transaction of any business in the city except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3069. - Articles to be retained for thirty days. 
Any pawnshop or pawnbroker shall hold all properties of every kind and description acquired for at least thirty (30) days after the date of acquiring same. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3070. - Dealing with minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any pawnshop or pawnbroker his agents or employees to receive or pawn from minors goods of any character or description. For the purpose of this article, a person shall be considered a minor if he/she has not reached their eighteenth birthday. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3071. - Surety bond. 
No person shall be licensed to conduct the business of pawnshop or pawnbroker in the city, who shall not have first posted, and which must be maintained with the city clerk, a surety bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5000.00), conditioned upon compliance with all laws and ordinances of the city and the state, for prompt payment to any person who sustains any loss or damage on account of in connection with such business, of the amount of such loss or damage, on demand, which bond shall be payable to the city for the use and benefit of the city or any person aggrieved, injured or damaged on account of violation of any law, ordinance, rules or regulation of the city or of the state, or whose loss, injury or damage is occasioned by or in connection with the conduct of such business, the surety on the bond to be a surety company authorized to do business in the state. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3072. - Penalties and suspension. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article be subject to prosecution and punishment pursuant to the provisions of section 1-1006 of this code. Further, the license may be revocable by the city upon violation by any person in the employ of or owner or operator of any pawnshop or pawnbroker of any of the provisions of this ordinance, or other laws, ordinances or regulations of the city or the state. Such revocation of license shall also be upon conviction in any court for a violation of any of the provisions of this article or any ordinance or regulation promulgated hereunder or any laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3073. - License fee. 
Fees for a pawnshop license are set out in Section 5-2016. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
ARTICLE I. - CARNIVALS, EXHIBITIONS, MISCELLANEOUS TEMPORARY BUSINESSES 

Sec. 5-3074. - Carnivals. 
Carnivals shall have approval of the chief of the fire department, or designee, to set up shows and concession and shall be inspected for compliance with public health, safety and welfare. Upon approval of the chief of the fire department, or designee, a regulatory fee shall be paid to the city. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3075. - Vendors at carnivals. 
(a)  For each person engaging in the display of goods, wares, or merchandise in association with a carnival, an annual license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be required. The annual license shall expire on December 31 of each year. The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons engaging in the sale of goods, wares, merchandise and services in conjunction with an association meeting where admission to the event is not open to the general public but is restricted by membership or invitation to a limited class of persons, convention or a professional or association meeting; and such persons shall not be deemed transient vendors for the purpose of this subsection. 
(b)  The City of East Point requires all vendors to exhibit their license. Any, person firm or corporation violating any provision of this article, shall be deemed liable for civil penalties not less than one thousand ($1,000.00) and not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). Each day's continuance of violation shall be considered a separate offense. In addition to the license described herein, occupation tax shall also be required. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3076. - Exhibitions. 
All panorama exhibitions or other shows not otherwise covered shall pay a regulatory fee. All shows exhibiting under tent or tents must have the approval of the chief of the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
ARTICLE J. - FLEA MARKETS 

Sec. 5-3077. - Definitions. 
(a)  Flea market means any business whereby there is operated a center for shopping among collected flea market vendors marketing merchandise to the public from booths, stalls, tables, benches and similar display and marketing configurations and arrangements for the sale of new and used merchandise. Flea markets shall not include antique stores, jewelry stores, coin shops, salvage operations, clothing stores or other businesses of common merchandise with flea markets where the vendor therein is not operating among a collection of similar vendors, All businesses in the city which meet the definition of flea markets above shall be subject to the provisions and regulations of these businesses as are hereinafter set forth. 
(b)  Flea market vendors means all persons, businesses or individuals of every type and character operating among collections of other flea market vendors for retail sales to the public of new and used merchandise in a collected marketing center for sales from stalls, booths, tables, benches and other similar displays or marketing configurations and arrangements. 
(c)  Flea market promoters means all persons, firms or corporations, partnerships or other forms of business entities operating, maintaining and promoting flea markets. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3078. - Application for license. 
All flea market promoters and flea market vendors, prior to the commencement of business, shall first file an application for a license with the city to conduct such business. Such application shall be on forms prescribed by the city and contain such information as, in the opinion of the city, is necessary or proper to regulate this business. In addition to the license fee, the applicant must pay occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3079. - Revocation of license. 
The city may revoke the license of any flea market promoter when the promoter allows the vendor to operate on premises without proper vendor's license, or operation without a promoter's license, or whenever revocation is necessary to prevent vendors engaging in the purchase, sale, barter or trade of stolen property, or to prevent the purchase, sale, barter or trade of property with minors provided the promoter has previously been warned of such activity and has not taken action necessary to prevent a recurrence, such action may also be taken when the flea market promoter repeatedly fails to keep an provide accurate records as required in section 5-3080 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3080. - Records required. 
(a)  Records shall be made of all transactions whether purchase, sale, trade, or barter of any merchandise with transaction or amount is ten dollars ($10.00) or more. The records transaction shall be made on a form or forms prescribed by the city. The form shall be dated and require a description of the property and the amount of the transaction. 
(b)  All sales of used or previously owned merchandise shall, in addition to the foregoing, require an accurate description of the property, including identifying marks and manufacturer's ID numbers of the item sold. Additionally, as to the purchaser of such items, the flea market vendor shall obtain and verify from current valid identification presented by such person, their name, current address, sex, race, height, weight, and date of birth. A current, valid driver's license with photograph shall be positive identification. The city may from time to time prescribe other reasonable, acceptable identification forms where one or more of the identification tools above is not available. 
(c)  All forms required above, shall be held by vendors and furnished to the police department of the city or to the flea market promoter for delivery to the police department of the city. 
(d)  No flea market vendor shall engage in any transaction to purchase or trade for any merchandise or property of a minor. For the purpose of this article, a person is considered to be a minor when such person has not reached his/her eighteenth birthday. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3081. - Holding period for precious metals. 
Any person operating under a flea market promoter's or flea market vendor's license, or any dealer in precious metals or gems who takes, purchases, barters, swaps, or otherwise acquires any gems, numismatic coins, or precious metals as defined in Section 43, Chapter 37 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated relating to dealers on precious metals and gems shall comply with all provisions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 5-3082. - License fee. 
The fee for flea market vendors operating as a part if a flea market promotion consisting of two (2) or more vendors shall be as set out in subsection 5-2016(C)(13). 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
ARTICLE K. - SPECIAL EVENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Art. K has been retitled by the editor from "Festivals and Special Events" to reflect the changes in subject matter of this article. 

Sec. 5-3083. - Special events. 
Special events are required to obtain an administrative permit or a use permit, in accordance with Article D of the City of East Point Zoning Ordinance, from the department of planning and zoning. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article, shall be deemed liable for civil penalties not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). Each day's continuance of violation shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11; Ord. No. 008-13, § 1, 4-15-13) 
Sec. 5-3084. - Special events classifications. 
Each special event shall be categorized as Class A, Class B, Class C, Class D or Class E. 
For classification purposes, the city shall evaluate the application by the anticipated number of persons attending the special event. In estimating this number, no regard shall be given to any estimate of the number of persons who may be anticipated to be in the vicinity of the special event as counter-demonstrators or to show hostility to any message the special event may be perceived as having. Unless such estimate shall appear to have been made in palpable bad faith or otherwise grossly in error, the city shall be guided by the estimate provided by the applicant. If the city determines not to adopt the estimate given by the applicant, the city shall state the reasons in writing on the permit. 
(a)  Class A. A special event at which the attendance is anticipated to be twenty thousand (20,000) or greater persons over the entire period of the special event. 
(b)  Class B. A special event at which the attendance is anticipated to be between ten thousand (10,000) and nineteen thousand nine hundred ninety-nine (19,999) persons over the entire period of the special event. 
(c)  Class C. A special event at which the attendance is anticipated to be between two thousand (2,000) and nine thousand nine hundred ninety-nine (9,999) persons over the entire period of the special event. 
(d)  Class D. A special event at which the attendance is anticipated to be between two hundred fifty (250) and one thousand nine hundred ninety-nine (1,999) persons over the entire period of the special event. 
(e)  Class E. A special event at which the attendance is anticipated to be fewer than two hundred fifty (250) attendees over the entire period of the special event. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11; Ord. No. 008-13, § 2, 4-15-13) 
Sec. 5-3085. - Severability. 
If any section, provision or clause of any part of this chapter shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this chapter as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such individuality shall not be construed to effect the portions of this chapter not so held to be invalid, or the application of this chapter to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent that this chapter would have been adopted and such invalid portion not be included herein. 
(Ord. No. 002-11, § 1, 2-21-11) 
CHAPTER 4. - CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS 

Sec. 5-4001. - Bids and awarding of contracts generally. 
All city buildings, such as public schools, fire engine houses and similar structures shall be built under contract, after advertisement for sealed competitive bids for two (2) weeks prior to the letting of a contract, and such bids shall be submitted, under and according to plans and specially prepared specifications, and the contract shall be awarded to the lowest and best bidder; provided, the city shall have the right to reject any or all bids; and provided further that nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the authorities in charge of any city building from performing any such branches of work by or through the regular employees, or in the case of public institutions, by inmates thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 2-102) 
Sec. 5-4002. - When competitive sealed bids not necessary in construction contracts. 
Any construction contract of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less may be let by the purchasing agent without receiving competitive sealed bids if it is impracticable in the judgment of the purchasing agent to obtain competitive sealed bids. 
(Code 1959, § 2-103) 
Sec. 5-4003. - Approval of plans and specifications of buildings for city; generally. 
No contract for the building or erection of any building for the city shall be let unless or until the plans and specifications for such building have been turned over to and approved by the building official of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 2-104) 
Sec. 5-4004. - Advertising, filing and opening of bids generally. 
Prior to awarding a contract for any municipal work, construction, improvements or repairs, involving an expenditure in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the purchasing agent shall advertise in the official organ in the city and in a daily newspaper once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks, inviting bids to be submitted by responsible contractors, such bids to be filed with the purchasing agent at any time prior to the time set for opening such bids. Bids for less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall be advertised in the manner in which the purchasing agent deems advisable. All bids shall be opened and read at the time designated in the advertisement in the presence of any interested bidder or persons. Such bids shall be tabulated by the purchasing agent and referred to the department head under whose supervision the work is to be performed for his recommendation on awarding such contract. 
(Code 1959, § 2-107) 
Sec. 5-4005. - Certified checks and financial statements to accompany bids; exception. 
Every bid involving twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) or more shall be accompanied by a bid bond, or in lieu thereof, cash or a cashier's or certified check on an East Point or Atlanta bank in the sum of five (5) percent of the amount of the bid. 
(Code 1959, § 2-108; Ord. No. 968-88, § 1, 8-15-88) 
Sec. 5-4006. - Bond of successful bidder. 
The successful bidder in all contracts covered by this chapter shall furnish a bond by a surety company qualified to do business in the city, in the sum of the contract price of the work, which bond must be approved by the council; provided, that if the contract price is less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) no bond shall be required unless the purchasing agent or the city council recommends that such bond be required. 
(Code 1959, § 2-109) 
Sec. 5-4007. - Reference of bids to department head; recommendation of award. 
After the opening and reading of all bids submitted, the bids shall be referred to the head of the department under whom the work is to be done, who shall recommend that the contract be awarded to the bidder whom he considers to be the lowest and best; provided, the council may reject any or all bids. 
(Code 1959, § 2-110) 
Sec. 5-4008. - Award of contract. 
After the head of the department has made his recommendation of award to the council, the council shall make the award of the contract to such bidder as the council may consider lowest and best. 
(Code 1959, § 2-111) 
Sec. 5-4009. - Assignment of lien for public improvement—Authorized. 
The mayor of the city shall have full and complete power and authority, in the name of the city, to sell, transfer, assign, set out and deliver unto such persons as may desire to purchase, all of the city's rights to collect and enforce payment of costs assessed against abutting real estate and the owners thereof for sewers, streets, sidewalks, and street curbing, except the initial cash payment in cases in which the owners of abutting real estate elect to pay such assessments in deferred equal annual installments, and it shall be the duty of the mayor to sell and transfer such rights in all such cases where possible, but such rights so sold and transferred shall not be sold by the city at a discount. The sales price shall be not less than the full amount of the balance of such cost plus accrued interest thereon at twelve (12) percent per annum from the date of the assessing ordinance by which the amount of such rights have been fixed. 
(Code 1959, § 2-112; Ord. No. 973-88, § 1, 11-21-88) 
Sec. 5-4010. - Same—Form. 
All persons electing to pay costs assessed against them or their properties for sewers, sidewalks, streets and street curbing shall evidence their election to pay one (1) part in cash and the balance in deferred consecutive equal annual installments by execution of a note in substantially the following form: 
"$ _____      _____ , year___ 
East Point, Georgia 
_______, year___  East Point, Georgia 
The undersigned owner of abutting real estate at the street address below and described on the back hereof hereby elects and promises to pay to the City of East Point, Georgia, its successors and assigns the balance of the ___ assessment levied against said abutting real estate in the amount stated in the upper left corner hereof in three (3) consecutive equal annual installments commencing on the_______day of_______, year___, (which is the date the assessing ordinance was finally adopted) with twelve (12) percent interest thereon from the date the assessing ordinance was finally adopted, for which the city has a valid and binding lien against real estate, the force and effect of which lien is not affected hereby, and the lien shall remain of full force and effect until the amount secured thereby shall have been paid in full. If any installment of this note is not paid within thirty (30) days after its due date, all remaining unpaid installments shall become immediately due and payable without notice or election, formal or otherwise, and thereupon an execution shall issue against the lot and the person who was the owner thereof as of the date of the adoption of the ordinance providing for the improvement and assessing the cost thereof, which execution shall be levied upon the real estate, and, after advertising the real estate for sale once a week for four (4) weeks, the same shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash for the unpaid balance of said assessment, with interest and costs of such execution, levy, advertisement, and sale as in case of tax sales for said City. 
This_______day of _______, year___. 
Whose Street and Post Office Address is:_______

CHAPTER 1. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 
Footnotes:
