(16) Article 28 of the East Point Fire Prevention code governing precaution against fire, general is hereby amended by adding a new section to be numbered 28.17, 28.18, 28.19, 28.20 and to read as follows: 
Sec. 28.17. Tar Heating Equipment. It is hereby prohibited for any person, firm or corporation to heat tar, asphalt, pitch or other combustible material in, on or within fifty (50) feet of any building, structure, combustible material, or substance for roofing, weatherproofing, waterproofing, or insulation purposes except in conformance with the following safety requirements: 
(a)  The fire prevention bureau shall be notified before any kettle or other container used for heating the above mentioned materials, shall be placed in, on, or within fifty (50) feet of any building, structure, combustible material or substance, and no such kettle or heating equipment shall be operated within any building, except by the written permission of the chief of fire prevention bureau of the City of East Point. 
(b)  There shall be a kettle operator experienced with the equipment involved, familiar with the fire hazards, the precautions to be observed, and the use of fire extinguishing facilities required, in attendance at the kettle at all times the kettle is being fired or heated, and so remain until the temperature of the kettle and its contents does not exceed three hundred fifty (350) degrees Fahrenheit as may be determined by a thermometer which shall be provided and maintained at or near the kettle at all times. 
(c)  There shall be at all times at or near the kettle and readily accessible to the operator, one approved Class B fire extinguisher with a minimum rating that equals or exceeds the Class B Hazard. At least one 20 B rated approved fire extinguisher. 
(d)  Not more than six hundred (600) pounds of combustible material or substance to be heated shall be stored within twenty-five (25) feet of any kettle while same is in operation. 
(e)  No kettle using flammable liquid for fuel shall be refueled while in operation and any flammable liquid placed within twenty-five (25) feet of a kettle shall be stored in an approved safety container which shall be kept sealed or closed at all times the kettle is in operation. 
(f)  No mop or other applicator which has been used or submerged in tar, pitch, asphalt or other combustible material or substance in the process of applying roofing, weather-proofing, waterproofing, or insulation shall be left overnight in, on or within twenty-five (25) feet of any building, structure, or combustible material or substance. 
(g)  Fired roofing kettles shall not be operated on roofs of buildings. 
(h)  All improved streets shall be protected from burning by use of sand and other noncombustible materials under roofing kettles. Streets shall be cleaned of all excess tar and other debris upon completion of work. 
(i)  No person shall use solid fuel or Class I flammable liquids as fuel for a roofing kettle. 
(j)  Compressed and liquefied gases shall be stored, handled, transported and used in accordance with applicable provisions of NFPA codes and standards. Storage and handling of compressed and liquefied gases not covered by NFPA codes and standards shall comply with applicable provisions of: Standards of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI); Code of Federal Regulations, Title 49, Parts 173 through 190 (transportation); Pressure Vessels, Section VIII, of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code (container fabrication); or the container fabrication specifications of the American Petroleum Institute. 
(16) Sec. 28.18. Vacant Structures. 
Every person owning, or in charge or control of, any vacant and/or fire damaged or unsafe building or structure shall remove therefrom all accumulations of flammable or combustible contents, waste, debris or rubbish and shall securely lock, barricade, or otherwise secure all doors, windows and other openings thereof. The premises shall be maintained free and clear of any waste or hazardous materials. 
(17) Sec. 28.19. 
Gas connections to stoves, heaters and other appliances shall be made by approved metal pipe or by approved metal tubing securely fastened in place, except that for devices which require a moveable connection, approved, flexible tubing may be used provided there is no shut-off on the device. 
(18) Sec. 28.20. Hazardous Gas in Balloons and Other Objects. 
It is prohibited to inflate toy balloons or other objects with any flammable, oxidizing, toxic, corrosive, or reactive gas including hydrogen. Air and inert gases, such as Nitrogen and Helium, are not prohibited for this purpose. It is prohibited to sell or to use toy balloons or objects so inflated. 
(19) Article 31, Section 8.8 is amended, to include AAI (Agricultural Ammonia Institute, Memphis, Tennessee) No. M-1, 1967 edition. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 18, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2038. - Modifications. 
The fire chief or the chief's designee shall have the powers to modify any of the provisions of the applicable codes upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or the owner's or lessee's duly appointed agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the fire chief or the chief's designee shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1959, § 10-5; Ord. No. 001-07, § 17, 1-16-07 
Sec. 6-2039. - Barbecue grills in multi-family dwellings. 
Georgia Law provides that no charcoal or liquefied petroleum gas or liquid fueled burners shall be kindled or maintained on balconies/patios or within ten (10) feet of combustible patios on ground floors. No grills may be used or stored in breezeways, balconies/patios, stairways, or exit access areas. The city further prohibits the use of grills, pits, or outside fireplaces on balconies or patios within ten (10) feet of patios or balconies in multifamily dwellings. 
(Code 1959, § 10-6; Ord. No. 001-07, § 19, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2040. - Fees for response to false alarm. 
(a)  Automatic response alarm systems. For a fire response to any false alarm of an automatic response fire alarm system, the fire chief or the fire chief's designee shall charge and collect a fine from the person or business having or maintaining the automatic response alarm system on the premises owned or occupied by such person or business on and after the third alarm according to the fire department false alarm fee schedule. The fire department false alarm fee schedule shall be posted in the office of the city clerk and the city fire marshal. 
(B)  Independent alarm systems. For the second fire response within a calendar year to an alarm activation of an independent fire alarm system that proves to be false, the corrective actions to be taken are the same as prescribed in the previous section. On the third response to a premise within a calendar year, the independent alarm system shall be deemed a nuisance. Failure of the alarm user to abate such nuisance will make the alarm user subject to penalties and fines as provided for in the fire department false alarm fee schedule referenced above. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 20, 1-16-07) 
Secs. 6-2041—6-2043. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 001-07, § 21, adopted January 16, 2007, repealed former §§ 6-2041—6-2043 in their entirety. 
Former § 6-2041 pertained to notification of the fire department of inoperative fire safety equipment and derived from this codification. 
Former §§ 6-2042 and 6-2043 pertained to fire lanes. Former § 6-2042 derived from Ord. No. 1002-90, § 1, adopted Sept. 15, 1986. Former § 6-2043 derived from Ord. No. 1002, § 3, 9-15-86; Ord. No. 944C-87, §§ 1, 2, 5-4-87. 
Sec. 6-2044. - Parking in fire lane prohibited. 
The parking of motor vehicles in designated fire lanes shall be prohibited at all times. This includes delivery trucks and vendors. The East Point Fire Department shall enforce and ensure that no vehicles are allowed to park in or obstruct an approved fire lane. 
(Ord. No. 1002-90, § 3, 9-15-86) 
Sec. 6-2045. - Permanent emergency escape ladders for multi-story permanent dwellings. 
Effective November 1, 2006, all multiple story single or multi-family dwellings over fifteen (15) feet in height are required to provide a means of egress in the form of permanent emergency escape ladders at the time of construction. Where the story of the multiple story single or multi-family dwellings over fifteen (15) feet in height contains one or more bedrooms or sleeping rooms, a permanent emergency escape ladder is required in each bedroom or sleeping room. The approved permanent emergency escape ladder shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer installation instructions. The word "approved" is used as defined in the Southern Building Code Congress International (SBCCI) Building Code which is the code used as the Georgia State Building Code and approved by the City of East Point. The height requirement of this provision shall be measured from the foundation to the roofline. 
(Ord. No. 013-06, § 1, 9-18-06) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 013-06, § 1, adopted Sept. 18, 2006, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 6-2044. In order to avoid conflicts in section numbering the editor has redesignated the provisions of said ordinance as § 6-2045. 
Sec. 6-2046. - Automatic residential sprinkler requirement. 
(a)  All new buildings/structures, including but not limited to multifamily residential structures such as apartments, townhouses, condominiums, duplexes and triplexes, and one-family dwellings with side yard setbacks less than seven feet, shall be protected throughout by an approved supervised automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with the current State of Georgia adopted Edition of NFPA 13, 13D, and 13R, Standards for the Installation of Sprinkler systems. A sprinkler control valve and water flow device shall be provided for each floor. This is not to restrict the fire chief or his/her designee from requiring the installation of a water-based fire protection system and/or smoke detection system if, in the option of the fire official, and for the public interest, the health and welfare of the firefighters, and the protection of human life, such a system would serve to benefit all parties that may be affected by the type of construction, hazard of content, limited access to the structure, and for other purposes. The kind of system shall be determined by the requirements of NFPA 13, 13D, and 13R, based on the type of construction and the tenants' ability to evacuate. Residential sprinklers shall be provided within dwelling units, apartments and guest rooms. 
(b)  "New," for the purpose of this section, shall include any addition to existing buildings or structures, other than single- family residential, which shall be deemed to be new in the event such building or structure is subject to substantial renovation. For the purpose of this section, the term "substantial renovation" shall mean any construction project involving exits or internal-external features of such building or structure costing more than or equal to thirty-five (35) percent of the building's or structure's gross assessed value according to county tax records at the time of such renovation, repair, remodeling, or replacement thereof. 
(c)  Existing buildings, when required to have automatic sprinkler protection by subsection (b) above, shall be retrofitted for automatic sprinklers are required by the fire official in accordance with NFPA 13, 13D, and 13R, when the cost of renovation exceeds thirty-five (35) percent of the latest approved value of the building. These buildings shall be required to upgrade in the renovation to meet all current codes, standards, and ordinances as applicable to required fire protection and life safety systems. Historical buildings may require an equivalency concept and working through of the process in conjunction with National Historical Society. The owner is responsible for having the system inspected and tested in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 25-2-13(a)(2). 
(d)  Where required, post indicator valves (PIV) and fire department connections (FDC) shall be located at or near the main entry site but no closer than one and one-quarter (¼ times the height of the building. Appropriate signage shall be provided to designate PIV and fire department connections. 
(Ord. No. 016-06, § 1, 10-16-06) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 001-07, §§ 22—33, amended this chapter by adding sections designated as §§ 6-2045, 6-2047—6-2057. In order to avoid conflicts in section numbering the editor has renumbered the provisions of §§ 22—33 of Ord. No. 001-07 as set out below. 
Sec. 6-2047. - Permits. 
The fire chief or the fire chief designee is authorized to charge fees, on a yearly, one time or location basis for the issuance of permits for certain activities or storing of certain materials that constitute fire hazards. The official list of fire department permit fees shall be posted in the office of the city clerk. The minimum fee for inspection and permit issuance for any activity not listed shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 22, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2048. - Habitual violators. 
Any facility found to have repeat fire code violations of the same nature shall be classified as habitual violators. These facilities shall receive citations when violations are found to exist, and the time frame for corrections shall be immediate. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 23, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2049. - Fire watch—Duty of owner or operator to provide service. 
It shall be the duty of all persons owning or operating any business, or any of the following occupancies: industrial, storage, places of assembly, educational, health care or penal, mercantile or others when declared by the fire chief or the chief's designee to be an imminent fire or life hazard to provide approved fire watch service throughout such occupancy until such time as the fire chief or the chief's designee of the fire department shall determine and certify that such service is not necessary in order to protect persons and property. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 24, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2050. - Outside buring. 
The outside burning of trash, debris, leaves, wood, tree limbs, or other substances, including the open burning of grass, weeds, or vegetation is unlawful in the city and shall be prohibited except lawful grills, pits or outdoor fireplaces may be used for cooking purposes only. Commercial burning will be permitted only with a permit issued from the East Point Fire Prevention Department. No permit shall be issued until a site inspection is performed, the weather, and wind conditions must be deemed as safe. This permit will require authorization from the fire chief or the chief's designee. Commercial burning shall be performed in pits, with air curtain destructors for the purpose of land clearing. All pit fires shall be operated in strict accordance with the "Air Curtain Destructor Operating Guide and Procedures" published by the North Georgia Region on Environmental Protection Division. Pit fires shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  The pit shall be at least three hundred (300) feet from any structure or public road. Air curtain destructors (ACD) used solely for utility line clearing or road clearing may be located at a lesser distance upon approval of the fire chief or his/her designee. 
(2)  Only wood wastes consisting of trees, logs, brush and stumps may be burned. Sawdust or other densely packed wood wastes, paper (any type), chemically treated, coated or impregnated wood, or non-wood construction materials cannot be burned. 
(3)  No more than one (1) ACD can be operated within a ten (10) acre area at one time, or there must be at least one thousand (1000) feet between any two-air curtain destructors. The air curtain destructor must be under control of a trained operator at all times during operation. 
(4)  Air curtain destructor must be able to pass an even, non-turbulent flow of air across the top of the pit. Air curtain destructors with an air duct or manifold that has been altered by bends, dents, holes, etc., and are incapable of providing an even and non-turbulent flow of air across the top of the pit shall not be approved for use. 
(5)  The air curtain destructor shall be operated in a manner to prevent air, land or water pollution, safety/health hazards or nuisances. 
(6)  Tires or other rubber products, plastics, heavy oils or asphalted-based or impregnated materials shall not be used to start or maintain the operation of the air curtain destructors. 
(7)  No smoke emissions exceeding forty (40) percent capacity may be produced during operations except for a reasonable period during ignition and charging of the pit. 
(8)  When the pit is cleaned of ash, airborne particulates are to be minimized by wetting or mixing the ashes with dirt. 
(9)  Diesel fuel for kerosene may be used to start pit fires. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 25, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2051. - Removal of dangerous and hazardous containers. 
No automobile or vehicular or other wrecking yard, junk yard, or waste salvage or waste material handling plant or reclaimed plant or other shall be allowed to process any object without first removing and rendering completely safe any object that may cause an explosion or fire or might cause danger or damage to life or property. Such objects include but are not limited to gasoline tanks, propane tanks, butane tanks, flammable or combustible liquid tanks or container, compressed gas tanks, cylinders and any other dangerous and hazardous object. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 26, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2052. - Vacant structure maintenance. 
(a)  The owner or operator shall maintain and operate any residential, commercial, institutional, or industrial structure in accordance with the following: Maintenance of grounds. The grounds of the premises and of all structures thereon shall be kept free of all nuisances, and any hazards to the safety of other occupants, customers, pedestrians, neighbors, surrounding neighborhoods, and other persons utilizing the premises or viewing the premises from the outside, and free of unsanitary conditions, and any of the foregoing shall be promptly removed and abated by the owner or operator. It shall be the duty of the owner or operator to keep the premises free of hazards, which include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Brush, weeds, broken glass, stumps, roots, obnoxious growths, and accumulations of filth, garbage, trash, refuse, debris, and inoperative machinery; 
(2)  Dead and dying trees, tree limbs and decorative landscaping specifically installed; 
(3)  Loose and overhanging objects which by reason of location above ground level, constitute a danger of falling on persons in the vicinity thereof; 
(4)  Holes, excavations, breaks, projections, obstructions, and excretions of pets and other animals on paths, walks, driveways, parking lots and parking areas and other parts of the premises; 
(5)  Inadequate run-off drains for storm waters; and 
(6)  Sources of infestation. 
(b)  The exterior of the premises and the condition of necessary structures shall be maintained so that the premises and all buildings thereon shall reflect a level of maintenance in keeping with the standards of the neighborhood and such that the premises and structures shall not constitute a blighting factor for adjoining property owners nor an element leading to the progressive deterioration and down-grading of the neighborhood including the following: 
(1)  Foundations, floors, and walls which are not structurally sound; 
(2)  Chimneys and flue vent attachments which are not safe, durable, smoke tight, and capable of withstanding the action of flue gasses; 
(3)  Exterior porches, landings, balconies, stairs, and fire escapes which are not provided with banisters or railings properly designed, installed, and maintained to minimize the hazard of falling; 
(4)  All permanent signs and billboards exposed to public view permitted by reason of other regulations or as a lawful nonconforming use shall be maintained in good repair. Any signs which have excessively weathered, those upon which the paint has excessively peeled or cracked, or those whose supporting members have deteriorated so that they no longer meet the structural requirements of the building code, shall, with their supporting members, be removed or put into a good state of repair. All non-operative or broken electrical signs shall be repaired or shall, with their supporting members, be removed; 
(5)  All store fronts and walls exposed to public view shall be kept in a good state of repair; 
(6)  Any awning or marquee and its accompanying structural members shall be maintained in a good state of repair. In the event said awnings or marquees are made of cloth, plastic, or a similar material, said cloth or plastic, where exposed to public view, shall not show evidence of excessive weathering, discoloration, ripping, tearing, or other holes. Nothing herein shall be construed to authorize any encroachment on streets, sidewalks, or other parts of the public domain; and all vacant buildings shall be kept secure against unauthorized entry and shall be secured in accordance with the specifications set forth: 
a.  The minimum specifications to secure a vacant building shall be as follows unless otherwise approved by the fire chief. 
i.  Except for the front door, all windows and doors on all levels, through which access to the interior of the building can be made, shall be secured from the interior of the building with inch exterior grade plywood sheathing. All window boards shall be fit to screen inset molding; 
ii.  All fabricated boards shall be painted with one (1) coat of primer on the exterior surface; 
iii.  All two (2) inches by four (4) inches interior wood stock used in securing the sheathing shall be padded with carpet type material of minimum dimensions four (4) inches by eight (8) inches permanently attached. This padding shall be adjusted to prevent damage to interior walls and wood trim; 
iv.  A dead bolt lock shall be installed on the front exterior door above the existing lock. 
b.  All openings must remain secured herein and the exterior of the building must remain in compliance with all applicable provisions to this Code. Failure of the owner or operator to maintain the secured vacant building as prescribed herein shall subject them to legal action without further notice from the fire chief. 
Further, when a vacant, burned or otherwise damaged or deteriorated building or structure has been boarded, corrective action to bring the building or structure into full compliance with the Code shall begin within 30 days after the building or structure has been boarded and shall be completed and the boarding removed within a period of six months from the date of the boarding. The building or structure shall be subject to an inspection beginning four months from the date of the boarding. 
Failure to have begun the corrective action to bring the building or the structure into full compliance with this Code within thirty (30) days after the building or structure has been boarded, and the failure to allow city code enforcement officers to gain access to the interior of the building or structure after proper notification, shall each constitute a separate violation of this Code. 
(c)  The exterior of every structure or accessory structure shall be maintained in a good state of repair and all surfaces thereof shall be kept painted or whitewashed where necessary for purposes of preservation. All surfaces shall be maintained free of broken glass, loose shingles, crumbling stone or brick, excessive peeling paint or other condition reflective of deterioration or inadequate maintenance. 
(d)  The owner of any improved parcel of land in the city shall cause the officially assigned street number for such parcel to be posted on the front of the building or in the front yard so as to be clearly visible from the street. Street numbers shall be posted in numerals no less than two and one-half (2½) inches in height. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or operator of any lot, tract, parcel of land or premises in the city, to have, permit or allow the growth of kudzu or excessive growth of grass, weeds, shrubs, or bushes thereon. 
(f)  Temporarily unoccupied buildings, apartments, structures, premises or portions thereof with the exception of buildings in portions of buildings undergoing additions, alteration, repairs or change of occupancy in accordance with 
the International Building Codes shall be secured, maintained, and protected in accordance with this section. 
(1)  Security; Exterior openings and interior openings accessible to other tenants shall be boarded, locked, blocked, or other wise protected to prevent entry by unauthorized individuals. Broken windows in apartments must be replaced with glass and cannot be boarded unless approved by the fire chief or the chief's designee. 
(2)  Removal of combustibles; Persons owning, or in charge or control of, a vacant building, apartments, or portions thereof, shall remove there from all accumulations of combustible materials, flammable or combustible waste or rubbish and shall securely lock or otherwise secure doors, windows and other openings to prevent entry by unauthorized persons. The premises shall be maintained clear of waste or hazardous materials, and must be kept free from hazardous conditions. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 27, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2053. - Opening hydrant; permit, proper tools. 
It shall be unlawful for any person other than authorized personnel in the performance of that personnel's duty to open, disconnect or tamper with any fire hydrant or fireplug unless such person shall first obtain a permit and water meter from the public utilities department. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 28, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2054. - Carelessness with fire. 
No person shall deliberately, or through carelessness or negligence, set fire to or cause the burning of any combustible or flammable materials or substance in such manner as to endanger the safety of any person or property. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 29, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2055. - Notification of fire department of inoperative fire safety equipment. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, controlling, or otherwise having control of any fixed fire extinguishing or fire warning system or standpipe system to cause or permit such equipment to become inoperable or to be taken out of service. 
(b)  Whenever such equipment as described in subsection (a) hereof is found to be inoperable or out of service, such information shall be promptly reported to the chief of the fire department or the chief's agent. The fire department shall also be notified when service is restored. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 30, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2056. - Fire department access. 
Fire apparatus access roads shall be in accordance with Appendix D and all other applicable requirements of the International Fire Code in its entirety. Facilities, buildings or portions of buildings hereafter constructed shall be accessible to fire department apparatus by way of an approved fire apparatus access road with an asphalt, concrete or other approved driving surface capable of supporting the imposed load of fire apparatus weighing at least seventy-five thousand (75,000) pounds (34050 kg.). 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 31, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2057. - Marking of fire lanes or private property. 
(a)  The fire chief or the chief's designee is hereby authorized to provide for the designation of fire lanes; for the manner, method and language for the posting of signs; to establish the penalty for violation of the same, to prohibit parking in designated fire lanes; and to provide restricted parking for emergency vehicles. 
(b)  The East Point fire chief or the chief's designee shall ensure that property owners comply with the proper marking of fire lanes. Punishment for non-compliance with this section should be handled under section 1-1006 of the Official Code of Ordinances of East Point, Georgia. This ordinance also authorizes the East Point Police Department to impound vehicles parked in "FIRE LANE—NO PARKING TOW AWAY ZONES." 
(c)  The marking of fire lanes on private property, devoted to public use, shall be approved by the chief of the East Point Fire Department. Fire lanes approved by the fire chief shall have a red painted curb in addition to a standard sign. 
(d)  The standard no parking sign shall be no smaller than twelve (12) inches by eighteen (18) inches and shall state "FIRE LANE—NO PARKING". In addition, under the letters "Fire Lane — No Parking, all signs shall state TOW AWAY ZONES." It shall be the property owner's responsibility to have their fire lanes marked with red curbs and "FIRE LANE—NO PARKING TOW AWAY ZONES." Signs shall have a white background, red border, with red letters and numbers, and shall be reflective. Marking of all signs and curbs are the sole responsibility of the property owners. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 32, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 6-2058. - Parking in fire lane prohibited. 
The parking of motor vehicles in designated fire lanes shall be prohibited at all times. This prohibition includes delivery trucks and vendors. The East Point Fire Department shall enforce and ensure that no vehicles are allowed to park in or obstruct an approved fire lane. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 33, 1-16-07) 
Secs. 6-2059—6-2100. - Reserved.

Sec. 6-2103. - Assessment and imposition of fees.

(1)  The coverage for such services is expressly provided by an insurance company to the non-resident insured and the services are lawfully billed to that insured; or

ARTICLE D. - VICTIM ASSISTANCE PROGRAM 

Sec. 6-2131. - Contractor qualifications. 
The City of East Point will seek qualified contractors who are available to provide post-incident services to victims of fire and other damaging events. Services would include, but not be limited to, the boarding up of all structural openings, and removal of excess water if required, including the ability to perform the following: 
(1)  Board-up services. 
(2)  Roof cover. 
(3)  Water extraction services. 
(4)  Temporary fencing. 
(5)  Contents care. 
(6)  Any other applicable services deemed important in assisting citizens. 
( Ord. No. 002-014, § 1, 1-21-14 ) 
Sec. 6-2132. - Associated fees and costs. 
All costs associated with services shall be passed on to the property owner's insurance provider if available. If property is not insured, at no time would the property owner or city be liable for any of the costs related to these services. The city anticipates establishing a relationship with one or more vendors with the capabilities and experience to perform these services for its residents. 
( Ord. No. 002-014, § 2, 1-21-14 ) 
Sec. 6-2133. - Rules and regulations. 
The fire department's city council may make rules or regulations and from time to time may amend, revoke, or add rules and regulations, not consistent with this section, as deemed necessary or expedient in respect to victim assistance and boarding up of property. 
( Ord. No. 002-014, § 3, 1-21-14 )

CHAPTER 5. - SWIMMING POOLS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Illegal entry into swimming pools and reservoirs, § 8-2019. 

Sec. 6-5001. - Fencing of swimming pools. 
Each and every person, firm, corporation, partnership or other entity owning and/or operating a swimming pool within the city limits of the City of East Point for the public or private use shall be and is hereby required to completely enclose such swimming pool in fencing, having a minimum height of five (5) feet, sufficient to regulate the point of access and parties accessible thereto in order to protect the public from accidental or unauthorized entry and access to such swimming pool. 
Any person violating the provisions hereof shall be subject to prosecution and penalty pursuant to the provisions of Section 1-1006 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of East Point, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 854-83, § 1, 8-15-83) 
Sec. 6-5002. - Standard Swimming Pool Code adopted. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide for the protection of the public health, welfare and safety by prescribing minimum standards for the design, construction or installation, repair or alterations of swimming pools, public or private and equipment related thereto. 
(b)  Adopted and incorporated by reference. The Standard Swimming Pool Code, 1997, edition, is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as the swimming pool code of the city. 
(c)  Controlling law. In the event a conflict between the provisions of the swimming pool code adopted and incorporated by reference in this section and the provisions of this Code, the provisions of this Code shall prevail. 
(d)  How cited. The code adopted and incorporated by reference in this section may be cited as "the swimming pool code" followed by the appropriate chapter or section number of the printed code herein adopted. 
(e)  Term construed. As used in this code, the term "chief appointing authority" shall mean and refer to the city council. 
(f)  Exception. The provisions of section 6-5001 shall apply to the fencing of swimming pools in the city.

CHAPTER 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 7-1001. - General powers and duties of superintendent of sanitation department; delegation of duties; police power of sanitation officers. 
(a)  Duties of the superintendent of the sanitation department of the city shall include investigation and inspection of sanitary problems and conditions and their location for the purpose of determining whether garbage or other waste materials the sanitation department is required to remove from dwelling house premises, apartment house premises, factories, stores, and other commercial and industrial premises of persons, corporations, partnerships, clubs, institutions, and enterprises within the city, are the cause of such problem, and to this end he is required, when necessary, to enter at reasonable times upon and into the property and premises of any person, firm, corporation, association, club, church, or institution from which it is his duty to cause garbage or other waste materials to be removed for the purposes of inspecting or investigating such garbage or waste materials, and to determine the nature, amount and location thereof, and to determine whether such garbage or waste includes items, materials, or things which it is not the duty of the city to remove, and to investigate complaints against employees of the sanitation department, and for the purpose of removing or causing garbage and other waste materials to be properly, efficiently and economically removed from such premises and the provisions of this part to be enforced, in connection with which he shall seek out and obtain evidence of violation of the laws and ordinances of the city relating to collection of garbage and other waste materials by the occupiers of premises from which such garbage or other waste materials must be removed until it can be removed by the sanitation department from such premises, and evidence of violation of ordinances relating to size or capacity of garbage containers and their convenient location on the premises from which garbage or other waste materials are to be removed until it can be removed, and the superintendent shall assign to the assistant superintendent and to the sanitary inspector such of the duties as he may find necessary from time to time in the efficient management, maintenance, and operation of the sanitation department of the city. It shall also be the duty of the superintendent of the sanitation department of the city to enforce all of the provisions of this part and to make such investigations and inspections as may be necessary to this end. 
(b)  The superintendent of the sanitation department, assistant superintendent of the sanitation department, and the sanitary inspector of the city, shall each have all of the power and authority, in the exercise of their official duties, of a regular police officer of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 11-1) 
Sec. 7-1001.1. - Limited police powers granted. 
There is hereby granted limited police powers to the department head or other designated individuals of the inspection, community development and sanitation departments for the purposes of enforcing regulatory ordinances involving those ordinances regulating open storage, abandoned automobiles, storage of ice boxes and/or refrigerators, storage of stoves, glass, building materials or trash and rubbish in public, as it may relate to violations of the above regulations viewable from the public streets of the City of East Point. The designated individual(s) of the above departments are hereby authorized to issue citations for violations of the above regulatory ordinances and present such cases in the city court of the City of East Point. The grant to such individual(s) is a partial limited grant of the police powers of the City of East Point. 
(Ord. No. 873-85, § 1, 2-18-85) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 873-85, § 1, adopted Feb. 18, 1985, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion herein as § 7-1001.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Police department, § 6-1001 et seq.; removal from right-of-way of discarded bulky appliances and furniture, § 7-2019; streets and sidewalks, § 8-1001 et seq.; planning and development, Pt. 10; parked vehicles, abandoned, § 12-2013. 
Sec. 7-1002. - Food-handling and certain other establishments to comply with board of health rules and regulations before license may be issued. 
No permit or business license shall be issued or granted for any person to open, establish, continue, carry on or work in any food-handling or other establishment required to comply with rules and regulations of the county board of health until such person furnishes proof that he has complied with all lawful rules and regulations of the county board of health. 
(Code 1959, § 11-2) 
Cross reference— Business license taxation, § 5-3001 et seq.; business licensing and regulations, Pt. 11. 
Sec. 7-1003. - Sale of unsound foods prohibited. 
The selling or offering for sale, for food, by any peddler or other person in the city of unsound or unwholesome vegetables, fruits, meats, game, eggs, fish or stale or rancid butter, shall cause the person so offending to be punished, upon conviction thereof in the city court, as provided in section 1-1006. 
(Code 1959, § 11-2.1) 
State Law reference— Food and drugs, Ga. Code, Title 42. 
Sec. 7-1004. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 993-89, § 1, adopted Sept. 5, 1989, deleted § 7-1004, relative to the fee for moving of property by the city, which derived from Code 1959, § 11-7.1.

ARTICLE A. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 023-13, adopted Aug. 19, 2013, amended former Art. A, §§ 7-2001—7-2011, 7-2012—7-2020, 7-2025, 7-2026, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. A pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative at the end of the volume for a listing of ordinances that amended former Art. A. 

Sec. 7-2001. - Definitions. 
Commercial customer means any firm, person, entity corporation or organization that owns a commercial unit. 
Commercial unit means any structure, whether freestanding or designed to serve multiple tenants, the primary purpose of which is conducting business. 
Company means any organization, firm, person, entity, corporation or other business that contracts with commercial customers to provide for the collection and disposal of solid waste material as defined in this article. 
Customer or consumer is defined as any firm, person, entity, corporation or organization that owns property with any habitable structure in the city, whether it is for residential living or business, that is not exempt from or relieved of the duty to pay the city's regular monthly solid waste removal service charge by reason of his failure or refusal to accept the solid waste service when such service is available. 
Gross receipts means the total amount collected by the company from any and all large commercial customers for services rendered under authority of this article as a result of charges for service. 
Large commercial customer means any firm, person, entity, corporation or organization that is required to contract with a company for the private collection and disposal of solid waste material as defined in this article. All hospitals, grocery stores, markets, restaurants or other places of business handling or selling fruits, vegetables, groceries or other articles of food shall be classified as a large commercial customer as well as any commercial customer that generates at least one (1) cubic yard of solid waste for disposal per week or which is located in commercial zones I-1, I-2 or BP. 
Residential unit means any structure, including single-family and multifamily dwellings, the primary purpose of which is living. Replacement of the 95-gallon cart shall be sixty dollars ($60.00) if lost or stolen. 
Solid waste means residential and commercial non-recyclable waste, residential and commercial recyclable waste. 
Waste means all perishable and nonperishable solid, semisolid and liquid wastes, including residential or commercial garbage, trash, refuse, paper, rubbish, ashes, manure, vegetable or animal solid and semisolid wastes, and other discarded solid and semisolid wastes. 
Yard trimmings is defined as leaves, brush, grass, weeds, shrub and tree pruning no longer than five (5) feet in length or more than five (5) inches in diameter, Christmas trees, and vegetative residuals and matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2002. - Container—deposit of solid waste; deposit of yard trimmings; requirements. 
(a)  All solid waste must be deposited in plastic bags securely tied with appropriate closure strips so that the contents thereof do not spill and place in covered plastic or metal garbage cans for disposal. It shall be unlawful to fail to store solid waste cans in the rear of the property or as close to the rear as possible on the side of the property to reduce their visibility from the public right-of-way. 
(b)  Yard trimmings shall not be placed in a plastic bag but, shall be placed in watertight paper bags or cardboard boxes which, when full, do not exceed fifty (50) pounds. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2003. - Same—location. 
(a)  Solid waste and yard trimmings shall be separated and placed on curbside in front of residence or business, or other place designated by the sanitation department of the city, no earlier than 5:00 p.m. of the day prior to the schedule pickup. 
(b)  Garbage cans and dumpsters shall be removed from the curbside no later than dawn on the day after the scheduled pickup. Garbage cans and dumpsters shall be stored in the rear of the property or as close to the rear as possible on the side of the property to reduce its visibility from the public right-of-way. 
(c)  Dumpsters at multifamily dwelling units and commercial dumpsters shall be enclosed and stored at the rear of the property so as to prevent visibility from the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2004. - Disposal of solid waste and sweepings generally. 
The manager of the solid waste division of the public works department shall see that all sweepings and solid waste within the limits of the city are removed to some suitable place to be approved by the manager, and the manager shall give similar directions about any and all things in the city which, in his discretion, should be removed for the protection of the health of the citizens of this city. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2005. - Disposal of debris from repairs and/or construction, and disposal of used needles. 
(a)  The removal and safe disposal of all debris resulting from repairs, remodeling, construction or demolition are the responsibility of the owner of the property to hire a private contractor for such removal. In the event the city deems it necessary to have such debris removed, the costs will be billed to the owner and levied against the property owner if not promptly paid within thirty (30) days of invoicing. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to dispose of exposed used needles or lancets through use of the city's solid waste collection system. All such needles and lancets shall be disposed as provided by City Code section 6-2015. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2006. - Disposition of solid waste by food sellers. 
All grocery stores, markets, restaurants or other places of business handling or selling fruits, vegetables, groceries or other articles of food shall be classified as a large commercial customer and shall place all refuse of vegetables, fish and similar matter shall be kept in air tight securely fastened bags and placed in a commercial dumpster for disposal. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2007. - Dumping on certain city property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dump any garbage, trash, papers or solid waste on any city property. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2008. - Solid waste removal tax—levied; amount; lien. 
(a)  A monthly solid waste removal tax is hereby levied and assessed against all of property owners of the various classes, kinds and sizes of improved building lots of land and improvements thereon to be served or benefited by the city's removal of solid waste there from, the only exception being large commercial customers as defined in this article; provided, however, that the maximum monthly solid waste removal tax per family dwelling unit on any improved building lot shall be as specified in section 7-2009; provided, further, that a building lot shall consist of any lot of land with a building thereon, and no building lot shall be considered "improved" unless there is a building thereon. 
(b)  For such solid waste removal tax, the city shall have a lien against such building lot and the improvements thereon and the owner thereof, which lien shall be prior and superiority to any and all other liens except state and county tax liens, and except that it shall be equal to any liens the city may have against such building lot for city taxes. 
(c)  In case of a lot with a business, commercial, professional, institutional building or factory thereon the tax shall be in an amount equal to the value of the solid waste removal service required and shall be as follows: 

 
Large Commercial Customers, as defined under this article, shall not be subject to any tax by the city. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2009. - Same—Residence fees. 
(a)  The amount of tax or charge for the removal of solid waste from residences is hereby fixed at twenty-one dollars and fifty cents ($21.50) per month for one 95-gallon cart with an additional charge of six dollars ($6.00) per each additional cart. Single family residences include both owner-occupied and rented detached homes. Duplexes and quadraplex small rental apartment building units shall receive the same services as single family residences and are considered to be their equivalent under this tariff. 
(b)  Multifamily residences with a central dumpster collection will be charged eighteen dollars ($18.00) per month per dwelling unit unless a waiver has been granted prior to the adoption of this provision. Multifamily residences are defined herein to be each of the individual dwelling units in an apartment complex which provides for central dumpster collection of household solid waste. 
(c)  Where two (2) or more dwelling units share a common 95-gallon cart, the full monthly solid waste division charge shall apply to each dwelling unit unless a prior waiver is granted by the solid waste division of the public works department. 
Oversized yard waste, per cubic yard (1) ..... $10.00 
Excess yard waste, per cubic yard (2) ..... 10.00 
NOTES: 
(1) Minimum charge for oversized yard waste shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per pickup. 
(2) Charge applies to all yard waste collected during special pickup. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2010. - Same—bulk material fees. 
(a)  At the request of a resident the solid waste division will schedule a special pickup appointment for the collection of bulk materials such as discarded appliances ("white goods") or large items of furniture. The required charges for this service are in addition to the standard monthly sanitation charge. The minimum amount of tax or fee for this pick-up is thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per collection for one item, with a ten dollar ($10.00) charge for each additional item to be picked up during the same appointment. (See attached chart). 
(b)  Where the bulk materials to be disposed of are non-standard, the manager of the solid waste division of the public works department or his/her designee will make an inspection trip to the requesting resident's premises to provide an estimated charge prior to removal. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2011. - Commercial solid waste collection by private contractors pursuant to nonexclusive contract with the city. 
(a)  Effective six (6) months from the effective date of Ord. No. 009-12, the city solid waste division shall cease to collect solid waste from large commercial customers as defined in section 7-2001. All large commercial customers shall thereafter be required to engage the services of a private contractor who has entered into a non-exclusive agreement with the city for the provision of commercial solid waste collection and disposal services within the city. 
(b)  The city shall grant to companies a nonexclusive contract to use the public streets, alleys, roads and thoroughfares within the city for the purpose of operating and engaging in the business of collecting and disposing of commercial solid waste; including, but not limited to, contracting with customers and providing service pursuant to the contract, placing and servicing containers, operating trucks, vehicles and trailers, and such other operations and activity as are customary and/or incidental to the business of commercial solid waste collection and disposal. It shall be illegal for any company to operate outside the terms of this ordinance. 
(c)  The company may collect and deliver for disposal all commercial solid waste accumulated within the corporate limits of the city by the company's customers. The company will furnish the personnel and equipment to provide the services described herein and as contracted with its customers, in an efficient and businesslike manner. 
(d)  Any company that operates in the city providing solid waste collection and disposal services shall meet the following minimum requirements. 
(1)  Obtain a solid waste handling permit from the director of the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-8-24. 
(2)  Use only vehicles and containers which comply with state EPD rules. Waste collection vehicles must be compactor-type trucks, covered or enclosed vehicles, constructed to be substantially leak proof, constructed of durable metal, easily cleanable and designed to prevent litter from escaping during transport. Recycling vehicles shall not be the same ones used for waste collection. Vehicles shall also meet all safety, size and weight requirements of the state department of transportation. 
(3)  Within thirty (30) days following the end of each calendar quarter, submit reports containing the following information to the city manager's office for distribution to the public works director and the finance director: the identity and location of all commercial customers service; the size of all dumpsters and frequency of service; the amount of refuse collected by weight; and the dollar amount of franchisee's gross receipts for all commercial solid waste collected within the city. 
(4)  Remit to the city finance department on a quarterly basis, with forty-five (45) days of the end of each quarter, a franchise fee equal to twenty (20) percent of the franchisee's gross receipts for all commercial solid waste collection services performed within the city. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2012. - Same—billing; when due and payable. 
(a)  The solid waste removal service charge shall be due and payable by each person liable therefore at the same time that water and electric bills are due and payable. 
(b)  Each person liable for such monthly solid waste service charge shall be billed for same by the treasurer at the same time that water and electric bills are rendered each month. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2013. - Same—refusal to accept service not to relieve duty to pay. 
No person shall be exempt from or relieved of the duty to pay the city's regular monthly solid waste removal service fee by reason of his failure or refusal to accept the solid waste service when such service is available. This code section shall not apply to large commercial customers as defined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2014. - Same—failure to pay. 
It shall be unlawful for any person liable to the city for any solid waste removal service charge to fail or refuse to pay the same when due. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2015. - Payment due by fifteenth of the month. 
All bills for solid waste or sanitary charges are due and payable upon receipt. Failure of the consumer to pay all amounts owing by the fifteenth of the month following billing shall subject the consumer to discontinuance of service. All bills not paid in full by the fifteenth of the month following billing shall be subject to a service charge of ten (10) percent of the amount of such bill plus the current charges in accordance with section 7-2013. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2016. - Collection of solid waste from individual containers at apartment houses. 
The solid waste division shall not be required to collect solid waste from individual garbage containers at apartment houses, including public housing projects, containing four (4) or more living units, except in such instances where there is no access for mechanized equipment. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2017. - Duty of apartment house owners to furnish commercial containers; type, size, location of containers; other regulations. 
The owners of apartment complexes, including the public housing authority, which consist of four (4) or more living units, shall furnish commercial dumpsters in sufficient number to adequately contain the solid waste disposal at such location. The type, size, number and location of such commercial dumpsters required shall be subject to the approval of the manager of the solid waste division of the public works department. Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions, the manager of solid waste division may impose such policies or rules and regulations as he may deem appropriate from time to time for the more efficient operation of collection of solid waste. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2018. - Submission of apartment house plans, specifications showing location of garbage cans, can wells, commercial containers, pickup points. 
Plans and specifications for the construction of apartment houses, or other multiple unit dwellings, containing more than four (4) units, shall be submitted to the department of planning and zoning, and shall show the location for commercial dumpsters, and pickup points. Such locations shall be in conformity with section 7-2003 of this chapter, and shall, with the exception of commercial dumpsters, be located at a point not more than one hundred (100) feet from the nearest point accessible to the trucks. The commercial dumpsters shall be located as required by the manager of the solid waste division of the department of public works whose approval shall be a condition precedent to the granting of a building permit by the building inspector. Any new pavement proposed by the developer/engineer shall be heavy duty pavement, of a depth to withstand the weight of the loaded garbage trucks servicing such sites, and as specified by the design engineer. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2018.1. - Solid waste removal services for tax exempt entities. 
In the event that any person otherwise subject to the solid waste removal tax imposed by section 7-2008 is exempt from taxation by virtue of any ordinance, state statute or regulation, or federal law or regulation, then that person or entity shall either provide for itself solid waste removal at least twice weekly from all premises owned by that person or entity within the city by a person or firm approved in advance by the manager of the solid waste division of the department of public works or shall utilize the solid waste removal services of the solid waste division and shall pay for said services a monthly solid waste removal charge to the city in an amount equal to the solid waste removal tax otherwise imposed by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2019. - Discard bulky appliances, furniture, etc.; notice to department of public works required. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of property within a residential district of the city to place any discarded appliances, items of furniture or other bulk items upon the premises or upon the right-of-way except that: 
(1)  Any owner or occupant desiring to discard bulk materials shall contact the sanitation department to schedule an appointment for the pickup of said materials and is subject to fees as outlined below. 
(2)  The pick-up fee for bulk materials is fixed at thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for the first ten (10) cubic yards of bulk materials and ten dollars ($10.00) per cubic yard for each additional cubic yard of bulk materials. Said fees will be applied to the utility account of the customer, or in the event there is no identified customer, the property owner. 
(3)  If said bulk material remains in the right-of-way without appointment for removal by the solid waste division, the owner or occupant of the property will be given notice to remove the bulky material within forty-eight (48) hours by the city. 
(4)  Property owners who fail to schedule a pick-up, and leave bulk materials on their property or upon the right-of-way for forty-eight (48) hours or more are subject to being cited by the city and upon being found in violation by the municipal court judge, may be fined at the maximum penalty fee allowed for such an offense under the law. Such a fine shall be in addition to any applicable pick-up fees outlined above and shall be set at a minimum of seventy dollars ($70.00) and shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(5)  Property owners shall be responsible for the bulk items left behind by their tenants and shall pay any outstanding bulk-rate removal and penalty fees when the tenant fails to pay said charges. 
a.  When a tenant fails to do so, within forty-eight (48) hours, property owners must schedule a pickup of bulk items and other items left behind by the tenant. 
b.  When a tenant fails to do so, property owners must pay the outstanding bulk-rate removal and penalty fees. 
c.  When a tenant leaves bulk or other items behind and fails to schedule a pickup, the city shall, in writing, notify the owner and/or tenant and/or any user and/or responsible party in possession of the property on which the violation exists, to abate the violation within forty-eight (48) hours after receipt of notice. 
d.  Notice shall be by personal service or certified mail addressed to the owner and/or tenant and/or any user and/or responsible party in possession of the property. If such person(s) cannot be located, notice shall be affected by posting a notice on the subject property. If notice is sent by certified mail and the notice is not returned or return receipt is not received within ten (10) days of sending the notice, notice shall be posted on the subject property. 
e.  The notice shall order that the violation of this section be abated within forty-eight (48) hours of receipt thereof. The notice shall also set a hearing date for five (5) days after receipt of this notice to be held if the violation is not abated within forty-eight (48) hours of receipt of the notice. 
f.  Failure to abate the violation within forty-eight (48) hours shall cause the city to take all such appropriate measures to ensure compliance with this section, up to and including causing the violation, after hearing on such failure, to be removed at the outstanding bulk-rate removal and penalty fees. 
g.  A hearing on the failure to abate the violation shall be set for and held five (5) days after receipt of the notice to abate the violation. 
h.  The owner and/or any user and/or responsible party in possession of the property shall be liable for all bulk-rate removal fees, penalties, fines assessed by the city court and any storage costs associated with removal by city equipment and city employees. 
i.  Citation for violation of this section does not relieve the owner, tenant, any user or responsible party in possession of the property from liability for violations of any other section of the city code. 
(6)  A property owner's failure to pay outstanding bulk-rate fees will subject the resident at the property to the utilities being cut off or the denial of utility services to the next resident at the identified property address. No utilities services shall be extended until the outstanding bulk-rate fees are paid in full. 
(7)  It shall be the policy of the city to waive bulk pick-up service fees to organizations sponsoring community clean-up days in specified areas and upon four (4) weeks' notice to solid waste division of the planned event. Such community clean-up days shall not exceed two (2) per year. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2020. - Collection of recyclable material. 
(a)  There is hereby created a program operated by the city for the collection of recyclable paper, aluminum, glass and other recyclable materials. All persons, firms or corporations may separate from normal solid waste said recyclable material. 
(b)  All of said recyclable materials shall be placed separately at the curb on days specified by the solid waste division for collection and pursuant to such other rules and regulations as may be prescribed. Recyclable aluminum, glass and other materials shall be placed for collection in recycling bins supplied by the city. Recyclable paper shall be placed for collection in recycling bins or kraft bags or tied securely with rope or cord in packages not exceeding fifty (50) pounds. 
(c)  The manager of the solid waste division may prescribe and publish reasonable rules and regulations to administer the purposes of this section. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation other than the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises to pickup said recyclable materials. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Secs. 7-2021—7-2024. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-2025. - Receptacles to be provided; notice to public. 
All public authorities and agencies having supervision of properties of this city are authorized, empowered, and instructed to establish and maintain receptacles for the deposit of litter and solid waste at appropriate locations where the property is frequented by the public, to post signs directing persons to the receptacles and serving notice of the provisions of Code sections 7-2021 through 7-2026, and to otherwise publicize the availability of such receptacles and requirements of Code sections 7-2021 through 7-2026. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-2026. - Designation of containers for household solid waste, misuse or vandalization of container. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to set fire to the contents of, indiscriminately scatter or disperse the contents of, or otherwise vandalize any containers provided by any county or city for the dumping of solid waste. 
(Ord. No. 023-13, 8-19-13) 
Secs. 7-2027—7-2050. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - LITTER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-2051. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare through the regulation and prevention of litter. The objectives of this ordinance are: 
(1)  Provide for uniform prohibition throughout the City of East Point of any and all littering on public or private property; and 
(2)  Prevent the desecration of the beauty and quality of life of the city and prevent harm to the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare, including the degradation of water and aquatic resources caused by litter. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 1.1, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 7-2052. - Applicability. 
This article shall apply to all public and private property within the City of East Point. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 1.2, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 7-2053. - Compatibility with other regulations. 
The requirements of this article should be considered minimum requirements, and where any provision of this article imposes restrictions different from those imposed by any other ordinance, rule or regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provisions are more restrictive or impose higher protective standards for human health or the environment shall be considered to take precedence. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 1.3, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 7-2054. - Severability. 
If the provisions of any article, section, subsection, paragraph, subdivision or clause of this article shall be judged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such order of judgment shall not affect or invalidate the remainder of any article, section, subsection, paragraph, subdivision or clause of this article. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 1.4, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 7-2055. - Definitions. 
Litter means any organic or inorganic waste material, rubbish, refuse, garbage, trash, hulls, peelings, debris, grass, weeds, ashes, sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, metal, plastic, and glass containers, broken glass, dead animals, discarded construction materials, abandoned construction materials, or intentionally or unintentionally discarded materials of every kind and description which are not "waste" as such term is defined in O.C.G.A., § 16-7-51, paragraph 6. 
Person means any individual, including both landlords and tenants, partnership, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private institution, utility, cooperative, city, county or other political subdivision of the State, any interstate body or any other legal entity. 
Public or private property means the right of way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof any park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; timberlands or forests; and residential, commercial, industrial, or farm properties. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 2, 12-19-06) 
Secs. 7-2056—7-2070. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITIONS, VIOLATIONS, ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 7-2071. - Prohibition against littering public or private property or waters. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump, deposit, throw or leave or to cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of litter on any public or private property in the City of East Point or any waters in the city unless: 
(1)  The property is designated by the state or by any of its agencies or political subdivisions for the disposal of such litter, and such person is authorized by the proper public authority to use such property; 
(2)  The litter is placed into a receptacle or container installed on such property; 
(3)  The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, or has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare; or 
(4)  The materials or condition otherwise subject to enforcement under this article are the direct and immediate result of the removal and deposit of a tenant's personal property in the course of a lawful eviction. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 3, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 7-2072. - Vehicle loads causing litter. 
No person shall operate any motor vehicle with a load on or in such vehicle unless the load on or in such vehicle is adequately secured to prevent the dropping or shifting of materials from such load onto the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 4, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 7-2073. - Violations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this article. Any person who has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this article may be subject to the enforcement actions outlined in this division or may be restrained by injunction or otherwise sentenced in a manner provided by law. Where the violation occurs on rental property, either the landlord or tenant (or both) may be held responsible for such violation. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 5.1, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 7-2074. - Evidence. 
(a)  Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane, or other conveyance in violation of this article, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated this article. However, the lawful distribution of newsletters, political publications, religious publications and other written communications shall not constitute litter. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (a), whenever any litter which is dumped, deposited, thrown or left on public or private property in violation of this article is discovered to contain any article or articles not easily obtainable in the public domain, including but not limited to letters, bills, publications or other writing which display the name of the person thereon in such a manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated this article. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 5.2, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 7-2075. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates this article shall be guilty of a violation and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  By a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) and not more than one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00); and 
(2)  In addition to the fine set out in subsection (a) above, the violator shall reimburse the city for the reasonable cost of removing the litter when the litter is or is ordered removed by the city; and 
(3)  a.  In the sound discretion of the municipal court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of way for a distance not to exceed one mile any litter he has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of execution of sentence; or 
b.  In the sound discretion of the municipal court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove any and all litter from any public property, private right-of-way, or with prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that he has deposited litter. Pick up and removal shall include any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence; and 
(4)  The court may publish the names of persons convicted of violating this article. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 5.3, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 7-2076. - Enforcement. 
All law enforcement agencies, officers and officials of this state and the City of East Point are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 007-07, § 5.4, 12-19-06) 
CHAPTER 3. - ANIMALS AND FOWL 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 7-3001. - Cruelty to animals prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to overload, cruelly treat, maim, bruise, abuse, mistreat, torture, deprive of necessary sustenance, ill use, abandon, or otherwise wrongfully deal with any domestic animal or fowl or otherwise treat such domestic creatures in a harsh, inhumane or unreasonable manner. Shelter for horses, cattle or other domestic animals shall be provided to protect such creatures against inclement weather and extreme temperatures. 
(Code 1959, § 5-2; Ord. No. 014-05, § 1, 8-1-05) 
Sec. 7-3002. - Bird sanctuary, city designated as such; molesting or killing birds prohibited, exceptions. 
(a)  The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the city is hereby designated a bird sanctuary. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob bird nests or wild fowl nests; provided, however, if starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or a menace to health or property in the opinion of the proper health authorities of the city, the health authorities shall meet with representatives of the Audubon Society, Bird Club, Garden Club or Humane Society, or as many of such clubs as are to be found to exist in the city, after having given at least three (3) days' actual notice of the time and place of such meeting to the representatives of such clubs. 
(c)  If as a result of such meeting no satisfactory alternative is found to abate such nuisance, such birds may be destroyed in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by the health authorities, under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Code 1959, § 5-1) 
Sec. 7-3003. - Dead animals—Disposition of. 
When the sanitation inspector shall be informed of any dead animal within the city, he shall cause all carcasses to be removed beyond the city limits and disposed of in such manner as not to create a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 925-86, § 1, 9-2-86) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 924-86, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 1986, repealed § 7-3003, relative to the disposition of dead animals as derived from Code 1959, § 5-3. Ord. No. 925-86, § 1, enacted Sept. 2, 1986, adopted a new § 7-3003 to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 7-3004. - Same—Storage prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to store or cause to be stored either on the premises of such person or other place within the city, the bodies of dead animals, fish or carnage of any kind, emitting an offensive odor. 
(Code 1959, § 5-4) 
Sec. 7-3005. - Killing of animals by police, only when necessary. 
No police officer shall kill or maim any domestic animal upon the streets or within the city, unless the destruction of such animal is necessary to prevent immediate and impending injury to a person or property. 
(Code 1959, § 5-19) 
Sec. 7-3006. - Poisoning prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to put out or cause to be put out any poison within the city for the killing of any domestic animal. 
(Code 1959, § 5-23) 
State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, Ga. Code, §§ 26-7902—26-7904. 
Secs. 7-3007, 7-3008. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 922-86, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 1986, repealed §§ 7-3007 and 7-3008, which pertained to reporting lost animals to the police department and the return of an animal to its owner respectively. Former §§ 7-3007 and 7-3008 derived from Code 1959, §§ 5-20 and 5-21. 
Sec. 7-3009. - Stock running at large—Prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to turn out or allow any hogs, horses, cows, or similar animals to run at large within the city. Such stock allowed to do so shall be impounded, if possible, until the fine is paid if the guilty party be convicted of such offense. 
(Code 1959, § 5-24) 
Cross reference— Dogs running at large, § 7-3055. 
Sec. 7-3010. - Same—Impounding. 
Whenever any domestic animal is at large anywhere in the city in violation of the law, it shall be the duty of any police officer to impound the same, but not to kill or injure such animal, unless necessary in accordance with the provisions of section 7-3005. 
(Code 1959, § 5-25) 
Secs. 7-3011—7-3013. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 923-86, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 1986, repealed §§ 7-3012, relative to feeding animals on the street, and § 7-3013, pertaining to hitching animals in the city. Former § 7-3012 derived from Code 1959, § 5-11 and former § 7-3013 derived from Code 1959, § 5-13. 
Sec. 7-3014. - Pens and enclosures; floor area and drainage, maximum number of animals allowed. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to keep horses, ponies, mules, asses, donkeys, cows, sheep, goats, hogs, dogs, rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters, chickens, turkeys, geese, ducks, pigeons or other fowl or animals except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Distances of animal enclosures from buildings. Any housing or enclosure used for the keeping of such animals or fowl shall be kept at the following minimum distances from any occupied building, except the dwelling unit of the owner, unless the permission of the owner/occupant of the adjacent building and the appropriate health officer is given for a lesser distance. So long as the minimum distances between other occupied buildings are not violated, said minimum distances shall not apply to an occupied unit of the owner of said animals or fowl. For the purposes of this subsection, a female animal and offspring shall be conclusively presumed as one (1) animal for the period of ten (10) consecutive weeks following birth or until the offspring are weaned, whichever is lesser. 
Feet 
(a)  Horse, pony, mule, donkey, cow, sheep, goat or other similar animal: 
One (1) animal ..... 200 
Two (2) animals or more ..... 500 
(b)  Swine: 
One (1) animal ..... 200 
Two (2) animals or more ..... 500 
(c)  Dogs and cats: 
Two (2) or less ..... 20 
Three (3) or more ..... 100 
(d)  Rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters and similar animals: 
Four (4) or less ..... 50 
Five (5) or more ..... 100 
(e)  Fowl: 
Four (4) or less ..... 20 
Five (5) or more ..... 100 
(2)  Area. Each such animal or fowl shall be provided with the following average minimum ground area in the enclosure in which it is kept. For the purposes of this subsection, a female animal and offspring shall be conclusively presumed as one (1) animal for the period of ten (10) consecutive weeks following birth or until the offspring are weaned, whichever is lesser. 
(a)  Horse, pony, mule, donkey, or cow ..... 10,000 
(b)  Sheep or goat ..... 3,000 
(c)  Swine ..... 3,000 
(d)  Dog and cat ..... 900 
(e)  Rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters, etc. ..... 10 
(f)  Chickens, turkeys, geese, ducks, pigeons, or similar fowl ..... 5 
(3)  Maximum number permitted. The maximum number of such animals or fowl that may be kept on any parcel smaller than five (5) acres shall not exceed the following. For the purposes of this subsection, a female animal and offspring shall be conclusively presumed as one (1) animal for the period of ten (10) consecutive weeks or until the offspring are weaned, whichever is lesser. 
(a)  Horses, ponies, donkeys, mules, cows ..... 0 
(b)  Sheep or goats ..... 0 
(c)  Swine ..... 0 
(d)  Dogs and cats ..... 3 
(e)  Rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters, etc. ..... 15 
(f)  Chickens, turkeys, geese, ducks, pigeons or similar fowl ..... 10 
(4)  Drainage, cleanliness. Any housing or enclosure used for such animal shall be well drained, free from accumulations of animal excrement and objectionable odors and otherwise clean and sanitary. 
(5)  Exceptions. Nothing contained herein shall apply to a duly licensed veterinary hospital, pet shop, pet grooming facility or similar commercial establishment where in compliance with local zoning regulations.
