(Ord. No. 666-77, § V, 7-1-77; Ord. No. 703-79, § 1, 10-15-79; Ord. No. 1123-96, § 1, 4-1-96) 
Sec. 7-5006. - Election of officers. 
The commission shall elect from its membership such officers as it may deem appropriate and shall elect a chairman for a term of two (2) years. The election of officers shall be for a term commencing July 1 and expiring June 30 two (2) years subsequent. Officers shall be elected for two year terms and shall be limited to serving two (2) consecutive terms so long as they are members of the commission. Nothing herein shall prohibit the reelection of officers in future elections. 
(Ord. No. 666-77, § VI, 7-1-77; Ord. No. 703-79, § 1, 10-15-79; Ord. No. 1184-99, § 1, 6-7-99) 
Sec. 7-5007. - Management of funds. 
The commission shall have the power to receive and disburse funds within the limitations of appropriations, gifts and grants which have been previously approved by the city council, and in connection with projects or undertakings consistent with the terms of section 7-5002. Within the same limitation, the commission shall be empowered to contract with any private or public agency to the extent required for its proper operation. The commission shall report to the city council twice annually, at the first regular council meeting in the months of March and September. The report shall include the commission's actions and accomplishments in connection with each project or undertaking and shall include as part of its report a statement of its receipts and disbursement from whatever source and to whatever object for the preceding six (6) months. Additionally, at the March reporting time the commission shall present its proposed budget to become effective July 1, indicating its anticipated revenues and expenditures, and the source of its anticipated revenues. The commission shall keep such records as will enable it to make such reports and accountings and the same shall be subject to verification and examination by the city treasurer and/or auditors of the city. 
(Ord. No. 666-77, § VII, 7-1-77) 
Sec. 7-5008. - Limitations of authority. 
Any project or undertaking begun by the commission shall be terminated when upon the decision of the city council and in the opinion of the city council, a project or undertaking is not in the public interest or unduly interferes with the city government's undertaking. The commission shall not have the power or authority to bind the city by any contract agreement, financial obligation or indebtedness, or otherwise; and no contract agreement, financial obligation or indebtedness incurred by said commissions shall ever be a claim against the city. 
(Ord. No. 666-77, § VIII, 7-1-77) 
CHAPTER 6. - COMMERCIAL AND HOME ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 7-6001. - Definitions. 
(a)  Alarm system shall mean an assembly of equipment and devices designated and arranged to detect and signal an unauthorized intrusion into a premises, to signal an attempted robbery at protected premises, a fire on premises, a medical emergency needing medical attention, and/or an ambulance, or like occurrences. 
(b)  False alarm shall mean the activation of an alarm system where none of the emergencies for which the alarm system has been installed, have in fact occurred. 
(c)  Response shall mean the dispatch of police, fire equipment, ambulance, or other appropriate equipment for the emergency signal, to the premises where the alarm system has been activated indicating such emergency is present. 
(Ord. No. 836-83, § 1, 2-21-83; Ord. No. 901-86, § 1, 2-21-83) 
Sec. 7-6002. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 104-019 , adopted Jan. 22, 2019, repealed § 7-6002, which pertained to registration and derived from Ord. No. 836-83, § 1, adopted Feb. 21, 1983 and Ord. No. 901-86, § 1, adopted Feb. 21, 1983. 
Sec. 7-6003. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-6004. - Requirement of alarm systems. 
(a)  Any audible alarm shall have an automatic thirty-minute shut off after activation. 
(b)  No alarm system designed to transmit emergency messages directly or indirectly to the police shall be tested or demonstrated without first obtaining permission from the director of communications. Permission is not required to test or demonstrate alarm devices not transmitting emergency messages directly to the communications center of the city unless the messages are to be relayed to said communications center. 
(c)  No user of an alarm system shall use or operate, attempt to use or operate, or cause to be used or operated, or arrange, adjust, program or otherwise provide or install any device or combination of devices that will upon being activated either mechanically, electronically, or by any other automatic means, call and deliver a recorded message to any telephone number assigned to the communications center for the city, except when approved by said communications center. 
(d)  In addition to the information required in the registration, any person installing an alarm system shall be required to maintain with the communications center the current name and telephone number of the owner or occupant of the premises on which the alarm is installed where said individual may be contacted within a reasonable time of the activation of said alarm. 
(Ord. No. 836-83, § 1, 2-21-83; Ord. No. 901-86, § 1, 2-21-83) 
Sec. 7-6005. - False alarms. 
During any calendar year, for any false alarms received by the communications center, that results in the dispatch of any appropriate emergency vehicle resulting from said false alarms, the owner or responsible person(s) of the premises installing said alarm system shall be charged under the following fee schedule for the response made to the location of the false alarm: 
First false alarm ..... No charge 
Second false alarm ..... $50.00 
Third false alarm ..... 100.00 
Fourth false alarm ..... 150.00 
Fifth false alarm ..... 200.00 
Sixth and subsequent false alarms ..... 250.00 
(Ord. No. 836-83, § 1, 2-21-83; Ord. No. 901-86, § 1, 2-21-83; Ord. No. 016-05, § 1, 8-15-05) 
Sec. 7-6006. - Liability of the city. 
The city shall take every reasonable precaution to assure that alarm systems and alarm messages received by the communications center are given appropriate attention and are acted upon with dispatch. Nevertheless, the city shall not be liable for any defect in operation of automatic devices and signal line systems, for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from such a source, nor for the failure or neglect of any person or agency providing dispatch or monitoring services to properly notify the city or its communications center as a result of failure in the connection with the installation and operation of equipment, the transmission of alarm signals and alarm messages, or the relaying of any such signals or messages to the communications center. 
(Ord. No. 836-83, § 1, 2-21-83; Ord. No. 901-86, § 1, 2-21-83) 
Sec. 7-6007. - Disconnection of alarm system. 
If more than four (4) false alarms are received by the city and its communications center within a calendar year period, the city may at its option, require the owner or occupant of the premises so having installed the alarm system to disconnect said automatic system, and the city shall incur no liability for such action. 
(Ord. No. 836-83, § 1, 2-21-83; Ord. No. 901-86, § 1, 2-21-83) 
CHAPTER 7. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 7-7001. - Adoption. 
The International Property Maintenance Code, 2003 edition, as published by the International Code Council is hereby adopted by the city council of East Point, Georgia for the purpose of regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the condemnation of buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use, and the demolition of such existing structures as herein provided. The International Property Maintenance Code, except such portions as are hereafter deleted, modified, or amended, is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. This code and all amendments shall be known as "the East Point Property Maintenance Code." 
(Ord. No. 993-89, § 2, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 035-07, § 1, 10-15-07) 
Sec. 7-7002. - Modifications to the International Property Maintenance Code. 
The following sections of the International Property Maintenance Code are hereby modified: 
(1)  Chapter 1 in its entirety, is modified to replace all references to the term "code official" with "the East Point Task Force"; 
(2)  Section 101.1 is modified to insert East Point, Georgia as the jurisdiction; 
(3)  Section 102.3 is modified by deleting International Zoning Code and adding East Point Code of Ordinances and adding the statement "Where, in a specific case, different ordinances specify different requirements, the most restrictive shall govern"; 
(4)  Section 103 is modified and titled "Property Maintenance Inspection;" 
(5)  Section 103.1 is modified to designate the Chief of Police, or designee, as the executive official in charge; 
(6)  Section 103.2 is replaced in its entirety by inserting the statement "The East Point Task Force shall consists of the following persons: Fire Chief, Police Chief and Director - Department of Planning & Zoning and/or their designee"; 
(7)  Section 103.5 is replaced in its entirety by inserting East Point Property Maintenance Code Account. An account is established for the sole purpose of collecting funds for enforcement of the East Point Property Maintenance Code. Funds are generated via inspection and restitution fees collected in association with this code. Funds shall be used to cover any cost incurred by the City regarding non-compliance with this code or operation of its programs. 
(8)  Section 106.4.1, Restitution Fees is added to state "Persons may be required, by court order, to pay the full amount. Restitution fees will be calculated based on the cost of enforcement." 
(9)  Section 107.2.5 is modified to state "inform the property owner that failure to abate the violation shall result in a summons issued to appear in Municipal Court"; 
(10)  Section 107.3 is modified by deleting "first-class"; 
(11)  Section 109.3 is modified to add the statement "Coordination shall occur with the Director of Public Works"; 
(12)  Section 109.6 is modified by deleting the statement referring to an appeals board and inserting the statement "Failure to comply shall be in the form as prescribed in Section 106.4"; 
(13)  Section 111 is deleted in its entirety; 
(14)  Section 302.4 is modified to replace (jurisdiction to insert height in inches) with six (6") inches in height. It is further modified to add the word "unkempt" plant growth; 
(15)  Section 304.14 is modified to replace [date] in two locations with March and November respectively; 
(16)  Section 602.3 is modified to replace [date] in two locations with October and April respectively; 
(17)  Section 602.4 is modified to replace [date] in two locations with October and April respectively; 
(Ord. No. 993-89, § 2, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 035-07, § 1, 10-15-07) 
Sec. 7-7003. - Occupants or owners to keep premises free of litter, debris, junk materials, derelict vehicles, and overgrowth. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the occupant of premises or the owner of premises to have or to place any of the following on said premises to the extent and in a manner that could threaten or endanger the public health, safety, or welfare or could adversely affect and impair the economic value of adjacent property: 
(1)  Any accumulation of litter, debris, garbage, dead trees, excessive leaf accumulation or animal excrement on any front, side or rear yard or on any porch, or underneath any building or in any accessory building. 
(2)  Any object or objects on the front yard or on a front porch of residential, commercial, or industrial property. 
(3)  Any object or objects on the side or rear yards, or on side or rear porches or underneath any building or in any accessory building unless such objects are completely enclosed within a building of such height that the objects are completely screened from the view of persons on adjacent property and to passers-by on public rights-of-way. 
(4)  Any grass or weeds of a height of six (6) inches or more or any other unkempt vegetation in any front, side or rear yard. 
(5)  Any storage building on the front yard or any dilapidated storage building on the side or rear yard. 
(6)  Any laundry, clothes, other household linens or food on the front or side yards; such are permitted in the rear yard, provided that the items are not visible from public rights-of-way, unless there is no back yard. 
(7)  Any cooking utensils, tools and accessories, including grills on the front or side yards, unless there is no back or side yard. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to place an automotive vehicle, boat or trailer, motor coach, camper or similar type vehicle on the front, side and rear yard of said premises unless placed on an established driveway or established parking lot. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to place, keep, store, or allow to remain any derelict automotive vehicle, derelict boat, or derelict trailer-type vehicle or parts thereof on a front yard, and it shall be unlawful to place, keep, store or allow to remain any derelict automotive vehicle, derelict boat, or derelict trailer type vehicle or parts thereof on the side or rear yards unless completely enclosed within an accessory building so as not to be visible from the street, lane or adjoining property. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to material which is being used in connection with a construction actively taking place on said premises provided the construction activity is being diligently pursued and complies with applicable ordinances and codes. 
(Ord. No. 993-89, § 2, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 1074-94, § 1, 6-6-94; Ord. No. 009-00, § 1, 5-15-00; Ord. No. 010-01, § 1, 6-18-01; Ord. No. 011-01, § 1, 6-18-01; Ord. No. 012-05, § 1, 6-20-05) 
Sec. 7-7004. - Fences. 
It shall be unlawful to erect a fence constructed of materials not specifically designed for fence construction, such as tin roofing material, plastic roofing material, barbed wire, or doors. The restriction of the use of barbed wire shall not apply to its use atop a lawful fence which is constructed at a height of not less than six (6) feet. 
(Ord. No. 993-89, § 2, 9-5-89) 
Sec. 7-7005. - Notification of owner and tenant. 
Whenever any provision of this chapter is being violated, the city shall notify the owner and/or any tenant and/or any user in possession of the land on which the alleged violation exists to abate the alleged violation within five (5) days of the date of service of notice. Notice shall be by personal service or certified mail addressed to the person in violation at the address where the person is determined to be located or, if not effected, notice shall be by posting a notice on the subject property. 
(Ord. No. 993-89, § 2, 9-5-89) 
Sec. 7-7006. - Violations. 
(a)  The failure to abate the alleged violation as set forth within the written notice within five (5) days of the notice shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and the director of community services or his designated agent shall take all such appropriate measures to ensure enforcement of this chapter is carried out, up to and including causing the violation, with approval of the city manager, to be removed or remedied by the use of city equipment and employees. In the event the city does not have sufficient equipment and/or employees to perform the removal or remedy, the director of community services may contract with outside forces for the removal or remedy of said violation. The total cost to the city for removing said violation shall be a special lien against the property and shall be placed on the tax records of the city and county. 
(b)  Should the owner or occupant give cause to receive notice for the same violation within twelve (12) consecutive months, the director of community services shall issue a citation to the owner or occupant to appear before city court. The minimum fine for such additional citation shall not be less than one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) and each subsequent citation within a twelve-month period shall be subject to an amount double the previously assessed fine. 
(Ord. No. 993-89, § 2, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 1074-94, § 2, 6-6-94; Ord. No. 028-03, § 1, 7-21-03) 
CHAPTER 8. - VACANT PROPERTIES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 024-13, adopted Aug. 19, 2013, amended former Chapter 8 in its entirety to read as herein set out former Ch. 8 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 018-05, § 1, adopted Aug. 15, 2005. 
Cross reference— Nuisances, Pt. 7, Ch. 4. 

Sec. 7-8001. - Registration of vacant and foreclosed single family real properties. 
(1)  For purposes of this Code section, the term: 
(a)  Agent means an individual with a place of business in this state at which he or she is authorized to accept inquiries, notices, and service of process on behalf of a vacant or foreclosed real property owner. 
(b)  Department means the department of public works. 
(c)  Foreclosed real property means improved or unimproved real property for which a land disturbance permit has been issued by a county or municipal corporation and is held pursuant to a judicial or nonjudicial foreclosure of a mortgage, deed of trust, security deed, deed to secure debt, or other security instrument securing a debt or obligation owed to a creditor or a deed in lieu of foreclosure in full or partial satisfaction of a debt or obligation owed to a creditor. 
(d)  Street address means the street or route address. Such term shall not mean or include a post office box. 
(e)  Vacant real property means real property that: 
(i)  Is intended for habitation, has not been lawfully inhabited for at least sixty (60) days, and has no evidence of utility usage within the past sixty (60) days; or 
(ii)  Is partially constructed or incomplete, without a valid building permit. 
(2)  Whenever any single family real property, including residential rental property, has been vacant for at least sixty (60) days, the owner shall provide to the department of public works the following information: 
(a)  The real property owner's name, street address, phone number, facsimile number and e-mail address; 
(b)  The agent's name, street address, mailing address, phone number, facsimile number, and email address; 
(c)  The real property's street address and tax parcel number; 
(d)  The transfer date of the instrument conveying the property to the owner; and 
(e)  At such time as it becomes available, recording information, including deed book and page numbers of the instrument conveying the realm property to the owner; and 
(f)  A filing fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(3)  The owner of a vacant single family real property who is a transferee shall not be required to comply with the registration requirements of subsection (2) of this section when: 
(a)  The real property was acquired by foreclosure under power of sale pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 44-14-160 or acquired pursuant to a deed in lieu of foreclosure; and 
(b)  The deed contains the information listed in subsection (2) of this section, paragraphs (a) through (f); and 
(c)  The deed is filed with the clerk of the superior court within sixty (60) days of the transfer; and 
(d)  Proof of the following is provided to the department of public works: 
(i)  A filing date stamp or receipt showing payment of the applicable filing fees; and 
(ii)  The entire deed under a power of sale or entire deed in lieu of foreclosure. 
(4)  The owner of vacant single family real property who is a transferee of real property acquired under power of sale pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 44-14-160 or acquired pursuant to a deed in lieu of foreclosure and who has not complied with the provisions set forth in subsection (2) of this section shall be required to comply with the registration requirements of subsection (2) of this section upon the ninety-first day after the transfer of such real property. 
(5)  The owner of any real property that is subject to the registration requirements of this chapter shall be required to update such information within thirty (30) days of any change, irrespective of whether the information was initially registered through subsection (2) reporting requirement or in accordance with subsection (3) pertaining to property registered by deed under power of sale or deed in lieu of foreclosure. 
(6)  Right to appeal: Any real property owner who is issued a citation for non-compliance with this chapter and who believes he or she has complied with the requirements set forth herein, shall have a right to appeal to the Municipal Court for the City of East Point. The penalty for non-compliance with the requirements set forth here shall be a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(7)  Removal from registry: Any residential real property owner who has registered such property in accordance with this chapter may file a request for removal of the property from the registry by providing proof that such real property no longer constitutes vacant or foreclosed residential real property. The grant or deny all such requests within thirty (30) calendar days of its filing and if no such determination is rendered within the thirty (30) day period, then the application for removal shall be deemed granted. 
(Ord. No. 024-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-8002. - Registration of non-residential vacant buildings. 
(1)  Except as provided in subsection (2) below, whenever any non-residential building, dwelling or structure is vacant for sixty (60) consecutive days, the owner shall cause such non-residential vacant building, dwelling or structure, to be registered with the City of East Point Planning and Zoning Department by completing and filing a proscribed form from the department and submitting it and a "vacant building plan" along with an administrative fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Such registration shall be valid for a period of six (6) months. The information on the authorized form shall for registration, shall include the following: 
(a)  Name, address, and telephone number of the owner; 
(b)  Name, address and telephone number of each responsible party; 
(c)  Name, address, and telephone number of any local agent or representative of the owner; 
(d)  Name, address, and telephone number of each person or legal entity with any legal interest in the property, building or premises, including mortgagees and successors in interest; 
(e)  Legal description and tax parcel identification number of the premises on which the building is situated; 
(f)  The common address of the building; 
a.  Date on which the building became vacant; and 
b.  Vacant building plan for non-residential structure. 
(2)  If at the expiration of any six (6) month registration, a non-residential building remains vacant and the vacant building plan has not been completed, the owner shall re-register such non-residential building and pay a fifty-dollar ($50.00) re-registration fee. If the building is vacant at the expiration of any registration period and the requirements of the vacant building plan have been completed, the owner shall re-register such building, but shall not be charged the re-registration fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) re-filing fee. 
(Ord. No. 024-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-8003. - Establishment of vacant non-residential building plan. 
(1)  When a non-residential building is registered as required by this chapter, the owner shall submit, or caused to be submitted, for approval a vacant non-residential building plan. The plan shall contain the following: 
(a)  The reasonably expected period of vacancy; 
(b)  A plan to make the building ready for occupancy with sufficient detail regarding the proposed repair and/or rehabilitation of the building to enable the director to determine the adequacy of such plan; 
(c)  A letter of written consent by the owner allowing city officials to enter and inspect the property for the period in which the vacant building plan is in effect; 
(d)  For buildings, dwellings or structures which have been cited or identified as being or containing public nuisances, then the vacant building plan shall contain a plan of action to immediately remedy such public nuisances; 
(e)  For each required plan, a time schedule shall be submitted identifying a date of commencement of repair and/or rehabilitation and schedule for completion of repair and/or rehabilitation for each building, dwelling or structure and each identified nuisance; 
(f)  When the owner proposes to occupy, sell, lease or demolish the vacant building, then the owner shall submit a plan and time schedule for such action; and 
(g)  A plan of action to secure, monitor and maintain the building and premises thereof in conformance with this chapter. 
(2)  The director is hereby authorized to collect a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee to the enable the city to monitor and inspect the building and to review and approve the vacant building plan. The director shall have discretion to determine the number of inspections required to monitor the subject building upon submission of the plan based upon the type and condition of the property and the history of violations at the subject property. A standard schedule of fees shall be published by the director. 
(3)  The vacant building plan shall be recorded and indexed in the property records of Fulton County, Georgia and shall be released by the city when it has been determined that the property is no longer vacant. 
(4)  Failure by the owner to submit a vacant building plan for any non-residential building or structure or to comply with a vacant building plan that has been approved by the city under this section or to pay a fee as required under this section is a violation of the Code and may be remedied by any of the following: 
(i)  An administrative penalty of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first citation; up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the second citation; and up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the third citation and any others after that; or 
(ii)  Acquisition of the property by eminent domain in a manner consistent with section 7-8003. 
(5)  If the property is subject to a vacant building plan and the plan has been properly recorded in the property records of Fulton County, the transferee is subject to the terms of the vacant building plan. The transferee may apply to the city to be released from the requirements of the vacant building plan upon bringing the structure into compliance or registering such vacant building plan under the transferee's name along with its vacant building plan. 
(Ord. No. 024-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-8004. - Acquisition of vacant buildings and residential dwellings by eminent domain. 
(1)  The city may acquire by eminent domain pursuant to applicable state law, any property determined to be vacant and a persistent nuisance, and shall have the power to hold, clear, manage or dispose of property so acquired for residential, commercial, industrial and related use. 
(2)  The city council shall not institute eminent domain proceedings pursuant to this section unless the director has certified that the property is vacant and a persistent nuisance. A property may only be certified to the city council as vacant and a persistent nuisance after the director has determined that: 
(a)  The owner of the property or designated agent has been sent a notice or order by the appropriate agency of the municipality to eliminate the conditions which are in violation of local codes or law; 
(b)  The property is vacant; 
(c)  The property is a persistent nuisance under the terms of this Chapter 4 of Part 7; 
(d)  The city has notified the property owner or designated agent that the property has been determined to be blighted or deteriorated and the time period for correction of such condition has expired and the property owner or agent has failed to comply with this notice. 
(3)  The findings required by subsection (2) shall be in writing and included in the report prepared by the director to the city council. 
(4)  The director shall notify the owner of the property or a designated agent that a determination that the property is vacant and a persistent nuisance has been made and that failure to eliminate the conditions causing such condition shall render the property subject to condemnation by the city under this part. Notice shall be mailed to the owner or designated agent by certified mail, return receipt requested. However, if the address of the owner or designated agent is unknown and cannot be ascertained by the commission in the exercise of reasonable diligence, copies of the notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the property affected and notice shall be published the newspaper which is the official organ of the county in which the sheriffs advertisements appear. The written notice sent to the owner or the owner's agent shall describe the conditions that render the property blighted and deteriorated, and shall demand abatement of the conditions within ninety (90) days of the receipt of such notice. 
(5)  An extension of the ninety-day time period may be granted by the city if the owner or designated agent demonstrates that such period is insufficient to correct the conditions cited in the notice. 
(6)  No elected official, officer or employee of the city shall acquire any interest in any property declared to be vacant or a persistent nuisance. 
(7)  If any elected official, officer or employee owns or has a financial interest, direct or indirect, in any property certified to be vacant and a persistent nuisance, the officer or employee shall immediately disclose, in writing, such interest to the city council, and such disclosure shall be entered in the minutes of the city council. Failure to so disclose such interest shall constitute misconduct in office. 
(8)  No payment shall be made to any elected official, officer or employee for any property or interest therein acquired by the city from such elected official, officer or employee unless the amount of such payment is fixed by court order in eminent domain proceedings, or unless payment is unanimously approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 024-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-8005. - Enclosure of vacant lots. 
(1)  The director, at his discretion and based upon substantial evidence of the occurrence of criminal activities or offenses affecting the public health, safety and welfare in or on any vacant lot in the city, may order the owner or agent for the owner of such vacant lot to erect or cause to be erected a fence of a height and type permitted by the zoning code along all or any part of the perimeter of such vacant lot. 
(2)  A conviction of any person of failure or refusal to comply with an order of the director issued pursuant to this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and no greater than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 024-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-8006. - Historic preservation exception. 
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to encourage the destruction of or irreparable harm to historic buildings, structures or fixtures. Responsible parties may include in their vacant building plan sections to specifically address historic elements of the property in a sensitive manner, which may fall outside of certain parameters of this chapter. The responsible party shall consult with historians, preservationists, other similar experts and/or neighborhood associations, if and as needed, to demonstrate to the city in writing the appropriateness of any historic preservation exceptions requested. This section is intended to allow for alternate means of bringing vacant structures into compliance with the codes of East Point, not to exempt any structures from this chapter as a whole. Standards for determination of historic value may be determined, after consultation as described herein, on a case-by- case basis as determined by the director, or according to standards adopted by the city council at some future date. The cost of consultations referenced in this section, when applicable, shall be borne by the responsible party. In the event of a dispute over historic preservation exceptions, the matter shall be presented to the city council for resolution within sixty (60) days. 
(Ord. No. 024-13, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 7-8007. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the term: 
(1)  Buildings, dwellings or structures mean any building or structure or part thereof used and occupied for commercial, industrial, or business uses, or intended to be so used, and includes any outhouses and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith and also includes any building or structure of any design. 
(2)  Director means the director of planning and zoning or his/her duly authorized appointee. 
(3)  Lot means a parcel of land with or without buildings, dwellings or structures. 
(4)  Owner means any person, agent, operator, firm, partnership, corporation or trust having a legal or equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the state, county or municipality as holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate or any such person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court. 
(5)  Persistent nuisance means any nuisance, as determined to exist by the director, which exists unabated for a period of twelve (12) or more months. 
(6)  Responsible party means any owner, occupant, agent, manager, operator and/or management company of a building, dwelling, structure or lot. 
(7)  Violation means conduct, or evidence of conduct, prohibited under this chapter. A violation does not require criminal prosecution and conviction but only a preponderance of evidence that the prohibited conduct is occurring or has occurred. Evidence of prohibited conduct may include, but is not limited to; police reports, investigative reports, execution of search warrants, results of police surveillance, arrest and/or conviction of local, state or federal laws, activities associated with trafficking of controlled substances, finding of weapons and/or controlled substances on or near the property, or increase volume of traffic associated with the property. 
(Ord. No. 024-13, 8-19-13) 
Part 8 - PUBLIC WORKS AND SERVICES 
Ch. 1. Streets and Sidewalks 
Ch. 2. Utilities 
CHAPTER 1. - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 8-1001. - Official block numbers. 
The city block numbers as prepared and placed on the 1915 city map by C.S. Roberts, county surveyor, are hereby adopted as the official block numbers of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 19-1) 
Sec. 8-1002. - House numbers—Duty of owners or occupants to apply for proper numbers. 
Each owner or occupant of a house, or part thereof, shall apply to the city engineer for the proper number of his house. 
(Code 1959, § 19-2) 
Sec. 8-1003. - Same—Size, material, etc. 
The owner or occupant of any house shall have the right to determine the size, material and location of such numbers, except that the numbers shall be inscribed or affixed in a conspicuous place, and shall be of such size, color or character that may be readily read from the street by any person of ordinary vision. 
(Code 1959, § 19-3) 
Sec. 8-1004. - Same—Method of numbering. 
All houses fronting on the various streets and alleys in the city shall be numbered under the supervision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1959, § 19-4) 
Sec. 8-1005. - Same—Improper numbering; failure to number. 
It shall be unlawful to have any house improperly numbered or without a number for as long as ten (10) days. 
(Code 1959, § 19-5) 
Sec. 8-1006. - Enclosure of streets, etc.—During emergency. 
It shall be the duty of city policemen and firemen to rope off, block, fence or enclose by suitable fence, cable, rope, wire or other suitable device any street, alley or area, or part of either, when the use thereof by any person would interfere with or interrupt the proper exercise of powers of the city or a proper discharge of official duties of officers or employees of the city where the exercise of such power or discharge of such duties is necessary on account of any catastrophe or fire, riot, crime, violence, breach of the peace, congestion of traffic or the prospect of any such conditions. 
(Code 1959, § 19-6) 
Sec. 8-1007. - Same—Breaking or removing material. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, break, remove, tear down, destroy or molest any barricade, rope, wire, cable, fence or roadblock lawfully erected or established whereby any area, street, alley or portion of either has been enclosed, blocked off, closed or fenced or from which area, street, alley or portion of either the public or any part thereof has been permanently or temporarily excluded. 
(Code 1959, § 19-7) 
Sec. 8-1008. - Same—Unlawful entry. 
It shall be unlawful to enter or cause an area, street, alley or portion of either, which has been enclosed, fenced, blocked or roped off by lawful authority to be entered by any person in violation of any lawful order of any officer of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 19-8) 
Sec. 8-1009. - Duty of abutting property owners to keep sidewalks clean and safe. 
It shall be the duty of every abutting property owner to keep sidewalks and streets abutting his property clear of obstructing defects and dangerous conditions due to his acts of negligence. 
(Code 1959, § 19-14) 
Sec. 8-1009.1. - Obstruction of sidewalks, gutters and streets. 
It shall be unlawful for anyone to put any obstruction of any kind including grass cut lawns, tree trimmings, tree leaves, household goods, furniture, trash or debris on any sidewalk or in any street or street gutters or any public right-of-way for more than forty-eight (48) hours and it shall be the duty of the superintendent of the code enforcement department of said city to enforce this section by prosecuting anyone violating its provisions in the city court of said city. 
(Ord. No. 771-82, § 1, 1-4-82; Ord. No. 038-03, § 1, 10-20-03) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 771-82, § 1, adopted Jan. 4, 1982, reenacted Code 1959, § 19-19; the editor has assigned § 8-1009.1 to these provisions. 
Sec. 8-1010. - Known dangerous conditions in streets, sidewalks, buildings, etc. 
(a)  All known dangerous conditions in public streets, sidewalks, buildings and other public places shall be corrected and said corrections shall be done in a reasonable time utilizing the necessary precautions as prescribed by the OSHA Safety Regulations and said hazards shall be documented on a case-by-case basis for unit cost analysis for system maintenance. Said documentation shall have been determined by proper inspection, examination, measurements and accurate photographs taken from all material directions and distances necessary to adequately portray the material hazards/facts made on behalf of the city. All necessary precautions shall be taken at the location of the alleged hole, defect or other hazardous condition, and the alleged hole, defect or other hazardous condition shall be barricaded, fenced or otherwise put out of use with properly lighted and/or all necessary and reasonable warning signs placed about and near such condition. 
(b)  It is the duty of every city officer and employee to properly notify the public utilities department director and/or designee as communicated by the city manager of any hazardous condition in any street or sidewalk of which they may have knowledge and to notify the buildings and grounds superintendent of any dangerous condition in any building of which they have knowledge and this is a duty and obligation. 
(Code 1959, § 19-14.1; Ord. No. 1178-94, § 1, 7-18-94; Ord. No. 1182-94, § 1, 7-18-94) 
State Law reference— Street improvements within municipalities, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 69-407, 69-417—69-419, 69-433 and 69-434. 
Sec. 8-1011. - Closing of street crossings. 
It shall be unlawful for any street or street crossing to be closed by any person, county or city work crew or others without first giving notice to the chief or the member discharging the duties of chief of the fire department of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 19-15) 
Sec. 8-1012. - Erection of structures over streets; permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to install, erect, have, hang, build, permit, establish, keep, construct or maintain any building, shelter, wall, fence, board, sign, scaffold, platform, shed or other structure or obstruction of wood, metal or other type of material in, on or over any street, except the sidewalk, at any time without a special permit granted by the council. 
(Code 1959, § 19-16) 
Sec. 8-1013. - Lighting of obstructions placed on streets. 
Any person, his agent or representative, who shall leave or cause to be left during the night, or any part of the night, any obstruction of any kind or character in any of the public streets, alleys or sidewalks, shall place or cause to be placed and maintained sufficient lights on such obstruction to show the outline of such obstruction and sufficient to warn any person using such streets or places of the danger. 
(Code 1959, § 19-20) 
Sec. 8-1014. - Awnings, height. 
It shall be unlawful to erect, install, maintain or hang any awnings over any sidewalk at a height of less than eight (8) feet above such sidewalk. 
(Code 1959, § 19-22) 
Sec. 8-1015. - Use of heavy equipment on private or public roads; consent of owner or permit from city engineer required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any public or private road, street, alley, lane, sidewalk, way, drive or driveway for the purpose of operating any heavy vehicle on, over, along or across the same, or any part thereof, or for moving any heavy machinery, equipment, freight, load or thing on, over, along or across any such road, street, lane, alley, drive, sidewalk, way or walkway, so that such operation or use results in more injury or damage to such road, street, way, drive, alley, lane, sidewalk, driveway or walkway than is inflicted by common everyday traffic by the general public, without the consent of the owner, if the road, street, lane, alley, sidewalk, drive, walkway, driveway or way be private, nor without a special permit from the city engineer issued pursuant to uniform city standards if it be public. 
(Code 1959, § 19-27) 
Sec. 8-1016. - Outside burning prohibited. 
The outside burning of trash, debris, leaves, wood, tree limbs or other similar substances, including the open burning of grass, weeds or vegetation is unlawful in the City of East Point and shall be prohibited except that grills, pits or outdoor fireplaces may be used for cooking purposes only. 
(Code 1959, § 11-29; Ord. No. 853-83, § 1, 8-15-83; Ord. No. 1008-90, § 1, 10-1-90) 
Editor's note— Provisions designated as § 6-2044 by Ord. No. 1008-90, § 1, adopted Oct. 1, 1990, have been included herein at the direction of the city as § 8-1016. 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Part 6, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 8-1017. - Starry Night standards for outdoor lighting. 
(a)  All outdoor light fixtures to be added or replaced by the City of East Point along the city's rights-of-way or on any other public property shall be downwardly focused in order to comply with Starry Night standards once any existing stock of streetlights has been depleted. 
(b)  Any light fixtures added or replaced in any new or existing subdivision, development or with any other type of construction permitted by the city shall be downwardly focused in order to comply with Starry Night standards. 
(Ord. No. 027-07, § 1, 6-4-07) 
Secs. 8-1018—8-1030. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - TREES AND PLANTINGS 

Sec. 8-1031. - Public shade trees—Authority of council. 
The city council shall have under its control all shade trees growing on the public streets of the city. It shall cause all statutes and ordinances made for the protection of the trees to be strictly enforced, and shall cause legal proceedings to be instituted against all persons violating such statutes and ordinances. 
Sec. 8-1032. - Same—Permits for cutting required. 
No person shall cut or trim any shade tree growing on the public streets for the purpose of stringing wires thereon, or for any similar purpose, without the permission of the council. 
(Code 1959, § 19-32) 
Sec. 8-1033. - Trimming of trees and tree branches constituting hazard to utility lines or citizens. 
It shall be the duty of the director of public utilities to cause to be trimmed, trees and tree limbs and branches which overhang sidewalks, streets, or utility lines maintained by the city when such trees, limbs, or branches constitute a hazard to such utility lines or to citizens using the streets and sidewalks. 
(Code 1959, § 19-32.1) 
Sec. 8-1034. - Planting of trees near streets, sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful to plant or replant any tree within ten (10) feet of any street or sidewalk or public driveway within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 19-33) 
Sec. 8-1035. - Removal of trees causing injury to pavement—Duty of engineer to do so; exceptions. 
It shall be the duty of the city engineer to remove or cause to be removed, trees, the roots of which are breaking up sidewalks, street paving and street curbing, such roots to be removed also, at the expense of the owners thereof, unless such owners will permit the city engineer to remove such trees on behalf of the city without charging the city for such trees. 
(Code 1959, § 19-34) 
Sec. 8-1036. - Same—Inspection to determine, remedial action. 
It shall be the duty of the city engineer to inspect the streets, street curbing and sidewalks of the city to determine where roots of trees are causing such street paving, street curbing, and sidewalks to be injured and to determine the ownership of such trees. In cases where the city owns the trees, they shall be removed by the city engineer, and in cases where such trees are not owned by the city, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to obtain, if he can, permission and authority from the owner of such tree to remove the same without expense to such owners, if such owners do not charge the city for such trees or for removing the same. 
(Code 1959, § 19-35) 
Sec. 8-1037. - Same—Notice to city attorney. 
Where the owner of a tree, the roots of which are injuring the street paving or street curbing or sidewalk, will not permit or allow the city to remove such trees and such roots, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to forthwith notify the city attorney of such fact, in which notice the city engineer shall give the city attorney the specific location of such tree and the roots which are injuring the sidewalk, street paving or street curbing and the name of the street, and the name of the owner of the property with a brief description of such location of the owner's property, stating whether it is on the north side, east side, west side, or south side of the street, and the house number of such owner, if such owner is a resident of the city, and if not a resident of the city then such address as the city engineer is able to obtain. 
(Code 1959, § 19-36) 
Sec. 8-1038. - Same—Condemnation proceedings. 
Upon receiving the notice from the city engineer as prescribed in section 8-1037, it shall be the duty of the city attorney, the city engineer and the mayor to determine the value of such tree and the amount of the damage which would result to such owner's other property if such tree is condemned and removed, and thereupon to offer such owner the amount of such value and such damage, and upon the refusal of such owner to accept such amount, it shall be the duty of the city attorney to immediately institute condemnation proceedings for the purpose of condemning and removing such tree and to cause the proper amount to be paid to the clerk of the Superior Court of Fulton County when it has been determined as provided by law, whereupon it shall be the duty of the city engineer to forthwith remove such tree and its offending roots, and to keep record of the costs of such removal which are hereby assessed against such owner of such tree, and a bill for such costs shall be promptly presented to such owner; and on his refusal to pay the same promptly on demand by the city engineer, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to notify the city clerk of such fact, whereupon it shall be the duty of the city clerk to issue an execution for the amount of such cost against such owner and the real estate of such owner from which such tree was removed and place such execution in the hands of the city marshal for levy and sale; whereupon it shall be the duty of the city marshal to levy such execution or cause the same to be levied by a police officer upon such real estate of such owner. After advertisement once a week for four (4) weeks as in a tax advertisement for sale of real estate, it shall be the duty of such city marshal to sell such real estate to the highest bidder for cash in front of the council chamber on the first Tuesday in the month next succeeding the expiration of such four (4) weeks' advertising, and the purchaser of such sale shall have the same rights as in the case of a purchaser at a tax sale conducted by the city. 
(Code 1959, § 19-37) 
Sec. 8-1039. - Same—Interference with officials. 
It shall be unlawful for anyone to obstruct or interfere with the city engineer or city marshal in the discharge of their duties under sections 8-1035 through 8-1038. 
(Code 1959, § 19-38) 
Sec. 8-1040. - Trimming shrubbery near drive-ways—Required. 
It shall be unlawful to have or maintain any hedge or shrubbery along any sidewalk or driveway where motor vehicles are used without keeping the hedges and shrubbery so trimmed and cut back that persons using such sidewalks can do so without injury from motor vehicles emerging from a driveway hidden behind a hedge or all shrubbery, whether the users of such sidewalk be children or adults. 
(Code 1959, § 19-39) 
Sec. 8-1041. - Same—Notification of violators. 
It shall be responsibility of the community development department to notify the owner of every lot, improved or unimproved, having a hedge or shrubbery thereon in violation of section 8-1040 to comply with the provisions thereof, and if such owner fails or refuses to comply with such provisions within ten (10) days from the date of such notice, the city will cut or trim such hedge or shrubbery at the owner's expense, and will in addition, thereto prosecute such owner in the recorder's court for such offense. 
(Ord. No. 927-86, § 1, 9-2-86) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 926-86, § 1 adopted Sept. 2, 1986, repealed former § 8-1041, relative to notification of violators of § 8-1040, which provisions derived from Code 1959, § 19-40. Ord. No. 927, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 1986, enacted a new § 8-1041 to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 8-1042. - Same—Compliance with notice. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner of any property within the city having hedge or shrubbery thereon, including growth, in violation of section 8-1040 to cut or trim the same to comply with such section within ten (10) days from the date notice to do so is served on such owner or the agent or tenant of such owner in possession of such property. 
(b)  No person shall be guilty of an offense under section 8-1040 for a violation of such section until the expiration of ten (10) days after service of such notice as provided in section 8-1041 of such violation. 
(Code 1959, § 19-41) 
Sec. 8-1043. - Same—When community development to trim; levying of costs. 
It shall be the duty of the community development department to have cut or trimmed, by the building and grounds department, all hedges and shrubbery in violation of section 8-1040 at the owner's expense after expiration of such ten (10) days' time allowed for the owner to comply with the notice as prescribed in section 8-1041, and to bill the owner with the expense. If the bill is not paid in ten (10) days, it shall be the duty of the clerk of the city to issue an execution for the expense against such lot and the owner thereof, which execution shall be a lien against such lot and the owner thereof prior and superior to any and all other liens, except liens for taxes, and it shall be the duty of the city marshal to collect the execution by levy and sale of such lot, if it be not paid on demand as in case of tax executions of this city. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 1, 9-2-86) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 926-86, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 1986, repealed former § 8-1043, which pertained to when the chief of police to trim hedges or shrubbery in violation of § 8-1040 and levying costs therefore. Ord. No. 927, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 1986 enacted a new § 8-1043 to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 8-1044. - Restrictions on the planting of lawns. 
It shall be unlawful for any lawn, yard or garden to be so laid out, planted, cultivated or maintained on any lot above or below the grade or level of the abutting street or sidewalk that the proper paving of the abutting street or sidewalk in the usual and ordinary manner will cause injury or damage to such yard, lawn, garden or flowers, which would not otherwise have occurred, or cause the abutting property to be washed away or to be flooded with surface water when heavy rains come, which washing or flooding would not have occurred otherwise. 
(Code 1959, § 19-43) 
Secs. 8-1045—8-1060. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 8-1061. - Street, drive, walk, sewer, storm drain improvements; contract and bond requirements. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to establish, locate, relocate, cut, lay out, construct, grade, pave, curb, widen or extend any public road, street, drive, walk, way, sewer or storm drain, which improvement is intended for or is likely to become a part of the city's highways, streets or roads, or which improvement is intended to be or is likely to be located within or become a part of a real estate subdivision or development within the city, without having first entered into an appropriate contract with the city, which has been approved by the city attorney and the city engineer. In the event the contract for such improvement is between a property owner or developer and the contractor, rather than the city, such contract shall be approved by the city engineer and city attorney. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city engineer to frequently visit, inspect, supervise and see that such work is done in accordance with such contract and the requirements of the city so that, upon completion thereof, he can make a certificate that he has inspected the work at every stage thereof, and that it has been done and completed in accordance with such requirements. No improvement shall be accepted by the city council without first receiving such certificate from the city engineer. 
(c)  It shall likewise be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to undertake any such improvement unless or until a satisfactory bond, with good and sufficient security, has been filed with the city purchasing agent and approved by the city attorney by the owner or person responsible for such improvement, whereby the city shall be adequately indemnified and protected against loss, injury or damage resulting from any failure to comply with any provision of this section, whether such failure be during the course of such undertaking or after its completion and the acceptance thereof by the city. 
(Code 1959, § 19-44) 
Sec. 8-1062. - Notice to owner of impending construction and/or repair to be assessed. 
When an ordinance has been introduced to construct or repair a sanitary sewer, a sidewalk, or street curbing, or to pave or repair a street and all, or any part of the expense of such work or improvement is to be assessed against the abutting lands and owners thereof, notice thereof, and of the time and place of a public hearing thereon, shall be published one (1) time by the city clerk in the official newspaper of the city at least ten (10) but not more than thirty (30) days prior to the date of such hearing. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-44.01) 
Sec. 8-1063. - Minimum width of new streets. 
Any road or street which shall be hereafter proposed, planned, platted or constructed shall have a minimum width of thirty-two (32) feet from curb line to curb line, except that the city council may by resolution waive the aforementioned requirements to conform to the width of the street or road with other roads or streets with which it may connect or for any other reason which the city council may deem fit and proper. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-44.1) 
Sec. 8-1064. - Liability insurance required; evidence of responsibility. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to commence construction upon any street or sidewalk in the city unless or until such person commencing such construction work has obtained and filed with the city adequate public liability insurance to protect and save the city harmless against loss, injury or damage on account of negligence of such person commencing such street or sidewalk construction, or satisfy the council that such public liability insurance has been obtained and is of full force and effect; provided, satisfactory proof that such public liability insurance has been obtained shall consist of a copy of the insurance policy or a certificate from the insurance company evidencing such fact. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-45) 
Sec. 8-1065. - Same requisites for approval. 
The public liability insurance required by section 8-1064 shall be subject to the approval of the city council and will not be accepted or approved unless written by some insurance company authorized to write public liability insurance in this state and having an officer and agent located within the state. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-46) 
Sec. 8-1066. - Acceptance of public improvements. 
The city engineer is hereby authorized and directed to approve and accept street and sidewalk paving and construction work and the construction of street curbing and the laying and constructing of sewers on behalf of the city, when and only when the work has been properly performed and completed in compliance with the contract, plans and specifications, where upon it shall be the duty of the city engineer to make and deliver to the city purchasing agent a certificate in which he shall certify that such contract and work thereunder have been properly executed and completed, and that it has been accepted on behalf of the city by the city engineer, and stating the unpaid amount of the contract price which is due and payable to the contractor, if such work has been done by a contractor; provided, it shall be the duty of the city engineer, on completion of any job, the cost of which or any part of the cost of which is to be assessed against abutting property owners, to furnish the city attorney with a copy of the certificate, in which certificate the city engineer shall certify the names of the abutting property owners and the lineal front footage to be assessed against each, with the amount to be assessed per lineal front foot, whereupon it shall be the duty of the city attorney to prepare and deliver unto the city council an ordinance assessing such costs as are assessable against such abutting properties and the owners thereof for action. 
(Code 1959, § 19-48) 
Sec. 8-1067. - Excavations in streets and sidewalks—Permit required; application for permit. 
Any person desiring to cut or make any excavation in any street or paved sidewalk in the city for the purpose of making connections with sewer, water pipes, gas pipes or for any other purpose, shall before cutting or making any such excavation obtain a written permit from the director of public works. The application for such permit shall state the name of the person who expects to cut the street or sidewalk or make the excavation therein, for whom, and for what reason, and where, and the number of days required to do the work. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-48) 
Sec. 8-1068. - Same; responsibility of permittee. 
Any person who shall obtain a permit required by section 8-1067 shall thereby assume full responsibility for any loss or damage to the city or any person as a result of such excavation or other acts of negligence, and shall indemnify the city against any loss resulting from any damage to either person or property of any person, and any such permit shall contain this provision. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-49) 
Sec. 8-1069. - Same; refilling excavations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, after having made an excavation in any street, to refill the same except under the immediate supervision and direction of the director of public works. It shall be the duty of any person making any such excavation to notify the city in writing when he shall have accomplished the work for which the excavation was made, and the city shall have the same refilled and the street restored to its former condition at the expense of the applicant. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-50) 
Sec. 8-1070. - Same; lighting and flagging excavations. 
It shall be the duty of the person making any excavation in any public street or place to maintain a signal at the place of excavation by keeping a red light burning at same from sundown to sunrise and red flag during the day. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-51) 
Sec. 8-1071. - Same; notification of abutting property owners to make necessary stub-outs prior to street or sidewalk paving; required. 
When any sidewalk or street is about to be paved it shall be the duty of the director of public works to notify in writing all of the owners of the abutting lots on such street requiring them to have made at their expense all necessary sewer, gas and water stub-outs from the sewer, gas and water mains to their respective property lines within five (5) days from the date of such notice. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-52) 
Sec. 8-1072. - Same; excavations upon failure of abutting property owners to make necessary stub-outs prior to paving. 
Any person failing to make all necessary sewer, gas and water stub-outs from the sewer, gas and water mains to their respective properties when duly notified to do so shall, in the event such person should desire water, sewer or gas connections made to his premises after the pavement has been laid, be charged a fee in connection therewith, in addition to ordinary and other costs of such connections or stubouts for entering the pavement, if such connection is made within five (5) years from the date the street is paved. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-53) 
Sec. 8-1073. - Charge for engineering services furnished private persons. 
A charge, as determined by city council shall be assessed, levied and charged against owners of lands abutting a street right-of-way (except the City of East Point) for engineering services necessary in making profiles for street curbing and guttering on both sides of a street, and the amount estimated in advance by the city engineer as necessary to pay such costs in each case shall be deposited in advance with said city engineer before such service is rendered by said city for any private person, firm, corporation or association. 
(Code 1959, Sec. 19-53.1) 
Secs. 8-1074—8-1090. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - SIDEWALKS, CURBS AND DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 8-1091. - Sidewalk and driveway specifications. 
All public sidewalks and those parts of all private driveways which are within the sidewalk or street area shall be laid and constructed according to specifications of the city, and shall be constructed and laid by the public works department, or by contract subject to final approval by the city, and it shall be unlawful for any sidewalk or private driveway within the sidewalk or street area to be constructed otherwise. 
(Code 1959, § 19-54) 
Sec. 8-1092. - Construction of driveway approaches—Specifications. 
All future private driveway approaches from public streets of the city shall be paved according to city driveway construction specifications within such street right-of-way. 
(Code 1959, § 19-54.1) 
Sec. 8-1093. - Same—Owner's expense. 
To secure uniformity of construction and compliance with city driveway construction specifications, all future construction of private driveway approaches from a public street, and within the street right-of-way, shall be performed at the expense of the owner of the lot to the driveway of which such approaches are constructed, but only after written permission shall have been obtained from the city engineer to whom application for such permission shall be made in writing accompanied by a set of plans and specifications approved in writing by said city engineer, in which application for such permission the applicant shall covenant and agree to construct such private driveway approaches in accordance with such plans and specifications. 
(Code 1959, § 19-54.2) 
Sec. 8-1094. - Same—Permit required. 
It shall be lawful for the owner of any lot desiring to construct a driveway into such lot from an abutting public street to construct the same or have it constructed provided a permit to construct the same is granted by the city engineer; provided, further, that such permit shall not be granted by the city engineer unless nor until he shall have approved written plans and specifications submitted in duplicate to him with a written application for such permit in which application the owner or applicant for such permit shall covenant and agree to construct such driveway in accordance with such approved plans and specification; provided, further, that upon completion such construction shall be subject to approval by the city engineer of the city, and shall not be open for use unless nor until the same shall have received such approval of the city engineer, of which completion the city engineer shall be promptly notified, so that the city engineer can inspect the same for the purpose of determining whether the construction has been completed in accordance with the plans and specifications previously approved by him. 
Sec. 8-1095. - Grading or paving sidewalks—By private person; permit required. 
When it shall be lawful for anyone other than the city to lay down, open, grade, pave or construct any public street or sidewalk, any person desiring to grade or pave any sidewalk shall first make application in writing to the city engineer and obtain a written permit for doing such work, and also obtain specifications, line and grade as to the manner in which such sidewalks shall be graded and paved and the kind and proportions of material to be used in the paving of same and the width and other dimensions of the sidewalk or curb. All of such work shall be subject to the approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1959, § 19-55) 
Sec. 8-1096. - Same—Line and grade to be obtained. 
Any person grading, paving or changing the condition of any sidewalk or curb shall first apply in writing to the city engineer and obtain the proper line and grade for such sidewalk or curb, and the city shall have a reasonable length of time in which to furnish the same. 
(Code 1959, § 19-56) 
Sec. 8-1097. - Same—Time of completion. 
No permit issued under the provisions of section 8-1095 shall be valid unless the work for which same is issued shall be completed within thirty (30) days from the date of the issuance of the permit therefor. 
(Code 1959, § 19-57) 
Sec. 8-1098. - Refusal of city to give line or grade for curbs or sidewalks. 
The city may in its discretion refuse to give the line or grade for any curb or sidewalk within the limits of the city, in which case the sidewalk or curbing shall not be molested. 
(Code 1959, § 19-58) 
Sec. 8-1099. - Authority of director of public works. 
The director of public works shall have supervision over sidewalks and curbing and shall see that any person changing the condition of any sidewalk or curb shall have obtained the proper permit, line, grade and specifications and before accepting any sidewalk or curb work shall determine that the proper line, grade and specifications have been complied with. 
(Code 1959, § 19-59; Ord. No. 877-85, § 1, 3-4-85) 
Secs. 8-1100—8-1102. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 2. - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 027-04, § 1, adopted Dec. 20, 2004, repealed former Chs. 2—5 in their entirety and enacted an new Ch. 2 as herein set out. Former Ch. 2 pertained to electric and water utilities, former Ch. 3 pertained to sewers, former Ch. 4 was reserved, and former Ch. 5 pertained to stormwater. Ordinances from which these former chapters derived are listed in the Code comparative table at the end of this volume.

ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 007-13, adopted March 18, 2013, amended former Div. 1, §§ 8-2001—8-2016 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 1 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 012-10, § 1, adopted Aug. 2, 2010. 

Sec. 8-2001. - Introduction. 
The City of East Point shall provide water, electricity, sanitation and sewer services to its residents and businesses as provided herein, unless said resident or business is eligible to choose its service provider as allowed by state or federal laws or regulations. Entities outside the city limits may be provided any or all such services on a contractual basis with any such contracts approved by city council. 
(Ord. No. 007-13, 3-18-13) 
Sec. 8-2002. - Definitions. 
Customer. Customers shall include any and all individuals, commercial entities or industries that obtain from the City of East Point retail electrical, water, sanitation and sewer services. 
(a)  Residential customers shall include individuals who own or rent a single-family residence, whether it is a house, an apartment, a condominium, a mobile home or any other structure permitted for residential dwelling. 
(b)  Commercial customers shall include any business or corporate entity. 
(c)  Industrial customers shall include entities meeting such criteria as shall be established by the city in writing from time to time. 
Cut-off shall refer to the termination of service to a customer as provided for in section 8-2011. 
Deposit shall refer to the deposit required of customers in section 8-2012 below. 
Due date shall refer to the due date described in subsection 8-2009(e) below. 
Late fee shall refer to the late fee described in subsection 8-2009(f) below. 
Payment plan shall refer to a negotiated term through Customer Care to pay a specific utility bill over a period, not to exceed twelve (12) months. 
Payment arrangement shall refer to a negotiated arrangement to pay a specific utility bill in full within thirty (30) days of its due date. 
Reconnect fee shall refer to the reconnect fee described in subsection 8-2011(d) below. 
Substantial improvements shall refer to any rehabilitation or remodeling to a residential unit that requires a permit from planning and zoning and is an alteration, modification or repair impacting at least twenty-five (25) percent or more of the residential unit. 
(Ord. No. 007-13, 3-18-13) 
Sec 8-2003. - Agreement for use of utility service. 
Any person receiving utility service from the city shall execute and comply with all rules and regulations of the city regarding the use of utilities. 
(Ord. No. 007-13, 3-18-13) 
Sec. 8-2004. - Installation of meters. 
For each new utility customer or where service is rebuilt or relocated for the convenience of or at the request of the customer, installation and connection charges shall be paid by the customer. The charges shall be recommended by staff and approved by the city council. Said charges shall be posted in Customer Care department and on the city website. Said charges shall be in addition to any other charges levied for provision of service. 
(a)  The city shall furnish electric meters and the customer shall furnish the electrical receptacles and water meters and receptacles shall be furnished as specified in subsections 8-2004 (e through k) below. 
(b)  No charge shall be incurred for normal maintenance or repair associated due to normal wear and age, provided that such repairs are acknowledged by public utilities as part of the city's normal maintenance responsibility. 
(c)  All meters shall be the sole property of the city and complete ownership and control of the meters shall be vested in the city. The city reserves the right in the event of actual or threatened power failure or safety hazard to make repairs of a permanent or temporary nature on the meters. No meter shall be tampered with or altered in a manner as to affect the safety, convenience, adequacy or the accuracy of the metering service in any manner, direct or indirect. 
(d)  If any materials or work associated with the customer's service installation are provided by the customer, such materials and/or work shall conform to the specifications and requirements as established by the city in writing from time to time. 
(e)  The service line from the water main to the meter box and three (3) feet beyond is type "K" soft copper. All connections on copper services shall be flared or compression type. The water and sewer department shall approve any exceptions in advance. 
(f)  All water main taps will be the same size or larger than the service line and meter. Multiple smaller, taps manifold together to achieve an equivalent tap size is not allowed. For taps larger than two (2) inches in diameter, a tapping sleeve and valve are required. The tapping sleeve shall be per the City of East Point Water and Sewer Department standard specifications. 
(g)  All meters are required to be of the type and brand as approved by the water and sewer department. All water meters less than two (2) inches shall be purchased from the city in addition to the water tap fee unless the water user is constructing a new development serving seven (7) or more residential customers. The property owner or water user shall purchase and install all other meters two (2) inches and above. The water and sewer department shall approve the type of meter such as turbine, compound, etc. All meters larger than two (2) inches shall be installed with the appropriate valves and a bypass, where, in the judgment of the water and sewer department, uninterruptible service is mandated and/or important. 
(h)  City policy is that a tap fee is due any time a new service tap or connection is made to the city's water main. This includes location where taps have previously been made and have been or are being abandoned. The city may waive the tap or connection fee at its discretion in cases where the existing tap is being abandoned and the location of the new tap is to the city's benefit. In all cases, a plumbing permit and, if applicable, a street cut permit are required. 
(i)  Meters shall be at least eighteen (18) inches and not more than thirty (30) inches in the ground. If a change in grade of the yard, parking or sidewalk is made the service line and meter shall be changed to correspond with this requirement. 
(j)  Although the city does not make taps larger than one (1) inch in diameter for water services, it is required, by state law, to inspect them. It is the contractor's responsibility to notify the water and sewer department directly. A tapping inspector from the water and sewer department shall be present before and during the actual cutting of the tap. If a tap is made before the water and sewer department inspector arrives, this will be a code violation. It is crucial for the inspector to observe that the tap coupon and cutting are recovered and not lost into the water main. The inspector shall further check the construction of the service line from the water main to the meter and the meter installation to ensure compliance with city codes. The contractor, prior to inspection, shall not cover any connections or fittings. 
(k)  The property owner or water user shall be responsible for the purchase of their required water meter. The customer shall purchase water meters less than two (2) inches and boxes from the City of East Point only if the water meter is being installed by the city. The city will install service tap, meter and meter box for any residential water meter ranging in size from five-eighth ( 5/8 ) inch to one and one-half (1½) inches serving residential customers and where one meter per residential customer is installed not to exceed six (6) total meters. 
(Ord. No. 007-13, 3-18-13) 
Sec. 8-2005. - Meter location. 
All utility meters for the measurement of electricity or water supplied by the city shall be installed outdoors. Electric meters shall be located on the property at a distance of four (4) feet above the ground. When outside installation is impractical, other installations may be made with standard meter sockets at acceptable locations with the permission of the city. 
(Ord. No. 007-13, 3-18-13) 
Sec. 8-2006. - Separate meters required for multiple dwellings. 
(a)  Owners of all new multi-family residential dwellings or complexes or any unit permitted for a substantial improvement shall install separate electric meters for each individual dwelling unit. If an owner of multi-family dwelling or complex fails to install such separate electric meter for each individual dwelling unit, the electric service to such customer at said address shall be discontinued until such property owner complies with the requirements of this section. 
(b)  All new multi-family residential dwellings, apartments, townhomes, condominiums, mobile home parks shall be built with individual water utility owned meters on each unit or sub-unit meters owned and managed by the property owner with a utility owned master meter that bills for water service based on volume of use for each customer. The billing for water use can be accomplished by the water provider or by a private, third party, such as the development owner, if conditions are met and approved by the water and sewer department director. If existing city owned rights-of-way are not suitable for the installation of individual meters, the following conditions must be met for the installation of individual meters on private property: 
(1)  The owners of all individual living units shall grant easements to the city for meter installation within ten feet of the curb line of existing rights-of-way for water mains. 
(2)  The easements shall comply with the specifications then in force of the department of water. 
(3)  The owner of all individual living units shall sign an agreement indemnifying the city from any and all damage claims resulting from the installation, maintenance of and access to meters on private property. 
(4)  The owner of each individual living premises shall sign a written acknowledgment that water lines between the meter and living unit and the living unit interior plumbing will be maintained by the owner and that cutoff valves must be installed by the owner on the discharge side of the meter box at or near the property line. 
(5)  If required in lieu of dedicated streets, a twenty-foot right-of-way centered on the water main shall be conveyed to the city, except that the director of the water and sewer department may accept a narrower right-of-way where obstructions are involved. 
If an owner of multi-family dwelling or complex fails to install such separate water meter for each individual dwelling unit, the water service to such customer at said address shall be discontinued until such property owner complies with the requirements of this section.
