(6)  Upon the licensed premises of a hotel, except for any area within the premises of a hotel being operated as a nightclub as defined herein. 
(7)  In any theater, concert hall, or similar establishment which is primarily devoted to theatrical performances. As used in this section only, the phrase "theater, concert hall, or similar establishment which is primarily devoted to theatrical performances" shall mean a building, playhouse, room, hall, or other place, licensed for consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises, having affixed seats so arranged that a body of spectators can have an unobstructed view of the stage upon which theatrical, vaudeville, live concert or similar performances are given, and in which the serving of alcoholic beverages is clearly incidental to such performances, and where the revenue derived from the sale of alcoholic beverages is insubstantial when compared to all other sources of gross revenue; provided, that the person under the age of twenty-one (21) years is attending a lawful activity, show, exhibition, performance or event on the premises or is required to be present as a condition of his employment. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1012. - Posting signs as to restrictions. 
Every licensee herein referred to shall keep a sign conspicuously posted over or near each entrance to any place from which persons under twenty-one (21) years are herein restricted giving public notice of such fact. The wording and size of such signs shall be in accordance with such regulations as the chief of police may prescribe. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Secs. 11-1013—11-1039. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - APPLICATION AND LICENSE FOR ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

Sec. 11-1040. - License required. 
No alcoholic beverages shall be manufactured, imported, brokered, sold to wholesalers or other importers or brokers, sold at wholesale or retail in the original package or by the drink nor shall any bottle house or tasting room be operated except under a license granted by the city as provided in this division. No licensee shall be authorized to operate a business until the license required in this section has been paid for by money order, certified check or cashier's check, and delivered to the licensee by the proper city official. Where there is a pending application for a new licensee or a change of ownership on a prior existing licensed premises, the authority of the prior licensee to operate the business shall be extended for a maximum period of thirty (30) days beyond the termination date of the prior license. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1041. - Keeping or storing without appropriate license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating a place licensed for the sale of malt beverages or wine or both to store or have therein any distilled spirits without an appropriate license therefor. 
(b)  The requirements of the chapter shall be in addition to any other requirements for business licenses under the Code, and if other licensing provisions of the Code conflict with this chapter, then this chapter shall control. 
(c)  Licenses which may be issued under this chapter include: 
(1)  Manufacturing for malt beverages, wines, and or distilled spirits; 
(2)  Wholesale for malt beverages, wines and/or distilled spirits; 
(3)  Retail for malt beverages, wines, and/or distilled spirits; 
(4)  Consumption of the premises for malt beverages, wine, and/or distilledspirits; 
(5)  Any combination of the above at the same location provided no retail or wholesale licensee shall hold any consumption-on-the-premises license for the same location. 
(d)  There shall be no greater ratio than one (1) retail sale of alcoholic beverage licensee per one thousand five hundred (1,500) residents for a retail business with a square footage of retail space of ten thousand (10,000) or less square feet, no greater ratio than one (1) retail sale of alcoholic beverage licensee per one thousand five hundred (1,500) residents for a retail business with a square footage of retail space of ten thousand one (10,001) square feet up to forty-five thousand (45,000) square feet and no greater ratio than one (1) retail sale of alcoholic beverage licensee per one thousand five hundred (1,500) residents for a retail business with a square footage of retail space of forty-five thousand one (45,001) square feet or greater, but not including any fraction thereof, in the city. The population of the city will be based on the latest decennial census report. Any and all new applicants may place their names on the waiting list maintained by the business licensee clerk and will be eligible on a first come first serve basis. This list will not apply to those businesses exempt by state regulation or a transfer of an existing license. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ; Ord. No. 010-014, 8-18-14 ) 
Sec. 11-1042. - Time limits on opening and continuing business. 
(a)  All licensees issued under this chapter must, within one hundred eighty (180) days (six (6) months), after the issuance of a city license, open for business. Failure to open for business shall constitute forfeiture and cancellation of the issued licenses and no refund of license fees or business taxes shall be made. Any applicant unable to comply with the time limit of this section may make written request to the chief of police or his/her or designee for an extension of time not to exceed ninety (90) days; and the chief of police at his or her discretion may grant or deny the request. 
(b)  In addition to the requirement set forth in subsection (a), where a building in which any person intends to operate under the provisions of this chapter is, at the time of the application for the license, not in existence or not yet completed, a license may be issued for the location provided the plans for the proposed building show clearly a compliance with the other provisions of this chapter. No sales or consumption shall be allowed in the establishment until it has been completed in accordance with the plans and is in conformity with all of the other provisions of the chapter and the Code. 
(c)  Any license issued under this chapter shall automatically be null and void when the licensed business has not operated or been open to the public for six (6) consecutive months. Said license shall automatically become null and void and be of no further force or effect without the necessity of any action of the chief of police. Hotels, lounges, bars, nightclubs, and restaurants shall be governed by this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1043. - Prohibited interests. 
(a)  No person who has any direct financial interest in a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at wholesale shall hold any other license or an interest in any other license under this chapter. 
(b)  No person, related within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity under civil law to any wholesale licensee or employee thereof or any person with any interest therein shall hold any other license or an interest in any other license issued under this chapter. 
(c)  No elected or full-time appointed official of the city or any person related within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity under civil law to such an official of the city shall own any interest in any license issued under this chapter unless the interest was obtained prior to election or appointment to office. 
(d)  No full-time employee of the police department or the employee's spouse or domestic partner or minor children shall own, control, or have a financial interest, in whole or partial or a beneficial interest in any license to sell alcoholic beverages to any license to operate a bottle house in the city. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1044. - Application. 
(a)  All persons desiring to obtain a license required under this chapter shall make written application to the East Point police department for that privilege upon forms approved by the city. The licensing process shall consist of two (2) applications. The short application is required of all licensees granting the police department authorization to perform a criminal background check of the licensee. The long application is for persons desiring to obtain a license for the premises and not solely for the pouring and serving of alcoholic beverages. The applicant shall complete one or both applications, as the case may be, and file it with the police department along with all required supporting documentation and the license fee payable by money order, certified check or cashier's check for all of the minimum fees and business taxes provided for in this Code for the classification into which the applicant falls. The police department shall deposit the funds into the appropriate accounts. 
(b)  The application shall be sworn to by the applicant or agent thereof and shall state the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  If a corporation, the names of the officers; 
(3)  If a partnership, the names of the partners; 
(4)  The address where the proposed business is to be located; 
(5)  Information regarding the distance of the location from the uses identified in Article A provided, however, that such information need not be provided if the proposed business or location is exempt from or not required to comply with the measurements identified in Article A of this chapter. 
(6)  The nature and character of the business to be carried on; 
(7)  The hours or operation of the proposed licensed business; 
(8)  The name of the agent/licensee; 
(9)  The name of the manager of the business; 
(10)  The identity of the owner of the property where the business is located; 
(11)  The plan for traffic flow, control and access in case of fire or other catastrophe; 
(12)  Ingress and egress to the property and proposed structure or uses thereon with particular preference to automotive and pedestrian safety and convenience; 
(13)  Parking and loading areas where required, with particular attention to the items in subsections (11) and (12) immediately preceding this subsection; 
(14)  Refuse and service areas and plans for maintenance thereof; 
(15)  The plan for appropriate buffering or screening to alleviate such potentially adverse effects as may be created by noise, glare, odor, lighting, signs or traffic congestion; 
(16)  Security plans and plans for training of employees; 
(17)  The nature of any entertainment to be provided on premises; 
(18)  Provisions for parking; 
(19)  A legal description of the property upon which the premises are located; 
(20)  A current photograph of the applicant; 
(21)  Fingerprints of the applicant to be taken by the police department; 
(22)  Such other information as may be required by the police department to investigate compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  All applicants shall furnish all data, information and records requested of them in writing by the police department and failure to furnish this data, information and records within thirty (30) days from the date of the request shall automatically dismiss, with prejudice, the application provided however the chief of police may extend the time to respond for good cause shown. Applicants, by filing an application, agree to produce for oral interrogation any person requested by the police department or the city attorney and considered as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to the license. The failure to produce the person within thirty (30) days after being requested to do so shall result in the automatic dismissal of the application provided, however, the chief of police may extend the time to respond for good cause shown. 
(c)  Each application shall contain an oath providing that the information disclosed is true and correct, and providing further that the applicant will abide by, observe and conduct his/her business according to the rules and regulations prescribed by the city, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq. (Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Act), as now or hereafter amended, and the rules and regulations of the State Department of Revenue in respect thereto. The oath shall be taken by the applicant and the agent-in-charge of the establishment, is different from or additional to the applicant, as well as the true owners. Any untrue or misleading information contained in either application or material omission left out of an original or renewal application for an alcoholic beverage license shall be sufficient cause for denial thereof. Moreover, any misstatement or concealment of fact in either application shall subject the applicant to prosecution for false swearing under Georgia law and shall constitute a violation of this chapter, which may be prosecuted as an offense against the city, punishable as provided by the city's charter. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1045. - Residency required; agents. 
(a)  All applications for licenses under this chapter by any person, firm or corporation shall name in the application one (1) or more residents of the State of Georgia who reside in the following counties: Fulton, Dekalb, Cobb, Clayton, Gwinnett, Cherokee, Douglas, Fayette, Coweta, Paulding. Henry or Forsyth (collectively referred to as "Metropolitan Atlanta"), as the agent and representative of the person, firm or corporation to receive all communications, notices, service of process or other papers or documents, on behalf of the person, firm or corporation in connection with any matter arising out of or connected with the issuance, holding, suspension, revocation or other action with respect to any city license. The application shall give the mailing address of the agent, and the mailing to any agent, at that address provided, of any notice required to be given under this chapter or any other law shall be sufficient notice to the person, firm or corporation. Additionally, the person must be a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence. If any agent shall cease to be a resident of the State of Georgia, another person shall immediately be appointed agent in writing in his or her place, and written notice shall be given to the police chief or a designee stating the name and address of the new agent within thirty (30) days. The additional following requirements shall also apply: 
(b)  Sale of packaged distilled spirits. No license for the sale of distilled spirits by the package shall be granted to any applicant who is not a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence and who has not resided continuously within the state and Metropolitan Atlanta, as defined in subsection (a) of this section, for a one-year period preceding the year for which application is made. If the applicant is a corporation whose primary business is the operation of a liquor store, the majority stockholder must meet the requirements of this subsection, and the license shall be issued to the corporation and the majority stockholder. If the applicant is a corporation whose primary business is other than the operation of a liquor store, the license shall be issued to the corporation and an officer or agent of the corporation who meets the requirements of this subsection. If the applicant is a partnership, the same requirements pertaining to corporations shall apply to all partnerships. 
(c)  Sale of distilled spirits for on-premises consumption. No license for the sale of distilled spirits for on-premises consumption shall be granted to any applicant who is not a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence and who is not, at the time the application is made, a resident of Metropolitan Atlanta, as defined in subsection (a) of this section. If the applicant is a corporation, partnership or association, the license shall be issued to the corporation, partnership or association and an officer or agent of the corporation, partnership or association who meets the requirements of this subsection. 
(d)  Grounds for denial or revocation. The inability of the police chief to verify any statement of information required to be disclosed on forms furnished by the police chief or to be able to adequately conduct a full investigation of an applicant or a place of business due to foreign background, ties or interest or for any reason beyond the police chief's control shall be, in addition to all other grounds, cause for denial of any license and, if any license has been granted, shall be cause for revocation of the license. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1046. - Preliminary review of application. 
(a)  The chief of police or a designee shall cause an inquiry to be made into the city tax records to determine if the applicant or other parties with interest in the application have any outstanding taxes or special assessments that are delinquent against his or her property or any other monies owning to the city. No license shall be issued or renewed until such debts are paid in full. 
(b)  All applications shall be reviewed by the chief of police or a designee. In the event that the police department determines that the application is not in order, in view of the requirements of federal or state law or this Code and any police department investigation, the chief of police or a designee shall then notify the applicant in writing of the adverse issues with the application and schedule an informal meeting. The applicant shall have ten (10) business days in which to respond by attending the meeting and providing any explanation or submission of additional information which may explain or ameliorate the adverse issue(s). The applicant does not waive any rights under this chapter by rejecting the offer to meet; however, the police chief will proceed to provide his/her recommendation to the council and shall disclose the adverse issues and the applicant's decision to decline the offer to meet. If the applicant accepts the offer to meet, the meeting is not a formal hearing and neither the applicant nor the city may have legal counsel present. This informal meeting shall not limit the city or applicant from presenting a more detailed and complete analysis of the adverse issue(s) with an application at subsequent hearings, including presentation of witnesses and documents not available at the time of the meeting. The police chief or his/her designee shall not provide assistance to any applicant in completing the applications. The police chief or a designee shall, after completing the preliminary report, provide the report to the mayor and city council with a recommendation to approve or deny the application, and the reasons therefore if the recommendation is to deny. The council will consider the recommendation after public comment on the application is received by the council. 
(c)  All applicants shall furnish all reasonable data, information and records requested of them by the police chief or a designee and failure to furnish such data, information, contracts, documents, financial statements and other records within thirty (30) days of the request shall automatically serve to dismiss the application. 
(d)  The police chief or a designee shall fingerprint and perform a background investigation of each person interested in the application, including any person with a financial interest, such as stockholders, partners or employees, and any spouse, brother, child or parent of any person with a financial interest. Should the applicant fail to produce such persons within thirty (30) days of the request, the application may be denied. 
(e)  Applicants by filing an application agree to produce for oral interrogation any person or persons requested by the chief of police or a designee and considered as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to such license. The failure to produce those persons within thirty (30) days after being requested to do so will result in a denial of the application. 
(f)  The city may require forty-five (45) days for processing any application for a license required under this chapter. For investigative purposes, the chief of police may extend the forty-five (45) days' processing period according to the applicant's compliance should the police chief or a designee deem it necessary. 
(g)  Irrespective of the recommendation of the police chief, should the mayor and city council deny the issuance of an alcohol license, the applicant shall have the right to appeal to the alcohol appeal board. All applicants for alcohol licenses who appeal to the alcohol appeal board shall abide by the following regulations at the hearing: 
(1)  The applicant shall appear before the alcohol appeal board on the scheduled date set forth in the notice to appear. At such hearing, the applicant shall be prepared to respond, to the best of his ability, to any questions regarding the application(s). The applicant shall provide, to the best of his ability, any additional relevant information about the proposed licensed establishment, which the alcohol appeals board requests. 
(2)  If the applicant fails to appear at the hearing on the scheduled set forth in the notice to appear and also fails to request an alternative date for the hearing, the applicant will be deemed to have abandoned his/her right to appeal. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1047. - License to sell from leased premises. 
Any person desiring to obtain a license to sell alcoholic beverages in a leased location within a licensed premises, shall, in addition to the application required hereinabove, provide additional sworn application forms and the required application fees for each proposed leased location. The prospective lessees shall in all other respects comply with this code section. In the event a licensee shall seek to change, substitute or add a leased location within the licensed premises, then before alcohol sales can continue or commence, the individuals in control of the proposed leased locations must comply with the provisions of this code section. No applicant or licensee may allow sales of alcoholic beverages at a leased location within a licensed premise without compliance with this section and all other applicable provisions of this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1048. - False information in applications. 
Any material omission, untrue or misleading information contained in or left out of an original, renewal or transfer application for a license under this division shall be cause for the denial thereof, and if any license has previously been granted, these circumstances shall constitute cause for revocation. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1049. - Minimum age of applicant. 
No application for any license under this chapter shall be granted unless the agent/licensee has attained the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1050. - Notice of application/appeal to be published; signs. 
(a)  Prior to any presentation and recommendation by the police chief for any applicant before city council, each applicant for a license under this division shall give notice of the purpose of making the application by advertisement at least two times on different days in the legal organ of Fulton County in which the legal advertisements of the city are carried. The notice shall contain a legal description of the location of the proposed business and shall give the name of the applicant and, if a partnership, the names of the partners and, if a corporation, the names of the officers and the date and time the license review board would hear the application. The second day of the advertisement shall be at least ten (10) days prior to the council meeting at which the application will be considered. The advertisement referred to in this subsection shall be in type not smaller than ten point capital and lower case and shall be at least one inch, one column advertisement. 
(b)  The running of the advertisement required in this section in a newspaper may be concurrent with the time after the application for a license is filed, and if the two (2) days' advertisement is not made before the filing of the application, the application shall state that the advertisement is being made. The applicant shall also cause to be placed upon the location of the proposed premises to be licensed, signs of a size, number and form prescribed by the police chief or a designee stating the time, date and location of the council meeting for which the hearing on the application or appeal before mayor and city council shall occur for the two (2) weeks immediately preceding the public hearing. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1051. - Tasting rooms of farm wineries. 
No tasting room shall be operated except under a license granted by city council as provided in this section. The applicant for a tasting room license must be a farm winery and must meet all legal requirements contained in this chapter for the sale of wine by the package and for the sale of wine by the drink. Individual patrons of tasting rooms may be given or sold samples of up to seven (7) different wines for consumption, but may not be given or sold in excess of five ounces of wine in any one two-hour period. A tasting room license shall allow the license holder to sell wine by the package and to give or sell wine samples at one location. No other license shall be required for the tasting room location pursuant to this chapter. Tasting room licensees are subject to all laws, rules and regulations of the state and are subject to revocation for violation thereof. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1052. - Grounds for non-acceptance of application. 
No application for a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be accepted by the police department or considered by city council if the person applying has had a license to conduct a similar type business denied or revoked by city council within the immediately preceding twenty-four (24) months for any reason other than location disqualification. 
For purposes of this section, the twenty-four (24) month period shall be tolled during any period of time that an appeal is pending of said denial or revocation, or any period of time that by operation of law the city cannot enforce said denial or revocation, or any period of time during which there is in place a valid, voluntary agreement between the city and the entity denied a license or whose license has been revoked to not enforce the decision pending the outcome of litigation in any way involving said denial or revocation. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1053. - Issuance to persons with prior convictions. 
No original license for the sale of or permit to serve alcoholic beverages or the operation of a bottle house shall be issued to any person, partnership or corporation for pecuniary gain if any individual having an interest, either as owner, partner or principal stockholder, directly or indirectly, beneficial or absolute, or the individual's spouse shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere, within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of the application, for any felony or misdemeanor of any state or of the United States or any municipal ordinance, except traffic violations. The term "conviction" includes an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime; if the violation is for a misdemeanor, forfeiture of bond, municipal ordinance or if there is a plea of nolo contendere, the alcohol appeals board may, after denial and an investigation, waive that disqualification after a hearing and recommend the approval of the license to council but it shall be city council which shall make the final determination. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1054. - Grounds for denial. 
Council shall receive public comment with regard to the application after the preliminary application review is completed by the police chief or his/her designee. Upon conclusion of the public comment, the city council may approve the application upon the determination that the application is in compliance with federal and state law and this Code. Alternatively, city council may deny the application, subject to the applicant's right to a hearing before the alcohol appeal board as provided herein, on any one or more of the following grounds: 
(1)  The applicant has had any license issued under the police powers of the city previously suspended or revoked; provided, however, the license review board may waive this subsection if two (2) years have passed since any prior revocation of any license held by the applicant; 
(2)  The applicant for a license to sell alcoholic beverages at a nightclub does not furnish evidence of adequate parking for a nightclub, as defined in Article A of the chapter, available to the applicant's patrons for the term of the license applied for and within 400 feet of the proposed licensed premises; 
(3)  The applicant, as a previous holder of a license to sell alcoholic beverages, has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to that business within a five-year period immediately preceding the date the application is presented to mayor and council; 
(4)  Any applicant for a retail license is related to any distributor or wholesaler of alcoholic beverages or related to any stockholder of a distributor or wholesaler of alcoholic beverages or related to any employee engaged in a management position by any distributor or wholesaler of alcoholic beverages within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as computed according to the civil law; 
(5)  That an applicant for renewal that is exempt from the certain distance requirements has failed to provide the police department with a statement from a certified public accountant evidencing that the package store derived less than the percentage established by ordinance of gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages; 
(6)  The application does not furnish evidence of adequate parking as defined in this chapter. This parking requirement is in addition to the requirement of subsection (3) of this section; 
(7)  Failure to meet state requirements for state license; 
(8)  Failure to pay required fees and taxes; 
(9)  Failure to provide valid or complete information, documents and the like required by this chapter; 
(10)  False information in the application(s) or attached documents; 
(11)  Improper residency of applicant, owner or registered agents; 
(12)  Failure to pass review by the chief of police of; 
(i)  The criminal background of the applicant; and 
(ii)  Criminal activity during the prior two (2) years within a one-mile radius of the location for which the application is sought; 
(13)  Failure to comply with the zoning laws as reported to the police department by the planning and zoning commission; 
(14)  Failure to meet distance requirements for a license of the class applied for; and/or 
(15)  Prior convictions as herein provided. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1055. - Open to inspection. 
Any establishment holding a license issued under this chapter shall at all times, during the period allowable by law for operation of the business, be open to inspection by any officer of the police department or any licensed inspector of the city or to any person designated by the police chief or the city manager. In addition, if the premises are being used after hours by employees or the owners or their agents, the premises may be inspected at this time by the designated persons in this section. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1056. - Open containers prohibited; exception. 
No bottle or other container of alcoholic beverages shall be opened or consumed by any person on the premises or in any adjacent parking area, upon which the place of business is conducted and licensed under this chapter, whether the bottle or other container so opened or consumed was bought or obtained at that place of business or elsewhere unless the premises is licensed for consumption on the premises under this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1057. - Transfer of license. 
(a)  Scope of section. Licenses hereunder shall not be transferable, except as otherwise provided herein. All transfers will require the applicant to pay the same fee as new applicants and go through the same process as a new applicant. 
(b)  Withdrawal of partner. Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more of the partners in a partnership holding a license from withdrawing from the partnership in favor of one or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of such license. Such a withdrawal shall not, however, serve to bring any new ownership into the partnership. 
(c)  New ownership. New ownership of an existing business will occur when an existing business is purchased or transferred in its entirety to a new person, persons or entity. The new owner must follow the same procedures as a new applicant. 
(d)  Addition of partners, stockholders. A licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined by the city that the additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or expanding the facilities of the business, or for building new facilities and where it appears that neither the licensee himself, nor any partner or stockholder therein receives directly or indirectly any of the additional capital invested. Under this section an additional partner or new principal stockholder must be approved by the city. 
(e)  Transfer from agent to agent; name change. Where licenses are held by agents, upon the resignation or removal of an agent holding the license for a particular location, the partners, owners or stockholders of the business entity shall immediately appoint a new agent to hold said license, which agent shall apply to the police department of the city for the reissuance of the license for the stated location in his name. Upon completion of the police background check and investigation as required herein, the police department shall make a recommendation to the licensing administrator for the approval or disapproval of the transfer of agent. In such a transfer, it will be required that a new investigation fee be paid for the investigation for the new agent, but no new fees for the issuance of the license will be collected until the normal expiration date of the existing license. In those instances in which only the name of the establishment holding a license is to change, with no change in the ownership or agent holding the license, the partners, owners or stockholders shall notify the police department of the change of name, which notation shall be made on the records of the police department and forwarded to those city offices as required by the police chief. No charge will be made for this name change. 
(f)  Licenses hereunder shall be transferable from licensee to licensee at the same location. Transfers are granted only if there is no lapse in time from the transfer from one licensee to another licensee, except when there is a death of a licensee, then this period may be extended to six (6) months. It is a requirement that a death certificate be presented to the police department, and the new applicant must meet the requirements to become a licensee. 
A new applicant for a license at an existing licensed location is exempt from the distance requirements as long as a lapse in license does not exceed six (6) months at that location. All prospective licensees must meet the requirements of a new applicant as set forth in this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1058. - Days and hours of operation. 
(a)  No licensee shall sell, give away or otherwise dispense distilled spirits, wines, champagnes or malt beverages between the hours of 11:59 p.m. Saturday and 6:00 a.m., Monday except those establishments which are licensed to sell distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine and which derive at least fifty-one (51) percent of their total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or foods in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served, or derive at least fifty-one (51) percent of their total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging, in which case such business may, in addition to the afore-described hours, open from the hours of 12:30 p.m. Sunday to and including 12:00 midnight Sunday. 
(b)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20(b)(2)(B), it is hereby ordained that any license holder may sell distilled spirits, wines, champagnes or malt beverages on any election day provided such sale does not occur within two hundred fifty (250) feet of any polling place or the outer edge of any building within which such polling places is established on primary or election days. 
(c)  Packaged distilled spirits. Licensees in distilled spirits by the package shall not engage in the sale of such distilled spirits except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on weekdays Monday through Friday, between 9:00 a.m. and 11:59 on Saturdays, and between 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sundays. No licensee shall, sell give away or otherwise dispense packaged distilled spirits between the hours of 11:30 p.m. Sunday and 9:00 a.m. Monday. 
(d)  Packaged wine and malt beverages. Licensees in packaged wine and malt beverages shall not engage in the sale of such wine and malt beverages except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on weekdays Monday through Friday, between 9:00 a.m. and 11:59 on Saturdays, and between 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sundays. No licensee shall, sell, give away or otherwise dispense packaged wine or malt beverages, between the hours of 11:30 p.m. Sunday and 9:00 a.m. Monday. 
(e)  Sale of wine or malt beverages for on premises consumption. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7 and as set out in a. and b. below, all license holders for the sale of wine or malt beverages for consumption on the premises shall be authorized to engage in the sale of wine or malt beverages on Tuesday through Friday between the hours of 9:00 a.m. on one day and 5:00 a.m. of the following day and on Saturday from 9:00 a.m. to 2:55 a.m. on Sunday. Sales of wine or malt beverages for consumption on the premises may start again at 12:01 a.m. on Monday and continue until 5:00 a.m. on Tuesday. 
a.  Wine and/or malt beverages may be sold on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight in public stadiums, coliseums and auditoriums with a seating capacity in excess of three thousand five hundred (3,500) persons, and in restaurants. 
b.  Wine and/or malt beverages also may be served on Sunday with the issuance of a special event permit. 
(2)  Anytime December 31st falls on a Sunday, beer and wine may be sold by the drink for consumption on the premises between the hours of 12:30 p.m. Sunday, December 31st, to 12:00 a.m. Monday, January 1st, only in public stadiums, coliseums and auditoriums with a seating capacity in excess of three thousand five hundred (3,500) persons, and in restaurants. Anytime December 31st falls on a Sunday, all other establishments licensed to sell beer and wine by the drink for consumption on the premises may sell such beer and wine between the hours on 12:01 a.m. Monday, January 1st, to 2:55 a.m. Monday, January 1st. Anytime St. Patrick's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day and Labor Day fall on a Monday, beer and wine may be sold by the drink for consumption on the premises between the hours of 12:30 p.m. of that particular prior Sunday, to 12:00 a.m. Monday, on the date of that particular holiday, only in public stadiums, coliseums and auditoriums with a seating capacity in excess of three thousand five hundred (3,500) persons, and in restaurants. Anytime Independence Day falls on a Sunday, beer and wine may be sold by the drink for consumption on the premises between the hours of 12:30 a.m. of that particular Sunday, to 12:00 a.m. Monday, the next day, only in public stadiums, coliseums and auditoriums with a seating capacity in excess of three thousand five hundred (3,500) persons: and in restaurants. 
(3)  This section shall apply in all respects to private clubs, as defined by this ordinance, except as provided by O.C.G.A. § 3-7-2 to the public at the time set by this section for the discontinuance of the sale of alcohol and the premises cleared of patrons within thirty (30) minutes after the time set by this section for discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
(f)  Sale of distilled spirits by the drink or for on premises consumption. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7, and as set out in a. and b.) below, all license holders for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink or for the operation of a bottle house on the premises shall be authorized to engage in the sale of those distilled spirits only on Tuesday through Friday between the hours of 9:00 a.m. of one day and 5:00 a.m. of the following day and on Saturday from 9:00 a.m. to 2:55 a.m. on Sunday. Sales of distilled spirits by the drink or for on premises consumption may start again on Monday at 12:01 a.m. and continue until 5:00 a.m. on Tuesday. 
a.  Distilled spirits may be sold on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 a.m. in public stadiums, coliseums and auditoriums with a seating capacity in excess of three thousand five hundred (3,500) persons, and in restaurants. 
b.  Distilled spirits also may be served on Sunday with the issuance of a special event permit. 
(2)  Anytime December 31st falls on a Sunday, beer and wine may be sold by the drink for consumption on the premises between the hours of 12:30 p.m. Sunday, December 31st, to 12:00 a.m. Monday, January 1st, only in public stadiums, coliseums and auditoriums, except as provided by O.C.G.A. § 3-7-2. 
(g)  Time limit for clearing patrons from premises. Establishments other than restaurants as described in this ordinance must be cleared of all patrons thirty (30) minutes after the sale of alcohol has been discontinued. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1059. - Drive-in and curb service prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to: 
(1)  Provide any alcoholic beverage outside of the licensed premises; 
(2)  Allow consumption on the premises except as allowed by Article D; 
(3)  Deliver any alcoholic beverages off the licensed premises, other than by wholesalers licensed hereunder or by the state. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1060. - Issuance to nonprofit performing arts theaters, museums, zoological parks, botanical gardens, and city park organizations for sale for consumption on premises. 
(a)  An applicant may be issued a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises of any nonprofit performing arts theater having a seating capacity of not less than one hundred (100), any nonprofit museum, any nonprofit zoological park, any nonprofit botanical garden, or any park facility, within the city upon meeting all of the following requirements and all other requirements of this chapter dealing with the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises: 
(1)  The applicant shall be a nonprofit corporation presenting legitimate indoor live performances or the applicant shall be a nonprofit museum, a nonprofit zoological park, a nonprofit botanical garden, or a city park organization; 
(2)  The performances of any such theater shall be held on a regular basis a minimum of three (3) times per week for a period of thirty-two (32) weeks per year; 
(3)  The applicant shall be the same group or corporation operating the nonprofit theater or nonprofit museum, nonprofit zoological park, nonprofit botanical garden, or park facility, and shall show that the profits from the sales under any license granted under this section shall be used for no purpose other than the sustaining and promotion of the theater, museum, zoological park, botanical garden, park facility, or the park in which the park facility is located; 
(4)  The applicant shall show by plat the physical delineation of the area where alcoholic beverages are to be sold; 
(5)  The location of the applicant shall not be within or upon any public property, whether federal, state, county or municipal, unless the applicant is a zoological park, botanical garden, or city park organization; 
(6)  The applicant shall be exempt from federal income taxes pursuant to section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended. 
(b)  The applicant shall pay an annual license fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and the fee shall be subject to all other rules and regulations relating to license fees for alcoholic beverages set forth in this chapter. 
(c)  Fees. The fire department and the building inspector, each shall charge a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for inspections made to ensure compliance status of structures where alcoholic beverage licenses are requested. 
(d)  For the purpose of this section, and notwithstanding the definition of premises contained in Article A, the premises of a park facility shall mean any number of the definite closed or portioned-in building(s), including any area or patio immediately adjacent to said building(s), which are located within one city-owned park, and wherein alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed. 
(1)  The area or patio need not be covered, but must be completely enclosed, except for entrances and exits, by a wall, fence, shrubbery or other decorative material no less than thirty (30) inches in height. 
(2)  Where any organization has agreements with the city to manage, operate or lease buildings located in more than one (1) city-owned park, the organization must hold a separate license for each park. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1061. - Right of licensee for sale by the drink; separate licenses required for package sales and sales for on-premises consumption. 
(a)  A licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink or for the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the licensee's premises shall have the right to serve malt beverages or wine or allow the consumption of malt beverages or wine on the licensee's premises during the same hours as are permitted under this article for the serving of distilled spirits by the drink. 
A licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink or for the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the licensee's premises shall have the right to serve malt beverages or wine to patrons seated in an outdoor dining area as part of the operation of a sidewalk cafe. A licensee operating a sidewalk cafe shall not have the right to serve malt beverages or wine to any person who is not seated, at a table, in a chair provided by the licensee. 
(b)  Licensees for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink, to allow the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises and for the sale of malt beverages by the drink, shall not permit the sale of distilled spirits by the bottle or package. These licensees shall have the right to sell wines, champagnes or malt beverages to the public by the bottle or package for consumption on the premises without the issuance of a separate retail license therefore. 
A licensee for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink shall have the right to allow the consumption of alcoholic beverages by patrons seated in an outdoor dining area as part of the operation of a sidewalk cafe. Bottles of beer and wine shall only be transported into outdoor dining areas and/or opened in outdoor dining areas by a licensee's working employees as part of their work duties. A licensee operating a sidewalk cafe shall not have the right to allow the consumption of alcoholic beverages by any person who is not seated, at a table, in a chair provided by the licensee. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1062. - Annual license fee; refunds. 
(a)  The annual license fee for each classification of license under this division shall be as follows: 
Fees Effective Beginning in the Fiscal Year 2014 
(1)  Wine. 
a.  Manufacturer of wine ..... $2,250.00 
b.  Wholesaler, importer and/or broker of wine ..... $2,000.00 
c.  Retail dealer in wine to be consumed on or off the premises of the dealer, which shall be authorized to conduct wine tasting events at any time during the year ..... $2,500.00 
d.  Retail dealer in wine to be consumed off the premises of the dealer only ..... $2,500.00 
e.  Tasting room for retail dealer in wine and wine to be consumed on the premises ..... $2,500.00 
f.  Tasting room for retail dealer in wine and wine to be consumed on the premises which sells wine by the package on Sunday ..... $3,750.00 
(2)  Malt beverages. 
a.  Brewer or manufacturer of beer ..... $5,000.00 
b.  Wholesaler, importer, and/or broker of beer ..... $2,000.00 
c.  Retail dealer of beer to be consumed on or off the premises of the dealer ..... $2,500.00 
d.  Retail dealer in beer to be consumed off the premises of the dealer only ..... $2,500.00 
(3)  Distilled spirits. 
a.  Manufacturer ..... $5,000.00 
b.  Manufacturer that manufactures, distills or blends liquors made whole from products raised in the state ..... $5,000.00 
c.  Wholesaler ..... $5,000.00 
d.  Retail sale in package form ..... $4,500.00 
Plus an amount equal to one percent of the gross sales of the previous year in excess of two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00), not to exceed a maximum license fee of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per annum. 
1.  In determining the license fee to be paid by any dealer in distilled spirits, each individual store or retail outlet shall be considered singly, and the license fee fixed shall be determined by sales made at each individual store. 
2.  Annual sales for the purpose of determining the license fee to be paid shall be the sales made by the store or outlet the previous twelve (12) months, except that all new stores or licenses shall, for the first year, pay three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per annum. 
(4)  Consumption on the premises of distilled spirits, wine and malt beverages. 
a.  Initial license ..... $5,000.00 
b.  Additional facility licenses, each ..... $5,000.00 
1.  Additional licenses shall be required for all additional facilities such as lounges, restaurants, nightclubs, patios or other areas located within the same building. 
2.  All restaurant patios and outdoor or open air eating areas which are immediately adjacent to restaurants shall be exempt from the additional facility license fee. 
3.  The licensee shall not provide any electronically amplified music or live entertainment on any patio, deck or in any other outdoor or open eating or drinking areas in which the licensed premises are within five hundred (500) feet of any area zoned for single-family residences. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no licensee shall provide any electronically amplified music or live entertainment on any patio, deck or in any other outdoor or open eating or drinking areas after 12:00 midnight. 
4.  All such licensees shall be required to comply with the requirements as to limitations on noise levels established by ordinance. 
c.  Bottle house ..... $2,000.00 
(5)  Retail of beer or wine off premises. 
a.  Initial license ..... $2,500.00 
b.  Leased locations as additional facilities, each license two thousand two hundred fifty dollars ($2,250.00). Additional licenses shall be required for each leased location located within a licensed premise. In no event, however, shall there be no more than four (4) additional facilities licenses at any location licensed for off premises consumption. Provided further, however, that the entire licensed location shall derive less than five (5) percent of its gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
Additional licenses shall be required for each leased location located within a licensed premise. In no event, however, shall there be no more than four (4) additional facilities licenses at any location licensed for off premises consumption. Provided further, however, that the entire licensed location shall derive less than five (5) percent of its gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(6)  Miscellaneous fees:* 
a.  Change of licensee ..... $500.00 
b.  Name change of business ..... $500.00 
c.  Change of ownership/stockholder ..... $500.00 
d.  Change of status (example: restaurant to bar) ..... $1,000.00 
e.  Additional bar ..... $1,000.00 
d.  Excise tax upon wholesalers for barrel or bulk containers of malt beverages not exceeding 15.5 gallons, per container ..... $6.00 
e.  Excise tax upon malt beverages sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, per 12 ounces or fraction therof ..... $0.05 
f.  Excise tax upon package sale of distilled spirits, per liter or fraction therof ..... $0.22 
g.  Excise tax upon sale of distilled spirits by the drink ..... 3% 
h.  Excise tax upon package sale of wine, per liter or fraction thereof ..... $0.22 
*Or percentage of sales in East Point as relates to total sales in distribution area, but in no event less than $100.00 
(b)  If the licensee is denied a license by the state, upon the proof of that refusal, the licensee shall be entitled to a refund of the license fee paid to the city, less a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to cover clerical cost of granting the license. If for any reason, the application for a city license is not approved, the applicant shall be entitled to a refund of the license fee pre-paid with the submission of the application, without interest. The refund may be made by the director of finance, with the approval of the city manager, and without the necessity of any action by the city council. 
(c)  No license shall be issued for less than a calendar year, and if a license is revoked or surrendered before the expiration of a calendar year, the holder thereof shall not be entitled to receive any refund. 
(d)  A licensee may be entitled to a refund of the license fee paid to the city if the licensed business cannot continue to be operated due to (i) destruction by fire or an act of God, (ii) death of the licensee, or (iii) any action taken by a governmental entity beyond the licensee's control. A refund shall not be granted if the license is revoked or suspended by resolution, approve or deny such refund. If a refund is approved by the council, the refund shall be calculated as follows: 
(1)  Three-fourths (¾)of the license fee if the licensee goes out of business during the first quarter of the calendar year. 
(2)  One-half (½) of the license fee if the licensee goes out of business during the second quarter of the calendar year. 
(3)  One-fourth (¼) of the license fee if the licensee goes out of business during the third quarter of the calendar year. 
(4)  No refund if the licensee goes out of business during the fourth quarter of the calendar year. 
(e)  If for any reason, the issuance of a license is delayed so as to entitle the applicant to pay a prorated portion of the license fee for the year when the applicant has already pre-paid with submission of the application the full year's license fee; the city shall refund any overpayment of license fees to the licensee within thirty (30) days after the license is issued. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1063. - Date for payment of license fees; prorated fees. 
Except as otherwise provided, duration and renewal of licenses under this chapter shall be as for business licenses generally; and no licensee shall have any vested right to the renewal of any city license. Moreover, except as otherwise provided in this Code, no licenses under this chapter may be renewed if the licensee could be denied a new license under this chapter. All annual license fees under this division shall be paid in advance by money order, certified check or cashier's check with submission of the renewal application on or before December 31st of each year. Any person granted a new license under this chapter during a calendar year shall pay the full license fee without proration by money order, certified check or cashier's check with submission of the application for a new license, except that the fee for a new license granted after June 30 in any calendar year shall be fifty (50) percent of the annual license fees for the remainder of that calendar year. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1064. - Supplemental requirements for sale of distilled spirits by the drink or for bottle house liquors for on-premises consumption. 
No license for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink or for the operation of a bottle house shall issue to any applicant who does not meet the requirements of a restaurant, hotel, private club, lounge, nightclub, convention center, bar, brewpub, nonprofit performing arts theater, nonprofit museum, nonprofit zoological park, nonprofit botanical garden, auditorium, sports coliseum, suite hotel, open air cafe, government center, tasting room, sidewalk cafe, or continuing education center. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1065. - Alcohol appeal board. 
(a)  Scope of review. The proceedings are de novo: accordingly, any relevant facts, data, information or records at issue will be subject to be presented and entered into evidence at the hearing, and considered by the alcohol appeal board in its decision, regardless of whether or not the same had been previously considered by the body initiating the action. 
(b)  Deviations from procedure. Technical, insignificant, or non-prejudicial deviations from the procedures set forth in this chapter shall not be grounds for invalidating the action taken. 
(c)  Chairman. The chairman shall perform the following functions: 
(1)  Act to reasonably provide all participants in the hearing with a reasonable opportunity to be heard and to present oral and documentary evidence in an efficient and expeditious manner. 
(2)  Prohibit conduct or the presentation of evidence that is cumulative, excessive, irrelevant, abusive, or that causes undue delay; 
(3)  Maintain decorum throughout the hearing; 
(4)  Determine the order of procedure throughout the hearing; 
(5)  Have the authority to make rulings on all questions which pertain to matters of procedure and to the admissibility of evidence; and 
(6)  If either party to the hearing is not proceeding in an efficient and expeditious manner, take such discretionary action as warranted by the circumstances. 
(d)  Failure to appear at hearing. Failure, without good cause, of applicant/licensee to appear and proceed in an efficient and orderly manner on the designated date shall be deemed to constitute voluntary acceptance of the pending recommendations or actions, which shall then be forwarded to the council for final action, without further input or appeal from applicant/licensee. 
(e)  Record of hearing. A record of the hearing shall be maintained by a stenographic reporter or by a voice recording of the proceedings. A copy of the record, by stenographic reporter or sound recording, shall be forwarded to the council through the city attorney along with the alcohol appeal board's decision. 
(f)  Rights of both sides at the hearing. 
(1)  At a hearing both sides shall have the following rights and subject to reasonable limits determined by the chairman: 
(i)  Opening and closing statements to the board; 
(ii)  To call and examine witnesses; 
(iii)  To introduce exhibits; 
(iv)  To cross-examine any witness on any matter relevant to the issues and to rebut any evidence; and 
(v)  To be represented by counsel. 
(2)  An applicant/licensee who does not testify in his or her own behalf may be called and examined as if under cross-examination. 
(g)  Rights of board member. The board members may question any witness, examine the applicant/licensee, call additional witnesses, and/or request documentary evidence. 
(h)  Admissibility of evidence. 
(1)  The hearing shall not be conducted according to rules of evidence. Any relevant evidence, including hearsay, shall be admitted if it is the sort of evidence on which responsible persons are accustomed to rely in the conduct of serious affairs, regardless of the admissibility of such evidence in a court of law. The guiding principle shall be that the board shall have before it adequate information relevant to the pending matter. 
(2)  Documentary evidence may be received in the form of originals or copies. Excerpts of documents may be received only in the discretion of the chairman. 
(3)  If the action appealed is based upon a prior criminal conviction, plea of guilty or administrative finding of violation, the alcohol appeal board will not consider, at the hearing, any evidence attacking the validity of those proceeding or evidence disputing the facts involved in those proceedings. 
(i)  Sale to minors. In appeals involving violation of the prohibition on furnishing alcoholic beverage to a person under twenty-one (21) years of age by an employee or agent of licensee, the alcohol appeal board's inquiry may include, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Employment standards of the licensee; 
(2)  Employee direction/supervision; 
(3)  Sales procedures; 
(4)  Training program (initial, recurrent, verification); 
(5)  Enforcement check reports; 
(6)  Previous violations; 
(7)  Any other ordinance or law deemed relevant to the violation that is the subject matter of the hearing. 
(j)  Burden of proof. The applicant or licensee shall have the burden of showing by a preponderance of the evidence that the denial of his/her application for a license or the suspension or revocation of license is not appropriately supported by a reasonable factual basis and is not arbitrary or capricious, or is contrary to law. 
(k)  Postponements and extensions. Postponements and extensions of time may be requested by the parties or the board members, but shall be permitted only by the chairman on a showing of good cause. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1066. - Distance and area requirements. 
(a)  No person shall be licensed by the city under this chapter for the retail sale of malt beverages, wine or distilled spirits where the parcel upon which the proposed place of business is located is within a distance of two thousand six hundred forty (2,640) feet of any parcel upon which is already located a business that is licensed by the city for the retail sale of malt beverages, wine or distilled spirits. This requirement does not apply to the following: 
(1)  Any hotel licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages; 
(2)  A retail business which contains an interior space of fourteen thousand (14,000) square feet or more and derives or anticipates deriving less than twenty (20) percent of its annual gross receipts from the sale of malt beverages and wine; 
(3)  A retail business that is located on a public street or road that intersects with an interstate highway and lies within one-quarter (.25) mile of the interstate intersection as measured from the property line of the tract on which the business is located to the beginning of the entrance ramp, or beginning of dedicated turn lanes into an entrance ramp, to the interstate highway, provided that all other applicable distance requirements under state law and this chapter are met. 
(b)  No person unless excepted by this section 11-1066(a) shall be licensed by the city under this chapter for the manufacturing, wholesale or retail sale of malt beverages, wine or distilled spirits where the parcel is located within five hundred (500) feet of any parcel upon which is located any of the following: 
(1)  Any structure in residential use; 
(2)  Any public or private school (six hundred (600) feet as to distilled spirits); 
(3)  Any public library; 
(4)  Any church or similar place of worship; 
(5)  Any child care or day care facility. 
The distance will be measured as provided in Article A of this chapter. 
(c)  No license shall be issued by the city under this chapter for the manufacturing, wholesale or retail sale of malt beverages, wine and/or distilled spirits where the use of the property is a lounge, restaurant or private club as defined in Article A of this chapter and either use is located on a parcel within three hundred (300) feet of any parcel upon which is located any of the following: 
(1)  Any structure in residential use; 
(2)  Any public or private school (six hundred (600) feet as to distilled spirits); 
(3)  Any public library; 
(4)  Any church or similar place of worship; 
(5)  Any child care or day care facility. 
The distance will be measured as provided in Article A of this chapter. The distance requirements of this subsection shall not apply for licenses, for the consumption on premises only, in the CR zoning district of the city. 
This exemption specifically does not apply to any license for retail sale of alcohol, including but not limited to, the sale of alcohol from retail stores, which is packaged to go and not for consumption on the premises. 
(d)  Except as is herein provided, no license shall be issued by the city under this chapter for the manufacturing, wholesale or retail sale of malt beverages, wine and/or distilled spirits where the use of the property is a restaurant or a hotel and either use is located on a parcel within one hundred (100) feet of any parcel upon which is located any of the following: 
(1)  Any structure in residential use; 
(2)  Any public or private school (six hundred (600) feet as to distilled spirits); 
(3)  Any public library; 
(4)  Any church or similar place of worship; 
(5)  Any child care or day care facility. 
The distance will be measured as provided in Article A of this chapter. 
(e)  Exemption. Those licensed locations, for sale of packaged malt or vinous liquors or sale of alcohol for on-premises consumption existing on the date of passage of the ordinance from which this subsection derives that are respectively identified in subsections (c) and (d) of this section shall, on the date of the passage of such ordinance, be exempted from compliance therewith; provided, however, that such exemptions shall not be construed to apply to adult entertainment establishments. 
(1)  Any restaurant located within the city that does not have "live entertainment, dancing, or amplified music" beyond the licensed premises shall be exempted from the distance requirement; 
(2)  Any location within the commercial redevelopment district (CR District) that is a "consumption on premises" location shall be exempted from the distance requirement. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1067. - Revocation or suspension of license. 
(a)  All licenses herein shall be a mere grant or privilege to carry on such business during the term of the license subject to all the terms and conditions imposed by the city's charter and related laws of the State of Georgia and of the United States, and applicable provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the city relating to such businesses. 
(b)  If any licensee should be engaged in unlawful activities, or acts which would constitute violations of state or federal laws or city ordinances or county health ordinances, and where such unlawful activities are such as to directly or indirectly affect the licensee's qualification to conduct the licensed business or be involved in the conduct of such business, the licensee may be fined or its license may be revoked or suspended in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  Where it is reported to the police chief that a licensee is engaged in such unlawful activities, a preliminary investigation shall be conducted by the police chief or his/her designee in order to determine whether there is a basis for the reports. After the preliminary investigation, the police chief or his/her designee may recommend: 
(1)  A finding that the evidence does not authorize action by the council; 
(2)  That a warning be issued to the licensee, for which there shall be no appeal to the council or the alcohol appeal board; 
(3)  For the first violation (criminal or civil) within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and suspension of the license for up to seven (7) days, or revocation. 
(4)  For the second violation (criminal or civil) within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and suspension of the license for up to thirty (30) days, or revocation. 
(5)  For the third violation (criminal or civil) within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, mandatory revocation of the license. 
If the police chief's or his/her designee's preliminary investigation reveals that there may be a basis for a fine, revocation or suspension of the license, the licensee will be notified of the police chief's recommended action and the basis therefore, and of the licensee's right to appear before the alcohol appeal board, where applicable, on a date certain and show cause why the police chiefs recommendation should not be implemented by the mayor and city council. 
(d)  Within ten (10) days from the date of delivery to the licensee of the police chiefs recommendation, the licensee may request a hearing before the alcohol appeal board prior to the city council taking action on the police chiefs recommendation (except for recommendations (1) and (2) above, to which there shall be no appeal). Any recommendations of the police chief, except recommendations (1) and (2), shall be scheduled for a hearing before the alcohol appeal board no later than thirty (30) days from the date of the receipt of the licensee's written request for hearing before the board. The chairman of the board shall schedule a hearing before the alcohol appeal board and notify the licensee of the time and date of the hearing. If the licensee fails to request a hearing within the allotted ten (10) days, the city council shall act upon the police chiefs recommendation without a hearing or input from the licensee. 
(e)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the alcohol appeal board is authorized to recommend: 
(1)  Finding in favor of the licensee; 
(2)  Issue a warning to the licensee; 
(3)  For the first violation (criminal or civil) within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and suspension of the license for up to seven (7) days, or revocation; 
(4)  For the second violation (criminal or civil) within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and suspension of the license for up to thirty (30) days, or revocation; 
(5)  For the third violation (criminal or civil) within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, revocation of the license. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1068. - Automatic suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Whenever the State of Georgia shall revoke or suspend any permit or license to sell alcoholic beverages of a city licensee, the city license to deal in such products, issued pursuant to this chapter, shall thereupon be automatically revoked or suspended without any action by the mayor, city council or any other city officer being necessary. There shall be no appeal to the alcohol appeal board of this action. 
(b)  Any licensee under this chapter shall be subject to automatic penalty and revocation or suspension of license for any conviction of the licensee or any agent, employee or officer thereof for violation of this chapter or any state law or regulation involving alcoholic beverages or sale of any illegal substance or article under the following procedure: 
(1)  Upon the conviction or entry of a plea of guilty of a licensee or any agent, employee, or licensee thereof for a violation described in this subsection (b), the city manager or designee shall propose a penalty to be assessed against the licensee according to the following schedule: 
a.  For the first violation (criminal or civil) within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and suspension of the license for up to seven (7) days; 
b.  For the second violation (criminal or civil) within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and suspension of the license for up to thirty (30) days; 
c.  For the third violation (criminal or civil) within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, revocation of the license. 
(2)  For purposes of the penalties in this subsection (b), there must be a prior criminal proceeding in which there was a conviction or a plea of guilty, or a civil administrative proceeding in which there was a finding or plea of violation. 
(3)  The police chief or designee shall cause to be served by personal service or certified mail return receipt requested upon the licensee or any license agent thereof a written notice of the violation described in this sub-section (b) and the penalty proposed therefore. The licensee shall be notified therein that he/she shall have five (5) business days from the date of service of the notice of violation to request, in a writing delivered to the police chief, a hearing before the alcohol appeal board. Upon receipt by the police chief of a written request for a hearing, the police chief shall provide by personal delivery or by certified mail return receipt requested a notice to the licensee of the date, time and place of hearing before the alcohol appeal board, which notice shall be sent not less than five (5) business days subsequent the date of receipt of such request for hearing. 
(4)  Within five (5) business days after the time to request a hearing has expired with no hearing requested, the police chief shall issue a written recommendation to the city council. If a hearing was conducted, the alcohol appeal board shall issue its recommendations to the city council. A copy of the written decision shall be provided to the licensee by personal delivery or certified mail return receipt requested. 
(5)  The council shall, by resolution, confirm, modify or deny the decision of the police chief or the alcohol appeal board, as appropriate. Following confirmation by the council, the police chief may cause a copy of the council's decision to be personally delivered to, or mailed by certified mail return receipt requested to the licensee and the notice of the penalty to be imposed. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1069. - New application after revocation. 
When a license has been revoked, no application for a new license from the licensee or applicant involved shall be received for a period of twenty-four (24) months from when the revocation becomes final and non-appealable. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1070. - Employment of persons convicted of certain offenses; alcoholic beverages permit for servers on premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee hereunder to employ in any premises used for the sale by the drink of distilled spirits, wines, champagnes, or malt beverages, any person in any capacity whatsoever, including but not limited to performers, entertainers and musicians, who have been or has been, within three (3) years prior to the date of such application for employment, convicted, served any sentence or other penalty or punishment, been on parole, or probation for a charge or violation of, soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting premises for prostitution, keeping a disorderly place, illegally dealing in narcotics or other controlled substances, sex offenses, or any crime involving moral turpitude. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee hereunder to employ in any premises used for the sale of distilled spirits, wines or malt beverages by the drink, any person in any capacity whatsoever, including but not limited to performers, entertainers and musicians, who have been or has been, within three (3) years prior to the date of such application for employment, convicted on two (2) or more occasions, or have or has served any sentence or other penalty or punishment, or have or has been on parole or probation, for a charge or violation relating to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages of any type.Each employee of a licensee who sells or serves alcoholic beverages shall obtain an alcoholic beverage registration permit issued by the police department. The fee for the permit is one hundred dollars ($100.00), which shall be renewed each year. Any violation of subsection (a) or (b) above will be grounds for revocation of the permit. No licenses shall allow any employee required to hold a permit to work on the licensed premises without displaying on his/her person in public view the permit issued by the police department. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1071. - Compliance with City Code and state law. 
(a)  All licensees who held licenses for alcoholic beverages sales by liquor stores or sales by the drink for on premise consumption within the city as of January 1, 2005 shall be exempt from the requirements of this chapter involving residency, distance requirements, location, parking and type of building structure for the purposes of license renewal provided that said licensees and their licensed locations: 
(1)  Were in compliance on January 1, 2005, with city code requirements involving residency, distance requirements, location, parking and type of building structure in effect at the time of first receiving the licenses; 
(2)  Are not responsible for the non-compliance involving residency, distance requirements, location, parking and type of building structure, as such non-compliance is a result of a code amendment enacted after January 1, 2005 or the result of a use, as defined in Section 11-1066, moving within such use's stated distance buffer at no fault to the licensee; 
(3)  Remain at all times in compliance with all other requirements of the Code and State law. 
(b)  Transferees of a license or transfer of license to a new location must comply with all current requirements of this chapter. 
(c)  All premises used by a licensee, as a liquor store within the city, as of January 1, 2005 shall also be exempt from the requirements of this chapter involving distance requirements, location, parking and type of building structure for the purposes such premises' use as a liquor store by a new licensee provided that said premises: 
(1)  Was in compliance on January 1, 2005, with code requirements involving distance requirements, location, parking and type of building structure; 
(2)  Any non-compliance involving residency, distance requirements, location, parking and type of building structure as such non-compliance is a result of a code amendment enacted after January 1, 2005 or the result of a use, as defined in Section 11-1066, moving within such use's stated distance buffer at no fault to the selling licensee; and 
(3)  Remained at all times in compliance with all other requirements of the code and state law. 
( Ord. No. 031-13, 12-16-13 ) 
Sec. 11-1072. - Collection of taxes from distributors, wholesale dealers and manufacturers. 
At the time of delivery of any of such beverages as set out in this chapter such wholesale dealer, distributor or manufacturer shall collect from the retail dealer the taxes imposed by this chapter giving a correct and proper receipt therefore, and hold such taxes in trust for the city until the tax is remitted to the city as provided in this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any wholesaler, distributor, manufacturer or person to sell or deliver any such beverages as set out in this chapter to any retail dealer in the city, or for any such beverage to be transported into the city for resale by any means whatsoever, except to a licensed wholesale distributor, without collecting the taxes thereon as above set out at the time of sale or delivery.
