(f)  Temporary variance permits. Any person who own or operates any noise source may apply to the community services department for a temporary variance from one or more of the provisions of this section, unless such noise source is specifically exempted pursuant to the provisions of subsection (c). The community services department may grant a temporary variance permit provided that: 
(1)  Additional time is necessary for the applicant to alter or modify the activity in order to comply with the provisions of this section; or 
(2)  The activity, operation or noise source will be of a temporary duration not to exceed fourteen (14) days and cannot be done in a manner that would comply with the provisions of this section; or 
(3)  No reasonable alternative is available to the applicant; and 
(4)  The activity, operation or noise source will not constitute a danger to public health. 
(g)  Enforcement procedures. 
(1)  The NCO shall enforce the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Anyone violating any provision of this article shall be issued a citation by the NCO or any official designee thereof. 
(3)  In lieu of issuing a citation, the NCO may issue an order requiring abatement of any sound source alleged to be in violation of this article. Such order shall specify a reasonable time, not to exceed sixty (60) days, within which such abatement must occur and may specify guidelines in order to effect such abatement. 
(4)  Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each day during which any violation occurs shall constitute a separate, additional offense. 
(Code 1959, §§ 14-34, 14-35; Ord. No. 023-00, § 1, 9-5-00; Ord. No. 023-05, § 1, 11-7-05) 
Sec. 13-2018. - Open-air eating places, lighting requirements. 
It shall be the duty of every person serving or selling at retail any food or beverage, except water, apparently to be consumed in, on, at or near the premises where sold or served, to keep the premises, drives, parks, lots, yards, alleys, walks, streets, lanes or other areas where the patrons park, stop, stand, sit or wait to purchase or be served, so lighted that all such patrons drinking or eating in, on, at, near or about such places of business and the streets, lanes, alleys, walkways, yards, parks, lots or other areas, and any automobile or other vehicle occupied by such patrons and the occupants thereof may be clearly and readily seen and identified by any person within ten (10) feet of such patrons or vehicles; provided, the provisions of this section shall not apply to any person serving food or drink exclusively and wholly within the enclosed completely lighted kitchens, rooms or buildings in which the food or drinks sold or served are usually kept when such place of business is not open for business at night or on Sunday. 
(Code 1959, § 14-38) 
Sec. 13-2019. - Palmistry or fortunetelling. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on or practice the art, wizardry or calling commonly known as "palmistry" or "fortunetelling" within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-39) 
Annotations— It is a proper exercise of a municipality's police power to declare the practice of fortunetelling unlawful within city limits. Williams v. Jenkins 211 Ga. 10 (1954); Gladstone v. Galton 145 Fed. 2D 742. 
State Law reference— County authorized to prohibit, Ga. Code Ann., § 23-2706. 
Sec. 13-2020. - Prostitution prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to do any of the following: 
(1)  Engage in prostitution; 
(2)  Procure or solicit for the purpose of prostitution; 
(3)  Reside in, enter or remain in any place, structure, building, vehicle, trailer or conveyance for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution; 
(4)  Keep, set up or maintain a house of ill fame, a brothel or a bawdy house; 
(5)  Receive any person or persons for purposes of lewdness, assignation or prostitution into any vehicle, place, conveyance, trailer structure or building; 
(6)  Permit any person to remain for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution in any vehicle, conveyance, trailer, place, structure or building; 
(7)  Walk on or loiter about the streets, sidewalks, alleys, or thoroughfares for the purpose of soliciting for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution. 
Sec. 13-2020.1. - Transporting or receiving persons or loitering for illegal purposes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly transport a person into or within the city limits of the city for the purpose of promoting that person's engaging in prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly receive, offer or agree to receive another into any place or building for the purpose of performing an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering or knowingly to permit others to remain there for any such purpose. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly provide money or anything of value to another for the purpose of inducing another to transport a person into or within the city limits of the city for the purpose of promoting that person's engaging in prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering or for the purpose of inducing another to receive a person into any place or building for the purpose of performing an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter while a pedestrian or in a motor vehicle, in or near any thoroughfare or place open to the public, parking lots of hotels and motels, in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to commit an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether this purpose is manifested are that such person is a known prostitute, pimp, sodomist, masturbator-for-hire or panderer and repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempts to stop, or engages passers-by in conversation, or repeatedly stops, or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators by hailing, or waving of arms or any bodily gesture for the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to commit an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. No arrest shall be made for a violation of this subsection unless the arresting officer first affords such person the opportunity to explain his conduct, and no one shall be convicted of violating this subsection if it appears at trial that the explanation given was true and disclosed a lawful purpose. 
(e)  For the purpose of subsection (d), a "known prostitute, pimp, sodomist, panderer or masturbator-for-hire" is a person who, within one year previous to the date of arrest for violation of the section, had within the knowledge of the arresting officer been convicted of violating any ordinance of any city or law of any state defining and punishing acts of soliciting, committing, or offering or agreeing to commit prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. 
(f)  For the purpose of subsection (d), "any person" shall also include panderers or solicitors of sexual acts, commonly referred to as "johns" or "tricks," who loiter in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of participating in, procuring, purchasing or soliciting any sexual act for hire made illegal by state law. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether this purpose is manifested are that such person, while a pedestrian or in a motor vehicle, repeatedly beckons to, attempts to stop, engages or attempts to engage in conversation with any person by hailing, waving arms or any bodily gesture for the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to commit an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. 
(Ord. No. 699-79, § 1, 5-21-79) 
Editor's note— At the editor's discretion, the section number 13-2020.1 has been assigned to the provisions of Ord. No. 669-79, § 1, enacted May 21, 1979. 
Sec. 13-2021. - School children, etc., disturbing prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who has no legal authority with respect to the individuals concerned to engage the attention of school pupils by conversation, signs or otherwise to the disturbance of the same or to the detriment of the discipline of any school within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-49) 
Sec. 13-2021.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1038-92, § 1, adopted Sept. 21, 1992, repealed former section 13-2021.1 in its entirety. Former section 13-2021.1 pertained to the selling of candy, toys, etc. from mobile conveyances and derived from Ord. No. 749-81, §§ 1, 2, adopted Aug. 3, 1981. 
Sec. 13-2022. - Vehicles for hire transporting school children; signs; passenger limitations; penalty. 
Under a franchise granted to anyone by the city council for transportation of passengers for hire, wholly within the city and over a fixed route, in and along public streets of the city, no school bus or other similar bus or carrier having written or painted thereon a name, a statement, or words indicating such bus is a school bus, will be allowed to engage in the regular transportation of passengers for hire along such fixed route, or elsewhere, except when such bus is engaged in the transportation of school children to and from a public school. 
Sec. 13-2023. - Water—Release or discharge of harmful chemicals, etc., into streams. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to empty, pour, release, discharge or permit any officer, agent, servant or employee to empty, pour, release or discharge any chemical or substance likely to kill or injure any person, animal, plant, flower, shrub, tree, grass or property of another into any stream, ditch, sewer, pond, lake, pool or place within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-52) 
Sec. 13-2024. - Same—Interfering with free flow of water. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with the free flow of water in any stream, ditch, or drain or change the course thereof within the city, by throwing, placing, emptying or discharging any paper, rag, trash, garbage, tree limbs, brush, or thing that will impede or hinder the free flow of water through said stream, ditch or drain or cause a change in the course thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 14-53) 
Sec. 13-2024.1. - Unauthorized use of sanitary sewer system. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to cause to be discharged into the sanitary sewer system waste by means of water which has not been delivered to the property by the city, except in cases of emergencies where the city cannot supply water to the property. 
(Ord. No. 1166-98, § 3, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 13-2025. - Garage sales. 
(a)  Permitted garage sales and permits. No garage sales of any type or character are permitted in the city without first having registered and obtaining a permit therefor, by payment of a five-dollar fee, and subject to the provisions hereinafter set forth. 
(1)  Churches, fraternal organizations and other charitable nonprofit organizations are hereby and hereafter permitted two (2) garage sales per calendar year upon registering with the city business license inspector and furnishing the date and place of such sale. Such sale shall be conducted at such location for not more than two (2) days per registration. 
(2)  Each residence address in East Point is hereby and hereafter permitted two (2) garage sales per calendar year upon registering with the city business license inspector and furnishing the date and place of such sale. Such sale shall be conducted at such location for not more than two (2) days per registration. 
(b)  Definition. For the purposes of this section, "garage sale" is defined to be a sale or any other commercial transaction including, but not limited to, the trading or sale from a residential location within the city for the purposes of selling or trading clothing, furniture, household items, foods, dishes, antiques, and any and all other personal property of every type and description. The term garage sale shall include yard sales, carport sales, and all other similar types of sales or events. 
(c)  Parking. The individual applicant in charge of and/or conducting the garage sale shall be responsible for the control of vehicles and parking of patrons so as to avoid congestion and hazardous situations. Any traffic congestion or hazardous conditions created by a garage sale may, upon such determination, solely in the discretion of the police department or its officials and officers, result in an immediate termination and dissolution of said garage sale. 
(d)  Promotion for fee prohibited. No individual, firm or corporation or partnership may be permitted in the business of promoting or conducting garage sales as permitted herein for a fee or other consideration. 
(e)  Advertising forbidden. No signs advertising or calling attention to or giving directions from or in any other way advertising such garage sale shall be permitted within the limitations placed upon signs within the zoning ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-56; Ord. No. 820-82, § 1, 11-15-82) 
Sec. 13-2026. - Peddling of fish or fresh meat. 
Peddling or fish and all fresh meats from house to house is strictly prohibited. 
Sec. 13-2027. - Display of pornographic materials to minors prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to exhibit, expose, or display in public at newsstands or any other business or commercial establishment or at any other public place frequented by minors or where minors are or may be invited as part of the general public: 
(1)  Any picture, photograph, drawing, sculpture, motion picture film, or similar visual representation or image of a person or portion of the human body which depicts sexually explicit nudity, sexual conduct, or sadomasochistic abuse and which is harmful to minors; or 
(2)  Any book, pamphlet, magazine, printed matter however reproduced, or sound recording which contains any matter enumerated in paragraph (1) of this subsection, or explicit and detailed verbal descriptions or narrative accounts of sexual excitement, sexual conduct, or sadomasochistic abuse and which, taken as a whole, is harmful to minors. 
(b)  All such sellers and/or distributors shall wrap such publications in a opaque or non-transparent cover or wrapper so that only the title may be seen by such minors. 
(c)  Any business establishment, seller, and/or distributor displaying such material shall not place that material in a position where minors may easily read those materials and the display must be at least five (5) feet in height from the floor. 
(d)  No minor shall be permitted to scan, read and/or peruse such material within the city limits of East Point, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 1032-92, § 1, 6-24-92) 
Sec. 13-2028. - Cigarette vending machines prohibited; exceptions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain any machine for the purpose of being operated within the city for the vending sale or distribution of cigarettes or tobacco related products, except as follows: 
(1)  In lounges, taverns, and bars which business is primarily constituted of the sale of alcoholic beverages and to which minors are not permitted entrance. 
(2)  In retail establishments where such vending machine is located behind an attended sales counter or other area not accessible to the public. 
Each day any such machine is maintained shall constitute a separate offense. The fine for the first offense shall be not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each subsequent offense occurring within a twelve-month period. 
(Ord. No. 1077-94, § 2, 6-6-94) 
Sec. 13-2029. - Display for sale of used motor vehicles at locations other than licensed dealerships prohibited. 
(a)  Except in the case of a licensed retail used car dealer location, no motor vehicle may be displayed for sale in the city without the owner of the vehicle having registered and obtained a permit therefore and having such permit being prominently displayed on the vehicle. A vehicle shall be considered to be displayed for sale when a reasonable person would perceive that the vehicle is for sale without having to inquire whether the vehicle is for sale. 
(b)  No permit for sale of a vehicle shall be issued to a person other than the owner of the vehicle. 
(c)  No person shall apply for nor receive more than three (3) permits within a one-year period. 
(d)  No permit shall be issued for display at an address of property not owned or under lease to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1118-95, § 1, 11-6-95) 
Sec. 13-2030. - Truancy of minors. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the following definition shall apply: 
Public place means any street, highway, alley or right-of-way, to include sidewalks, any park, playground, mall, or other place or building open to the public; any cemetery, school yard, body of water or watercourse; any privately or publicly owned place of amusement, entertainment or public accommodation including parking lots, and other areas adjacent thereto, and any vacant lot or land. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any minor between the ages of four (4) years and sixteen (16) years to loiter, wander, stroll, or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots, or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. on any school day; provided, however, that the provision of the this section shall not apply to the following incidents: 
(1)  When a minor is accompanied by his/her parent, guardian, or other adult person twenty-one (21) years of age or older having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his/her parent, guardian, or other adult person twenty-one (21) years of age or older having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above-referenced places during the prescribed period of time; 
(4)  When the minor is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal travel with interstate and intrastate travel through the City of East Point being excepted in all cases from this section; 
(5)  When the minor is enrolled in a valid home study program as authorized by O.C.G.A. Section 20-2-690; 
(6)  When the minor has completed all course study requirements for high school graduation; 
(7)  When the minor is married in accordance with applicable law; 
(8)  When the minor has written proof from school authorities that he/she is excused from school attendance at that particular time; or 
(9)  When the minor is participating in an approved school or study activity which requires the minor to be off school property. 
(c)  No parent or legal guardian of a minor between the ages of four (4) years and sixteen (16) years of age shall negligently allow a minor to violate subsection 13-2030(b). 
(d)  Upon conviction of negligently allowing a minor to violate subsection 13-2030(b), a person shall be guilty of a violation of city ordinance and punished in accordance with section 1-1006 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of East Point, Georgia. Each violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. It shall be an affirmative defense if the parent or legal guardian has initiated the jurisdiction of the juvenile court against the minor prior to the time that the minor was found in violation of subsection 13-2030(b). Any minor who violates subsection 13-2030(b) is subject to the jurisdiction of the juvenile court. 
(e)  A police officer shall transport any minor found in violation of subsection 13-2030(b) to a designated school district facility. A minor transported to the school district facility will be released to the custody of the school officials or to the custody of his/her parent or legal guardian. 
(f)  If a minor is suspended or expelled from school, that minor's parent or legal guardian, for the duration of the suspension or expulsion, shall: 
(1)  Personally supervise the minor or arrange for a responsible adult twenty-one (21) years of age or older to supervise the minor at the times the minor would have required to be in attendance at school had he/she not been expelled or suspended; and 
(2)  Prohibit the minor from being in any public place at the times the minor would have been required to be in attendance at school had he/she not been suspended or expelled unless: 
a.  The minor is accompanied by his/her parent or legal guardian or a responsible adult, twenty-one (21) years of age or older, selected by the parent or legal guardian to supervise the minor; or 
b.  The minor is employed pursuant to an age or schooling certificate during the actual working hours or traveling directly to or from the job site. 
(g)  Upon conviction of a violation of subsection 13-2030(f), a person shall be guilty of a violation of city ordinance and punishable in accordance with section 1-1006 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of East Point, Georgia. Each violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(h)  Any minor who violates subsection 13-2030(f) above is subject to the jurisdiction of the juvenile court. 
(i)  It shall be an affirmative defense if the parent or legal guardian has initiated the jurisdiction of the juvenile court against the minor prior to the time the he/she violated subsection 13-2030(f). 
(Ord. No. 1151-97, §§ 1—9, 11-3-97) 
ARTICLE B. - GRAFFITI ORDINANCE 

Sec. 13-2031. - Definition. 
"Graffiti" is defined according to O.C.G.A. 42-17-15A (2) as "any inscriptions, words, figures, paintings, or other defacements that are written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn, painted, or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface of real property or improvements thereon without prior authorization of the owner or occupant of the of the property by means of any aerosol paint container, broad- tipped marker, gum label, paint stick, graffiti stick, etching equipment, brush, or other device capable of scarring or leaving a visible mark on any surface. 
(Ord. No. 036-03, § 1, 9-2-03) 
Sec. 13-2032. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person(s) to deface, alter, modify, change, draw, damage or destroy by spraying or use of paint, or marking of ink, dye or any other similar substance on public and/or private buildings, structures and places, an inscription, slogan, drawing or modification, or otherwise damage private or public property in contradiction of other city ordinances, by or through the application of "graffiti" as defined herein 
(b)  Unless in compliance with section 13-2036 of this article, it shall be unlawful for any person owning or otherwise being in control of any real property within the City of East Point to maintain, permit or allow any graffiti to be placed upon any structure located on such property when the graffiti is visible from the street or other public or private property after notice, in writing, has been given to such person in control of said property. 
(Ord. No. 036-03, § 1, 9-2-03) 
Sec. 13-2033. - Graffiti placement penalty. 
Any person who is convicted of placing graffiti shall be guilty of a violation of city ordinance and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months, or both such fine and imprisonment in accordance with section 1-8 of the City of East Point Code of Ordinances. The court may suspend or probate a portion or its entire sentence upon such conditions to include but not be limited to the restoring of the property so defaced, damaged or destroyed, or other remedial action. No fine or punishment shall accrue to a business or individual who is in compliance with section 13-2036 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 036-03, § 1, 9-2-03) 
Sec. 13-2034. - Notice to remove graffiti. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, utility owner, or acting manager, tenant or agent of the owner of the property, to fail to remove graffiti within thirty (30) business days after written notice is given. 
(b)  Whenever the city becomes aware of the existence of graffiti or other unsightly conditions on any property, including structures or improvements within the city, a police officer or code enforcement officer shall give or cause to be given, written notice to the property owner, an/or owner's agent, tenant or manager to remove such graffiti or other unsightly condition. 
(c)  The notice required by this section may be served personal service or registered or certified mail addressed to the owner or the last known address of said owner. If this address is unknown, the notice will be sent to the property address. Such notice shall allow thirty (30) days from the date of notice for removal of identified graffiti. 
(d)  For the purpose of giving notice to the owner of the property, the person shown as the owner of said property on the ad valorem tax records of the city shall be sent such notice at the address shown thereon unless the city receives actual notice that another person owns said property. In addition, the owner may notify the city that the tenant, pursuant to a written lease, has control of the property or has control of that portion of the building which is the subject matter of this article and, in the event the city receives such notice, the city shall notify the tenant of the notice of removal as provided in this article and proceed against the tenant and not the owner. Provided, however, as to any violation of this article in existence prior to the date of approval of this article, any notice of removal shall give sixty (60) days for the removal thereof. 
(e)  A property owner that has received proper written notice of the presence of graffiti on their property shall have thirty (30) days from the date of that written notice to remove the graffiti themselves or through the use of a third party. 
(Ord. No. 036-03, § 1, 9-2-03) 
Sec. 13-2035. - Penalties for failure to remove graffiti. 
The property owner or occupant's failure to remove graffiti prior to the expiration of the thirty (30) days shall be summoned to appear in the East Point Municipal Court in order to determine if they are in violation of the provision of this article. If it is found that the property owner or occupant is guilty of violating this ordinance they shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each seven-day period past the expiration of the thirty-day period that the graffiti remains on the property. Said fines shall not exceed the limits of the court as imposed by law. 
(Ord. No. 036-03, § 1, 9-2-03) 
Sec. 13-2036. - Sign or approved art. 
Businesses that have been allowed or funded the placement of approved signs or art on their property shall be exempt from this ordinance. Those businesses that do not have permits for the signs or art shall apply for a sign permit as outlined in section 10-2156 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 036-03, § 1, 9-2-03)

Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic. Pt. 12. 

Sec. 13-3001. - Obstructing streets. 
It shall be unlawful for any conductor, engineer or other employee of any railroad company having tracks running across any of the public streets of the city to obstruct such street or prevent the free passage of vehicles or pedestrians longer than three (3) minutes at any one time while the railroad cars are not in motion. 
(Code 1959, § 17-4) 
Sec. 13-3002. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1039-92, § 1, adopted Sept. 22, 1992, repealed former section 13-3002 in its entirety. Former section 13-3002 derived from the Code of 1959, § 17-5 and pertained to speed limits for railroad trains. 
Sec. 13-3003. - Protection of grade crossings. 
(a)  Definitions. Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different intention, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings indicated herein: 
(1)  Grade crossing. Grade crossing shall mean a crossing at grade of a street intersecting a track of a railroad. 
(2)  Train. Train shall mean a locomotive and a car; or a locomotive without a car; or cars in movement but not attached to a locomotive. 
(b)  Safety devices. In the interest of public safety, and for the protection of those using streets of the city, it shall be the duty of every person operating a train, locomotive or car across a grade crossing in the city to provide at each such grade crossing complete public safety from danger from approaching trains for all persons using the streets at such crossings. For this purpose, persons operating trains, locomotives or cars on rails, or having control of the tracks, shall place and keep at each such grade crossing at all times a watchman or flagman, or shall install, operate and maintain standard automatic gates or in signalling devices sufficient to protect the public fully from the danger of any approaching train. 
(Code 1959, § 17-10) 
CHAPTER 4. - TRAFFIC CONTROL FOR STREET AND HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS, AND UTILITY WORK[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 869B-84, §§ 1—3, adopted Nov. 5, 1984, provided for the inclusion of provisions designated as Ch. 4 of Part 13, §§ 13-4001—13-4007, to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, Pt. 12. 

Sec. 13-4001. - Authority and control. 
The East Point Police Department Traffic Division will have the responsibility of enforcing and assuring compliance in sections 13-4001 to 13-4006. 
(Ord. No. 869B-84, § 1, 11-5-84) 
Sec. 13-4002. - Reserved. 
Sec. 13-4003. - Fundamental principles. 
All traffic control devices used on street and highway construction, maintenance operations, or utility work shall conform to the applicable specifications of the approved Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) and Volume 11 of traffic controls in construction and maintenance work zones. 
(Ord. No. 869B-84, § 3, 11-5-84) 
Sec. 13-4004. - Governmental agencies to present traffic control plan. 
This includes city government operations; departments, state operations, and governmental authorities. The above agencies shall at all times before construction of any kind, present a traffic control plan to the East Point Police Department for review and approval. These traffic control plans are needed for lane closures, street closures with detour routes, shoulder work, mid-block closure, lane closures for trench with plating. 
(Ord. No. 869B-84, § 3, 11-5-84) 
Sec. 13-4004.1. - Short length detours, water line, utility and electrical line construction. 
For short length detours, water line construction, utility construction and electrical line construction, the East Point City Departments will work with the police department in devising the best possible traffic control operations in construction zones. 
(Ord. No. 869B-84, § 3, 11-5-84) 
Sec. 13-4005. - Private contractors. 
Contractor employed in road and street construction or maintenance operations under contract to any governmental department or agency shall abide by this chapter and shall bear the expense of flagmen or police officers if deemed necessary by the East Point Police Department. All city department heads will notify private contractors of this requirement when bidding for construction and utility projects or tree trimming operations. Other private contractors not working for the City of East Point shall also abide by this chapter when working with the City of East Point, this includes but [is] not limited to Southern Bell, Georgia Power, Atlanta Gas Light. (If police officers are deemed necessary they will be off-duty East Point Police Officers if available. 
(Ord. No. 869B-84, § 3, 11-5-84) 
Sec. 13-4006. - Flaggers. 
The East Point city departments shall provide their own flaggers for work in their construction sites if needed. The police department is to only be called in cases of emergency or [when] a situation arises that regular city employees cannot control traffic safety through the construction site. The department supervisor must call the traffic division commander and relate the situation. 
(1)  Flaggers should be used where one (1) lane is used for two (2) directions of traffic; 
(2)  At other locations where judgement indicates they are needed to warn, guide or control traffic; 
(3)  Where workers or equipment intermittently block an unprotected traffic lane or leave and enter construction sites or zones. 
(Ord. No. 869B-84, § 3, 11-5-84) 
Sec. 13-4007. - Temporary traffic control devices. 
The police department traffic division will ensure proper lane marking, signs and detour routes are used by anyone working in or around construction zones. The police department shall notify the fire department of street closure and detour routes. 
(Ord. No. 869B-84, § 3, 11-5-84)
